HEADLINE: On a Day of Peace in Belfast, Faiths Join to Cheer Clinton

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 30

 BODY:
President Clinton ranged across a remarkably transformed Northern Ireland today, promising the once bitterly hostile Catholic and Protestant communities that if they persevered in their search for peace, "the United States of America will proudly stand with you."
Tens of thousands turned out to cheer Mr. Clinton, the first American President to visit Ulster, where 13 American presidents, from Andrew Jackson to Mr. Clinton himself, can trace their roots. 
 "There will always be those," the President said in his big speech of the day at the Mackie International textile-machinery plant in gritty West Belfast, "who define the worth of their lives not by who they are, but by who they aren't, not by what they're for but by what they are against. They will never escape the dead-end street of violence.
"But you, the vast majority, Protestant and Catholic alike, must not allow the ship of peace to sink on the rocks of old habits and hard grudges."
In the revived center of Belfast, defaced until recently by miles of barbed wire and hundreds of concrete-filled barrels that formed an awful monument to sectarian savagery, Mr. Clinton switched on the lights of a 45-foot-tall Christmas tree that he had brought from Nashville, Tenn., Belfast's twin city.
In the Falls Road and the Shankill Road, whose names became synonyms for murder and mayhem, he hopped from his limousine to chat with onlookers, shake hands and buy apples and oranges. Among those he greeted in the Falls Road and again tonight at a reception at Queens University was Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army.
And in Londonderry, where the "troubles" first flamed out of control in the 1960's, he inaugurated a new chair in Peace Studies at the University of Ulster. The chair is named for the late Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, who worked in the 1970's and 80's to halt the collection of American money for weapons here. A blur of tiny American flags and shouts of "We want Bill!" greeted him outside the Guildhall in the old walled city.
It was Mr. Clinton's decision to grant a visa to Mr. Adams last year that gave the peace process a needed jolt of energy. From that time forward, the President has been more deeply involved than any of his predecessors in the intractable problems of this island, an involvement that caused him to cast aside the fears of other Presidents that a trip here might fray relations with the British.
Expressing amazement at the changes that have taken place, Mr. Clinton said that crossing the border with the Republic of Ireland to the south, once an ordeal of search and delay, "now is as easy as crossing a speed bump."
John Hume, a Catholic moderate widely revered for his reconciliation efforts, said the President's visit made this "the most historic day ever" for Ulster. He lavished praise on Mr. Clinton for his aid to economic development in Ulster and expressed thanks that "peace in our land has been central to his policy since the day he took office."
Ann Hanna, a Belfast Protestant who heard the President more than once today, said: "I didn't think his presence would do much good, but he was absolutely first class, and after listening to him, I think he will help people come together."
One American President in four traced his roots to Ulster; only England nurtured the families of more. But Mr. Clinton was the first sitting President to set foot in Northern Ireland when he landed this morning after a brief flight from London.
The Ulster leadership hailed his visit as a sign that the truce between the warring factions and the all-party talks that are scheduled for February signaled the approach of an era of peace and prosperity for this 5,267-square-mile enclave of British territory at the northeastern corner of Ireland.
Peace has so far brought modest economic benefits to Northern Ireland. In the last two weeks, 14 companies have announced $1.25 billion in new projects, and both the British Government and the European Union supply major subsidies.
But the overall unemployment rate is 11.5 percent, and in some neighborhoods it reaches 50 percent. The Union Jack and the Irish tricolor still fly in mute combat as symbols of the conflicting sympathies of various neighborhoods. There were police riflemen keeping watch today on the roof of the Mackie plant.
But fruits and vegetables, racks of clothing and other goods now spill onto once-desolate sidewalks in Belfast shopping streets, British Army patrols have all but disappeared and the checkpoints that blocked roads leading from the airport and the Catholic south have been dismantled.
The often-bombed Europa Hotel, where Mr. Clinton stayed tonight, has been refurbished, and the old Crown pub, celebrated by the poet John Betjeman as "the many-colored cavern," is crowded once more.
A new convention center for Belfast, a new Hilton hotel and a new concert hall are under construction on a large site near the River Lagan.
At the hangar-like Mackie plant, jammed with workers in coveralls, supervisors in long white coats and managers in business suits, Mr. Clinton took part in a kind of pageant celebrating the gains in Northern Ireland since the I.R.A. cease-fire on Aug. 31, 1994. The factory is considered a showplace for efforts to end widespread employment discrimination. It sits astride the line dividing Catholic from Protestant neighborhoods.
The company's chairman, Patrick R. Dougan, described it as a place "where men and women of all traditions have come together to work for prosperity, and through prosperity, for peace." A Catholic, he was followed by Ronnie Lewis, the senior shop steward for the Transport and General Workers' Union, a Protestant who seconded his call for sectarian cooperation in the search for lasting peace.
Then a 10-year-old Protestant boy, David Sterrett, and an 8-year-old Catholic girl, Catherine Hamill, jointly introduced the President, holding hands. David commented that peace "means I can play in the park without worrying about getting shot." Catherine said quietly that "my first daddy died in the troubles."
A big delegation of important Irish-Americans had been flown to Belfast from Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland on Wednesday. Among those on hand were Senators Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and Connie Mack, Republican of Florida; the new president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John Sweeney, and the authors Pat Conroy and William Kennedy.
In his speech, Mr. Clinton pressed all parties for rapid progress in the coming peace talks, asserting that "engaging in honest dialogue is not an act of surrender, it is an act of strength and common sense." He told them, "You must stand firm against terror."
Mr. Clinton also replied, in barely veiled terms, to those in Britain who have suggested that by involving the United States in the peace effort he was meddling in Britain's internal affairs.
Noting that he himself was of Ulster Scots stock as well as Irish stock, the President made this blunt argument:
"Because our greatness flows from the wealth of our diversity as well as the strength of the ideals we share in common, we feel bound to support others around the would who seek to bridge their own divides. This is an important part of our country's mission on the eve of the 21st century, because we know that the chain of peace that protects us grows stronger with every new link that is forged."
Only twice did he hear anything but an enthusiastic response. When he said that "those who do show the courage to break with the past are entitled to their stake in the future," which his audience took to mean that Mr. Adams and Sinn Fein must be rewarded, a 40-ish man in a blue suit in a back row said, "Never!" The same heckler said the same thing at another, similar point in the speech.
He was later identified as Cedric Wilson, a former city councilman in East Belfast, representing the radically anti-Catholic Democratic Unionist Party of the Rev. Ian Paisley. He regularly stages one-man demonstrations in this area.

HEADLINE: Alexander Takes Aim at G.O.P. Congress

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: KEOKUK, Iowa, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Congress has sunk so low in the public's esteem that Lamar Alexander has come full circle and is once again running vigorously against it.
The Republican takeover of the House and Senate a year ago blunted Mr. Alexander's attacks on Congress, once a chief theme of his long campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination. But he is now frequently urging voters to "cut their pay and send them home," trying to draw a bright line between himself and those he sees as his chief rivals for the nomination, Senators Bob Dole of Kansas and Phil Gramm of Texas. 
 "I don't think it helps our country to replace a Democratic arrogant empire with a Republican one," he told a breakfast meeting of the Chamber of Commerce today here on Iowa's southeastern tip, criticizing Republican legislation on welfare and crime.
Mr. Alexander, a former Governor of Tennessee and United States Secretary of Education, has sought all along to portray himself as a Washington outsider. That message, his strategists believe, is gaining heft as public opinion of Congress falls.
"Bill Clinton is just licking his chops at having the chance to run against one of our Republican senators from Washington, D.C.," Mr. Alexander repeatedly told voters in a three-day swing through Iowa, which will hold its caucuses on Feb. 12.
It is too early to tell whether Mr. Alexander's feistier attacks on Congress, combined with harsher criticism of President Clinton, will at last lift his well-financed and well-organized but stubbornly low-flying campaign. Recent polling has shown Mr. Dole with a substantial lead in Iowa. The other candidates are bunched in single digits, locked in what Brian Kennedy, the chairman of the state Republican Party, refers to as "the race for second place."
Still, Mr. Alexander's new message, or the new incarnation of his old one, is getting through to some Republican voters and leaders.
"Originally, I supported Dole," said State Representative Russell J. Eddie, the Republican chairman of the agriculture committee of the Iowa House of Representatives. "But many people are worried that Bob is just a little too old, and there's a question of whether Dole, being a Washington insider, can really beat Clinton."
Mr. Eddie said that Democratic attacks on Republican plans to change Medicare had alarmed elderly voters in Iowa. Voters are less likely to blame Mr. Alexander than Mr. Gramm or Mr. Dole for such changes, he said.
Indeed, Mr. Alexander has found an unlikely, accidental ally in President Clinton. He said in an interview that Mr. Dole would probably emerge weakened after struggling against Mr. Clinton to push through a Republican budget.
"Ironically, the better he does at that, the less likely it may be that he would be our best nominee against Bill Clinton next year," Mr. Alexander said.
Asked why, Mr. Alexander started to talk about the "ratings of the Republican Congress," before halting. "Well, let me put it positively," he said. He said that an outsider was "more likely to be able to carry the fight against Clinton than someone who's battered and bruised in a Congressional fight."
He added that he would "fully support" Mr. Dole in his efforts to balance the budget.
On the stump, Mr. Alexander also tars Mr. Gramm with guilt by association with Congress. And he derides Mr. Gramm's message as "the politics of anger," contrasting it with his vision of a "rising, shining America." Usually speaking without a lectern and in folksy terms, Mr. Alexander highlights his experience as a chief executive and Tennessee's economic growth during his two terms there, from 1979 to 1987.
To support his contention that the Republican race has narrowed to three candidates, Mr. Alexander points to the results of a Florida straw poll 12 days ago, in which he was third with 23 percent. Mr. Gramm was second with 26 percent, and Mr. Dole won with 33 percent.
But in Iowa the pack is more muddled. Mr. Kennedy, the party chairman, said that so far Mr. Alexander "just doesn't seem to stand out from the crowd." But his attacks on Congress could help, Mr. Kennedy said.
"Republican caucus-goers don't have the same level of angst about the Congress as they did before it became Republican," said Mr. Kennedy, who will not endorse a candidate. "But it's a good way for him to say: 'It doesn't matter who's controlling Congress, I won't be co-opted. I'll be the same outsider when I get there.' "
Mr. Alexander has spent more time in Iowa than any other Republican candidate save Morry Taylor, an industrialist from Michigan. But the national news organizations have been paying far less attention to the race here than in past contests, said Hugh Winebrenner, a professor of public administration at Drake University.
As a result, Mr. Alexander is still struggling for recognition, here and nationally.
"I thought I'd probably have a higher profile by now," Mr. Alexander acknowledged.
But he is probably being aided by another peculiarity of the Iowa race this year: Republican operatives say the powerful Christian Coalition is divided among several candidates. That could help Mr. Alexander, who has staked out a more moderate position on abortion rights.
Although he calls himself pro-life, he says the Federal Government should not regulate abortion. States should restrict it, he says, but cannot outlaw it completely because of the Supreme Court's decision in Roe v. Wade.
Mr. Alexander rarely mentioned his abortion position in the last three days, emphasizing views and credentials that are more popular here. And when the chairman of the Butler County Republicans introduced him at a potluck dinner on Tuesday night as Ronald Reagan's Education Secretary, Mr. Alexander, who served under President George Bush, did not bother to correct him.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

PATAKI TO RETAIN NURSING HOME QUOTAS
Governor Pataki announced that his administration would not repeal a regulation that requires hundreds of nursing homes across the state to set aside many of their beds for Medicaid recipients. A senior aide said that Mr. Pataki would not abolish the regulation because he was concerned about "unfair treatment to Medicaid recipients." The State Health Department had been reviewing a proposal to abolish the regulation. [Page A1.]
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
PARENTS FIGHT PLAN TO MOVE GIFTED PROGRAM
On its surface, the proposal seems barely capable of causing a ripple: Administrators of the community school district on the Upper West Side of Manhattan hope next fall to move a kindergarten class for "gifted and talented" students from an elementary school on West 84th Street to another one five blocks away. But parents at P.S. 9 are deeply suspicious that officials are trying to improve another school at their school's expense. [B3.]
 
HEARING EXAMINES CHILD ABUSE RULES
At a hearing to examine what was called the veil of secrecy surrounding child abuse cases in New York State, that very veil seemed to prevent any fresh insights into what the city might have done to prevent the killing of a 6-year-old, Elisa Izquierdo. [B3.]
 
MAYOR ORDERS AGENCIES TO CUT 7.5%
Facing another looming budget gap, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered city agencies to prepare to cut spending by 7.5 percent for the fiscal year that begins in July. The Mayor's order eliminates 4,500 jobs through attrition, and raises the specter of more reductions in services used by millions of New Yorkers. [B4.]
Charles Millard, a Republican City Councilman from the East Side of Manhattan, is to be appointed president of the Economic Development Corporation. [B4.]
 
CONDOMS ARE RECALLED FOR DEFECTS
The New York State Health Department has been recalling thousands of potentially defective condoms sent to community-based organizations in the state for distribution to poor people, college students and other clients of safe-sex programs, health officials said. [B7.]
 
STATE CUTS DRUGS FOR POOR WITH AIDS
Low-income people with the AIDS virus will no longer get state money to pay for most painkillers, antibiotics, and other drugs, health officials said. [B7.]
 
A DIG FOR TWO MOBSTERS CONTINUES
Not far from the continuing life-and-death dramas at Staten Island University Hospital, a sideshow is going on. The secondary show is very much about death, mob style. Investigators are looking for the corpses of two mobsters. [B8.]
 
REGION
 
PARISH REELS AT BURIAL PRACTICE
Three gravediggers in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have come forward to say that on orders from supervisors, they customarily took miscarried fetuses and amputated limbs from the local Roman Catholic hospital and buried them in a Roman Catholic parish's own cemetery on the edge of town. The remains were buried in the freshly dug graves of people who bore no relation to the fetus or the limbs. [B6.]

HEADLINE: Aristide Insists He Will Leave Office When Term Ends

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Acting to end the widespread uncertainty over his political plans and the friction it has generated in Haiti's relations with the United States, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide said today that he would step down in February despite calls by his supporters that he remain in office for three more years.
"I kept saying a long time ago that I will be happy to go home on Feb. 7," Mr. Aristide said during an informal early morning meeting with foreign reporters in his office at the National Palace. 
 "I already did it, and I will continue to do it," he added, referring to earlier public statements that he would leave office rather than try to extend his term.
But in a wide-ranging, 75-minute conversation in English, Mr. Aristide also expressed dissatisfaction with the state of Haiti's relationship with the United States and the United Nations peacekeeping force here. He urged both to do more to help him disarm "extremists and professional terrorists," and said the withholding of American and other economic aid has contributed to a sudden resurgence of Haitian "boat people" sailing to Florida.
"It's a contradiction when on one side some friends are urging us to do our best to create jobs, while at the same time on the other side they are holding money which could be used to create jobs and keep the refugees here," Mr. Aristide said.
As President, he added, it is "our responsibility to urge those who say they are our friends to respect their promise" to help rebuild Haiti's economy.
Mr. Aristide has on numerous occasions indicated that he planned to leave office when his term expires, as required by the Constitution.
But he raised doubts about his intentions last week when he told a conference of cheering supporters here that "if you want three years, I will not turn my back on you."
Mr. Aristide said today that his remarks had been misinterpreted and that he had never considered remaining in power in order to recuperate the three years of his five-year term that he spent in exile following his ouster in a military coup on Sept. 30, 1991.
His intention, he said, was merely to calm potentially dangerous political passions and not to be seen as imposing his own will on the people.
To eliminate any lingering doubts about his position, Mr. Aristide's press office distributed a list of a half-dozen occasions on which the Haitian leader had publicly declared his intention to step down.
"When I say something, I do my best to respect my word," he said when asked about his credibility.
Mr. Aristide's remarks appeared to clear the way for Haiti to go ahead with a presidential election scheduled for Dec. 17, which had been in doubt as a result of the confusion over the President's own plans. Rene Preval, the candidate of Mr. Aristide's Lavalas party and a former Prime Minister, is the frontrunner in that race, and the President made his own sympathies obvious.
It is part of his job, he acknowledged, "to support all the candidates in terms of being neutral." But, he added, "Lavalas is Lavalas, so I am around the table," a reference to the party's symbol of four people seated at a table. "I cannot deny it."
Mr. Preval has said he wants to govern "hand in hand" with Mr. Aristide, whose personal relationship with him is so close that, as Mr. Aristide pointed out today, "they used to call us twins." But the Haitian President said he is not willing to serve as Mr. Preval's Prime Minister, and appeared to rule out accepting any formal post in the next administration.
"I don't think it is necessary," he said. "I can still serve without having an official role."
Still, Mr. Aristide gave every indication that he intended to remain a political force and a sort of sounding board for the impoverished masses that form his base of support.
"I will do my best to be a good citizen," he said. "In my mind, it is better for me to be home in a peaceful context -- to read, to write, to listen to the people."
Mr. Aristide also rebuffed suggestions that an impassioned speech of his, delivered at the funeral of a slain relative and political associate earlier this month, was responsible for a subsequent outbreak of political violence. By speaking so emphatically and mobilizing the people, he said, he prevented paramilitary groups from "attacking some priests" and plunging the country into turmoil.
"I will not tolerate this kind of killing," he said, even if it meant incurring criticism from the United States and other allies. "We can't tolerate professional terrorists, extremists. We have to disarm them."
Mr. Aristide indicated that the question of Haitian boat people and how to deal with them is another area where he and Washington differ. Early last year, while still in exile in Washington, he abrogated an agreement that allowed the United States to send Haitians picked up at sea back home, but the full impact of that decision is only being felt now.
Speaking of the Coast Guard's repatriation of more than 1,100 Haitian boat people in the last week, Mr. Aristide said "it is illegal" because of the lack of a treaty and complained that "we are not consulted.
Mr. Aristide said that Haitians have again begun leaving the country in recent weeks "because of the economic situation," which has been worsened by the suspensions of American aid.

HEADLINE: Orders for Durables Fell 1% in October

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Led by plunging demand for aircraft, orders to United States factories for expensive, long-lasting goods fell 1 percent in October, the first drop in three months.
The Commerce Department said today that the decline pushed durable-goods orders down to a seasonally adjusted $167.3 billion. 
 Orders had risen 2.9 percent in September and 5.1 percent in August. The last time they fell was in July, when they were off 1.8 percent.
"The economy, after a very strong summer, seems to be softening again," said David Wyss, an economist at DRI-McGraw-Hill, a forecasting service in Lexington, Mass. "Frankly, it looks like very mediocre Christmas."
Half the October decline was in transportation goods, as falling orders for aircraft and parts led a 10.5 percent plunge in this volatile category. The decrease all but wiped out a 10.6 percent advance for transportation equipment in September.
In another report, the Labor Department said the number of American workers filing first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 16,000 last week, the largest drop in nine weeks.
Analysts had predicted the October drop in durable goods, although many expected it to be even steeper. The economy over all has been expanding at a modest pace in recent months, they said.
New orders were 8.2 percent higher in October than for the corresponding period a year earlier. In an up-and-down year, orders fell in six of the first 10 months.
The Commerce Department said that excluding transportation durable-goods orders rose 2.3 percent in October, compared with a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent for the previous month.
Orders for military equipment fell 18.4 percent last month. Orders for nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft fell 3.7 percent in October. Unfilled orders rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month, to $439.6 billion, the third gain in the last four months.
Shipments in October fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $164.7 billion, following two straight increases.

HEADLINE: A Budget Debate Not About Dollars, But About Whose Plan Makes Sense

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Usually when families or companies or even governments think about budgets, the main issue is money -- how much is in the till, how much will be spent and how those two figures relate to each other.
But the big budget showdown this year between President Clinton and Congress is much more about principles. Because splitting the difference is impossible, compromise could be more difficult to achieve. 
 Some of the issues involved:
*Should balancing the budget in precisely seven years become a fundamental tenet of governing or merely a goal?
*How much should Federal taxes be lowered, and how much of a tax break should the wealthy get?
*Should the Medicare system be overhauled, and should the elderly have to pay more for their coverage?
*Should the Federal Government continue to guarantee basic assistance to poor people under Medicaid, Aid to Families With Dependent Children and food stamps or should this mostly become the responsibility of the states?
*Should the Federal role in education, training and the development of technology be expanded or contracted?
*Should commercial interests be given greater access to natural resources on public land?
To understand the budget negotiations now under way between the President and Congress, it is essential to grasp this philosophical distinction: The Republicans who control Congress want to shrink the Federal Government and reduce its presence in the lives of Americans; the President, for the most part, is comfortable with the place of the Government in American life and in some instances would like to expand it.
It is also important to understand the basic differences on these issues:
 
A Balanced Budget
 The Republicans have made the vow to balance the budget in exactly seven years -- not six years or eight years -- the most crucial element in their budget plan, the one item they consider nonnegotiable.
In the Contract With America, their campaign manifesto last year, the Republicans promised a constitutional amendment to accomplish a balanced budget by 2002. The amendment failed by one vote to get the necessary two-thirds majority in the Senate. So the Republicans set about accomplishing the task legislatively.
At a breakfast with reporters two weeks ago, Speaker Newt Gingrich was asked why seven years was so important. He replied, "Seven is the longest period in which you can maintain the discipline to insist on it happening."
And what is the basis for that view?
"Intuition," Mr. Gingrich answered.
Last June, Mr. Clinton offered a revised budget plan that he said would lead to a balanced budget in 10 years. Later, the White House said the economy had improved enough that the President's plan would reach the goal in nine years.
To prepare such long-term budgets, both sides were forced to make predictions, by their nature exercises in uncertainty, about the state of the economy years in advance.
The economic outlook the Administration relied on to write the President's program is slightly more optimistic than the one used by Congress. Because of compounding, the small differences in predictions about such matters as how fast the economy will grow each year mean that hundreds of billions of dollars of additional spending cuts would eventually be necessary to meet the seven-year target using the Republican forecasts. The Congressional Budget Office is in the process of reviewing its economic assumptions. The prevailing view is that its new forecasts will be more favorable than the ones Congress initially used but not so optimistic as the ones used by the White House.
In the agreement the President and Republican leaders signed last week to end the partial shutdown of the Government, Mr. Clinton accepted the notion of a balanced budget in seven years as long as it was consistent with what he called his values and principles. But from what Mr. Clinton and his assistants have said since the agreement was signed, it is clear that they regard a balanced budget in seven years as a goal, not a commitment in concrete.
 
A Tax Break
 This is an area where compromise may be reachable. Congress would cut taxes by $245 billion over seven years, $140 billion more than the President proposed. But Republican leaders have suggested that they might be willing to trim their sights.
Both would give a tax break to middle-income families with children. Both would expand eligibility for tax-favored individual retirement accounts.
The main difference is that Republicans would reduce the tax on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments, to 19.8 percent from 28 percent, a step that would make the capital gains rate the lowest in more than 40 years. Most of the direct benefit from that change would be received by affluent taxpayers because they hold most stocks, bonds and other financial assets.
 
Medicaid and Medicare
 Congress would restrain the growth of spending for Medicare by $270 billion and for Medicaid by $163 billion. The President maintains that savings that large are impossible without destroying the programs. His savings would be $124 billion for Medicare, the program for the elderly and disabled, and $54 billion for Medicaid, the program for the poor and for two-thirds of all people in nursing homes.
But as in other areas, the dispute is about more than money.
The President would not make fundamental changes in either program. In a letter to Congressional leaders last week, the White House insisted that Medicare beneficiaries, who are mostly retirees, be protected from any additional out-of-pocket costs, that resources available to them keep pace with the growth in private health care costs and that Medicaid remain a Federal program guaranteeing coverage for poor families with children and residents of nursing homes.
By contrast, the legislation approved by Congress would place a ceiling on how much could be spent each year under Medicare. So the elderly would no longer be assured of having all the treatment and services they wanted.
Medicare beneficiaries would be encouraged to enroll in managed care programs and to invest in a new form of savings account that would keep them protected against catastrophic illness but might require them to pay hundreds or even thousands of dollars for ordinary medical expenses. The elderly would also be required to pay higher premiums for insurance covering doctor bills and other outpatient expenses.
For Medicaid, Congress would have the Federal Government pay the states an annual lump sum, called a block grant, and the states would then decide who was eligible for which benefits. No longer would families with incomes below a certain level be guaranteed medical care or nursing home residents be assured that the Government would pay the bill if they ran out of their own money.
 
Redefining Welfare
 Congress would end the 60-year-old Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor children through Aid to Families With Dependent Children. This program would be turned over to the states. The Federal contribution through block grants would be limited. Strict time limits would be placed on how long families could remain on welfare. Assistance would be withheld from children born to poor, unmarried women under 18 and in some instances to children born to women already on welfare.
Spending on food stamps would be 15 percent below what would be expected without changes in the law, and benefits would no longer be adjusted annually for inflation or be allowed to rise as much as necessary to cover all poor people fully during recessions. Restrictions would also be placed on school lunches and other nutrition programs for children.
President Clinton's position on welfare has fluctuated. But his current view is that the Republican plan bites too deeply into cash assistance, child nutrition, child care and food stamps. He has accepted the principle of allowing states to set eligibility requirements and benefit levels. But he would substitute measures that would have the effect of continuing the programs as Federal entitlements for the poor.
Republicans are so sure they are on the right side of this issue politically that they plan to break out the welfare portion from the big budget legislation and pass it separately. They believe they will gain an advantage if President Clinton vetoes welfare legislation specifically and not just as part of the overall budget.
 
The Cost of an Education
 This is an area where Republicans want to limit the Federal role, and President Clinton wants to expand it. Congress would cut education spending by about 15 percent in the next seven years. President Clinton would like to increase spending by 18 percent.
The biggest difference arises in programs like Head Start for preschool children, aid to elementary and secondary schools with large numbers of poor children, student loans and scholarship grants to low-income college students.
 
The Environmental Debate
 Republicans hope to give loggers, miners, ranchers and oil and gas drillers freer access to develop natural resources on public lands. They would also cut financing for enforcement of laws against air and water pollution. President Clinton opposes these measures. He finds especially objectionable the Republican plans to increase logging in Alaska's Tongass National Forest and to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling.

HEADLINE: Councilman to Take New Post

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Charles Millard, a Republican City Councilman from the Upper East Side of Manhattan, has been selected by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to be president of the Economic Development Corporation. The Mayor is scheduled to make the announcement today at City Hall.
The corporation tries to encourage business growth in the city and attract and retain private-sector jobs. Mr. Millard, 38, will replace Clay B. Lifflander, who resigned in August to become president of Millbrook Management, an investment company with holdings in wineries owned by John S. Dyson, Mr. Giuliani's Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development. 
 Mr. Millard's resignation will open up a battle for the seat. A Councilman since 1991, he ran for Congress last year against Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Democrat.
Since Mr. Lifflander's resignation last summer, Mr. Millard has been said by administration officials to have lobbied fiercely for the position. But, the officials said, there had been strong resistance from Mr. Dyson, who is said to have wanted someone with a broad background in investment banking and experience in economic development deals.
But Mr. Millard, who is closely allied with State Senator Roy M. Goodman and the Liberal Party leader Raymond B. Harding, both confidants of the Mayor, ultimately prevailed. The position has an annual salary of $110,000.
A graduate of College of the Holy Cross and Columbia Law School, Mr. Millard was a lawyer with Davis Polk & Wardwell in Manhattan for five years. This year, he became managing director at Cambridge Partners, an investment banking firm.
The opening created by Mr. Millard's resignation from the Council has already attracted several candidates to fill the $55,000-a-year seat in a district that includes the neighborhoods of Yorkville and Sutton Place as well as Roosevelt Island.
The candidates include Mr. Millard's director of constituent services, Judith G. Marcus, and A. Gifford Miller, who is New York chief of staff for Ms. Maloney. Others are George N. Spitz, a longtime political gadfly, and Jack Lester, a lawyer specializing in community issues.
The City Charter calls for a special election within 45 days of a vacancy on the Council.

HEADLINE: Rough-Edged Russian Liberal Rides High

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Democracy seems imperiled in Russia. Communists and nationalists are on the rise, the battered and increasingly corrupt presidency of Boris N. Yeltsin is backing away from economic reform. The spirit of Andrei D. Sakharov, the late physicist and dissident who is a Gandhi-like figure in Russia, has dimmed.
There is a leading candidate in the December parliamentary elections who is running as Russian democracy's last hope. The candidate, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, 43, a Harvard-trained economist, says he can reverse the mistakes of the Yeltsin Government and put the country back on the path to democracy and economic reform. 
 He frequently names Dr. Sakharov as his role model. Asked in a recent interview if he really meant to liken himself to the man known as Russia's conscience, Mr. Yavlinsky shrugged impatiently. "Well," he said. "I'm not a physicist."
Mr. Yavlinsky is famous for his energy, his intelligence and his outsized ego.
His party, Yabloko, is likely to win the greatest number of liberal seats in Parliament, and Mr. Yavlinsky is treating the December elections as a springboard for a presidential race in 1996. For now, he is the only democratic opposition candidate with a passing chance: he stands for free-market reform while still remaining untainted by the unpopular policies of the Yeltsin administration.
Mr. Yavlinsky is campaigning on a platform of radical economic reform that is sugarcoated with populist promises, and his ratings in public opinion polls are as high as those of any of his rivals.
"You have to assure voters that reforms will improve their lives," he said. "Do you like the tax system? Then we have to reform it. Do you like not being paid, do you like crime on the streets? What we have now is not reform -- we have liberated the Soviet system instead of liberating society from the Soviet system."
Mr. Yavlinsky, who in 1989 co-wrote a blueprint for radical economic reform that Mikhail S. Gorbachev never carried out, was not offered a prominent role in the early Yeltsin Government, and he turned down lesser jobs. He kept a distance from the Government's policies, and as the election approaches, he is increasingly critical of them and their architect, Yegor T. Gaidar, a liberal economist who was Mr. Yeltsin's Acting Prime Minister at the height of the reforms.
A frequent visitor to the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, Mr. Yavlinsky, who speaks English fluently, is admired by politicians, academics and opinion-makers in Cambridge and Washington.
At home, his image is more complex. "Grigory is fascinating, he's a character straight out of Dostoyevsky," said Alla Gerber, a member of Parliament from Mr. Gaidar's party, Russia's Choice. "He isn't driven to kill an old woman, like Raskolnikov," she added with a laugh, "but to become President."
Mr. Yavlinsky's uncloaked ambition -- and particularly his determination to leave Mr. Gaidar in his wake -- bedevils his natural constituency of intellectuals, teachers and white-collar professionals who still feel loyal to Mr. Gaidar, the foremost post-Soviet radical economic reformer.
Mr. Gaidar, who is widely blamed for the drop in living standards and deepening inequities that followed economic policies begun in 1992, after the breakup of the Soviet Union, is the favorite scapegoat of Communists, but he has become a kind of Adlai Stevenson figure to Moscow liberals.
At times, the relationship of Yabloko and Russia's Choice has resembled that of an unhappy couple. The needy Mr. Gaidar keeps struggling to make peace with a stern, hypercritical Mr. Yavlinsky. Whenever reconciliation seem imminent, as it did when the two appeared to strike a deal on a television program last May, Mr. Yavlinsky abruptly pulls out the rug. The next morning, he issued a terse statement that he had changed his mind.
Mr. Yavlinsky has a short answer for why he is refuses to join forces with the only other major liberal party. "The easiest explanation," he said, "is that the polls say that if I join Mr. Gaidar I will lose 46 percent of my voters."
But at times, he can seem more preoccupied with measuring himself against Mr. Gaidar than battling more fearsome competitors, like the Communist leader Gennadi A. Zyuganov or the nationalist Gen. Aleksandr I. Lebed.
"I can't just campaign for intellectuals sitting around the kitchen table in Moscow," he lamented. "I listen to them, but I don't always take their advice, so they call me arrogant."
He painted his relationship with Russia's intellectual elite as a painful family drama. "It's like they are my parents -- I say 'I'd cut off my right hand for you, but I cannot always do what you want me to do.' "
Yelena G. Bonner, Dr. Sakharov's widow, seems to view Mr. Yavlinsky more as a wayward nephew than a son. "What worries me is that Yavlinsky seems to be moving from serious economics at a rather drastic speed to populism," she said, referring to Mr. Yavlinsky's vows to raise pensions and wages without increasing inflation. Mr. Yavlinsky says he will raise the money painlessly by closing tax loopholes on Government monopolies.
Miss Bonner said she will support Mr. Gaidar's party in the December elections because he took the plunge and made bold, difficult economic choices at a critical moment in Russian history and stood by them. Mr. Yavlinsky, she said, "has not been tested."
That has mostly worked in his favor until now. One of Yabloko's political advertisements carries a message that is not that different from that of Communists or nationalists.
A handsome young man in a construction hard hat looks soberly into the camera and says, "Paying pensions on time is not a matter of politics, it's a matter of conscience." He pauses grimly, then adds, "We shall hold the powers that be accountable."
Mr. Yavlinsky has detractors, but even his harshest critics concede that he may be the strongest candidate liberals have. One of the only nationally known candidates willing to engage in public debates, Mr. Yavlinsky went one-on-one with Mr. Zyuganov last week, and by common consensus deftly ripped the Communist's arguments to shreds.
These days, Mr. Yavlinsky is more of a politician than an economic purist, and it has cost him support within his own party.
Yuri Y. Boldyrev, a founder of Yabloko, recently quit over policy disputes with Mr. Yavlinsky. Mr. Boldyrev, an economist who is a member of the upper house of Parliament, the Federation Council, is particularly upset about Mr. Yavlinsky's support of a proposed law that would make it easier for the Government to sell off natural resources to domestic and foreign investors.
Yabloko, the Yeltsin administration and even foreign financial institutions like the World Bank support the measure as a way of quickly increasing state revenues. Mr. Boldyrev complains that some of the law's provisions would also encourage the kind of Government corruption and sweetheart deals that are already rampant in Russia.
Without Mr. Boldyrev, Yabloko is more than ever a one-man show, and can sometimes mirror Mr. Yavlinsky's restless, overconfident personality. Yabloko was almost knocked off the ballot this year after the Central Election Committee disqualified it for failing to turn in minor registration paperwork.
An uproar followed, as most political parties denounced it as a conspiracy, and Mr. Gaidar said he would not run if Mr. Yavlinsky could not. The issue was forced into the Supreme Court, which ruled in favor of Mr. Yavlinsky.
The flap won Mr. Yavlinsky plenty of free air time and press attention, but it was also underlined the disarray within his political organization.
There are other issues simmering beneath the surface that could cost him votes. Mr. Yavlinsky is half-Jewish in a country where there is still a strong strain of anti-Semitism. He has been more open about it than many other public officials, and caused a stir when he candidly discussed his Jewish roots on a highly rated national television talk show last February.
But there is tension between Mr. Yavlinsky's desire to be honest and his understanding of the political undercurrents in his country.
When asked during a recent appearance at a military base why a Jew should be elected to high office in Russia, Mr. Yavlinsky deflected the question. If people think that Jews have done so much to destroy Russia, he replied, "maybe it will take a Jew to rebuild it."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 3, 1996, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about Russian politics referred imprecisely to the academic background of Grigory A. Yavlinsky, liberal economist and candidate for the Russian presidency. Two readers have pointed out that although he has worked with Harvard professors, he did not attend Harvard University and should not have been described as Harvard-trained. (A profile on Dec. 1, 1995, which served as a source for the latest article, included the same error.)

HEADLINE: Billionaire's Gift Helps Columbia to Exceed Its Fund-Raising Goal

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
Alfred Lerner is one of America's wealthiest men, with a net worth of $1 billion gained in real estate and banking. But he started life in the back of a Queens candy store run by his parents. Looking back, he credits his four years as an undergraduate at Columbia University with setting him on a path toward many of life's riches.
"Whatever good fortune I have, Columbia was part of that, so I owe them something," said Mr. Lerner, 62, the chairman and chief executive of the MBNA Corporation, one of the nation's largest credit-card issuing companies. 
 Mr. Lerner, in fact, decided he owed Columbia about $25 million. And with a gift in that amount, as well as tens of thousands of others from grateful alumni, Columbia will announce today that it has surpassed its five-year goal of raising $1.15 billion. Rather than taking a breather as most universities do, it plans to exploit momentum and buttonhole enough moguls and dial enough alumni to raise another billion before the century is through.
The robust flavor of the announcement seemed to broadcast the university's belief that it has worked its way out of the troubles that culminated roughly five years ago, when several unbalanced budgets forced it to bite into its endowment and close a few departments. Its drawing power, some national experts say, seemed to slip sometime after the student demonstrations of the late 1960's as more students tended to spurn urban universities, some of its alumni left the New York City area -- the base of 35 percent of Columbia's student body -- and colleges like Stanford, Duke and Rice gained new appeal.
But in the last two years, officials said, the school has a 29 percent surge in applications and has balanced its budget.
"Columbia College is becoming one of the hot schools in America," said Dr. George Rupp, the university's president, in an address he plans to deliver tonight to benefactors. "Many of the best students increasingly want to be here. They want to be in the world's media center; they want to be near the financial markets; they want the exciting arts and cultural richness; they want to live in a diverse community that is at the heart of a profoundly dynamic global economy."
The $1.15 billion will be put to a multitude of uses, though almost half of it is to go to operate the university and help avoid increases in tuition, room and board, which now total $27,126 a year for Columbia College. And Dr. Rupp disclosed that the college, the smallest of the Ivy League schools with 3,400 undergraduate students, is contemplating expanding its enrollment by roughly 10 percent.
Butler Library, among the world's largest collections of books, will be spruced up at a cost of $160 million and carried further into the digital age.
The School of Arts will be renovated with a $6 million gift from artist LeRoy Neiman. More than a hundred professorships will be given stable endowments that officials said would help hold down tuition.
And Ferris Booth Hall will be torn down and replaced with a sunnier, more spacious student center named after, yes, Mr. Lerner.
The new $2.2 billion goal stretched over the 10 years of the 1990's is the largest fund-raising target any American college has ever projected, though Harvard's $2.1 billion goal would be achieved in half the time.
Columbia University, which was founded in 1754 as Kings College, has a $2.2 billion endowment, the nation's seventh largest, though still one-third the size of the leader, Harvard. It has 20,200 graduate and undergraduate students and 2,350 full-time faculty members and remains one of the nation's most competitive institutions. Its college admitted 23.4 percent of the 8,714 students who applied last year, and 43 percent of those chose to attend.
The $1.15 billion raised since the campaign was begun in the fall of 1990 by Michael I. Sovern, then the Columbia president, was made up of 300,000 donations. They ranged from a dollar to such gifts as $85 million contributed by John W. Kluge, chairman of the Metromedia Company, for minority scholarships and faculty development, and $10 million donations each by two leading trustees, Jerry Speyer, president and chief executive officer of Tishman Speyer Properties, and Lionel I. Pincus, chairman and chief executive of E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company.
Amassing this money required a mixture of tact, stamina and plain audacity. Dr. Rupp traveled to Asia and Europe to meet with prosperous alumni identified by the college's development office. He schmoozed with alumni, trying to determine some university function that they favored, like gene-therapy research or the library.
"Giving is highly personal," Dr. Rupp said. "People go back to first principles. We ask what are our deepest values. What do we hold most dear, what are we grateful for."
The trustees themselves made rounds of telephone calls and burnished chairs at many a dinner party.
"I have no compunction to ask on behalf of the university," said Mr. Speyer, who is chairman of its board of trustees.
Mr. Speyer, in fact, was on the receiving end of a full-court press by the college president, looking for a sizable gift.
"I had something else in mind, and George made the case that it was important for the trustees and the other people involved in the university to show their support in a major way," Mr. Speyer said.
Columbia, after all, was the place where Mr. Speyer met three of his lifelong friends as well as an art professor who helped him acquire the sensibility to gather his impressive art collection.
"My family's first, my business is second, but the third interest I have is art, and I was first exposed to art at Columbia and I've been collecting for 30 years," Mr. Speyer said.
Although gifts would have come in annually in any case, colleges like to create campaigns with specific deadlines, said Henry King, former chairman of the board of trustees, because they "generate a certain amount of excitement."
"Alumni are mobilized to reach a target and strive for it," he said.
Spending the money also involved some hard choices. The college decided not to renovate Ferris Booth because it would still end up with an inadequate center for a growing student body and because it did not reflect the rest of the campus's architectural style. But tearing Ferris Booth down will now mean that for three years students will have to use temporary prefabricated buildings for many activities.
In debating what to do about Butler Library, Dr. Rupp recalled, some trustees argued that in the computer age, it was a white elephant and a "monument to past scholarly habits."
Still, he said he found the whole fund-raising process exhilarating.
"People express what they care about even more than money because, after all, they're giving money away," he said.

HEADLINE: Castro All Hugs and Kisses On First Visit to Old Ally

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Fidel Castro began a visit to China today to embrace fellow leaders of one of the world's last Communist-run nations, and to find a willing ally in his defiance of the United States.
The Cuban President, a belated convert to market reforms since aid from the Soviet Union dried up, and perhaps eager for a new source of handouts, enthusiastically praised China's economic miracle. 
 But the timing of his visit, with China's relations with the United States strained, suggested that it was welcomed by the Chinese as a way to assert diplomatic independence from America, increasingly seen by some Chinese leaders as its nemesis because of disputes over trade, Taiwan and human rights.
Mr. Castro, wearing his trademark olive military uniform, embraced the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, complete with three kisses, for television cameras, apparently trying to convince the world that they are old friends.
It is Mr. Castro's first visit to China. Despite decades of proclaiming Communist solidarity, the Cuban's close alliance with Moscow prevented him from becoming too friendly with China.
At a signing ceremony for a small increase in Chinese economic aid to Cuba, Mr. Castro seemed to charm his hosts by gracefully uttering two Chinese words "Xie xie" -- "thank you" -- in response to Mr. Jiang's "gracias."
Chinese-Cuban trade hovers around a relatively small $500 million, and the new economic aid that was announced today includes just a $3 million economic grant and the increase in a science and technology grant from $5 million to $8 million.
A state-run Chinese newspaper praised Cuba for its defiance of the United States today.
"China and Cuba both are socialist countries and both have experience facing 'blockades' and 'sanctions,' " the Jingji Ribao, or Economic Daily, said today. "But the two countries do not fear blockades or strangleholds."
Mr. Castro went out of his way to flatter his hosts with a nod to Deng Xiaoping's statement about building "socialism with Chinese characteristics" to justify market reforms and private ownership in a Communist-run nation.
"Cuba is carrying out steady reform and opening, with a view toward building socialism with Cuban characteristics," Mr. Castro said at a three-hour meeting with Mr. Jiang, according to the official New China News Agency. "We'll continue to march forward along such a road."

HEADLINE: Iraq Sanctions Kill Children, U.N. Reports

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 30

 BODY:
As many as 576,000 Iraqi children may have died since the end of the Persian Gulf war because of economic sanctions imposed by the Security Council, according to two scientists who surveyed the country for the Food and Agriculture Organization.
The study also found steeply rising malnutrition among the young, suggesting that more children will be at risk in the coming years. The results of the survey will appear on Friday in The Lancet, the journal of the British Medical Association. 
 "I had a sense that the situation had gotten worse, but I didn't think that there would be such a dramatic difference," said Mary Smith Fawzi, a researcher at the Harvard University School of Public Health, who conducted the survey for the Food and Agriculture Organization. The co-author is Sarah Zaidi, science director of the Center for Social and Economic Rights in New York.
Dr. Fawzi, who surveyed 2,120 children under 10 years of age in 25 neighborhoods in Baghdad in August, said 28 percent were stunted in growth, up from 12 percent in 1991.
In 1991, she said in an interview, rates of malnutrition in Iraq were similar to those in Kuwait. In the paper for The Lancet, she says Iraq has now sunk to the levels of poor developing countries, with underweight rates among children comparable to those in Ghana or Mali.
The percentage of Iraqi children affected by "wasting," or emaciation requiring urgent attention, rose to 12 percent in 1995, from 3 percent in 1991, Dr. Fawzi reported, adding that these figures are extraordinarily high, similar to those found in Malagasy and Myanmar.
Several United Nations agencies, including F.A.O. and Unicef, have expressed concern about the damage being done to Iraqis, especially children, by United Nations economic sanctions. Two years ago, F.A.O. warned that Iraq risked widespread starvation.
The Security Council responded to these concerns earlier this year when it offer Iraq the opportunity to sell $2 billion worth of oil to purchase food and medicines under United Nations supervision, the second such offer in four years. Iraq rejected both as infringements of its sovereignty and has continued to demand an unconditional end to sanctions.
The sanctions were imposed by the Security Council after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990. Led by the United States, the Council has rejected many Iraqi appeals to lift the restrictions, which have crippled the economy, until Iraq accounts for all its weapons of mass destruction and United Nations inspectors can certify that they have been destroyed in accordance with several Council resolutions.
Recent revelations about significant secret biological and chemical weapons programs have set back any chances of an early end of sanctions.
In 1991, after the war ended, Dr. Fawzi and other researchers found that mortality rates for children under five had tripled during the war and its immediate aftermath. By this year, the rate had increased fivefold.
Deaths related to diarrheal diseases have tripled in an increasingly unhealthy environment, the study says. Water and sanitation systems have deteriorated, hospitals are functioning at 40 percent of capacity, food prices are high and many people are living on Government rations that provide only 1,000 calories a day.
Infant deaths, which had doubled during the gulf war, continue at a high rate, Dr. Fawzi wrote.
"These findings illustrate a strong association between economic sanctions and increase in child mortality and malnutrition rates," the study says.
"The United Nations humanitarian arm offers palliatives for the alleviation of suffering while the U.N. Security Council is intent on continuing the sanctions," the authors write, adding that the situation poses a challenge to "the moral, financial and political standing of the international community."

HEADLINE: Cleaning Up Carting Together

 BODY:
Garbage removal has been a scandal in New York almost since the city "privatized" commercial carting more than four decades ago. Costs are wildly out of line -- perhaps three times as steep as in Chicago or Los Angeles. The owners of 23 carting companies and their trade organizations are under indictment for extortion and restraint of trade.
Yesterday the city's political and law enforcement leaders joined to call for a new commission that would regulate and license the city's carters. It was a good and rare day for New York, in which Mayor Rudolph Giuliani showed an unusual willingness to share the podium with political rivals like Public Advocate Mark Green and City Council Speaker Peter Vallone. Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau was another welcome participant, expressing an uncharacteristic willingness to share some of his turf. 
 The proposal that drew all those normally fractious officials to City Hall would create an agency with unprecedented authority over the carters. It would have the power to audit the carting companies' records, investigate the backgrounds of their employees and set standards for service. It could set maximum fees and run pilot programs in which the agency itself would choose one or more carters to do business in an entire district.
The idea of letting the city award district carting rights to one or more companies is the most controversial part of the bill. Ideally, it will be used only as a tool to lure more companies into bidding for carting work, and to embolden businesses to award their contracts to reputable low bidders. Clean and open competition should be the ultimate goal, not legalized monopolies.
The bill will almost certainly pass early next year, and then face a series of court challenges from the carting industry. The city's task in defending its plan is made much easier by Mr. Morgenthau, whose investigators spent five years infiltrating the carting industry, spending $800,000 on extortion payments themselves along the way.
Mr. Green deserves special praise for his long fight to clean up commercial carting. There was a danger the Mayor would torpedo the Public Advocate's crusade solely because of its source. Speaker Vallone and the City Council member Kenneth Fisher of Brooklyn played important roles in brokering an agreement.
The city's new commission will have about 80 employees, drawn from existing agencies like Consumer Affairs, Sanitation and police. Mayor Giuliani says this new initiative will not cost the city any extra money. But if it does, it would still be worth it. City businesses spend $1.5 billion a year for garbage removal, and Mr. Morgenthau has charged that about 40 percent of that is due to the existence of a Mafia-run cartel that sets prices and drives off competition. When it comes to improving the economic climate in New York, cleaning up the carting industry would be worth more than a hefty tax cut.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Germany Doesn't Change Rates, But Dollar Still Gains vs. Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose to a two-month high against the German mark yesterday, holding on to gains even after the Bundesbank left interest rates unchanged.
While a number of currency traders were expecting a rate cut after the German central bank's policy meeting today, many still hold out hopes of a rate cut soon, given Germany's flagging economic growth and moderate inflation. 
 "My general outlook for the dollar is bullish, particularly on dollar-mark," said Charles Spence, director of currency sales at Standard Chartered Bank in New York. "Even though the Bundesbank didn't change rates today, prospects are that it will happen soon."
The dollar initially dipped after the Bundesbank left its discount rate, which acts as the floor for German money market rates, unchanged at 3.5 percent. The slump proved short-lived, though, as investors wagered a rate cut merely had been deferred. The Bundesbank's policy-setting council will hold its next meeting, the last of this year, on Dec. 14.
The dollar also benefited because "U.S. stock and bond markets are doing so well," said Bob Gruber, senior currency salesman at the Chemical Bank.
The dollar rose as high as 1.4507 marks, its strongest since Sept. 21, when it reached 1.4637 marks. In New York late yesterday, it settled at 1.4470 marks, up from 1.4366 marks on Wednesday. The dollar rose to 102.15 Japanese yen from 101.58 yen. The British pound slipped to $1.5325 from $1.5336.
In other trading, the French franc slumped against the dollar and the mark as a series of strikes threatened to worsen the economic slowdown in France.
"There is a fundamental conflict" between the Government trying to cut the budget deficit, reduce unemployment and buoy the franc, said Graham Broyd, manager of currency sales at the National Westminster Bank in New York. "Those don't go together. As a result, the market keeps going back to haunting the French franc."
The weakness in the franc apparently helped persuade the Bank of France to leave two important interest rates unchanged. The central bank left the intervention rate, the floor to French money-market rates, at 4.8 percent, and the securities-repurchase rate, the ceiling to money-market rates, at 6.10 percent.
The dollar was last at 4.9970 French francs, up from 4.9445 francs on Wednesday. The mark was at 3.4553 francs, up from 3.4370 francs. Earlier, the dollar rose to 5.0049 francs, its highest level since Sept. 21.

HEADLINE: In America;
Going Nowhere Fast

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
A two-year study of fast-food-restaurant employees in Harlem and Oakland, Calif., has found that young people from the inner city benefit substantially from the work, despite the low wages, but there usually is no "next tier" of employment to which they can climb by using the skills they have learned or honed in the restaurants.
This absence of employment at the next step up, according to two professors of anthropology who conducted the study, makes it extremely difficult for the inner-city youngsters, who are not well educated, to work their way out of poverty. 
 "The kids have mixed feelings," said Prof. Katherine Newman of Columbia University, who studied the Harlem workers. "They feel that if they work hard at this it will lead somewhere. But their experience is that it doesn't."
The point of the study was to look closely at the lives of the working poor at a time when much of the attention of government and the media is focused on poor people who are not working. Professor Newman and her colleague, Prof. Carol Stack of the University of California at Berkeley, who did the Oakland study, said the fast-food workers were representative of the majority of the urban poor -- men and women who are working at jobs that even on a full-time basis do not pay enough to adequately support a family.
What they found is that the competition for even minimum-wage jobs is intense. At the restaurants studied in Harlem, 14 applicants are turned away for every person who is hired.
In contrast to the persistent canard that poor people do not want to work, Professors Newman and Stack have shown that people are fighting for jobs that, full time, pay only $8,840 a year.
Most of the 400 workers studied were in their 20's. Most were members of families that would have trouble remaining intact without the workers' financial contributions. Many belonged to families in which there were serious and sometimes disabling illnesses. Many had endured the loss of close relatives to premature death.
The professors found that the fast-food jobs for these young people were helpful on a number of fronts. They provided a meager but crucial income. They imposed an additional level of structure and order on their lives. And they gave them the sense of dignity and accomplishment and independence that usually results from being employed.
The workers may not be thrilled about putting on hamburger uniforms and toiling at jobs disdained by many, but they know they are doing better than those who are without work, and they nurture the slender hope that more rewarding days are ahead.
The rest of the picture is bleak. Despite their training and experience in such areas as food preparation, inventory control and customer relations, there is no demand for the services of inner-city youngsters who are too often seen merely as hamburger flippers.
And because the job market in general is so tight, the younger workers are facing heightened competition for the fast-food jobs from older, better-educated men and women who once held better jobs.
"In Oakland," said Professor Stack, "many of the young people are actually competing for the same jobs with elders in their own families."
When Professor Newman tracked job applicants who were not hired by the Harlem restaurants, she found that a year later 73 percent still had not found work.
The study by Professors Newman and Stack was supported by a number of organizations, including the Russell Sage, Rockefeller and Ford foundations. A final report will be completed next spring.
Despite the obvious need for increased employment opportunities in the inner city, both researchers said in interviews this week that they expected the problem to get substantially worse. Government and the health-care industry, which have traditionally provided work for inner-city residents, are shedding workers, and are likely to shed many more.
At the same time, the welfare policy trend is to push as many recipients onto the job market as possible, whether there are jobs available for them or not.
If this generation is the first to get stuck at the entry level, said Professor Stack, the next may be the first that is unable to "get its foot in the door at all."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Economic Data and Dollar Aid Rally in Bond Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The bond rally built a head of steam yesterday, aided by weak economic data and a firm dollar that helped to push the rate of the 30-year Treasury bond to its lowest level in more than two years.
A sharp drop in the Chicago Association of Purchasing Agent's report for November yesterday raised expectations for a subdued report by the National Association of Purchasing Managements which is scheduled for release today. That, in turn, helped to stoke anticipation of another interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve, the better to stimulate what some perceive is a slowing economy. 
 In trading yesterday against the German mark, the dollar rose as high as 1.4505 marks, before trading late in the day at 1.4470 marks. The dollar was also changing hands in New York at 102.15 Japanese yen, up from 101.58 on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction from its yield, increased 29/32, to 110 3/32 for a yield of 6.13 percent, down from 6.19 percent on Wednesday and the lowest yield since Feb. 3, 1993, when it was 6.10 percent.
Other factors accounting for yesterday's strong market, traders said, included an underlying optimism about progress in Federal budget negotiations. This, they said, allowed the market to disregard some stronger economic numbers and focus on the weak data instead.
Traders also noted that the market continued to price in an expected easing of monetary policy at the Dec. 19 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-setting arm.
Adding some momentum to the rally was a report by Market News Service that the Fed's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, said that the central bank has a "window of opportunity" to cut rates now to head off an economic decline in 1997.
The market opened higher yesterday, only to have early gains shaved briefly by the Government's report on October orders for durable goods. The decline in orders was not as steep as economists had been expecting after a big increase in September.
But prices headed higher again after the Chicago purchasing index slipped to 49.9 in November from 53.4 in October. A reading of more than 50 generally indicates a growing economy, while less than 50 means some contraction.
Carl Palash, chief economist for MCM Moneywatch in New York, a market research and analysis firm, saw the market remaining positive, despite the mixed data. But Mr. Palash does not see the picture to be as rosy as the market appears to. "A case can be made that the data is telling us that the economy is better than many think," he said.
Orders for durable goods, after excluding the volatile transportation component, were up 2.3 percent, well above the third-quarter average, Mr. Palash noted, "which suggests that the demand for manufactured goods is still robust."
Another economic indicator, the weekly number of initial jobless claims, fell yesterday by 16,000, to 363,000, presumably another sign of economic strength. Mr. Palash considers that a high level, but over all, he said, it was likely a figure that had been depressed by the close of state offices for the Thanksgiving holiday.
Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago, found some of the Chicago purchasing numbers weaker than the October data, suggesting that the economy was softening.
Mr. Davis noted that it had been a tendency of the bond market to trade up in the last few days of a month as portfolio managers extended the maturities of the securities in those portfolios.
"That, coupled with the very successful two- and five-year note auctions this week and the weaker-than-expected Chicago N.A.P.M. report, was enough to propel the market," he said. "Technically, the bond market put in a good performance today, closing so close to its highs it is encouraging traders that the bull market would continue."
Another reason people were positive, Mr. Davis said, was the fact that the Fed executed a "coupon pass" -- that is, buying Treasury securities to add currency to the economy to adjust for seasonal demand -- using a new procedure.
"Before, when the Fed did a coupon pass," he said, "dealers submitted offerings across all maturities. Under the new procedure, the Fed specifies the maturity sectors in which it will be active. So traders think that because the Fed came in today buying in the one-to-two-year range, there is a likelihood that they will come to market again looking for longer maturities."
Analysts said that when the Fed came in the market for a coupon pass, the market saw it as a ready buyer.
"My only concern," Mr. Davissaid, "is that everyone I talk to is positive on the market because the last shorts have thrown in the towels, but the market needs the fuel the shorts provide."
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auctions of 13-day and 27-day cash management bills, which the Government often sells to meet cash flow shortages when it needs to meet interest and principal payments:

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Blockades Of Taiwan

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
They come almost every day now the military threats to this island country from the Communist Government in Beijing.
Chinese Army commanders order repeated amphibious landings at the mainland coast nearest the island -- the precise kind of operation that would be needed to invade Taiwan -- and "tests" of missiles in the straits dividing China and the island. In recent days there has been a series of leaked reports that Beijing is considering a naval blockade of Taiwan. 
 Nobody knows whether the threats are meant only to frighten all Taiwanese into abandoning any thought of independence, however distant, or whether Beijing is readying its people and the world for an attack. If it does take place it is likely to be in the spring of 1996 before or after Taiwan holds its first direct presidential election.
But the evidence is that the military command is beginning to operate and plan independently of the civilian leadership in the Politburo.
This much seems clear from here: The West is operating on the assumption that if it says and does nothing, why, any dangers will vanish in a merciful blip.
The studious silence arises from the fundamental China policy of the West: Rock no Chinese boat lest Beijing throw easy Western access to the Chinese market overboard.
The West manages to maintain its silence because a Chinese blockade of Taiwan already exists: the political and diplomatic blockade created by Beijing after it took over the China seat in the U.N. in 1971.
The government on Taiwan was not only ousted from the U.N. but from the international community. Taiwan, one of the largest trading nations in the world, has been cut off from normal diplomatic and political relations with almost the whole world.
The U.S. maintains an "institute" in Taipei headed by a "director." But no flag is flown outdoors to save Beijing a fit. In Washington, representatives of Taiwan cannot sully the State department or White House by their presence. So far, separate drinking fountains for Taiwanese representatives have not been set up.
Taiwan is not only barred from the U.N. but from all its many specialized agencies, including those supposed to deal with such universal subjects as health and agriculture -- say, AIDS or starvation.
The blockade is so obsessively enforced that it even excludes aid to refugees. Last year the U.N. appealed for funds for Rwandan refugees, among the most suffering of God's human creatures. Taiwan offered $2 million; refused. The Taiwanese did manage to get their gift accepted -- by channeling it through an American committee for Unicef.
Correspondents from Taiwan are not permitted to enter the U.N. As a former reporter at the U.N., in its early days, I have thought of slipping my pass to a correspondent from Taiwan, to annoy U.N. authorities, but I decided it wouldn't work.
Before Beijing commanded the U.N., correspondents from non-member peoples were allowed in. I learned more about North Africa and Indonesia from independence-movement reporters than I ever did from the colonial French or Dutch.
North Korea and South Korea are members and so were East and West Germany. The Palestine Liberation Organization was given representation at the General Assembly with only a vote lacking.
But when China decided that any dreams of independence, sovereignty or even dignity that Taiwan might harbor were too dangerous to tolerate, this special apartheid was created for the island. The U.S. and most other U.N. members meekly kissed Beijing's iron slipper.
That means Taiwan cannot use the U.N. or any normal diplomatic channel to raise an alarm that had to be officially heard about the open military threats from Beijing. If any other country had threatened another so blatantly the case would immediately have been on the U.N. agenda.
Now of course most U.N. members, including the U.S., would be paralyzed with economic terror at the very idea of proposing that Taiwan as well as China be represented at the U.N. But perhaps Washington, London, Paris and Tokyo will dredge up enough courage to increase their own diplomatic contacts with Taiwan as a warning to China. Perhaps.
Until now the Chinese diplomatic blockade and Western submission to it have been merely disgusting. Now they are getting dangerous.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
