HEADLINE: Retailers Had Weak Sales In November

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Retailers found more reason to weep yesterday as they posted weak November sales, following the worst October in four years.
Salomon Brothers said its same-store growth index rose only 2.9 percent in November from the month a year earlier. 
 By comparison, sales were up four-tenths of 1 percent in October and 4.2 percent in November 1994. Mild weather at the end of last month, price deflation and a slowing economy all played a role, analysts said.
"The fact is, consumers basically had little wage growth in general," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, vice president of retail research at Salomon Brothers. "Those who were spending were at the upper end of the income spectrum because they are the ones who have gained from the over $1 trillion created by the stock market increase in the last 12 to 18 months.
"The Guccis and the Tiffanys of the world seem to continue doing well," he said. "Everyone else is slugging along."
Not surprisingly, apparel again took the worst beating. Ann Taylor reported a stunning 15.9 percent decrease in same-store sales, which are considered the best measure of a retailer's performance, though it had a banner year in 1994 that was difficult to compete against. Sales at the Limited Inc. fell 3 percent, Charming Shoppes Inc. was down 13 percent and the Catherine Stores Corporation declined 1 percent. The Gap Inc. gained a mere 1 percent.
Department stores reported weak results. A lone winner was Sears, Roebuck & Company, which enjoyed a 5.1 percent increase in same-store sales, a better performance than competitors like J. C. Penney Inc., which reported a 1.8 percent increase, and the Dayton Hudson Corporation, whose same-store sales grew 1.7 percent. Sales at May Department Stores were up 1 percent; Carson Pirie Scott & Company reported a 3.6 percent increase.
"The trends you have been seeing for 1995 in retailing continued in November," Mr. Feiner said. "Department stores continue to take shares of the market from specialty retailers."
Discounters and electronics merchants did somewhat better, although many sales required heavy promotions. The Best Buy Company, for example, saw a 15 percent increase, and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. had increased sales of 3 percent.
"All that was achieved through deep markdowns," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report. "The rest is the pits, which confirms that American households are in a deep economic squeeze."
But luxury stores seem to be moving their merchandise. Richard N. Baum, vice president of investment research at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said that jewelry merchants all reported between mid-single to double-digit same-store increases. "We think that is significant that jewelry retailers are doing phenomenally when specialty retailers are doing so poorly," Mr. Baum said.
The Goldman, Sachs composite index, which measures big retailers' sales at stores open at least one year, was up 2.94 points for November, compared with November 1994, when the index rose 4.11 points.
Because Christmas shoppers increasingly wait until the 11th hour to shop, these November numbers do not necessarily translate into a terrible Christmas, but neither are they a harbinger of good cheer.
"The start of the season being sluggish is not an accurate four days to extrapolate from," Mr. Feiner said, in reference to the post-Thanksgiving holiday rush that wasn't.
Retailers posted disappointing holiday weekend sales after shoppers filled the malls but mostly window-shopped, holding out for last-minute price slashing that has become as much a part of Christmas as gift wrap and mistletoe.
These price cuts directly reduce profit margins and bring a great deal of added woe to retailers in already-tough times, because most stores count on the fourth quarter for roughly 40 percent of their profits.
The International Council of Shopping Centers said that specialty-store sales from Friday through Sunday were unchanged from the corresponding period last year, based on a survey of 80 malls that last year reported a 4.5 percent sales gain.
"Investors have to look at November and December together," Mr. Baum said, "Because historically, it is quite unusual to have a disconnected relationship between the two."

HEADLINE: In Russia, Change Must Take a Little Longer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is not surprising that Jeffrey D. Sachs (Op-Ed, Nov. 29), one of the architects of economic shock therapy in the former Soviet Union, should claim that the corruption, inflation and privatization now rampant in Russia is a result of the failure of Western governments to provide adequate financial support. 
 The most successful capitalist societies have learned by bitter experience over a long period that the law of the jungle must be restrained by reasonable regulation, carefully administered, to prevent the kind of situation prevailing in many of the former Communist countries. Despite our efforts, there is still a good deal of poverty, inadequate access to education and medical care, and a striking disparity of opportunity.
Given this background, where did the idea come from that it was possible to shift the economic systems of Eastern Europe from a state-directed economy to a capitalist system nearly overnight?
On what evidence did anyone conclude that this remarkable transformation could be successfully accomplished by "young, inexperienced and lagely honest reformers," advised by Western experts equally short of experience in instant transformation of societies?
Should it not have been obvious that without strong control from the top the fruits of shock therapy would largely go to society's most aggressive and unprincipled?
As for the role of funding, the experience of West Germany in effecting a similar transformation in East Germany is instructive. With virtually unlimited funds and a common language and starting with one of the West's most economically and technically advanced countries, the problem has turned out much more difficult than once thought. It will take generations, not years, to finish a job that is surely much easier than the task facing Russia.
A certain amount of humility is required when one tries to reform human society. No matter how lofty our goals and how transparent our good intentions, we ought to realize that such transformations are very difficult, take a long time and often don't end up the way we expected.
 
WILLIAM F. SCHREIBER
Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 29, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Imagining Race Relations With Roles Reversed

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Watching "White Man's Burden," you can almost hear the sound of feet treading lightly on eggshells. This didactic political fable, which imagines an America in which the roles of blacks and whites are reversed, approaches its subject with such nervous self-consciousness that the arguments in its debate about racial injustice are measured out in quarter-teaspoons. Were it not for John Travolta's big-hearted portrayal of an unemployed white factory worker driven to commit a desperate act, the movie would be an emotionally frozen exercise in cautious high-mindedness.
As Louis Pinnock, a hard-working family man who loses his job and eventually his home through a minor misunderstanding at work, Mr. Travolta creates a sympathetic portrait of a man who comes unstrung. Until disaster strikes, Louis lives with his tight-lipped wife, Marsha (Kelly Lynch), and their two children in a poor white neighborhood of chain-link fences and decomposing auto parts that resembles south central Los Angeles. 
 Borderline poverty has strained the marriage, and the couple are behind in their mortgage payments. The film's most harrowing scene depicts the family's humiliating eviction, in which they are given 15 minutes to pack a few belongings and vacate the premises.
The Pinnocks' economic plight is pointedly contrasted with the opulent world of Thaddeus Thomas (Harry Belafonte), the well-heeled businessman who inadvertently caused Louis to be fired. The pet project of Thaddeus's elegant wife, Megan (Margaret Avery), happens to be a glitzy fashion show benefiting underprivileged white children. In a film that often pulls its punches, the scenes depicting the self-congratulatory condescension attending such events carry a satirical bite.
"White Man's Burden," which was written and directed by Desmond Nakano, changes from a what-if fable into a dull but well-meaning essay on race relations once Louis kidnaps Thaddeus in his rickety pickup truck and gives him a tour of his shabby world. At a fast-food stand, the pair are menaced by white skinheads, and guns are drawn. Later, Louis picks up his 6-year-old son and takes him to a toy store where, over the father's objections, the little boy chooses a doll of a black super-hero as a birthday present.
But as bold as it is, the premise of the film remains frustratingly undeveloped. In imagining America run by a black ruling class, the movie skirts any questions of what the dominant culture might be like. Beyond imagining white skinheads as inner-city gangsters, the movie is just as reluctant to flesh out the texture of a white ghetto culture.
This leaves the actors in a stylistic limbo. The black actors adopt similar masks of stiff upper-class gentility. With the exception of Mr. Travolta, the white actors exude the same attitude of clenched, suppressed bitterness.
The movie's timidity is especially apparent in a scene in which Louis, who is stopped on the street and questioned as a suspected robber, is beaten senseless by black policemen while a small crowd gathers to protest. Both the beating and the reaction to it are so perfunctory and low-key that the movie's caution becomes duplicitous. It wants to portray incendiary events, but in a way that avoids stirring up anger, and that's impossible.
 
 "White Man's Burden" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes some violence and mildly vulgar language.
 
WHITE MAN'S BURDEN
 
Written and directed by Desmond Nakano; director of photography, Willy Kurant; production designer, Naomi Shohan; music by Howard Shore; produced by Lawrence Bender; released by Savoy Pictures. Running time: 96 minutes. This film is rated R.
 
WITH: John Travolta (Louis Pinnock), Harry Belafonte (Thaddeus Thomas), Kelly Lynch (Marsha), Margaret Avery (Megan) and Tom Bower (Stanley).

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Wrong Galleries
The Metropolitan Museum of Art and Chuck Close have collided over a retrospective of Mr. Close's work scheduled for April 1997. Last week, the artist backed out of the show, which had been in the works for two years. The cancellation wipes out the only exhibition of a living artist scheduled at the Met for the rest of the century. 
 The conflict was over where the show would be. Mr. Close said he was promised the B galleries, the skylit spaces at the top of the museum's grand staircase; the Met insists it made no such promise and instead offered the artist the Cantor galleries, where the John Singleton Copley show is and the Velazquez show was. The Cantor galleries are considerably smaller than the B galleries and have no natural light.
"The space wasn't adequate to properly give an overview of my work in all media," Mr. Close said in a telephone interview. "There wouldn't be room for enough large-scale paintings to represent the changes and permutations my work has undergone over the last 30 years. I felt strongly that I wanted to do it right or not at all."
Philippe de Montebello, the Met's director, was out of the country and unreachable, said Harold Holzer, a spokesman for the Met. But Mr. Holzer said: "It is unfortunate that there has been a misunderstanding about the space. And there seems to be no way to adjudicate it." Mr. Holzer added that the galleries Mr. Close wanted for his show had already been committed to "a major medieval show."
The Museum of Modern Art had also offered Mr. Close a retrospective, but he chose the Met. Will the Modern rekindle its interest?
An official at the Modern declined to answer, saying, "It is completely inappropriate for us to comment on another museum's relations to an artist."
Meanwhile, Mr. Close's work is not out of the public eye. Tomorrow, a show of his recent paintings opens at Pace Wildenstein's SoHo gallery at 142 Greene Street. It will be on view until Jan. 6.
 
 
 
Education Building
 The Mortimer D. Sackler Family Foundation has given the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum a gift to establish the Sackler Center for Arts Education and create a related endowment. The museum declined to say how large the donation was, but insiders say they think it was over $5 million. The gift will enable the museum to build an arts education center next to its Frank Lloyd Wright theater, which is being restored with part of a $10 million gift from Peter B. Lewis, a trustee, in October.
"This is an important first step toward establishing an educational endowment for the museum," Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim's director, said. "We established a new education department early this year, and this gift will provide us with a physical location for all our educational activities."
The project includes the construction of classrooms, a multimedia center and conference rooms. It is expected to be open by the fall of 1996.
Downtown, there's news from the Guggenheim's SoHo branch: contrary to what everybody's been saying, the museum is not permanently closing its doors. But in January it will close for two months, during which time some long overdue renovations are to be completed. The Guggenheim's agenda includes opening the building's Mercer Street entrance and improving the gallery space on the first floor. The museum plans to reopen in March with "Jeff Koons: Celebration."
 
 
 
Formaldehyde Artist
 Damien Hirst, the 30-year-old sculptor best known for his shocking pieces with dead animals suspended in formaldehyde, has won this year's Turner Prize. The prestigious $30,970 award was established in 1984 to "promote public discussion of new developments in contemporary British art." It is given annually to a British artist by the Tate Gallery in London. Mr. Hirst, who is prominent among the generation of young artists who have revived the London art world, was short-listed for the prize in 1992, when the surprise winner turned out to be the sculptor Grenville Davey. This year, the sure money was on Mr. Hirst (although the Palestinian sculptor Mona Hatoum was thought to have a good chance with a 12-minute video she made of her body, both inside and out).
 
 
 
Quiet London Sales
 London's important sales of Impressionist and modern art were this week, but neither Sotheby's nor Christie's had the kind of blockbuster paintings each offered in New York in November.
Persuading sellers to put big-ticket works up for sale in London is hard these days. The perception in Europe, and especially in London, is that New York is where all the money is. Sellers with something truly valuable therefore generally insist that their art be sold in New York.
"It's got a lot to do with economics," said Melanie Clore, who heads Sotheby's Impressionist and modern art department in London. "Everyone here believes there's a lot of money in the United States, especially on Wall Street."
Ms. Clore described the sale she put together as of more European taste. "It was sophisticated and less flamboyant," she said. "These are the kinds of sales I like because they bring out the interesting collectors."
But as was true in New York in November, when works were well priced and fresh to the market, there was a lot of competition from bidders all over the world. Both at Sotheby's and Christie's, buyers were split nearly equally between Americans and Europeans. Of the two houses, Sotheby's took in more money. Its sale on Monday evening totaled $26.1 million, above its $24.3 million low estimate. Christie's sale on Tuesday made $20.6 million, below its $24.6 million low estimate.
The star of the sales was Gauguin's "Women at the Edge of the Water" (1892), which was bought at Sotheby's by an unidentified American for nearly $5 million, way above its $2.3 million to $3.1 million estimate.
At Christie's, a 1924 Brancusi, "The Beginning of the World," a bronze in the form of an egg, was one of two casts, and it sold for $1.9 million, slightly above the low estimate. The other was given to the Pompidou Center in Paris by the artist in 1957. While Christie's would not say who bought it, word from experts in London is that the buyer was a European museum.
 
 
 
Paula Cooper to Chelsea
 Paula Cooper has always been a pioneer. In 1968, she opened the first gallery in SoHo. Now she's in the first group of SoHo dealers to relocate to Chelsea. Ms. Cooper just bought a 5,000-square-foot, one-story garage on 21st Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues.
"I'm hoping to be open by fall," she said. "But there's a lot of work to do." Ms. Cooper added that she has grown tired of SoHo. "It's changed so much," she said. "It's just too crowded with dress and furniture shops."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
AIDS After Randy Shilts: Still Blame Enough for All

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

THE GRAVEST SHOW ON EARTH
America in the Age of AIDS
By Elinor Burkett
399 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95
Elinor Burkett's impassioned new book, "The Gravest Show on Earth: America in the Age of AIDS," takes up where Randy Shilts's 1987 study, "And the Band Played On," left off. Mr. Shilts argued that "AIDS did not just happen to America -- it was allowed to happen" by the initial failure of doctors, scientists, government bureaucrats and leaders of gay groups to mobilize "the way they should in a time of threat." 
 Ms. Burkett, a former reporter for The Miami Herald, similarly argues in her book that the AIDS problem has been made worse by human failure: by "politics, greed and utter stupidity" and by society's "failure to treat AIDS as a disease, pure and simple."
"I began to see AIDS as a lens through which the flaws of the nation were magnified," she writes. "It revealed America's need to blame someone rather than to accept tragedy and cope with the truth of our relative powerlessness against nature. It shone a light on Americans' need to define themselves by membership in victim groups, competing for most-victimized status and the financial and psychic benefits that carried. AIDS provided a glimpse of a society more comfortable with fairy-tale villains -- human or viral -- than the reality of sluggish scientific progress and the complex interaction between behavior and infectious agents."
Although Ms. Burkett rehashes the life stories of Kimberly Bergalis, a college student, and the MTV star Pedro Zamora, she devotes relatively little space in this volume to case studies. For the most part, she focuses instead on the politics and economy of AIDS: on the infighting between AIDS action groups, on intramural debates about the direction AIDS research should take and on the cozy relationship between large pharmaceutical companies and Government bureaucrats.
Writing in quick, feisty prose, Ms. Burkett makes her own positions crystal clear, and in some cases they are positions that are bound to provoke heated debate. She accuses both the Christian right and leaders of gay groups of "waging competing jihads," of claiming the moral high ground while "slinging blame and attempting to legislate their own versions of political correctness." She contends that African-American leaders "acted like ostriches" during much of the 80's, instead of working on AIDS prevention and education. And she argues that the AIDS lobby has received "a level of Federal attention, support and services that were the envy of people with cancer, multiple sclerosis and heart disease."
Because AIDS is "the most politicized disease in human history," Ms. Burkett observes, health-care agendas and plain common sense often get caught in the political crossfire. When Dr. Stephen C. Joseph, a former New York City Health Commissioner, announced plans to distribute a million condoms, he was assailed for endorsing promiscuity by a spokesman for John Cardinal O'Connor; and when he suggested implementing some sort of system for partner notification (a standard public health procedure used to help contain tuberculosis, syphilis and hepatitis), he was assailed by people intent on preserving the principle of confidentiality.
A member of the New York State Assembly, Nettie Mayersohn of Queens, Ms. Burkett reports, similarly found herself condemned by both the left and the right when she introduced a bill requiring that all newborn infants be tested for H.I.V. and that all parents of H.I.V.-positive infants be notified of the results. Routine testing of pregnant women for H.I.V., after all, is opposed not only by women's groups like NOW (not to mention most AIDS lobbyists) but also by abortion opponents who worry that infected women might decide to terminate their pregnancies.
As local, state and Federal agencies dispense more and more money to fight the epidemic, political infighting has begun to afflict the very groups organized to help AIDS patients. "States fought with states over who was the hardest hit by the disaster," Ms. Burkett writes. "Cities argued with states over control of the funds. Municipal officials battled community organizations over how to divide up the spoils. Blacks and gays traded charges of homophobia and racism. Amid the court battles and screaming matches, everyone complained that the Federal Government wasn't handing out enough."
Money, in fact, plays a large role in this book, for Ms. Burkett argues that AIDS has become "a multi-billion-dollar growth industry," offering scientists a chance to make their name and drug companies and entrepreneurs an opportunity to make a fortune. This is more than simply a matter of competing for the millions of dollars the Federal Government annually spends for AIDS research; it's also about scientific reports bolstering the stock prices of multinational drug companies, an expanding job market for bereavement counselors and benefits coordinators, and the proliferation of new businesses catering to the needs of the ill and the fears of the healthy.
Condom makers, mail-order drug companies, home health-care services, vitamin and health-food stores have all benefited from the AIDS epidemic, Ms. Burkett says, as have a host of more unsavory enterprises, including trading card manufacturers (selling cards emblazoned with the likenesses of Magic Johnson, Arthur Ashe and Rock Hudson, among others) and plain old charlatans selling phony cures and false hopes.
"Even in the midst of recessions," Ms. Burkett writes, "there are few cutbacks in the industry that is AIDS. No layoffs are expected for those who make their living off the imminent demise of 40 million citizens of the planet."
Although Ms. Burkett writes with enormous energy and genuine outrage on behalf of AIDS patients who have been caught up in the AIDS bureaucracy, she displays a tendency to make broad -- and sometimes distorting -- generalizations that undermine her many valid points. In one chapter, she writes that "shooting galleries had become to black Americans what bathhouses had become to gay Americans."
In another chapter, she suggests that had the AIDS epidemic perhaps surfaced at another time in American history when the country "still maintained its innocence, its belief in its ability to solve all the great problems, the history of the epidemic would have been different," as though the fact that the disease first appeared to be an affliction of gay men did not have something to do with the slow response of mainstream scientists and physicians, as though sheer will and faith could have affected the course of a disease.
In fact, Ms. Burkett's main point in this book remains important: "AIDS is not caused by avarice, indifference, opportunism, careerism or homophobia," she writes. "As best we know, it is caused by a virus (from the Latin for 'poison'), an exquisitely primitive form of life that does not care about politics, money or the Nobel Prize. A virus is programmed to care about only one thing: survival."

HEADLINE: U.S. Reopens Trade Dispute, Saying China Ignores Piracy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Reopening a major trade dispute with China, the United States has told Beijing that it has 90 days to enforce an agreement struck with Washington earlier this year to end the pirating of computer software, music and movies, or once again risk the imposition of large trade sanctions.
The public warning comes after numerous private admonitions during meetings with top Chinese leaders, Clinton Administration officials said. 
 While the renewed threat of sanctions risks a new breach in relations, American trade officials said today that China's continued foot-dragging in closing the 29 factories that churn out millions of illegal copies of American films and software had already cost United States corporations more than $800 million this year. In fact, there is evidence that some factories that halted making illegal copies of compact disks had resumed production, this time producing far more expensive CD-ROM's containing pirated copies of just-released computer software.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said today that while he had been encouraged by China's "spirit of cooperation" on a range of other economic issues, "we will not wait forever as the Chinese Government attempts to implement these agreements."
Mr. Kantor would not elaborate on the kind of action the United States would take unless the accord was enforced. But Mr. Kantor has previously said that Washington had simply "suspended" the imposition of $1 billion in sanctions against Chinese imports that were averted at the last minute by the agreement in February.
That means the Government would not have to go through a lengthy investigation of the harm done to American industry before imposing the 100 percent tariffs on Chinese imports.
The State Department has been laboring for months to rebuild the Administration's rocky diplomatic relations with China. But recently, Washington's growing commercial troubles with China, including a trade deficit that is ballooning to Japan-sized proportions, have become an increasingly hot subject on Capitol Hill, eclipsing in political importance Beijing's continued repression of dissidents. Administration officials are clearly concerned that unless they take a tough line, Republican candidates for President will portray President Clinton's major trade agreements in Asia as hollow victories that have done little to protect American jobs.
As a result, Mr. Clinton's top economic aides have gradually warned China to fulfill its commitments, making clear that the country's admission to the World Trade Organization, which the United States has blocked, depends on it.
The strongest warning came on Wednesday during testimony before a Senate committee, when the deputy United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said that the United States would take "decisive action" if China did not carry out the anti-pirating agreement struck in February.
Ms. Barshefsky's warning drew an immediate response from Beijing. A spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, Shen Guofang, said that any punitive action would be "unacceptable," and would "harm the trade ties between the two countries."
China has taken some steps to comply with parts of the accord. By its own count, it has conducted 3,200 raids on retailers who sell the pirated products on virtually every street corner of Beijing, Shanghai and other major Chinese cities. But the campaign has been akin to arresting drug dealers without touching their suppliers. With a few symbolic exceptions, the offending factories have escaped the attention of the Chinese authorities.
It is widely rumored that some of the authorities or their families hold financial stakes in many of the factories. In other cases, instructions from Beijing to stop the production of pirated goods are ignored by provincial governments.
The piracy issues have been a consistent source of concern to Hollywood, which makes much of its profits on the foreign distribution of films, and to the software industry. In Congress, those complaints have merged with another set of concerns: that China is becoming what many trade experts now refer to as "the next Japan," with a trade deficit to match.
In the first three quarters of the year, according to the most recent Commerce Department figures, the United States imported $33.83 billion in goods from China, but exported only $8.37 billion. The resulting trade deficit, $25.46 billion, is more than half the deficit with Japan for the same period. But Mr. Kantor, who headed President Clinton's election campaign in 1992 and is acutely attuned to the politics of trade issues, has noted several times recently that American exports to China have doubled in the last year, increasing far faster than imports.
"All the changes are in the right direction," he said today. "That doesn't mean we don't have a number of problems; obviously we do."

HEADLINE: Congressional Memo;
2 Sides in Budget Talks Take the Road to Nowhere

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The budget negotiations this week between Congress and the White House were a complete bust.
For three days in a row, lawmakers and Administration officials met around a table in a conference room in the Capitol, closed the doors, accomplished absolutely nothing and came out and accused each other of refusing to negotiate in good faith. Then, on Thursday afternoon, they adjourned until next week. 
 No one savvy about Washington politics was surprised.
Making a budget is not like building a house, where one brick is laid after another until the structure is complete. It is more like the creation of the universe, where one moment there was a mass of swirling gases and then there was a big bang and a Sun and nine planets.
"I told my clients last week not to expect anything the first week but finger pointing," said Stanley E. Collender, director of Federal budget policy at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm.
"It's still too early for anything to happen," Mr. Collender said. "We're two weeks away from Dec. 15 and three weeks from Christmas."
Dec. 15 is the expiration date of the Government's temporary authority to spend money, which was signed last month to end the six-day partial shutdown of the bureaucracy. Unless all 13 appropriation bills are enacted by then, a highly unlikely eventuality, another accord will be needed or the parts of the Government that have not had their spending approved will again have to close down. As matters stand now, that would include agencies like the Department of Health and Human Services, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Veterans Affairs.
Despite the high stakes involved, no politician wants to take responsibility for putting hundreds of thousands of Government workers on furlough the week just before Christmas. That suggests they will be reaching out for an accommodation.
But resolution of the impasse will be impossible until both parties decide that a compromise is in their best interest. So far, neither side has shown the slightest desire to strike a deal on anything but its own terms.
Republicans hold that balancing the budget over the next seven years should be the overriding concern of the Government. The President and his Democratic allies insist that the Republican plan will do irrevocable damage to Medicare, education, the environment and programs for the poor.
The dispute is over two kinds of legislation.
The first kind is the 13 annual spending bills, which provide money for the operations of Government departments and agencies. Only seven of these measures, called appropriation bills, have become law so far.
The second is the omnibus budget bill, known as a reconciliation bill, which is the Republicans' main vehicle for balancing the budget in seven years. It would cut taxes and make big changes in Medicare, Medicaid, welfare, food stamps and other benefit programs. These are called entitlements because money is paid automatically to everyone who meets the eligibility requirements. They are not subject to annual approval by Congress.
President Clinton seems willing to make big concessions on the spending bills. He might have to give up much of what he wants in the areas of education, training and environmental protection, for example. His desire to get through the appropriation process is one explanation of why he allowed the $243 billion military spending bill to become law this week, even though it would allow about $7 billion more to be spent than he and the Pentagon believe is needed.
If these spending measures become law, the Republicans will no longer be able to wield the threat of a Government shutdown. Mr. Clinton could go into legislative hibernation and refuse to deal with the reconciliation bill. Then, taxes and Medicare and all the rest would continue without change.
His problem is that the Republicans are not political patsies. They are insisting that the appropriation bills and the big budget measure be negotiated as one package. "We're not going to buy the car without the windshield and the tires and the bumper," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee.
Speculation abounds over how all this will work out.
Ted Van Dyk, a Washington consultant for businesses and Wall Street concerns, suggested this week in his newsletter that by splitting the difference here and cutting a deal there, a rather painless compromise could be struck.
"This is an 'everyone wins, no one loses' outcome which could get done on the back of an envelope in a few minutes of negotiation," Mr. Van Dyk told his clients. "It would prove to voters that Democrats and Republicans could work together. It would provide a responsible path to a seven-year balanced budget. It would reduce debt, foster economic growth, facilitate lower interest rates and more greatly protect vulnerable Americans."
Maybe so.
But Mr. Van Dyk's prescription may underestimate the bitter feelings that abound. If the negotiators do not hate each other -- and some clearly do -- they absolutely hate what their opponents stand for. And personalities aside, negotiators on both sides find themselves in ideological straitjackets.
Perhaps the climate will improve as the winter solstice approaches. But as of this weekend, the prospects seemed bleak. Even Mr. Van Dyk, more optimistic than most, told his clients that there was a 30 percent chance that the President and Congress would still be at odds over the budget at Christmas.

PRESSURE TO CLOSE CHILD WELFARE CASES
 Even as the death of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo has prompted a new investigation of New York City's Child Welfare Administration, budget cuts appear to be compounding its chronic problems. HEADLINE: Key Bosnia Question: Where Are Exits?

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The Administration has spent a lot of time this week explaining how and why American troops should go to Bosnia, but the question still on many lawmakers' minds is under what conditions the troops will leave.
Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, has lent his support to President Clinton's plan to send troops to Bosnia, even though his main concern is that the Administration has not specified how the United States and its allies will know when their peacekeeping mission has succeeded and what happens if it has not. 
 The reason, Administration officials and Western diplomats say, is that the United States is still struggling to resolve many of the biggest questions about the so-called exit strategy, which depends on a vast civilian effort to rebuild a country torn by over three and a half years of civil war.
In hearings before House and Senate committees this week, President Clinton's senior military and foreign policy advisers insisted that the Administration would bring American troops home in about a year, saying the military could achieve within that time its limited goals of insuring that the combatants pull back from the front lines and that a cease-fire is enforced.
That narrow mission is intended to provide a 12-month breathing space that will enable an array of other organizations to resettle refugees, deliver aid, train new police forces and build the political structure for elections.
The Administration has also promised not to leave until a separate force equips and trains the Bosnian Army to defend itself. But Mr. Dole said today that the Administration's plan to do this is "vague." A resolution that Mr. Dole and Senator John S. McCain, Republican of Arizona, are drafting would require the United States to lead an "immediate" effort to "to provide equipment, arms, training and related logistics assistance of the highest possible quality" to Bosnia.
But the testimony of Defense Secretary William J. Perry, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Gen. John Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, begged the question: Would all the troops come home if the long-term rebuilding goals, outside the military's scope, were failing?
The contrast between the military's precision and the vagueness of the civilian operation was captured in an exchange on Thursday between Mr. Perry and Representative Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican on the House International Relations Committee. Mr. Leach said he was impressed by the peace agreement but skeptical about some of the nonmilitary issues.
"Where there is apparently an exit date," he said, "there has not been a well-articulated exit policy."
Mr. Perry acknowledged that limiting the mission to a year was based on a judgment, not hard facts. "How long that breathing space is necessary, no one can estimate," he said. "A year of breathing space is a pretty good breathing space."
Over the last two days, lawmakers peppered the three Administration officials with a volley of questions that underscored how many important parts of the overall Bosnia mission are still works in progress.
Who will oversee the civilian tasks, like insuring the safety of thousands of returning refugees and rebuilding the shattered Bosnian economy?
Who will arm and train the Bosnian Government if a Balkan arms control policy alone does not level the military playing field before NATO troops withdraw?
How will the United States remain impartial if it helps train the Bosnian Army?
The Pentagon is particularly concerned over the stark asymmetry between NATO's detailed 1,100-page military plan and the parallel civilian program that does not even have a leader or a budget yet.
International relief officials acknowledge that planning for the civilian tasks lags behind the military's forward march into Bosnia, but they promise their efforts will pick up steam in the next week, culminating in a conference in London on Dec. 8. President Clinton will meet with relief and human rights organizations on Monday at the White House to discuss the Bosnia mission.
To distance the new civilian effort from the United Nations operations it succeeds, which many lawmakers have criticized, the United Nations is turning over some of its tasks to other international organizations. For example, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe will assume responsibility for organizing elections in Bosnia.
But dozens of relief agencies have been operating in Bosnia under the United Nations since 1991, and will pick up with the new civilian authority where they left off with the United Nations. "We've been there four years, so to hear that we're not ready is a little bit strange," said Soren Jessen-Petersen, the envoy to the Balkans for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
Caring for and resettling as many as 2.1 million refugees in the former Yugoslavia and another 700,000 people who fled mainly to Europe will be a monumental task.
Refugee officials say that for the first time in four years, winter will be on their side. Most refugees are not expected to travel until the spring thaw, when they will also have a better opportunity to judge if peace is holding.
To insure the safety of refugees and other citizens, the United Nations will lead efforts to bring about 2,000 police monitors and trainers from around the world into Bosnia. But the United Nations learned only last week that it would lead the operation, so many details about which countries will provide the trainers and who will pay for the operation must still be worked out.
Nor is it clear yet which countries or international organizations will pick up the $6 billion tab for the civilian reconstruction effort.
Mr. Christopher said in testimony that the European allies will pay for "most" of the civilian effort. But President Jacques Chirac of France said Washington will pay for one-third, just like the Europeans. Mr. Christopher, however, said the United States will spend $600 million over the next three years, including $200 million this year.
As the civilian effort takes root, the United States has promised to leave only after insuring that the Bosnian Army can defend itself. Under the peace accord, a total arms embargo will continue for three months after the treaty is signed on Dec. 14. A ban on the sale of heavy weapons, including artillery, will continue for six months.
During this six-month period, NATO hopes the Serbs, Croats and Muslims will negotiate fair levels of arms. But most analysts expect that effort to fall short. "It's unquestionable we'll have to provide some equipment to the Bosnian Government," Mr. Christopher said today.
But European leaders strongly oppose arming and training the Bosnian Army, fearing it will trigger a new Balkans arms race. And many lawmakers here fear the United States will lose its neutrality if it helps the Government rearm.
But Mr. Perry said neither NATO nor American troops will be involved. Private contractors would probably train the Government troops, who would then buy Eastern European weapons once the ban was lifted. An international consortium, including the United States and Islamic countries, would pay for the training.

HEADLINE: Pataki Cuts Off Money for Projects Cuomo Approved, Saying They Don't Meet Rules

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The Pataki administration announced today that it has pulled back financing from 177 economic development projects costing $24 million that had been approved under the Cuomo administration.
Several of the projects were favored programs of Democratic legislators. 
 State economic development officials said that the projects were rejected because they did not meet strict new standards drawn up in the last few months for creating jobs and stimulating the economy. They said the organizations and companies on the list could reapply for grants and low-interest loans under the new criteria.
"I insisted on this review," said Charles A. Gargano, the commissioner for economic development. "We wanted to scrutinize projects so they meet the test, so there is no political favoritism involved."
But Democratic legislators said political favoritism was at the heart of Mr. Gargano's selection process. They said that in many cases, projects that were rejected were similar to projects that were financed. They charged that Mr. Gargano's only real criteria was whether the projects were in Republican or Democratic districts.
"With Charlie Gargano at the head, you can't exclude political or fund-raising considerations for their reasons," said Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat. "They have a history of geographical patronage when it comes to jobs."
Mr. Gargano replied, "There's no way they can demonstrate that. We checked and cross-checked that. We were being fair."
Mr. Silver said that 11 of the rejected projects were in the lower Manhattan area that he and Assemblywoman Deborah J. Glick, also a Democrat, represent. Of the 177 rejected projects, 94 were in New York City and were worth $5.4 million.
Today's announcement is the latest salvo in what has been a yearlong battle between the Pataki administration and Assembly Democrats over economic development money. During last year's campaign, Mr. Pataki accused Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of trying to "buy the election" by overspending state economic development money in politically sensitive areas.
In October, Mr. Gargano held a news conference to attack the Cuomo administration for mismanaging economic stimulus programs -- an apparent prelude to today's announcement of cutbacks.
The Democrats in turn have accused Mr. Gargano of holding back grants for Democratic districts. They even threatened to use their subpoena powers to force him to release the list of rejected projects that he made public today.
The money for the development projects was to be used for a variety of purposes, ranging from buying equipment to fixing up storefronts to studying new business ventures.
Mr. Gargano said his agency reviewed more than 300 state-financed projects costing $89 million. Of that total, $38.6 million in projects will still receive grants. The remainder will either be canceled or pushed off into future budget years.
Citing a typical example of a project that was rejected, state officials mentioned the case of a $25,000 plan to study establishing a fish farm in an abandoned reservoir in Brooklyn. "Can you see the marketing: fresh from central Brooklyn?" Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gargano, said.
Other projects were rejected because they never got off the ground or repeatedly misspent their money, she said.
But Assembly Democrats said there was no clear criteria for rejecting some projects. They cited the case of two programs to improve storefronts. One, a $355,000 project for North Amityville in Suffolk County, a largely Republican district, received financing. The second, a $166,000 project for Pitkin Avenue in Brooklyn, an overwhelmingly Democratic area, did not.
"What was their criteria?" said a Democratic official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The 1994 election returns?"

HEADLINE: British Court Supports Bankers Trust in Derivatives Case

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Providing a measure of vindication to the beleaguered Bankers Trust New York Corporation, a British judge yesterday ordered an Indonesian company to pay $69 million it owed the bank from interest rate bets gone awry.
The company, PT Dharmala Sakti Sejahtera, argued that it should not have had to make good on its losses because Bankers Trust did not properly disclose the risk of the transactions. 
 A number of corporations have lost money from speculative transactions with Bankers Trust, most notably the Procter & Gamble Company, which is suing the bank to nullify its $150 million loss. These transactions used instruments known as derivatives, so named because their value is derived from the value of stock, commodity or interest rate markets.
Bankers Trust officials said they were pleased by the 95-page decision handed down yesterday in London and argued that it was a positive precedent.
"This is the first time that a court has had an opportunity to look at both sides of the issues raised in these controversies," Melvin A. Yellin, chief legal officer of Bankers Trust, said. "The Dharmala case and Procter & Gamble case have many issues in common."
Legal experts agreed that the British decision could well influence the case that Proctor & Gamble has brought in a Federal court in Detroit.
"The issue in both cases is to what extent a dealer has a fiduciary duty to make sure that the transactions of its clients are suitable and appropriate," said Henry Hu, a derivatives law professor at the University of Texas. "This will influence judges in the United States, even though it is from a British court, because there is so little precedent in this area."
Moreover, he said, a court in the United States might be reluctant to impose much tougher restrictions than British courts for fear of driving business overseas. London is a center of derivatives activity, and it is easy for international dealers to write contracts -- even with American companies -- so that British law applies, he said.
Working in Procter & Gamble's favor is the fact that the company's case could be heard by a jury, which could be more sympathetic, particularly in light of audiotapes in which Bankers Trust traders, using rude and callous language, discuss how much risk Procter & Gamble had taken on and how much money the traders were earning from the deals.
The court decision does not assure Bankers Trust of reclaiming the $69 million from Dharmala. For one, the Indonesian concern will probably file an appeal in the British courts, Bankers Trust officials said. Moreover, Dharmala has a separate suit in Indonesia to invalidate the bank's claim. And even if Bankers Trust wins all of these cases, derivatives executives say that it may find collecting its debt difficult.
At least half a dozen international banks and brokerage firms have lost money on similar dealings with Indonesian companies, executives said. Like many investors, these Indonesian concerns made speculative bets in 1993 that interest rates would continue to fall. They turned out to be wrong. But many of the Indonesian companies have refused to cover their losses, and the Indonesian courts have not been amenable to the efforts of the banks and brokerage firms to collect, financial executives said.
Dharmala, a conglomerate with interests in farm commodities, electronics and banking, is controlled by Suyanto Gondokusumo, one of a number of ethnic Chinese entrepreneurs working in Indonesia. The company's London lawyers did not return calls seeking comment.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed as Dow Is Up; Technology Issues Weaken

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday, as the blue chips resumed their ascent, while technology issues weakened.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.64 points, to 5,087.13, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 1.61 points, to 606.98. But the Nasdaq composite index, rich in technology stocks, declined 3.89 points, to 1,055.31. 
 Blue-chip stocks were bolstered in part by a rally in the bond market.
"The strong bond market seemed to have a more direct impact on blue chips than on secondary issues," said Ricky Harrington, senior vice president of Interstate/Johnson Lane in Charlotte, N.C. "That makes sense because the blue chips are more conservative stocks."
Bond prices rose after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that manufacturing activity unexpectedly contracted in November for the sixth time in seven months, fueling hopes that interest rates will be reduced soon. The rally drove the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down to 6.08 percent -- its lowest level since Nov. 2, 1993 -- from 6.13 percent on Thursday. The prospect of lower interest rates helps stocks because it means lower borrowing costs for companies.
"The economic data released this week by the Government and private sources showed an economy in which consumer spending is growing moderately -- not too fast, not too slow," said Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company. "There is no inflation threat, no chance of the economy overheating."
Advances far exceeded declines on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,434 to 944. Volume on the Big Board fell to 393.3 million shares, from 440.1 million shares on Thursday.
Financial stocks, the most interest-rate-sensitive group, continued to push ahead. J. P. Morgan increased 1 1/2, to 80; Nationsbank rose 1/4, to 71 3/4; BankAmerica added 1 3/4, to 65 3/8; First Fidelity advanced 1 5/8, to 75, and Wells Fargo climbed 2 3/4, to 213.
Some of the cyclical companies, which perform well when the economy advances, also gained. Du Pont closed at 67 5/8, up 1 1/8; United Technologies ended at a record 95 1/8, up 1 3/8; General Electric closed at 68 5/8, up 1 1/2, and Goodyear finished trading at 42 7/8, up 1/2.
Semiconductor stocks were lower on concerns that consumer purchases of computers would be curbed during the Christmas season. Texas Instruments declined 2 5/8, to 55 1/4, and Micron Technology dropped 2 3/8, to 51 7/8.
Software issues wound up on the down side as well. Microsoft closed at 86 1/4, off 7/8, and Oracle ended at 44 5/8, off 3/4.
But shares of Macromedia surged 16 percent after The Wall Street Journal reported that the company had an edge over its competitors in providing interactive animation for World Wide Web sites. The stock advanced 7 1/4, to 53 3/4.
Magma Copper soared 6 1/4, to 27 5/8, after Broken Hill of Australia said that it would acquire Magma for $28 a share. The American depository receipts of Broken Hill inched up 1/4, to 54 5/8.
Westell Technologies gained 10 1/4, to 23 1/4, on its first day of trading. Another initial public offering, Meta Group, increased 7 1/2, to 25 1/2. And Objective Systems, which also went public and said that Cisco Systems had bought a 4.4 percent stake, surged 22 1/4, to 41 1/4. But Cisco Systems slipped 2 1/8, to 82.
Earlier yesterday, stocks in Japan ended higher. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 88.68 points, or half of 1 percent, at 18,833.10, the index's highest finish since 18,840.22 last Jan. 20. The Nikkei climbed as high as 18,985.85 just before the close.

HEADLINE: Global Warming Trends Should Spur Us to Act, Not Delay

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your otherwise admirable Nov. 28 front-page article on how the United States is failing to meet its stated goal of reducing carbon dioxide emissions to 1990 levels by 2000 downplays the extent of scientific concern about the threats posed by unchecked global warming. 
 You rightly note that "scientists around the world are more convinced than ever" that emissions of greenhouse gases pose a serious threat. But you speak of "scientists' uncertainty about how serious the climate problem is." It would be more accurate to say that scientific uncertainty about how Earth's climate system will respond to increasing emissions of greenhouse gases is itself reason for the most serious concern.
For instance, the atmospheric scientist Wallace Broecker, writing in the November Scientific American, reviews evidence that the climate has been subject to far more rapid shifts than have been thought possible.
These shifts, involving a sudden cooling of Europe's climate, are occasioned by a sudden alteration of Atlantic Ocean currents, which themselves depend on particular patterns of rainfall and salinity.
How ironic it would be if global heating were to lead to catastrophic cold in parts of the Northern Hemisphere, and sundry unpleasant changes elsewhere. Mr. Broecker worries that this could perhaps occur within a century, when our overcrowded planet will be more vulnerable than ever before. "It behooves us," he concludes, to better understand the climate system.
It also behooves us to quit hesitating and change our social and economic behavior in ways that may seem "costly" and "Draconian" (your words) to some. For Earth's climate does not hesitate when making its own costly, Draconian changes.
 
MICHAEL PERLMAN
Williamsburg, Mass., Nov. 28, 1995
 
The writer teaches environmental philosophy at Vermont College.

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Journal;
Gates Goes Public

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
If you're Bill Gates, the wealthiest man in America, you don't have to settle for merely one publicity blitz a year like every other mogul -- you can help yourself to two.
Though it seems like only yesterday that the logo for Windows 95, the latest software product from Microsoft, was as ubiquitous as O. J., now Mr. Gates's face itself is everywhere -- in an Annie Leibovitz photograph on his new book, "The Road Ahead," which is elbowing Colin Powell and Howard Stern out of prime superstore display space, and on "Nightline," "Today" and the David Letterman show, where Mr. Gates, wearing a lab jacket, served as stooge in a sketch about a Rube Goldbergesque "quiz machine." 
 What does Bill Gates want this time? Well, certainly not to make more money; he's giving his royalties away in any event. Is it to transform his image for marketing advantage -- from that of an elusive, nerdy and megalomaniacal tycoon to a chirpy digital evangelist? Maybe a bit. A centerpiece of "The Road Ahead" and its accompanying CD-ROM is a tour of the zillion-dollar manse Mr. Gates is building near Seattle. With its video reproductions of great art and eco-architecture, this narcissistic exercise in Futurama is already as much of a promotional tool for its owner as San Simeon was for Hearst newspapers and the Playboy Mansion was for bunny clubs.
Nonetheless, after reading "The Road Ahead," and hearing Mr. Gates flog it in a 92d Street Y lecture on Monday, I'm inclined to believe he may have written his book for the exact reason he says -- to provoke a national debate about the future.
But is anyone listening?
I wonder. This week the biggest headline in the computer industry was the ascent of a new billionaire, Steven Jobs, whose current venture, Pixar, is now a media obsession to rival Netscape, the creator of the year's previous instant billionaire. Like Mr. Gates's house, such tales of Silicon Valley windfalls are what most seize the popular imagination -- even if many people reading about them know little about what Pixar, Netscape or, for that matter, Microsoft do.
"There isn't anyone here who knows the difference between a computer and a hot tub," said a man to me on Monday night as a group of somebodies gathered for a private reception honoring Mr. Gates before his speech. With the exception of some twentysomethings, he seemed to be right. More people wanted to talk to Mr. Gates about what he calls the "gold rush" atmosphere of his business than about the business itself.
Meanwhile, the technological revolution roars ahead -- personal computer sales have now passed those of TV's, Mr. Gates says -- with social and economic consequences scarcely examined by those Americans who are computer illiterate. "The Road Ahead" tries to get the unwired to join the wired to contemplate the many dislocations sure to occur as the information highway grows from a cliche to reality over the next two decades. Once the country is equipped with high-speed fiber-optic cables, computers will be able to retrieve so many kinds of media so quickly that many present-day trips to the office, library, bank, department store and Blockbuster will become obsolete.
In such a society, Mr. Gates says, there will be less need for cities, less assurance of one's electronic privacy and fewer jobs ("lots of companies will eventually be far smaller"). That society may also compound our current social divisions, given that men, whites, the young and the affluent so far tend to be the information "haves" while women, blacks, the old and the poor are the have-nots.
Bill Gates doesn't offer solutions for these troubling issues. He merely raises them, professes optimism, and invites the rest of us to cope as he returns to making money. Who will lead the debate? Most politicians think about computers only when it's time to grandstand against pornography. Most mass-media reportage on computers is turned over to specialists, whose assignment is to chart the changing fortunes of technology corporations and products rather than look at their long-term impact. Even David Letterman boasted to Mr. Gates this week of how little he knows about computers. If he and the millions of Americans like him were to actually read "The Road Ahead," they would discover that digital ignorance offers no protection from a future that will arrive whether we want it to or not.

HEADLINE: Court Rejects Sculptors' Case

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
Three New York artists seem to have lost their battle to prevent the dismantling and removal of their sculpture from a former Macy's warehouse in Long Island City. Yesterday, in a unanimous decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed a lower court and ruled that the sculpture is not protected by the Visual Artists' Rights Act because it is a work made for hire.
The case is the first legal test of the artists' rights law, which took effect in June 1991. An amendment to Federal copyright law, the act is intended to protect certain categories of visual art commissioned or completed after June 1991 from intentional "distortion, mutilation or other modification" that would harm an artist's honor or reputation and to prevent the destruction of works "of recognized stature." 
 The court ruled on narrow, factual grounds, rather than constitutional questions of artists' rights versus property rights. In a decision written by Judge Richard J. Cardamone, the court found that the three artists, John Carter, John Swing and John Veronis, were employees of the company that held a lease on the warehouse, not independent contractors fulfilling a commission, and that the sculpture is therefore a work made for hire.
The sculpture takes up large portions of the lobby floor, walls and ceiling of a warehouse owned by Helmsley-Spear. Because parts of it are mosaics embedded in the concrete floor, it cannot be dismantled and removed without being at least partly destroyed.
"We felt all along that this is a work-for-hire case that took the matter outside the scope of the Visual Artists' Rights Act," said Adrian Zuckerman, of Davidoff & Malito, which represented Helmsley-Spear.
Mr. Zuckerman declined to comment on what might happen to the sculpture. "My clients are still reviewing the decision," he said.
Daniel H. Weiner of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, which represents the artists, said: "This is a sad day for the artists, and a sad day for art in New York. We will be urging people to get in touch with the Municipal Art Society, which has been conducting tours of the work, so they can see it before Helmsley-Spear swings the wrecking ball."
Mr. Weiner said that he and the artists had not decided whether to appeal the case to the Supreme Court. The case would be extremely difficult to appeal, he said, because yesterday's ruling dealt with specific facts rather than constitutional issues.
"It's sad, almost as though a family member has died," Mr. Carter said. "Either the law or the process turns out to be very weak, since it wouldn't have protected the Sistine Chapel. You have to wonder what is being protected."
In the summer of 1994, Richard A. Altman, representing the artists, argued in Federal District Court in Manhattan that the untitled work met the definition of an artwork of stature and that the artists, because they had artistic control over the work and used their own materials and tools, were not employees.
Under the artists' rights law, he said, the work could not be removed or altered by Helmsley-Spear during the lifetime of any of the three artists. On Aug. 31, 1994, Judge David N. Edelstein ruled in favor of the artists. Mr. Altman ceased representing the artists soon after the trial, when he and they disagreed about legal tactics.
The Appeals Court, in its decision, pointed out that the artists received a weekly salary, took paid vacations, had payroll taxes and Social Security withheld and carried out additional projects elsewhere in the building at the request of the leaseholder. Two of the artists, after the project was halted by Helmsley-Spear in May 1994, filed for unemployment insurance. The court ruled that these circumstances added up to an employer-employee relationship.
The court sidestepped an additional argument by Mr. Altman that the artists could not be employees because the leaseholder, in a written agreement, granted them the copyright to their work. Judge Cardamone wrote that the court was uncertain on this point, and that any decision on the argument would have to be "put off for another day."
Mr. Altman said that he found the court vague on this point. "There is something very wrong here," he said. "If this is your artwork and you have the copyright, how can I have the right to destroy it? It creates the weird situation in which the artist has the copyright but the copyright is worthless, because it doesn't protect the artwork from being destroyed."

HEADLINE: Rally Takes Long Bond's Yield to 2-Year Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday for the third consecutive session as expectations grew that the Federal Reserve would soon reduce short-term interest rates. The current rally has lowered the yield of the 30-year bond to a two-year low.
Among the factors behind yesterday's spurt of buying was a report of weak manufacturing activity last month, released by the National Association of Purchasing Management, and comments by a Federal Reserve official who sees the economy slowing. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 12/32 , to 11019/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.08 percent, from 6.13 percent on Thursday. The yield is at its lowest since Nov. 2, 1993, when it was 6.05 percent.
Prices were firm before the purchasing management group released its monthly report. The group's index fell to 46.5 in November, from 46.8 in October, with the employment component down for the ninth consecutive month.
The weaker manufacturing number was expected, and analysts said it pointed to a slowdown in the industrial economy.
The main message of the report, said Bruce Steinberg, manager of macroeconomic analysis at Merrill Lynch & Company, "is that the industrial sector is not going anywhere fast and that inflation pressures continue to abate."
"This is another in a string of economic reports suggesting that interest rates should decline further," he said.
The market's view of a slowing economy was bolstered by comments late Thursday by the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, Robert T. Parry.
After speaking before executives in San Francisco, Mr. Parry told reporters that the growth rate of gross domestic product for the fourth quarter would be "significantly below" the rate of the third quarter.
His comments were interpreted to mean that the Fed saw room to cut short-term interest rates, even though Mr. Parry is not a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's rate-setting panel. The committee next meets on Dec. 19.
Mr. Parry's comments came on the heels of statements by the vice chairman of the Fed, Alan S. Blinder. Mr. Blinder told the Market News Service on Thursday that the central bank had a "window of opportunity" to cut rates now to head off an economic decline in 1997.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, said the market was getting somewhat ahead of itself after a string of reports showing a slowing economy and moderate inflation.
"There are signs of weakness in the economy," Mr. Donne said. "I think the two issues facing the market are: one, how or will those be corroborated with the employment numbers next week, and secondly, and more significantly, are we going to get a real budget-deficit-reduction program or a lot of quilt patchwork?"

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls vs. Mark and Yen, But Gains on Franc and Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar retreated against the German mark and Japanese yen yesterday but strengthened vs. other European currencies in slow foreign-exchange dealings.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 101.25 Japanese yen, down from 102.15 on Thursday, and at 1.4460 German marks, down from 1.4470. 
 For the week, the dollar was up more than 2.5 pfennigs against the mark and lost only 0.16 yen against the yen.
The prospect of a drop in interest rates in Britain helped the dollar against the pound. In New York, the pound fell to $1.5310 from $1.5325.
A selloff in French francs and purchase of marks in Europe helped the dollar against the franc. France has been partly paralyzed by the worst strikes in a decade. The dollar rose to 4.9981 French francs, from 4.9970 francs on Thursday.
"The market is quite bearish on the French franc," said Laura Jean McCarthy, a senior trader at the New York branch of the Union Bank of Switzerland. "You always get a sale like that when you get turmoil."
The dollar retained most of the gains it accrued during the week, when traders were buying the currency in anticipation of a German interest rate cut that could have diminished the value of the mark. The dollar held those gains even when Germany's central bank left rates unchanged on Thursday.
"In general the dollar is holding up very well," said Al Pugliesi, a trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer & Company. "That maybe shows the market is looking at the dollar in a different way as we get toward the end of the year."
Demand for dollars usually rises as the year draws to a close, partly because many American multinationals repatriate profits and exchange local currencies for dollars. The dollar's allure has also been enhanced by strength in the United States stock and bond markets, which raises demand for the currency needed to buy them.
Traders said the dollar initially weakened in early trading in New York after the National Association of Purchasing Management's widely followed monthly survey showed American manufacturing slowed for the fourth consecutive month in November to its lowest rate since June.
The retreat was unexpectedly sharp, suggesting that it could prompt the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to stimulate growth. Lower rates tend to diminish a currency's value.
