LENGTH: 2137 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Dysfunction Wears Out Its Welcome

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES 

 BODY:
JUST LIKE JUNE CLEAVER OR Jim Anderson, today's sitcom moms and dads know what's best for their families. Of course, they may not know where their families came from. John Hemingway, the hero of "The John Larroquette Show," is a recovering alcoholic who has a teen-age son he abandoned as a baby and a grown daughter (by a different mother) who he didn't know existed until last year. The children know nothing about each other, so one day Tony asks Rachel out for coffee and Dad exclaims in sitcom horror, "Oh, my God, my son has a date -- with my daughter!" Sure, the old son-dating-daughter gag; that was always the part where Danny Thomas would spit out his coffee, right?
Meanwhile, behind the white picket fences of "Roseanne" and "Grace Under Fire" live two of the most popular families on television, reflecting what the typical American household is all about: alcoholism, spousal abuse, unemployment, abortion, abandoned children, children put up for adoption, drug abuse, impotence, clinical depression, infidelity, divorce and single parenthood. And that's just in the family, never mind the neighbors. There is something strange going on when the Simpsons are the best-adjusted family around. 
 In their quest to be realistic and relevant, family sitcoms have piled on the social issues, from everyday problems like day care to serious disorders like physical violence. Any one or two or even three of these issues might concern an average family; all of them at once might strike Job.
Lisa Simpson, the smart middle child of the cartoon family, defined the situation best when her long-lost grandmother reappeared two weeks ago. As a boy, Homer Simpson had been told his mother was dead; it turned out she was merely on the run from the F.B.I. "This is so weird," Lisa said. "It's like something out of Dickens. Or 'Melrose Place.' " As sitcoms approach dysfunction overload, they have come to resemble melodrama and soap opera more than they reflect comic versions of real life.
These warped-family sitcoms have created a dark mirror of the classic good-family series of 30 years ago, and they may be nearing the end of a cycle. Both trends began with a genuine connection to reality, then wildly exaggerated it. It was true that in the 50's and early 60's, the norm was a two-parent household like the Cleavers', in which the father went to the office and the mother stayed home. Television took those facts and went crazy, to the point where Beaver's mom is now famous for dusting while wearing high heels, a full skirt and pearls.
The Cleavers of "Leave It to Beaver" and the Nelsons of "The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet" (Was there ever a less adventurous household? The boys didn't leave home till they were 30) eventually overdosed on sweetness and clean living. They were swept away partly by old age and partly by the social changes of the mid-60's, but they also imploded on the strength of their own unbelievable goodness.
Similarly, sitcoms from the late 80's and early 90's began with the fact that there were many single-parent households (a third of all families with children, by a recent census count) and a greater, healthier awareness of social and psychological disorders. As they have developed, though, shows like "Roseanne" and "Grace Under Fire" can hardly bear the weight of their characters' troubles. The series present these families as typical, and the shows win praise for their supposed realism. But as their problems pile up, these proud-to-be dysfunctional families seem ever less attached to reality.
When "Roseanne" first appeared in 1988, the Conners were refreshingly realistic; the two working parents worried about money, and everyone yelled all the time. With its loud, crass, blue-collar chic, the show was the television daughter of "All in the Family." More important, Roseanne rode into town as the anti-Cosby. The Conners were the rejoinder to the well-bred, well-educated, upwardly mobile Huxtables of "The Cosby Show," which then ruled sitcom land.
"Roseanne" deserved praise for tackling touchy issues like abortion and for avoiding the moralistic posture that presents sitcom families as flawless role models. But seven years involves a lot of plots, and the once-ordinary Conner family has become more socially troubled than all the characters on "E.R" and "N.Y.P.D. Blue" put together.
IN THE LAST FEW SEASONS ALONE, Roseanne's mother was arrested for driving while drunk and sent to Alcoholics Anonymous, and Roseanne's sister, Jackie, lived with a man who beat her, then left him, quickly got pregnant by a man she hardly knew, had the baby and married the child's father. And last year, Roseanne's grandmother turned up at Thanksgiving dinner with a new husband and revealed that she had had two illegal abortions when she was young. "Gee, I wonder who told the abortion stories at the very first Thanksgiving," Roseanne said with a redeeming, acerbic twist increasingly rare for her. (Roseanne has said this season will be the show's last, probably a good move.)
"Grace Under Fire," with Brett Butler as a working-class mother, began two years ago with Grace, a recovering alcoholic, just divorced from an alcoholic who beat her. Last season, a son she had given up for adoption 19 years before re-entered her life. This season she has been dating her boss, and recently she was taken hostage at gunpoint by a former co-worker laid off from the oil refinery where she works. Where can she go from here?
Not every popular show relies on social tragedy. "Home Improvement," one of the top sitcoms, is in the "Cosby" mold. When one adolescent son steals a tool from a hardware store (that's as hairy as the show usually gets), he learns his lesson by the end of the half-hour.
And there is no correlation between the level of dysfunction and the comic strengths of a series. "Larroquette" has weaker writing than "Grace" and "Roseanne," and lower ratings to match. In general, the shows work best when they assume a leavening attitude toward weighty problems. When Grace is annoyed at her newly found son, Matthew, she tells him, "If I wanted you to grow up to be an idiot, I would have raised you myself."
But there is a definite connection between dysfunction overload and the characters' social class. The working class is the setting for most of the serious social problems in comedies. John Hemingway manages a bus station; Roseanne, having worked in a factory and then at a restaurant, now owns part of a diner; Grace Kelly (her name is one of the show's first jokes) was recently demoted because of cutbacks at the oil refinery.
There is an upper-middle-class version of sitcom dysfunction, too. It probably started with "Murphy Brown." At the start of the series seven years ago, Candice Bergen's wealthy journalist character was just out of the Betty Ford clinic. The show's most famous and best plot, of course, was a perfect example of a sitcom reflecting not dysfunction but a new social reality. Murphy accidentally got pregnant, decided to have the child on her own and, in a happy ending, told Dan Quayle where to get off.
Life is more dysfunctional on "Cybill," in which Cybill Shepherd plays an actress with two ex-husbands. This season, her first husband's second ex-wife was impregnated with his frozen sperm, without his knowledge (the setup for a maladjusted spinoff?). Cybill's best friend, Maryann, is perpetually and agreeably drunk, and eagerly planning revenge on her cheating former husband.
All these people can afford therapy. The hero of "Frasier," of course, has a broken marriage, a snappish but improving relationship with his father, and an about-to-be-divorced brother, Niles, who lusts after the housekeeper. In fact, both Frasier and his brother are psychiatrists. Therapy doesn't do them much good, but then it's not really meant to. Dysfunction seems more innocuous in this comfortable economic sphere, where the characters and the writing are far more sophisticated than in the blue-collar-chic series.
The working class heroes face their problems with Oprah-like intensity; the world-weary characters of "Cybill" and "Frasier" tacitly assume that dysfunction is here to stay, providing fodder for pithy one-liners. When Niles substitutes on Frasier's radio call-in show, he announces that he is a Jungian, Frasier a Freudian and "there will be no blaming Mother today."
It is fair, though, to attribute much of television's dysfunction overload to the genre's founder and matriarch, Roseanne herself, whose off-screen behavior makes the Conners' problems seem petty. Behind the scenes, "Roseanne" has been known from the start for its periodic turbulence, with firings, star behavior and family feuds a way of life. As recently as a month ago, both Roseanne and her co-star, John Goodman, threatened to walk off the show.
And when Roseanne discusses her real life, it sounds like a catalogue of social problems. She has said that she was abused by her parents and has multiple personalities. She had a child she gave up for adoption and is on her third marriage.
Roseanne's success has been extraordinary, and so have her personal misfortunes. One thing she has never been is average. Yet she still holds herself up as the most ordinary of role models. Take a look at this season's opening credits for "Roseanne," which morph all the characters to show how they've changed from the show's first years to the present. Roseanne's transformation is the most chilling case of excessive plastic surgery since Michael Jackson. This is the typical mom, working-class and addicted to expensive cosmetic surgery?
The fact that sitcoms these days sometimes mirror the stars' real lives doesn't necessarily make the fiction more believable. Brett Butler has talked about her own abusive situation, but that doesn't make Grace seem typical. When she tells Matthew, now a college student, about her hard-luck past, he says, "You've gone through what people I know only read about." That is meant to be a comment about class; it accidentally calls attention to the melodramatic aspect of one person having such a load of problems.
WHAT'S ESPECIALLY Eerie about such major family maladjustment is the way television helps shape reality. In the vicious circle that flows between television and society, a show takes that kernel of real life, exaggerates it, then beams it back in its most outrageous form, still posing as ordinary. Experience to the contrary, viewers may begin to wonder if what they are watching is normal everywhere else in the country. The most powerful subterranean message sent by television, after all, is: if it's on TV, it must be true.
There may be a hint that this dysfunctional cycle is ending with shows like "Cybill." Beyond the class difference, that series is so jokingly aware of its characters' maladjustments that it gives a new twist to the genre -- just the way that "The Brady Bunch," when it came along in 1969, was a semi-parody of the Cleavers and of the Andersons on "Father Knows Best."
Oddly, the shows that seem to have the most outrageous families, "Married . . . With Children" and "The Simpsons," are the least involved in dysfunction overload because they were designed as caricatures to begin with. When Al Bundy on "Married . . . With Children" walks into his living room singing a theme from his favorite television show, "Psychodad," he's already far from reality.
And "The Simpsons" has managed to maintain its status as one of the funniest shows on the air, offering a satiric version of the typically dysfunctional sitcom family. Recently, child-welfare authorities temporarily took the children away from Marge and Homer. (It was all a misunderstanding: Bart got lice when a monkey sat on his head.) The kids were sent to stay with their holier-than-thou neighbors, the Flanderses, a fate worse than anything in Dickens. "It seems like our house, but everything has this creepy, Pat Boone-ish quality about it," says Lisa, suspiciously looking around a household where, Ned Flanders admits, "My Three Sons" is too strong for his children to watch before bedtime.
Compare this clever "Simpsons" episode with "That's Our Rosey!," the recent "Roseanne" parody of 50's sitcoms, and the difference between a knowing satire and a self-congratulatory message becomes obvious. "Roseanne" turned its parody into a heavy-handed statement about women, with Rosey, in pearls and a lacy apron, remarking that it would be so silly to try to have a job and a family at the same time.
The Simpsons were once actually tossed out of family therapy, with double their money back. "The sad truth is," said that model of satiric wit Lisa Simpson, "all families are like us." The earnest, dysfunctional sitcoms would have us believe this is true.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 47; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1388 words

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
All-Conquering Hungarians, Empire or No

BYLINE: By Vicki Goldberg 

 BODY:
Hungarian culture is best known for music -- Franz Liszt, of course, and Bela Bartok and Zoltan Kodaly -- but it spawned an even greater number of important and influential photographers. Photography between the two world wars would be sorely diminished without the Hungarians. Significantly, those who became best known emigrated, and then they conquered the world.
Brassai went to Paris and pictured its demimonde as more vivid, more complex, more quintessentially French than anyone had since Toulouse-Lautrec. Martin Munkasci, a sports photographer and photojournalist, came to America in the early 1930's and transformed fashion photography with an injection of natural movement. Andre Kertesz moved to Paris and then New York, transplanting to America a European appreciation of split seconds, incongruities and spatial surprises. 
 In Berlin in the 20's, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy helped fashion the Bauhaus curriculum; then, when the Nazis closed the Bauhaus, he transported its credo to Chicago. Robert Capa's pictures of war in Spain and China earned him the accolade "greatest war photographer in the world." His younger brother, Cornell, founded the International Center of Photography in New York.
How could so much much talent emerge from so small a place? Why did they all leave, and what happened when they did? "The Hungarian Circle," an exhibition of 49 images taken between the wars, plus an anonymous album of collages, at the Howard Greenberg Gallery and Gallery 292 in SoHo through Dec. 30, offers a preliminary answer to the question of what happened back in Hungary. A catalogue essay by Michael Simon, a scholar of Hungarian photography, hints that there were national and economic reasons for the richness of that country's photography and the fact that its prodigal sons left home.
A few of the prints are by names like Kertesz and Moholy, but even scholars will not recognize most of these photographers, which says something about the study of Eastern Europe. Many members of "The Hungarian Circle" traveled and worked throughout Europe and were well known in their time. Though this show is not likely to change photographic history in any substantial way, it does suggest that rather than wasting away in the 20's and 30's when its great men left, photography in Hungary flourished on home soil.
Three styles, sometimes overlapping, mark the territory: a kind of picturesque-romantic look at native villages; an elegant late Pictorialism (the soft-focus style that originated around the turn of the century) and the international modernist style that is the period's signature. Many of the stay-at-homes were apparently committed to the first of these, a lovely but occasionally tedious and sentimental view of village and peasant life, pictures that ricochet between real charm and the Hallmark card variety.
Kertesz in his early years was indebted to this concentration on unspoiled villages, peasants (either quaint or dignified) and peaceful, rural landscapes. Karoly Escher and Kalman Boronkay both knew how to find quietly effective moments in this genre. It was, in fact, a style consciously adopted in the second decade of the century by a country bent on finding its true national character in the people and landscapes regarded as most purely Hungarian.
The defeat of the Austro-Hungarian Empire in World War I left Hungary shriveled, split up and decimated: its population had fallen from almost 21 million people to 7.5 million, and its territory had shrunk from 125,000 square miles to 36,000. The country was united, however, in its yearning to restore some pride in Hungarian identity and some part of its former glory. Thus the ethnographic romanticism in these photographs was not merely an esthetic choice but the expression of an idealized and wishful nationalism.
Severe political and economic tensions drove away those who became so famous elsewhere. A revolt shortly after the end of the war brought in a republic, which was soon displaced by a Communist dictatorship; that, too, was overthrown by a second revolution. The economy was a shambles and employment a mirage. After a few months, the second revolution failed, and the right-wing Adm. Miklos Horthy stepped in as regent; he lasted 25 years.
Eager to revive the lost sense of empire, the admiral suppressed all manner of criticism. Moholy, a left winger, emigrated first. Others followed, in search of work and artistic freedom. When the economy improved in the mid-20's, art grew temporarily freer, but those who practiced social commentary and montage were often under threat of arrest, and the police got on-the-job training closing art exhibitions. The album of inventive and lively collages in "The Hungarian Circle" was apparently never exhibited, possibly because some of the subjects are so overtly political. Economics and politics change the map of culture as surely as they change the outlines of history.
It is not surprising that a Pictorialist strain continued to thrive in Hungary through the 30's. Though such work was snubbed by the early historians of photography, who tended to be adherents of sharp-focus modernism, Pictorialism was a style with staying power; it can be found almost everywhere before World War II. A photographer like Emery Revesz-Biro in Hungary preserved the warm and beautiful print techniques that earlier photographers had favored. Pictorialism was already a conservative approach by the second decade of the century, but conservatives are notoriously stubborn and hang on.
In 1927, a large international exposition introduced the Hungarian photographic community to the hard-focus dispassion of the German "new objectivity." And though many continued on the path they were on, some were subsequently poised between the Old World and the New. Pal Funk Angelo shrouded the diagonal geometries of the industrial environment in a photographic fog thicker than London pea soup. Imre Kinszki turned a view of city houses into an unusual combination of romantic nocturne and architectural cubism.
Sharply focused modernism, bold in form and semi-abstract, also made a strong showing within Hungary's borders. The style was truly international, its spread insured by the rapid growth of photographically illustrated journals and travel. Kinszki transformed a stairway and the shadows of its railing into vertical, paper-thin planes written over by pattern. Olga Mate's tilted image of a dock and its reflections in the water becomes a kind of Mondrian with intimations of depth.
So, when the photographic pioneers moved to new frontiers, those left behind polished their lenses and wielded an influence of their own at home and abroad. The mystery is not so much why that was as why this small country produced such a wealth of fine photographers. (It might be noted that about the same time, Hungary reaped a brilliant crop of scientists -- the physicist Leo Szilard, the nuclear physicist Edward Teller, the mathematician John von Neumann and two Nobel laureates, the biochemist Albert Szent-Gyorgyi and the physicist Eugene Wigner. Some of the most famous also emigrated.)
The catalogue essay notes that at the turn of the century the country enjoyed great affluence, the middle class expended effort and money on educating its children, and photography was a popular activity for aristocrat and bourgeois alike. In fact, Hungary was exceptionally hospitable to photography during the first two decades.
IN 1908, A NATIONAL EXHIBITION OF scientific and artistic photography that occupied 15 halls was opened by the Grand Duke and Duchess in the company of several cabinet ministers. (Think of Alfred Stieglitz's struggle to get a museum to exhibit a photograph or two in America at this time.) During World War I, one Hungarian paper ran four photographic competitions for soldiers at the front; the pictures were so exceptional that they were published in journals across Europe.
Combine this sense of status with the nationalistic pride coded in so many photographs, plus whatever trick of fate favored Hungary with a particular talent -- perhaps some whimsical god, knowing no one could speak their language, decided that Hungarians deserved a vision -- and you get a Kertesz, a Moholy, a Brassai and a second rank that need not hang its head.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Imre Kinszki's "In Moonlight," 1930, above; Andre Kertesz's "Hungarian Village," 1915, left, and Olga Mate's "Fisherman's Dock," 1930, below--A national style of photography that had a truly international impact. (Howard Greenberg Gallery)

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
TWO RUSSIAN AIRLINES TO BEGIN U.S. SERVICE

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
FOR Americans wanting to fly directly to Moscow from anywhere but New York, which is served by Delta, there has been only Aeroflot-Russian International Airlines to consider.
Soon, however, it will be possible to fly directly from Chicago or Los Angeles to Moscow (and back) on two Russian airlines that have just received approval to fly in the United States. 
 Based in Krasnoyarsk, Siberia, Krasair, a semiprivatized offshoot of the old Aeroflot regional system, was scheduled to begin the Moscow-Los Angeles route (and twice a week from Moscow to New York) last week. Krasair flies two McDonnell Douglas DC-10's with 40 seats in business class and 243 in economy.
The other airline, Transaero, is one of the great aviation successes in the new Russia, providing Western-style service on Western-style planes within the former Soviet Union and building an enviable reputation compared with domestic Aeroflot. Transaero flies to international destinations like London and Tel Aviv, and beginning in June it will fly the Chicago-Moscow route three times a week with a Boeing 767.
Both airlines say that their prices will becompetitive, and that their real price competition will be with international Aeroflot, which is normally the cheapest way to fly between the two countries. The airlines have spotless safety records, at least so far.
Krasair is 51 percent owned by the Russian Government, while 44 percent is owned by its employees, with the rest belonging to two Russian investment companies, according to its marketing director, Andrei U. Yegorov. Its pilots have been trained by Douglas Aircraft Company and its service staff by British Airways, which sent representatives to Krasnoyarsk to train Russian crew. Its food will come from Western companies. This is a big departure for Krasair, a large regional Siberian airline that flies to some 50 cities within the former Soviet Union, Mr. Yegorov said, and can provide reasonably convenient connections for Americans traveling onward from Moscow, especially into Siberia, but the service is likely to be different domestically.
Transaero was started in 1990 with $5,000 by Aleksandr Pleshakov, now only 30, whose mother happened to be the head of the Inter-State Aviation Committee, a job she retains. Russians and foreigners here can only be grateful. Mr. Pleshakov refused to hire any Aeroflot employees. He leased Boeing airplanes, put an Israeli company in charge of servicing and had Air France train his staff. Now Transaero trains the staff of other airlines and has introduced a frequent-flier program.
Transaero also provides a good, reasonably priced service from Moscow to other international destinations, including London, Berlin, Frankfurt, Tel Aviv and Eilat, important cities for Russia's businessmen and burgeoning middle class.
And Transaero is without question the carrier of choice for internal flights to long-distance destinations in Siberia, the Far North and the Far East, like Vladivostok, Norilsk, Nizhnevartovsk and Novosibirsk; the Urals, like Yekaterinburg; the Black Sea, like Sochi, and major cities of the newly independent states of the former Soviet Union, including Tashkent, Uzbekistan; Almaty, Kazakhstan; Kiev and Odessa, in Ukraine; and Riga, Latvia. It also flies to St. Petersburg, which is a short flight on a route served by another good carrier, an Aeroflot offshoot called Pulkovo.
Domestic Aeroflot, which has been broken up into many companies, some good and some not, preserves the old idea of a "trolleybus of the air." One class fits all. Seats are often dirty or broken; leg room is a cruel joke; seat belts are often missing; life preservers are nearly always missing (though many flights are only over land), and service is grudging, sparse and truculent. After providing mineral water of questionable quality in unsanitary plastic cups, flight attendants normally disappear until it's time to roll a cart down the aisles in an effort to sell passengers newspapers, beer, soft drinks, candy and pistachios.
On long flights, one may be fortunate enough to miss the infamous scrawny, pale "Aeroflot chicken." The same plastic cups that contained the mineral water then appear with lukewarm water, in which one may float a harsh tea bag.
Transaero, which does not always get the best takeoff times in what was once an Aeroflot monopoly, does provide adequate food and Western-style service to go with its Western planes. Normally, there is a business class. On flying Transaero for the first time, most Russians are left speechless when a pleasant voice on the working loudspeaker system thanks them for choosing to fly Transaero and wishes them a comfortable flight.
Krasair information in New York, (212) 290-3300.
Transaero information in New York, (212) 582-0505; in Chicago, (312) 917-3200.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Its Name Restored, a Hotel Rides the Tourism Wave

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
TIME seems to bring change to hotels more regularly than to most forms of commercial property. To maintain quality, renovation work has to be undertaken constantly. But the ownership of the property, and the character of its use, often changes as well.
In the case of what is now formally known as the Hotel Pennsylvania, in Manhattan, the changes extend also to the name. It was built in 1919 as the Hotel Pennsylvania by the Pennsylvania Railroad, whose late-lamented station faced it across Seventh Avenue between 32d and 33d Streets. It became the Statler in 1949 when the Statler Company bought it. Five years later, Conrad Hilton bought all 17 Statler hotels, and renamed it the Statler Hilton. 
 In 1984 it became the New York Penta Hotel when Penta Hotels, run by a consortium of European airlines, became the operating partner in the ownership group, Ascot Associates, headed by Abraham Hirschfeld, the real-estate investor and sometime mayoral candidate. Penta completed a $35 million renovation program, but Mr. Hirschfeld said he acquired Penta's interest in 1991 when the hotel was operating at a loss.
Then Hampton Hotels Corporation, headed by Simon Elias, a 38-year-old Israeli investor, and Mary Diem, an experienced hotel manager, took over as manager. The debt was restructured and a long-term $15 million upgrading begun. Hampton became the operating partner two years ago.
The Pennslyvania's saga shows how hotel properties change their character in different times under different management, and also how the city's tourist hotels are benefiting at present from the increase in foreign travelers seeking moderate-priced rooms in New York City. Many of these hotels are currently charging individual travelers $90 to $130 a night, hotel consultants say. Tour groups, or airlines that book rooms wholesale for their crews, usually pay about 30 percent below that.
As the Penta, the hotel had aspired to the deluxe category of hotels, an attempt that failed there and elsewhere in the recession of the late 80's and early 90's. It is reasserting itself at a time when tourist hotels in general are enjoying their best year of the 90's. It The Pennsylvania has 1,705 rooms, making it the third largest in the city after the New York Hilton (2,041 rooms) and the Sheraton New York (1,746 rooms).
Hotels are benefiting from an upsurge in foreign travelers to New York City, particularly, this year, from Latin America, and also from the fact that the commercial-oriented hotels have cut back on discounted rates aimed at economy-minded tour groups. The discount to tour groups is said to have declined in the last year or so.
"The first-class commercial hotels no longer have to concentrate on the tour and travel and contract segments of the market, like the airlines, which get significant discounts," said Frank Dougherty, a consultant with Hospitality Valuation Services in Mineola, L.I. That has tightened the market for tour groups.
Citywide, occupancy has been rising gradually since its low of 67.6 percent in 1991, according to PKF Consulting, in Manhattan. The firm projects 1995 occupancy at 76.5 percent, the highest since 1988. In October, occupancy reached 91.9 percent, the highest figure for a single month since October 1979, said John A. Fox, senior vice president.
The improved occupancy has led to new investment at a number of hotels, including the Roosevelt, on Madison Avenue between 45th and 46th Streets. Its owner, PIA Investments Ltd., an arm of Pakistan International Airline, closed the 1,070-room hotel in July and launched a $55 million reconstruction. It will be completed in 1997 but a partial reopening is scheduled for next June. Its name will be the Radisson Roosevelt.
 ANOTHER large hotel headed for a major renovation is the 654-room Doral Inn, on Lexington Avenue and 49th Street, where Starwood Lodging Trust, a real estate investment trust that focuses on hotels, took a long-term lease in September from Carol Management, parent company of Doral Hotels and Resorts, the operator. The hotel is planning a renovation that will cost $10 million to $15 million, said Bruce Blum, chief executive of Doral Hotels.
And at the Milford Plaza, on Eighth Avenue between 44th and 45th Streets, the general manager, Russ Smith, said the hotel would finish the year with an occupancy figure of 84 percent, "better than we've ever done since we opened in 1980." Business from Latin America -- Argentina and Brazil, in particular -- has picked up tremendously, he said. The Milford Plaza has 1,300 rooms.
The Pennsylvania story is one of slow recovery from deep trouble. The Penta, not alone among hotel operators in the West 30's during the mid-80's, tried to make the location a destination for corporate travelers. Once Penta withdrew, the leaderless hotel experienced a deep drop in tour bookings.
It's a big building: 1.5 million gross square feet of space on 20 floors, including 300,000 square feet of commercial space and 70,000 square feet of banquet and ballroom space. The Diem-Elias partnership brought in The Sports Authority as a 50,000-square-foot tenant on the second floor and MTI Studios, which leases out space for television productions, 60,000 square feet mainly at the mezzanine level.
A week ago Ms. Diem (pronounced DEEM), the hotel's manager, was elated to report that a month earlier she was able to buy 800 rooms of furniture from the Palace Hotel, on Madison Avenue between 50th and 51st Streets, which is undergoing a top-to-bottom redecoration itself. The furniture will be used in 1,000 rooms at the Pennsylvania, where most rooms are 14 by 16 feet or 12 by 20 feet.
The total number of rooms is also a building characteristic that changes over the years in hotels. The Pennsylvania was designed by McKim Mead & White with 2,200 guest rooms, more than any other Manhattan hotel at the time. Over the years more space has gone into nonresidential use, and some rooms have been enlarged, to bring the current count to 1,705.
 UNDER the new management, the decor has become less contemporary and more traditional, Ms. Diem said. New carpeting has been installed on most hallways, which are 10 feet wide and run the length of four bowling lanes from Seventh Avenue toward Avenue of the Americas.
"We've redone 13 floors over four years," said Ms. Diem, "mostly using the cash flow from the building. We've got three floors left to go, and one will be finished in December."
The renovation has made the Pennsylvania competitive again for the tour-and-travel groups and the airline-crew business. Ms. Diem said that an average of 500 rooms a night are leased to airline crews and 400 to travel groups. The rest of the rooms are leased at "rack" rates to the public at prices that change according to occupancy conditions. The typical rate is $109 for a single and $129 for a double.
What has helped most of all at the Pennsylvania and other moderate-priced hotels is the pick-up in foreign tourism. The beneficiaries are also the tour operators.
"Our business grew 50 percent this year," said Carlos Lahuerta, who runs American Way Tours, which books tours mainly from Spain, Portugal, Italy and South America. Forty percent of the growth was from Brazil, largely because the value of its currency rose in relation to the dollar.
The occupancy picture has also assisted, according to hotel people, because New York City has become more competitive for tour and convention business. A key reason is the reduction of state and city taxes on hotel rooms. The taxes are now pegged at 13 1/4 percent, plus a flat $2 charge per room per night. The tax consists of an 8 1/4 percent city-state sales tax and a 5 percent city occupancy tax. Before the reduction, rooms renting for more than $100 a night paid 19 1/4 percent in state and city taxes, plus the $2 flat tax.

HEADLINE: West Side Story: Three Partners And an Idea

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
THE next century may be several years away, but for Broadway between 66th and 68th Streets, the Millennium has already arrived -- and brought with it startling changes.
The Millennium in question is Millennium Partners, developers who have spent $500 million on those blocks for the construction of three new high-rise buildings -- two of them complete and the third in progress -- with 740 new rental and condominium apartments and about 540,000 square feet of commercial space that includes the Sony Lincoln Square multiplex, a Gap, an Eddie Bauer, a Coconuts music store, a 60,000-square-foot, five-level Barnes & Noble superstore and the $55 million, six-story, 140,000-square-foot Reebok Sports Club. 
 Still to come, at the base of the third building, are a 50,000-square-foot Tower Records and a 30,000-square-foot Pottery Barn. Millennium has also acquired, in a deal that is essentially a swap, the Chinese Mission to the United Nations, a 10-story former hotel on 66th Street just west of Broadway. The mission is next door to the Tower Records site, and Millennium has used zoning bonuses and the mission's air rights to add 100,000 square feet to the 31-story building, now called Lincoln West, that is to be its neighbor.
The 500,000-square-foot Lincoln West is going up on the west side of Broadway between 66th and 67th Streets, where the five-story General Media building, a much smaller Tower Records and Video and an NBO store used to be. Millennium has stripped the skin from the building, is reinforcing the skeleton and is using it for the base of the tower that is to rise above.
The lower floors of Lincoln West will be a hotel for extended stays, with between 120 and 150 furnished one-bedroom suites for visits of seven days or more. Above the hotel will be about 175 rental units, and the top five or six floors will hold luxury condominium units. The building is expected to be completed by the end of next year, with Tower Records and Pottery Barn moving in by next Christmas.
The Chinese Mission will be moving to 34th Street and First Avenue, on the site of the old Evyan Perfume factory, in two buildings that Millennium is renovating and constructing. In a year or two, after the Chinese diplomats and their aides have departed, the 66th Street building will come down and be replaced by a smaller building whose lower floors will probably hold the Ansonia Post Office.
(The post office had been on the undeveloped site of the first building, Lincoln Square, on the east side of Broadway between 67th and 68th Streets. It moved temporarily to 66th Street east of Columbus Avenue and had originally been scheduled to move back to Lincoln Square.)
Plans for the rest of the new building on the Chinese Mission site are indefinite, but among the possibilities are a luxury hotel or -- if Lincoln Center decides to go ahead and can raise the $40 million said to be needed for the project -- a new opera house, a "mini-Metropolitan Opera House" with 800 to 1,000 seats.
All of which is a major turnaround for what had long been an oasis of underdevelopment between the liveliness of Lincoln Center to the south and the crowded intersection of Broadway and 72d Street above. Until the beginning of the 1990's, the two streets had held a small bank branch, the Cinema Studio 1 and 2 -- two tiny art-movie houses -- an old, low-rise office building with a rundown luncheonette on street level, a vacant former La Crepe restaurant, the low-rise post office adjacent to the headquarters of the Transport Workers Union and, around the corner at Columbus, a small ABC television studio that had been used for the taping of soap operas.
Then along came Millennium Partners, a partnership of Philip E. Aarons, Christopher Jeffries and Philip Lovett. Mr. Aarons and Mr. Jeffries had first met when Mr. Aarons was head of the New York City Public Development Corporation -- a quasipublic nonprofit agency involved in the city's redevelopment efforts -- and worked with Mr. Jeffries on a project Mr. Jeffries was developing in Staten Island. They had actually been undergraduates at Columbia University together -- Mr. Aarons is Class of '73, Mr. Jeffries Class of '72 -- but had not known each other at Columbia.
Mr. Jeffries, a Michigan native, returned to his home state to attend the University of Michigan Law School before coming back to New York. Mr. Aarons, who grew up in the Boston suburbs, went on to graduate from Columbia University Law School.
AFTER Mr. Aarons left government, the two men got together and in 1984, with their General Atlantic Realty Corporation, began converting a former nursing home at Fifth Avenue and 107th Street into market-rate apartments. They spent much of the rest of the 1980's constructing subsidized low-income housing (including Spring Creek Gardens in the East New York section of Brooklyn, which they developed in partnership with the Related Companies) and later building in Manhattan under the city's inclusionary zoning program, which gave bonus space for market-rate housing when low-income units were put up.
(Mr. Lovett, a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Business School, joined General Atlantic five years ago.)
Then they came upon the Broadway blocks. The property on the east side of Broadway was owned by Capital Cities/ ABC, whose offices were across the street, on 66th and 67th between Columbus and Central Park West and which was finishing a spate of development on those blocks. It was in the middle of the real-estate recession of the late 80's and early 90's; property values had plummeted, and it was difficult if not impossible to get financing for almost any kind of construction.
But Millennium had an idea. The partners envisioned an urban entertainment, retail and residential complex, a complement to ABC and Lincoln Center. And they thought they had a novel way to finance it.
"We had an unusual opportunity," Mr. Aarons said. "There were two largely vacant contiguous full-block sites that had been held off the market by a corporate owner for a much longer time than was traditional. For the first building, there was more than 55,000 square feet on the street, which was unusual in a congested environment like New York. So we could plan a development that could take advantage of such a site and its flexible zoning, and we had the ability to do something that would be different."
Mr. Aarons is sitting in Millennium's offices in the Jamaica Savings Bank building at Broadway and 68th, next to large windows that look out at his new structures. Perhaps because of his government experience he is the more public of the partners, the designated spokesman. Mr. Jeffries appears more the dedicated businessman, the number-cruncher, the detail man, at first a little reticent. But after a brief warm-up period, he does not hesitate to expand on his partner's comments.
"The opportunity Millennium Partners had is based on a collapsing real estate market," he said, "where no one had access to construction financing or equity and where everyone was looking at the problems of the past instead of the opportunities of the future. It was a situation in which certain fantastic assets, such as these three blocks, could be acquired for prices that were less than half of what they could have been acquired for three or four years earlier."
Mr. Aarons agreed. "The challenge we faced was finding a way to get financing for the first building," he said. "And that really happened by building partnerships with major retailers."
The idea, he said, was to work with the chief executives of Sony, Reebok, the Gap, Coconuts, Barnes & Noble (which opted for the second building, Lincoln Triangle) and others to custom-build spaces in exchange for financial commitments and a piece of the action -- or, as Mr. Jeffries put it, "a chance to participate in the success of those businesses."
"We tell people," Mr. Aarons added, "that if they're thinking of doing something different in an urban environment, we can design a building that suits their needs. We can give you ceiling heights you don't have when you find yourself at the bottom of a residential building on Third Avenue. We can give you floor plates, column locations, whatever you need. If you get people to commit to a little bit more rent and more space, you can build the fundamentals of the financing."
THEY used a similar technique for the residential part of the Lincoln Square building -- preselling space. They worked out a deal with J. P. Morgan & Company, the project's financial adviser, and Morgan took six floors of apartments for use by senior executives and trainees. In exchange, Millennium received a Morgan-owned building on the East Side, Hampton House at Madison Avenue and 70th Street (where they are now marketing floor-through condominiums for upwards of $3 million each).
To further structure the financing, Mr. Jeffries said, they decided to sell off, for condominiums, "the best part of the building, which most developers will try to keep to make the profit in the transaction."
"We didn't want to be in the condo business," he said, "but in addition, doing this allowed this project to be financed at a time when no other projects could be financed." The top 12 floors, 100,000 square feet of apartments with their own lobby and elevator bank, were sold to a partnership that included Goldman, Sachs, the Zeckendorf Company and Sumitomo Realty and Development.
Millennium obtained a $142.5 million construction loan from the Bayerische Hypotheken-und-Wechsel-Bank of Munich and the Sudwestdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale of Stuttgart. They secured a completion guarantee from the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company of London, the parent of Lehrer McGovern Bovis, construction manager for all three buildings.
And so they created Lincoln Square, a 56-story tower on Broadway and Columbus Avenue between 67th and 68th Streets that engendered much controversy and protest after it was announced in 1992.
The first problem was size. The 545-foot-tall building was in the Special Lincoln Square Zoning District set up north of Columbus Circle in the late 1960's to encourage development with the idea that the area remain a mixed-use residential, retail and entertainment-oriented neighborhood. It was constructed as of right, meaning no zoning variances were required. But community protests over the building's height led the city to adopt new zoning rules for the district, rules that in effect limit the height of future projects to 30 or 31 stories by requiring that 60 percent of their interior space be below 150 feet.
The second problem was design: Neighborhood residents felt that the building, with its somewhat garish orange-and-rust brick facing, was ugly. The third was density: Many people declared that the new apartments, and especially the Sony multiplex, would bring hordes of pedestrians and cars to an area already crowded by theater- and concertgoers at Lincoln Center.
AS anyone who lives on or visits the West Side can attest, the crowds have descended. A walk on Broadway between 66th and 72d Streets, especially after a film has let out, can be a shoulder-to-shoulder experience. But the protests seem essentially to have, if not died out, at least become minimal -- in large part, residents say, because of the building's success. The concern about density has not vanished, but the neighborhood and the neighbors, as well as visitors, seem to appreciate the amenities.
"The Sony theaters are now acknowledged publicly to be the highest grossing movie theaters in the country," Mr. Jeffries said. "About 3 million people will go through their doors this year." The Reebok Sports Club has more than 4,500 members, and the membership list grows daily.
Millennium Tower, the upper-floors condominium -- which was put on the market when condominiums were becoming hot items in Manhattan -- commands prices that average $675 a square foot, and that go as high as $890 a square foot -- over $1 million for a two-bedroom apartment. More than 90 percent of the 93 apartments have been sold.
Rents at Lincoln Square and Lincoln Triangle (between 66th and 67th Streets) are among the highest in Manhattan, Mr. Jeffries said: about $3,000 a month for a one-bedroom, and about $11,000 a month for a four-bedroom.
Mr. Aarons unapologetically defends the neighborhood's increased density. "I believe cities are about density," he said.
Others' feelings are more complex. Nathan Leventhal, who as the president of Lincoln Center is a major neighbor, said he believed that what Millennium has done is "in the main very exciting."
"It reaffirms the area of Broadway north of Lincoln Center as the entertainment center of New York City," Mr. Leventhal said. "I'm thinking of moving here. Then I could never leave. I could go to concerts and movies and buy records and books. But it hasn't come without a price. There are legitimate concerns as to how much development the area can take, how much it translates into infrastructure issues."
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, also gives the developers mixed reviews for their work, but also with an emphasis on the positive.
"They're bringing a lot of additional commercial services to the neighborhood," Ms. Messinger said, "but they're bringing them to a neighborhood that was tremendously alive and tremendously crowded already. The services are a big plus, but they can also cause severe congestion problems. They're also creating housing, which the city needs, and that's worthy of positive note. But I wish they would turn some of their creative talents to affordable and middle-income housing, which is an area in which they have a track record."
The Lincoln Triangle building attracted none of the controversy of its older brother. At 30 stories it is much smaller, having been built under the new zoning rules. Its quieter, off-white brick has also been found by most observers to be more esthetically pleasing. Its apartments are almost all rental, with only the penthouse units being marketed as condominiums -- this time, with the market so positive, by Millennium itself. The partners will also market the condominiums they are planning for Lincoln West.
THE third site was purchased from Bob Guccione, publisher of Penthouse magazine and chairman and chief executive officer of General Media, whose offices were in what had earlier been an Equitable Life Assurance building. It will, Mr. Aarons said, "be smaller than Lincoln Square but bigger than Lincoln Triangle." In April, Millennium reached an agreement in Beijing with the Chinese Government to obtain the Chinese Mission next door. In exchange, Millennium is to construct a new residence building for the mission at 34th Street and First Avenue and renovate an adjacent building at First Avenue and 35th Street for use as office space for the mission. The First Avenue properties were bought from the estate of Evyan's founder and owner, Baron Walter Langer von Langendorff.
At the time of the agreement, Kening Zhang, the first secretary and legal adviser to the Chinese Mission, explained that the current mission building was "too far away from the U.N."
Mr. Aarons said he and his partners had been "intrigued" by the mission site but had always assumed "that a real-estate transaction with China would be impossible to do." But several years ago, he said, they were approached by the Chinese for help with a tax issue. "When we asked why the tax issue was relevant, since I assumed China wasn't paying taxes, they said it was not important now but would be important if they were to sell the building," he said. "So that gave us the first inkling that the building might be available."
Two years of talks led to the agreement. But State Department approval was acquired, and getting that approval, at a time of difficult relations between the Chinese and United States Government, took several months. Mr. Jeffries said the deal had a "value in excess of $30 million," in that "each site is worth $30 million or more."
The deal was especially good news for them in terms of the Lincoln West building. "It allows us to design a bigger building for Lincoln West," Mr. Aarons said. "Also, since we anticipate having possession of the mission building, we know what's going to be there, so we can design the Lincoln West building knowing what's going to be next door, where the views in Lincoln West are going to be."
Millennium used air rights from the mission, and an inclusionary-zoning bonus it had obtained five years earlier from low-income units it built on 107th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, to add 100,000 square feet to the building.
(Neighborhood residents may remember that Lincoln West was the original name of the development proposed for the old rail yards between 59th and 72d Streets near the West Side Highway, the plan now known as Riverside South.)
 ONE result of the anticipated swap is the likelihood that a full-service Ansonia Post Office -- customer-service windows, mail sorting and loading docks for mail delivery -- will move into the first and basement levels of the new building to be constructed on the mission site.
Mr. Aarons said the Postal Service was "in the approval process to move forward on the mission site."
The location of the post office, which has had a temporary retail site on 66th Street east of Columbus, has been a guessing game for neighborhood residents since its old Broadway home was torn down to make way for Lincoln Square. The original plan was for the post office to move into Lincoln Square, in a now vacant 46,000-square-foot storefront site on 68th near Columbus that was purchased by the Postal Service as a condominium for $10 million.
But Andrew Sozzi, a spokesman for the Postal Service in New York, said that several changes in the neighborhood had made the site "no longer desirable for us."
"The mere fact that the Lincoln Square building was constructed, and other high-rise buildings went up in the neighborhood, has increased the volume of mail coming into the Ansonia station, making the space we bought in the building no longer adequate," Mr. Sozzi said. Another problem, he said, was that "the Sony theaters had created much more pedestrian and vehicular traffic on 68th Street, where the loading bays would have to be."
The Chinese Mission space, he said, "offers the two things we were looking for: more space to process our mail, and a street where there is a lot less traffic, making that site a lot safer for us." He added that the plan for the site was awaiting final approvals in Washington.
There is also, Mr. Jeffries said, another important factor: The retail space in the Lincoln Square building "is now worth certainly more than double what the Postal Service paid us for it three years ago."
Leasing it for retail, therefore, would provide a potential bonanza for the owners. Both Mr. Sozzi and Mr. Jeffries said it was not clear what the Postal Service would do with the space, whether it would lease it on its own or sell it back to Millennium.
Possibilities for the upper floors at Lincoln West, Mr. Jeffries said, include a 200-room "high-end" hotel or a new building for Lincoln Center -- a small opera house.
Mr. Leventhal of Lincoln Center said he was "working with Millennium on the possibility of that site as a future theatrical facility."
"It's a dream we have always had: a mini-Met building at Lincoln Center," he said. "But the idea is very speculative and would require an enormous amount of money. It's still more a dream than anything, but it's one that might well happen."
NOT everything in Millennium Partners' existence has been successful. A bid to develop the former Gulf and Western Building at Columbus Circle as a luxury apartment tower lost out to Donald Trump's proposal for what is now called the Trump International Hotel and Tower, a mixed-use luxury hotel and condominium building.
But their success has brought praise and admiration from many of their colleagues. Even Mr. Trump, not known for lavishing praise on his competitors, called the partners "fine people who have done a very, very solid job."
"I think their performance has been excellent, and their theaters are really beautiful," Mr. Trump said. "And they accomplished it at a time when a lot of people were very skeptical about many of aspects of real estate. I take my hat off to them."
Millennium is also expanding outside of New York City. In downtown San Francisco near the Moscone Center, the partners are building a 400,000-square-foot urban entertainment center that has been entirely leased to Sony and will contain a major movie complex, retailing and restaurants.
They have also been selected to develop another 750,000-square-foot site adjacent to the Sony one, Mr. Jeffries said. "So we're going to try to replicate in San Francisco what we're doing here," he said.
Mr. Aarons said that as far as the West Side is concerned, the Chinese Mission will be the final piece of the puzzle. But he and his partners say that they want to continue to find ways to improve the neighborhood and alleviate the density situation. They are taking an active part, with Lincoln Center, Capital Cities/ABC and other neighborhood companies in creating a Lincoln Center business improvement district.
"We believe in our buildings," Mr. Aarons said. "I live in Lincoln Square; Chris lives in Lincoln Triangle."
Mr. Jeffries asked the remaining critics to give them time. "Don't judge what it is until it's all over," he said, "whether it's the color of the brick, the height of the building or the way in which the base of the building relates to the tower. Wait two years."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Retail;
Stores Direct Their Feet to the Sunny Side Street

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
TWO years ago, with great trepidation, Hilary Lloyd, a Kinko's franchisee, opened his first Kinko's copying service store at 16 East 52d Street. Every instinct told him he should be on a major thoroughfare. Problem was, he was priced out of the market on Avenue of the Americas, upper Third Avenue and other heavily trafficked streets.
He needn't have worried. The store, which gets huge orders from surrounding office towers, is among the most successful in the national Kinko's chain. 
 Mr. Lloyd has since opened stores at 78th Street near Lexington and on 47th Street between Sixth and Seventh. He will soon open stores on 54th Street, between Eighth Avenue and Broadway, and on 46th Street between First and Second Avenues.
"Sure, I'd still prefer avenue stores, but I'm getting a big bang for my buck on the side streets," he said.
Mr. Lloyd is not alone. Duane Reade, once an avenue mainstay, is dotting side streets with drugstores. A Staples office supplies store is thriving on 49th Street east of Fifth Avenue. Maud Frizon's, a woman's shoe store, moved a few years ago from 57th Street and Madison Avenue when the rent jumped to $800,000 a year, and is said to be doing fine in an East 69th Street store, where the rent is an eighth the amount.
"The idea that side-street retailers are poor relations to avenue retailers is just wrong," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in the New Spectrum brokerage.
So much for the idea that retailers operating off the beaten track should write an epitaph for their stores. Yes, some people, particuoarly outside of Manhattan, still believe that. "It is simply bad business to go on a side street," stated Michael D. Friedman, vice president of Clay-Daniel Associates, a Queens brokerage. But others say that is no longer a hard and fast rule.
"If a store has a well-known label, and puts money into advertising and direct mail, it can do fine on a side street," said Faith H. Consolo, senior managing director of the Garrick-Aug brokerage.
Lately, few but the most deep-pocketed national chains have much choice. Rents on avenues like Third and Madison, and on major cross streets like 57th Street and Prince Street, have soared. And even at high rents, small stores are hard to find, as many landlords, hoping to attract chains, combine their small spaces into larger ones. So, numerous stores are being forced onto streets they would not touch before.
Few are happy about it; but many say that it is not as bad as they had feared.
"I was devastated when we had to move, and we would be doing better business on Madison," said Wallis Mayers, owner of Wallis Mayers Needlework, which was forced by rising rents to leave 780 Madison Avenue, near 67th Street, for a bigger but cheaper store at 30 East 68th. "But our customers are finding us again."
Some retailers are even reaping mini-boons from the major bane of soaring avenue rents. In July, Broadway Panhandler moved from 520 Broadway, near Spring Street, to much quieter Broome Street. It got a much larger store at a much lower rent, which enabled it to pour money into fixtures, design and advertising.
"I was nervous about moving off Broadway, but it turns out that the rising rents were a blessing in disguise," said Norman Kornbleuth, the cookware store's owner.
Maurice Idy, co-owner of the Brooklyn men's store Kings Row, used that same phrase to describe his recent rent-driven move from 86th Street, Bensonhurst's main shopping street, to Sheepshead Bay Road, a quieter, narrower road three miles away. He doubled his space and slashed his rent, which allowed him to broaden his inventory (he now sells boys' and oversized men's clothes) and lower prices.
"We would have loved to stay put, but I really believe we will do better business here," said Mr. Idy, who opened his new store two months ago.
None of these stores are side-street pioneers. Whenever avenue rents have heated up, shoemakers, dry cleaners and other local service stores have moved to side streets, "creating new service shopping corridors around the corner," said Peter Botsaris, Garrick-Aug's president.
What is new is the flow of non-service retailers into those corridors. "Clothing stores are recognizing that they can get as much traffic next to a dry cleaner as they can next to a shoe store," said Rob Nager, director of retail leasing at Colliers ABR.
Few side-street stores leave traffic flow to chance, though. Most step up their advertising and direct-mail budgets, and put up huge awnings and lavish window displays.
Carole Greene, a New Spectrum vice president, says that her client, Hallmark Cards, gambled -- successfully, it turned out -- on a store at 31 West 52d Street because it had 50 feet of windows. "They have a store that makes people blink when they walk by," she said.
This new willingness to gamble on off-avenue locations has been a bonanza for landlords. "We're negotiating numerous leases for side-street space that our clients could not rent in the past," said Rosina K. Abramson, a real estate attorney.
Examples abound. A few months ago, Pisa de Torre, a white-tablecloth restaurant, opened at 19 West 44th Street, in space that had been vacant almost two years. "The kind of space they wanted was neither available nor affordable on the avenues," said Gerard Nocera, executive vice president of S.L. Green Real Estate, which manages the building.
Similarly, W&M Properties is getting a lot of nibbles for the off-avenue stores at 1185 Avenue of the Americas, at 47th Street. It expects to soon have a permanent tenant for a store just west of the avenue that is currently under month-to-month lease to financially troubled Herman's. And it is close to a deal with a restaurant for a vacant spot in the plaza behind the building.
"The retailers know that, in a big building, you get sales from the people above you, not just from people walking by," said Anthony E. Malkin, W&M's president.
Indeed, some skyscraper-rich side streets may be turning into seller's markets. David M. Wess, a retail associate at Williams Real Estate, is seeking a sublet tenant for a Chemical Bank branch on 43d Street, west of Fifth Avenue. "Food stores are offering above asking rents, but Chemical is holding out for a non-food use," he said.
Some side streets have even turned into first-choice locations for certain types of stores. Sewing machine stores now congregate on 25th Street west of Seventh Avenue. Electronics stores are rife on 31st Street west of Sixth and on 45th Street east of Sixth. And 60th Street east of Third Avenue is to antiques what west 47th Street has long been to diamonds.
"The antiques stores that left Third Avenue because of rents wound up creating their own antiques district," said Alan Victor, an executive vice president of the Lansco brokerage.
Conversely, some retailers see side streets as a way to differentiate themselves from what they view as increasingly homogenized thoroughfares. "As Eighth Street has gotten more commercial and honky tonk, East Ninth Street has evolved by choice into a carriage trade street," said Mr. Fox of New Spectrum.
Susan Penzner, an independent broker, sees a similar phenomenon happening in SoHo. "Lower Broadway has come to look so much like a regional mall that the high-fashion stores really prefer the side streets," she said.
Still, most side-street stores are there from economic necessity, not choice. Thoroughfare rents are just too high.
IN SoHo, for example, stores on major shopping streets like Prince and Spring that used to go for annual rents of $50 a square foot now command double that amount; stores on secondary streets like Greene and Wooster can be had for $55, while Mercer Street rents hover around $40.
On Third Avenue, stores between 72d and 80th Street -- north of the real bastion of mall stores -- get annual rents of as much as $160 a square foot, while on Second Avenue they command $100; annual rents on the streets connecting the two avenues rarely top $75 on busy streets like 77th, and can be as low as $35 on quieter streets.
Rents on Madison Avenue in the 60's are up to $250; side streets can be had for $100.
But side-street rents are inching up, too, particularly in newly developing areas. As Ladies Mile -- that stretch of Avenue of the Americas from 14th Street to 23d Street -- has metamorphosed from a strip of vacant former department stores to a bustling discount haven, the side streets surrounding it have blossomed with restaurants and other stores looking to capitalize on the increased pedestrian traffic. The area's side-street rents are now between $28 and $35; a year ago they did not top $25.
Still, as fast as side-street rents go up, avenue rents seem to go up faster. "Side streets are no longer cheap," said Ms. Consolo. "But they will always be cheaper."

SECTION: Section 13; Page 2; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Will a No-Tax Policy Go Up in Smoke?

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Each of two million New Jerseyans smoke 4.8 packs of cigarettes on average per week. They are arguably not the most health-conscious people around, and given what we know about smokers, they are probably also not the richest. Are they to be the ones who pay for Governor Whitman's first new tax?
The possibility comes up because of the way Christine Todd Whitman has structured her administration. She cut government income (by reducing income taxes) before she figured out where to cut the government to match. Among other consequences, this back-to-front approach (Ronald Reagan also favored it, but he had a credit card called the national debt) has left the Governor sailing ever closer to the wind, fiscally speaking, and with less and less room to maneuver when the sudden need for ready cash comes up. 
 We are now in one of those scrambles for money, in this case over ways to pay for a program that reimburses hospitals that care for people without health insurance.
New Jersey does not have any public hospitals to care for the working poor who account for most charity care. Instead, the state pays about $450 million a year to reimburse hospitals that do the job, and the hospitals in turn are glad to have such a dependable source of income.
But the fund to pay for this care is empty, and for the past three years the state has raided the surplus in the Unemployment Insurance Fund, paid for by employers and workers, to cover the cost. Meanwhile, authorization to raid the Unemployment Insurance Fund expires on Dec. 31. And the Legislature is not going to extend it.
So Len Fishman, the Governor's Health Commissioner, floated a trial balloon for her: a 20- or 25-cent tax on each pack of cigarettes to pay part of the charity-care bill. The idea has symmetry: cigarettes are bad for the health; discouraging people from smoking them is good; nothing discourages consumption like higher prices, and the added money, about $125 million a year at 25 cents a pack, would go to health care.
That covers the public policy side of the debate. Now for the politics.
Mrs. Whitman has promised not to raise taxes. She did not literally say "read my lips," but the "no new taxes" part is understood, and her aversion to new taxes was underscored in the debate this spring over renewing the Transportation Trust Fund, whose bonds were falling due. Some in the Legislature thought a 5-cent-a-gallon gasoline-tax increase to pay for the new bonds would make sense, since out-of-staters buy a lot of cheap New Jersey gas and thus would help bear the burden for the locals. In addition, taxes on fuel tend to depress consumption as much as they do on cigarettes, and lower consumption tends in turn to depress prices. A result of recent Federal gasoline tax increases has therefore been to take the extra money, in effect, out of the pockets of the producers, not the consumers.
But Mrs. Whitman dismissed these arguments, and chose instead to pay for the transportation bonds by extending an expiring auto registration surcharge that began life under former Gov. Jim Florio as a way to pay for bad-driver insurance, and which falls on New Jerseyans alone. The message, lest anyone missed the point, was surcharge, yes; new tax, no.
Now the charity-care issue has put the Governor in the same corner but without the same options, because the labor and business groups whose members pay into the Unemployment Insurance Fund have organized a powerful bloc against continuing the raid.
To no one's surprise, the Governor said she "could be comfortable" with a tax on cigarettes. It would discourage smoking, she said, and the cause of maintaining the health of the working poor is certainly a worthy goal.
But it will not be that easy. Several important Republicans oppose a tax even on cigarettes, and the Democrats are certainly not going to help the Governor get one through he Legislature. Moreover, the men and women who sell cigarettes, and that means a lot of convenience stores, family delis and restaurants, are still angry over the 15-cent tax Governor Florio added to the existing 25 cents the state already collected on cigarettes in 1990.
The talk around here is of a three-way compromise: the cigarette tax, a second tax on hospital income of about 1.5 percent and a continuing but declining resort to the Unemployment Insurance Fund. It will not be easy, because the Legislature will make the Governor go first in calling for the taxes and the minority Democrats will sit on their hands as long as they can. At the same time, the Republicans will hint that charity care, after all, goes mostly to hospitals in urban, therefore Democratic, districts.
At the end of the day the poor will be protected, the charity hospitals will get the money they depend upon, and in 1997, when Mrs. Whitman runs for re-election, the Democrats will utter the words she had hoped would never be spoken of her: she raised taxes.

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
Changing Health Insurance?

 BODY:
This month, many employers are asking employees if they would like to change their medical insurance. Are you thinking about switching?
 
Pay Your Own Way
Most of us have given up our rights to purchase direct health care under the mistaken belief that we can't afford it. We have gotten the Government involved, which has insured a non-competitive system, and now we moan and groan about it.
The solution is simple. Take the money your employer pays for medical care. Pay for your selected doctor yourself. Determine with your doctor and any specialist referred by your doctor if you need the particular medical procedure. Then, work out a price. In the long run, competition will solve the problem of medical costs' rising above inflation.
Oh, one more thing. Control your Government's monolithic position in the health care market. It spends more in the health care market than any other user. Remember, you let them create Medicare and Medicaid. Someone has to pay for it. Who might that be?
 
RALPH D. CORSI
Riverton
 
Traditional Choice
As a nurse, I will continue to stick with the traditional style of health insurance. I have seen many people having problems getting authorization to see a specialist. The H.M.O.'s deem it unnecessary. I am for health care reform, but there has to be a better way.
 
ALICE M. INNES
Harrison
 
Disappearing Coverage
I was talked into changing my health coverage to an H.M.O. The H.M.O. gave a sales pitch that sounded great. My doctor had just signed on as a physician to the plan. She ended my skepticism with her pitch of $3 appointments. Wow, no choice. She was never paid; it turns out my primary physician did not approve of her.
 
CLAIRE GIBBONS
Greene, N.Y.
 
A Luxury Item?
I've been forced to choose between a $200 deductible and a $2,500 deductible, which will give me a savings in premiums of $235 per month, as long as I do not have to file a major claim. I feel that that insurance is moving in the category of a luxury for the rich. I was paying almost as much in health insurance as my mortgage.
 
STEPHEN T. BRODI
Plattsburgh, N.Y.
 
Care With Choice
Most of what I have read is negative, but there are carriers that provide the option of using a managed-care network or selecting an out-of-network physician. The goal of this dual option is to shift the patient into a network by offering significantly higher benefits. However, an individual can select his or her own physician.
 
ROBERT WOLFF
Bridgewater
 
Check Fine Print
One question to ask is whether an insurance carrier's new and renewal premiums are the same that year. Carriers lowball new entrants, then send them substantial increases at the end of the guaranteed rate period.
 
SANDRA R. BARRON
Perrineville
