HEADLINE: Suiting Up for America's High-Tech Future

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: RIO RANCHO, N.M.

 BODY:
ABOUT the only sound inside Intel's new factory here is a robotic whir, high overhead, made by the tiny white cars of a miniature monorail. They ferry a precious cargo of eight-inch silicon wafers. Each is covered with a grid of nearly 300 thumbnail-sized semiconductor chips, and each chip is microscopically packed with millions of electronic gateways, or transistors.
Producing a state-of-the-art microprocessor is the Everest of modern manufacturing, and the Intel Corporation's new plant stands at the summit. The futuristic factory, opened in September, makes the most sophisticated microprocessors that run today's personal computers: the Pentium chip, packed with 3.3 million transistors, and Intel's next-generation Pentium Pro, with 5.5 million transistors. 
 The Intel plant is leading a surge of investment in semiconductor manufacturing by American companies. The current spending spree carries risks, but it also speaks of how far the nation's high-technology manufacturing prowess has come from a decade ago, when many experts predicted that the domestic chip industry was locked in a cycle of decline and its demise threatened to reduce the United States to an economic also-ran in the information age.
"Companies like Intel have done a lot of the things that we all said American companies weren't doing -- investing heavily for the long term and buckling down to really take manufacturing seriously," said Richard K. Lester, director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Industrial Performance Center, a business research group.
No one who has seen Intel's new plant here could question the company's commitment to leading-edge manufacturing. The factory, called Fab 11, is a vast, five-story building with floor space that equals more than two dozen football fields. Intel has already invested $1.8 billion it. As output increases, the price tag is expected to rise to $2.5 billion.
Intel's microchips are designed with circuitry measured in the thickness of atoms and light waves. The manufacturing environment is thousands of times more pristine than a hospital operating room; the tiniest speck of dust is a chip killer. And much depends on getting it right. Botch one wafer, and $250,000 or so goes out with the garbage.
The 140-step manufacturing process -- cleaning, planing, etching, baking and chemically coating the wafers -- occurs in laboratory-like alcoves off seemingly endless hallways. Before entering the production area, known as the clean room, the plant's 1,300 technicians suit up like astronauts -- in white Gore-Tex suits with hoods, goggles, boots and yellow latex gloves. Workers must then take a series of "air showers" to remove any dust particles. Makeup must be removed at "wipe-down stations." The plant's floor is raised and perforated for filtering the air, which whisks by at 100 feet per minute.
"All this is to protect the wafers," Bruce Sohn, a manufacturing manager, explained as he escorted two reporters last month, the first journalists inside the factory since it opened. "And it's part of what makes this the most advanced semiconductor facility in the world."
Indeed, this chip plant on a high desert mesa in New Mexico is probably the most productive factory in the world, in terms of the value of goods it makes. By industry estimates, it has the potential to generate revenue of more than $5 billion a year -- more than all but the 200 or so largest companies in America.
The Intel plant heads an armada of $1 billion-plus chip plants under construction around the world. About 40 semiconductor fabrication plants earmarked for $1 billion or more are going up or are on the drawing boards, said George Burns of Strategic Marketing Associates, a technology consulting firm in Santa Cruz, Calif. The pace, if anything, seems to be accelerating. In the month of October alone, there were eight announcements of $1 billion-plus plants.
Japanese, South Korean and Taiwanese companies are spending heavily on semiconductor plants. Yet the investment wave is being led by American companies -- not just Intel but also Motorola, Micron Technology, I.B.M., Advanced Micro Devices and others, building mammoth chip factories in the United States and abroad. Eighteen of the giant plants are being built by American companies, while the Japanese are next, with 10.
Producing in the United States with American workers is an attractive proposition these days for American companies and for East Asian chip makers as well. Thirteen of the $1 billion-plus factories are going up in the United States; nine of those are being built by American companies.
The aggressive investment strategy of the American companies reflects their confidence not only in the prospects for their industry but also in their manufacturing abilities -- an extraordinary reversal from the 1980's. Back then, it seemed, semiconductors were another high-technology industry, pioneered by America, that was being lost to Japan.
The plight of the semiconductor business, more than any other industry, pointed to manufacturing as the Achilles' heel of the American economy. The United States companies were at the forefront of semiconductor research and design, but stumbled badly on the factory floor in production quality and efficiency. A decade ago at American plants, die yields, the share of usable chips among the few hundred etched onto each silicon wafer, were often less than 50 percent, far below Japanese levels.
Today, things could scarcely be more different at leading American plants. Die yields, for example, are now routinely 80 to 90 percent. Once, the semiconductor industry was unable to produce new generations of chips of high quality in high volumes. But today, the factory floor at a company like Intel is confidently described as a competitive weapon, alongside design know-how and financial muscle.
"Manufacturing is no longer an obstacle to anything the company wants to do," said David B. Marsing, the plant manager in Rio Rancho. "That change is fairly recent at Intel, something we've really seen only in the last few years."
Admittedly, there are caveats for the chip makers. Their optimism about the steadily rising demand for all manner of semiconductors -- from Intel's sophisticated microprocessors to simple microcontrollers, found in appliances like hair dryers -- could be off target. The optimism is based on the belief that more semiconductors will be used in more and more products. In fact, the semiconductor share of the total cost of electronics goods has doubled in the last decade, rising to 16 percent, and some analysts predict it will reach 25 percent by the year 2000.
But if demand eases, then the traditional boom-and-bust cycle of the semiconductor industry could return -- and turn some of the huge chip plants being built today into the white elephants of tomorrow. In short, the American semiconductor industry could be pursuing the wrong strategy.
Concerns about the future certainly color Wall Street's view of the chip makers, even Intel, whose microprocessors run 80 percent of the world's personal computers. Its domination of that lucrative market has made Intel a profit machine. Daniel Klesken, an analyst for Robertson, Stephens & Company in San Francisco, expects that given its growth rate, Intel will have $11 billion in profits around the year 2000 -- more than any other American company, likely surpassing the current profit leaders like Ford, Exxon and General Motors.
But many investors are apparently skeptical that Intel can keep it up, and the stock market often reacts nervously to any bad news. Last week, for example, Intel shares dropped sharply when the company announced that a large customer was having trouble paying its bills. Intel did not name the company, but most industry analysts said it was Packard Bell Electronics Inc., a leading marketer of personal computers to home users. Later, Packard Bell, a privately held company, said it was not in financial trouble. Intel shares closed Friday at $61, down 3 percent for the week.
The episode illustrates Wall Street's skittishness about Intel because the company's high-profit franchise is so dependent on a single industry, personal computers. Anything that stalls the rapid growth of the PC industry would hit Intel hard. So investors are willing to pay only a modest 15 times current earnings for Intel shares.
DESPITE Wall Street's qualms, the resurgence of America's high-technology manufacturing capability is still a triumph -- and a turnaround with consequences well beyond the semiconductor industry. The worried analysts of the 1980's were correct in pointing out the crucial role of semiconductors as a basic building block of information technology, and the growing importance of that technology to the economy. For example, investment in information technology, which excludes software, now accounts for 52 percent of all business capital equipment spending, up from 31 percent a decade ago.
"In terms of size, growth and importance to our economic future, information technology is now clearly the basic industry of America," said Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist of Morgan Stanley & Company.
There is no single cause that explains how the American semiconductor industry regained the lead in the 1990's, after seeing its share of the world market slide to 37 percent from 57 percent in the 1980's. A weaker dollar and the 1986 semiconductor trade agreement with Japan helped lift American sales. The recession of the early 1990's in Japan slowed down that nation's semiconductor makers. Finally, the demand for chips shifted from consumer electronics products, which Japan dominated, toward the fast-growing markets for personal computers and telecommunications equipment, in which American companies were strong.
Yet, by all accounts, much of the credit for the comeback belongs to the American companies. An instinct for corporate survival, recalls Steven Appleton, the chief executive of Micron Technology Inc., proved a powerful incentive for his company. Micron was, and is, a specialist in DRAM, or dynamic random access memory, semiconductors, the chips that serve as a PC's temporary memory, where data for current tasks are stored. The DRAM business was the market in which the Japanese producers were strongest. Unlike Intel, which dropped out of DRAM's to focus on high-end microprocessors, Micron had few options.
"We either kept making DRAM's and got competitive or went out of business," Mr. Appleton said.
Throughout the industry, and on every rung of the corporate ladder, manufacturing expertise was suddenly recognized as a valued asset. The 35-year-old Mr. Appleton, for example, started working for Micron on the factory floor in a clean room in Boise, Idaho, for $4.46 an hour. Craig R. Barrett, the chief operating officer of Intel, is a former associate professor of materials sciences at Stanford University. At Intel, he rose to the top as a manufacturing expert.
"In the mid-1980's," Mr. Barrett said, "the U.S. semiconductor industry got a big bucket of cold water thrown in its face. It became brutally apparent that all the smart technologists in the world would not make this industry a success. We had to get down and vastly improve our manufacturing efficiency."
After sojourns to Japan, studying chip making there firsthand, Mr. Barrett decided that Intel needed greater cooperation among its design, development and manufacturing teams. Specifically, the designers and developers of each new generation of chip must now shepherd their creation through the early stages of production.
One result: chip designs that are easier to produce. Mr. Barrett explains the benefits with a hiking analogy. "You put fewer stones in the backpack if you're the one who has to carry it," he said.
Today, the Intel factories also make extensive use of computer simulations to predict production problems before they occur. "The emphasis has really moved away from defect detection and toward defect prevention," noted David B. Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard Business School who is also a director of Intel.
Back at the plant in Rio Rancho, the 34-year-old Mr. Sohn, who is an M.I.T. graduate, marvels at how much chip manufacturing has changed since he joined Intel 12 years ago. He stands in one of the factory's control centers -- a bank of 20 personal computers monitored by a few technicians, who track production data, run simulations and order minute adjustments in the manufacturing process.
"In the old days, we used to do our best, wait at the end of the line and pray that things came out," Mr. Sohn recalled. "As you can see, we're worlds beyond that now."
If factory-floor practices have changed beyond recognition from the days when workers baked pizzas in the chip ovens, so has the composition of the work force. A decade ago, workers typically had high school diplomas and no specialized training. Today, two-year degrees from technical schools or electrical engineering degrees are the norm.
For the Rio Rancho factory, Intel recruits students from Albuquerque Technical-Vocational Institute and other nearby technical schools. Starting salaries for newly hired technicians are in the high $20,000's. Within three or four years, salaries can rise to $50,000 or more a year. In some cases, with overtime, pay can reach $90,000 for these skilled factory technicians. That kind of money buys a measure of affluence, especially in the Albuquerque area, where the average one-bedroom apartment rents for about $500 a month.
The more skilled work force and increased automation have helped to make the chip-producing process far more disciplined than it once was, said Mr. Marsing, the plant manager. The technicians work with 1,000 personal computers in the factory, searching for what Mr. Marsing calls "a plethora of small continuous improvements" intended to hasten production and improve chip yields.
THE manufacturing discipline extends beyond the Intel factories. Equipment suppliers vying for orders from Intel are subject to painstaking scrutiny. Producers of chip-etching machines or furnaces, for example, will be put through runoffs judged by Intel that last months. One equipment maker will be chosen to supply Intel factories worldwide, reducing the chances of variation from one factory to the next. Because chip making is so precise, any variation is anathema, potentially reducing yields.
Once selected, the supplier will be subject to even closer monitoring from Intel. It demands to know whether equipment makers want to use different subcontractors, even for screws and bolts, because any change could affect the manufacturing process slightly.
And unlike in the making of cars or airplanes, manufacturing technology in the chip industry changes almost with each generation of chip. Every two or three years, the level of miniaturization increases and production equipment changes, meaning that the plants' owners have to make their money back on all the equipment in that short span of time.
"What you have here is a frightening pace of change in manufacturing improvement," said Mr. Marsing. "At least, we certainly hope it's frightening to our competitors."
 
 
 
The Plants of Tomorrow
 Three semiconductor plants costing $1 billion or more are already up and running in this country, and 10 more have been announced. Nonetheless, the building boom has done little for investors lately. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index, consisting of 16 chip makers, has fallen 17 percent since September, and some companies are down more than 40 percent.
 Investors may be anticipating a replay of the mid-1980's, when a sharp spike in manufacturing capacity led to a glut of chips and depressed stock prices.
But some industry insiders say the historical analogy is flawed. James C. Morgan, chairman of Applied Materials, the world's biggest supplier of chip-making machinery, called demand for memory chips in particular "almost insatiable."
His stock is only down about 22 percent from its midsummer highs. So investors either buy his argument or they feel that they have less downside betting on the company that is equipping many of the new plants. EDWARD WYATT

LENGTH: 2548 words

HEADLINE: TALKING MONEY WITH: SHERRY LANSING;
Under a Mattress Will Be Fine, Thanks

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
AN attractive, well-dressed man drives along a Beverly Hills street in a white Rolls-Royce, a glamorous blonde by his side. They see a tattered homeless woman sitting forlornly in the street, and the man seems to recognize her.
"You know her?" the blonde asks disdainfully. 
 "Just someone I used to know," he replies.
It's only a dream, but it is a recurring nightmare for Sherry Lansing, the 51-year-old chairman of Paramount Pictures. For in it she is the homeless woman, and the man in the Rolls is her ex-husband, a successful plastic surgeon from whom she has long been divorced.
Even today, having accumulated an ostrich-sized nest egg of tens of millions of dollars from producing hits like "Fatal Attraction," "Black Rain," "Indecent Proposal," "The Accused" and "School Ties," Ms. Lansing is still leery about her financial future.
Her film credits may reflect a passion for high-voltage drama, but when it comes to investing, the last thing she wants is a thriller.
Given Ms. Lansing's nightmares, that suits her just fine.
In fact, it would be hard to imagine a stodgier approach to managing money, short of putting cash under the mattress. She is a financial adviser's nightmare, as Michael Gordon, her business manager, would surely attest. "He was so embarrassed by my portfolio that he didn't want me to show it to anyone," Ms. Lansing recalled, giggling. "His sole purpose is to watch my T-bills and CD's," she said during a recent interview in New York.
By her own definition, Sherry Lansing is a control freak. She is compulsive about trying to return every telephone call within 24 hours, about reviewing every detail in every script. Indeed, her New York stopover was one leg of a trip to Thailand, where she was visiting the set of "Phantom," a coming release from Paramount, partly to make sure she knew what was going on during production.
She has nothing against investing; she just won't do it unless she knows all about what the money is being invested in, and she believes that is generally impossible. Film she knows. "If I take a risk with a film," she said, "I know every in and out."
 But outside the movie business, "I don't know enough," she said. "I worked hard for my money. The idea of turning it over to someone else to manage and putting my fate in their hands is inconceivable. I know my business, but I never thought I knew anyone else's business. And I am not a person who likes to abdicate control of my financial interests."
The only exception to her Treasury bills and CD's is a big wad of stock in Viacom Inc., the owner of Paramount, where she has been since 1992. "I want to sleep well at night," she said over breakfast at the St. Regis. Her Hollywood uniform hinted at both her success and her caution: a conservative brown Armani pants suit, with a black turtleneck and high heels. "I have enough money, and I don't want to worry about it."
 That may seem peculiar coming from Hollywood's most powerful female executive, a woman who not only understands every financial angle in the tangled business of movie making but has served on a variety of corporate boards, from Primerica's to Leslie Fay's.
"I know people think it's odd, but I think it is about the way we were raised," Ms. Lansing said.
"We were raised to get married and have at least two children," she continued. "But the thing I wanted most in life was to be independent." And to be that, "you have to be not only emotionally independent," she said, but "able to take care of yourself economically. In my mother's world, the man always took care of you."
 For Ms. Lansing, investing carries the perilous risk of losing the independence that a nest egg provides. As a result, she won't invest in companies when she doesn't have firsthand knowledge of them. Unless she has been a board member or worked for a company, she will not buy its stock. She would not buy, say, I.B.M. shares, because "they weren't going to invite me to an I.B.M. board meeting. So then I would be relying on things I had read or what people told me, rather than my own knowledge."
It is a disciplined strategy, but it can be expensive -- especially this year, when one could have thrown darts at the stock tables and made 30 percent. Of course, "there was a time when T-bills were 18 percent," she said, and she did well. Impeccable timing? Hardly. "I didn't know they were 18 percent. I don't have time to pay attention." She did serve on the board of Cetus and bought its stock, but that was a disappointment.
"Cetus did not get approval on Interleukin 2, a cancer drug. Because of that, the company was forced to be sold under pressure. My options were worthless," she recalled, though she said she had no regrets. "I believed in it. It was an intelligent, educated guess. I thought it was the greatest company in the world."
THOUGH Ms. Lansing is far from an avid stock buyer, she has made an exception with Viacom. Not only is she holding onto options that are valued at about $6.5 million, but she has bought Viacom stock on the open market. Though she refused to comment on these holdings, a close associate said that Ms. Lansing had not held onto options she received at Fox or at Paramount, before it was bought by Viacom, but that she believed strongly in Viacom's chairman, Sumner M. Redstone.
What made Ms. Lansing such a wary investor? No trial and error was involved. She set her course when she made her first killing in Hollywood, back in 1980, when she was already president of production at 20th Century Fox. When the investor Marvin Davis bought the company in 1981, "We had stock options and he bought everybody out in one fell swoop," Ms. Lansing recalled. She won't say how much she made, but associates put the figure at several million dollars. "I remember thinking, 'What should I do with it?' " Ms. Lansing recalled.
 Soon afterward, she was at dinner at Elaine's restaurant, a New York favorite for media moguls, with Mo Rothman, a veteran film executive who owned the rights to Charlie Chaplin's film library. Mr. Rothman, a gruff, outspoken man who has known Ms. Lansing for years, told her: "Why don't you pretend you've made half of it, because the rest is what you pass on in taxes. Put it in CD's and you will sleep very well at night, knowing your money is safe."
 At that time Mr. Davis, who had made a fortune in the oil business, "was putting lots of people into oil deals," Ms. Lansing said. But she ignored such high-flying ideas, instead following the advice of Mr. Rothman and other friends. It was a seminal decision, she said.
 In a telephone interview from London last week, Mr. Rothman recalled: "She has always been worried about money. She was a girl alone, a single girl. She didn't know if she would be fired or get another deal -- all the preoccupations that women are worried about when they are alone in the world."
Sherry Lansing's caution comes from her background as well as her experience. She spent her Chicago childhood ensconced in movie theaters, and once out of school she wanted to get into the movie business. She had no idea how, though, so instead she took a job teaching in the Watts area of Los Angeles.
During a brief stint as an actress in the soap opera "Loving," she started offering suggestions on the script to Ray Wagner, the producer. That led to a job reading scripts for him for $5 a hour. From there she worked for a talent agency. She moved on to MGM, where she ultimately became president for creative affairs, and to Columbia, where she was senior vice president for production.
BUT even as her salary soared, Ms. Lansing worried. "I had been in the business and I had watched the ups and downs," she said. "I had seen people who were big-salary people. They lived high on the hog, and they did not prepare for the future. And one day it stops for everybody. This is a very tough business, tough and cruel. When I was a reader and story editor, I watched what happened to people. I watched how cruel people were to them when they couldn't get jobs.
"I can give you 20 examples of people who did not prepare for the future, and then one day the salary stops, the hit movies stop. They lose everything, including their self-esteem."
For Ms. Lansing, money was freedom. "From the time I started making money at Fox -- I was 35 -- I always wanted to save to have enough so that I didn't have to worry," Ms. Lansing said. "If you ever need a job, you will always do the safe thing because you will be scared. The only way you can perform in a job is if you don't need it. Then you can make pure decisions that are not based on fear."
Her peace of mind would not come so easily if Ms. Lansing were a world-class spender for whom there was never enough money. But to hear Ms. Lansing's friends tell it, she's hardly that. When Stanley Jaffe, the man with whom she produced the hit "Fatal Attraction," asked whether she had spent much of what she had made from the movie, Mr. Jaffe laughed. "I don't think Sherry has spent the money she made when she graduated from college," he said. And Mr. Gordon added: "She has a greater sense of what she wants than most people. When I ask clients about risk tolerance, usually they talk out of both sides of their mouth." So when Mr. Gordon was raising money to open a restaurant in Hollywood, where a new one opens every 10 minutes, he didn't even ask Ms. Lansing to invest.
MS. LANSING'S family background clearly played a role. Her mother's affluent childhood in Nazi Germany ended when "she put on an armband and she and her family escaped with nothing," Ms. Lansing recalled. Ms. Lansing's father died when she was 9. Though she was close to her stepfather, who owned a successful furniture company in Chicago, her parents were "very conservative," Ms. Lansing recalled.
"My stepfather paid for everything with cash," she added. "There was a Depression-era mentality."
Indeed, when she bought her first home, she had to be talked out of paying for it in cash. But even a small mortgage didn't sit well. "I slept better after I paid it off," she said.
 Ms. Lansing recalled once bringing her stepfather to visit 20th Century Fox and showing him an executive's large corner office. "My father asked me if something was wrong. He figured that if the guy had such a big office, he was about to be fired," Ms. Lansing recalled. "In the Midwest it was so pretentious to have a big office that he figured the guy was doing it for show."
It made a big impression on her, she said, that as her stepfather's furniture company grew, "and they started knocking out walls so everyone had a big office, he continued to keep his desk on the floor near the salesmen."
Not only was her family conservative about money, they wanted their daughter to have a conservative life style. "They cut me off when I graduated from college," she said. "They thought it would build character."
Just after college, she got married to the aspiring plastic surgeon, and they drove to California. "My stepfather had this theory that if they gave me money I would be spoiled, wouldn't learn the value of hard work or have ambition. When I asked to borrow money, he said he would lend it to me, but he would charge me interest."
As she began to grow successful, though, her family changed their strategy, offering, after her divorce, to give her money if she would come back to Chicago, meet a nice guy and get married. She declined.
Even today, though she owns a home in Beverly Hills, "she doesn't own a condo in every city," Mr. Gordon said.
Friends say that when Ms. Lansing turned 50, she began to believe that she ought to be able to live it up more. After all, she had the money. Because Hollywood is hardly the home of low-key living, she wondered whether she had a problem about spending.
She even consulted a psychiatrist about becoming a chic shopper. He asked her what she liked to own and, presumably, was reassured when she told him she liked abstract art -- an expensive choice. He urged her to go out and buy something she liked so they could study her reaction.
 Ms. Lansing took herself to the Knoedler Gallery in New York. As one friend recalled it, "she zoomed through the gallery, said she wanted a particular painting by Helen Frankenthaler and bought it in 16 seconds. They had probably never seen anything like it."
 But Ms. Lansing soon discovered that she didn't care much about collecting expensive art. Looking at it in other people's homes was good enough. "All I could think was that the money would be better used if I gave it to charity," she said. Finally the therapist dismissed her. Regardless of whether she was normal by Hollywood standards, he concluded that she was happy nonetheless.
 To be sure, she does live well. "Don't get me wrong," she said. "I live in a house, not a garret. I'm not a bag lady. I am sitting in a beautiful hotel room. I have a beautiful suit on. Of course I like making money very much. But there is a limit to the things I think are worth buying. There is nothing that I want to buy that I don't have."
CLEARLY she has grappled with the inevitable question of whether people in the film industry ought to make so much. "I wanted to make money because I wanted to be successful," Ms. Lansing recalled. "I wanted people to see my movies, so I deserved the money that came from the movies."
Just as Ms. Lansing had to come to terms with her success, so did her parents. While she was working her way up the ladder in Hollywood, her mother was so unhappy about it that she didn't tell friends where her daughter was working until Ms. Lansing got the headline-catching job at 20th Century Fox.
Surely her family was also happy two years ago when, without even going back to Chicago, she found her second husband, the film director William Friedkin. His most recent credit is "Jade," but he built his reputation with films like "The Exorcist" and "The French Connection."
Ms. Lansing said she had already had an influence on her husband's spending habits, if not his approach to investing. They do have his-and-hers business managers and do not discuss specific investments with each other, but their disparate life styles are coming together.
 When they married, Mr. Friedkin had five homes: a house in Aspen, an apartment in New York, a house in Big Bear, Calif., one in Los Angeles and a second that he was building.
"I said, 'What do you need an apartment in New York for? That is the stupidest thing. I don't want to live in that apartment that you lived in with your other wives, and I don't want to do it over. Wouldn't you rather have the money? We can stay at the St. Regis or the Peninsula.' "
He bought the life style script. They now own just one house, the one in Beverly Hills, which they bought together. "He was the exact opposite of me," Ms. Lansing explained, but now, she says, he is coming around to her way of thinking.
 "Billy's attitude toward money is much different from mine. He is an artist. He takes no responsibility. Because he takes no interest in money, he spends it. If you tell him not to spend it, he doesn't."
Presumably, now they are both putting their money in the bank and sleeping well -- at whatever hotel around the world they choose to stay in.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
How to Get a Job, Even One That Suits Your Psyche

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
THE reason adults are always asking children what they want to be when they grow up, the comedian Paula Poundstone says, is that they're looking for ideas.
Of course, most of us don't have what it takes to become, say, a really great dentist-queen (to cite the dual-career plan of a 5-year-old I once knew). But in a survey conducted a few years ago, about 45 percent of American employees said they would change jobs if they could. 
 Soon they may have to: Economists tell us that with today's market shifts, college graduates can expect to work at 12 to 15 jobs in at least three different fields. (Those of us who have already done this out of sheer aimlessness can now pretend there was a method to our meanderings).
So how do we reconcile those childhood dreams with the demands of the labor market? The question looms as large as the Jobs & Careers section at my local bookstore, where shelf after shelf is jammed with guides on job searches, salaries and self-discovery. Here are a few that might help.
"The 1996 What Color Is Your Parachute?" by Richard Nelson Bolles (Paperback, Ten Speed Press, $14.95) has just swooped down, and this edition, like other "Parachutes," buoyantly and reliably covers lots of terrain.
The content of this perennial best seller hasn't changed much (the career-resource pages have been updated); it's an organized hodgepodge -- a cheerful collection of grids, diagrams, exercises, pep talks and statistics that somehow add up to a systematic approach to the world of work.
Mr. Bolles doesn't skimp on psychology. He writes plenty about self-fulfillment, the "rejection shock" that makes us hate job-hunting and the depression that is unemployment's frequent companion. This expansive, detailed book points the entrepreneurial toward entrepreneurship, explains the five best and five worst ways to hunt for a job, practically dresses you for an interview and even takes you inside the interviewer's mind (for six smart and funny pages). It's what the author promises in the subtitle: "a practical manual."
People who need a deeper dive into the psyche to locate their career desires may find what they are looking for in "I Could Do Anything If I Only Knew What It Was," by Barbara Sher with Barbara Smith (Dell Trade Paperback, $11.95). Despite the somewhat dopey self-help title, this book, which recently came out in paperback, offers a strategy for grappling with the demons of indecision and apathy.
There are two reasons that some of us shrug helplessly when we're asked what work we'd like, the author says: We have lots of choices, and we're pretty neurotic. So, using a kind of common-sense psychology, "I Could Do Anything" takes aim at the internal conflicts that bury our desires.
Without ignoring the economic realities of life, the book offers solid insights into what may be going on with people who would rather complain than make a career commitment, who feel glued to impressive jobs they hate, who always stop short of success, or who -- this is the big one -- are waiting to be rescued by someone else (the phone call that changes your life because finally someone has noticed what a talented person you are).
But readers aren't asked to navel-gaze. This is a workbook of conversations, essay exercises and games -- some corny, some creative. At the same time, the author gently reminds readers that not even the perfect job leads to perfect happiness all the time. The goal here is to get in touch with your inner dentist-queen and to muster the courage and maturity to find her some grown-up work she'll enjoy.
Finally, if your career obstacles are external ones, try "101 Great Answers to the Toughest Job Search Problems," by Ollie Stevenson (Career Press, $11.99). Its subtitle conveys its useful content: "What to do if you're too old, too young, too inexperienced, female, minority, physically challenged or otherwise blocked from landing the job you want."
Ms. Stevenson guides readers skillfully through their insecurities and gives good tips for navigating some of the narrow-minded, unspoken requirements of the job club. This includes creative responses to impertinent, discriminatory or illegal interview questions. And honest ways to de-emphasize dates of birth and other details that might prejudice some employers.
My only disagreement is with the book's emphasis on those "functional resumes" you see these days -- the ones that start with a "Summary" and "Selected Achievements" and relegate actual work histories to a footnote. But this is a quibble, maybe even old-fashioned resistance. (So much for de-emphasizing my own date of birth.) Here is an author who wants us to keep our integrity, but also get the job.
"The Road Ahead," by Bill Gates, with Nathan Myhrvold and Peter Rinearson (Viking, $29.95), has sped onto the best-seller list this month with, naturally, a CD-ROM version tucked inside for those who would rather interact with the electronic age than read about it.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Who Pays Capital Gains Taxes?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Investors are hoping that President Clinton and the Congress will agree to lower the capital gains tax rate. But many rich investors couldn't care less. They have found perfectly legal ways to take their profits without paying a nickel in capital gains taxes.
No one knows just how much money is saved through such tax strategies. But it almost certainly is huge and growing. In 1993, the last year for which figures were available, taxpayers reported less in capital gains than they had in 1985, when stock prices were far lower. Why? Chances are that there are not fewer gains being taken, just more taxes being avoided. 
 Congressional leaders will sit down with Administration officials this week to try to hammer out a tax and budget package. One thing that isn't on the table, but should be, is closing the capital gains loophole.
Here's how it works. Let's say you have $1 million of stock in a company, for which you paid next to nothing years ago. If you sell your shares, Uncle Sam will take 28 percent of your profits. But if you instead borrow an equivalent number of shares, and sell them, the tax law figures you still own the original shares, so no tax is due. Your broker will be happy to "lend" you almost all the money you got, for a fee of 1 or 2 percent a year, letting you invest in other stocks or just spend the money.
That vigorish for Wall Street adds up to a lot of money, especially considering the brokerage firm has no risk at all, just an income stream. "In return for not paying taxes, you pay an annual toll fee," says an investment banker who has made plenty by arranging such deals. "It is a categorical abuse." He laughed at the idea he might want to say that publicly, explaining he didn't want to lose all his friends.
It used to be that such tricks were used mainly to postpone taxes on a sale late in one year until the next. That still is what small investors do. But big ones, who can afford the fees, sometimes keep the offsetting positions until death, when capital gains taxes no longer matter. That is a major reason that published figures for the number of shares sold short keep soaring.
When the Estee Lauder Companies went public, both Estee and her son Ron sold a lot of stock. But not their own shares. They "borrowed" shares from other family members, and will evidently claim that they no owe no tax. Similarly, the William Dart family made a brilliant move by buying a large stake in Salomon Inc., the brokerage firm, when it was mired in the Treasury bond scandal, and then selling last year as the shares peaked. But they used the shorting trick, and so delayed paying taxes on their huge gain. Others have accomplished much the same thing with equity swaps, which differ in details.
This raises issues beyond the tax code. Swaps in particular are often designed so that corporate insiders keep the voting power even after they get rid of the economic risks and benefits of owning stock. In a tight fight for corporate control, a boss might keep his job using votes from shares in which he no longer has an economic stake.
None of this is a secret on Wall Street. Bankers Trust ran an ad last year urging you to call them "if your stock is worth at least $2 million" and you'd like to get out without paying taxes. But it has not alarmed Washington even as some say it is unfair to cut the capital gains tax rate. Wouldn't it be fairer to give smaller investors a break while making sure those customers of Bankers Trust also pay their share?

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Soaring Shorts" shows shares sold short and not covered in American markets from 1987 to 1995.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The Political Dance of Calvin Butts

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
BACK in October, when most of New York was turning its back on President Fidel Castro during the United Nations' 50th anniversary festivities, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d opened the doors of his Abyssinian Baptist Church to the Cuban revolutionary, giving him a rare platform and an enthusiastic audience of 1,300 people.
But perhaps far more revealing of the minister's political leanings was a moment a few months before, when the church's economic arm, the Abyssinian Development Corporation, hosted a "Day of Commitment" to generate corporate funds for Harlem. The guest list read like that of a Republican fund-raiser: Gov. George E. Pataki; Mayor Giuliani; the Economic Development Commissioner, Charles A. Gargano, Time Warner's president, Richard Parsons. 
 Harlem has come to expect such political unpredictability from Mr. Butts, and he has been criticized in the past, even by some of his own congregants, for endorsing Ross Perot in 1992 and inviting Mr. Pataki to speak at his church during the last gubernatorial election.
But these days, the criticism, at least the public kind, is notably muted. In fact, with the community hungry for economic development and Republicans ensconced in City Hall and Albany, even some of Harlem's most vocal Democrats are adopting a similar flexibility.
"I don't care if it's Republican money or Democratic money, as long as it rebuilds our community," said Councilman Adam Clayton Powell 4th.
Few believe that Mr. Butts's spirit of cooperation portends a black exodus from the Democrats. But, in Harlem, the first black community in the nation to break the Republican stranglehold over the black vote earlier in the century, there is growing talk of a new pragmatism, a byproduct of the defeat of Mayor David N. Dinkins, disappointment with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and a sense of urgency about Harlem's economy.
"The key word is independent thinking," said J. Phillip Thompson, a visiting scholar at the Russell Sage Foundation. "That's what I think you're beginning to see -- not a shift to Republicanism, but a critical eye toward both parties."
Mr. Butts's flexibility has paid off. Governor Pataki recently appointed him to two influential state development boards: the Empire State Development Corporation, formerly the Urban Development Corporation, and the New York State Science and Technology Foundation. Both boards control loans and grants to businesses.
Sensing that economic hard times may have created a chink in Harlem's political armor, the Republicans are moving to offer alternatives. The recently reconfigured Harlem Urban Development Corporation, once run by Harlem old-timers like Donald J. Coggsville, is now called the Harlem Community Development Corporation, and is dominated by Pataki appointees.
Like Representative Floyd H. Flake, a Democrat who has leveraged his political power with Republicans to gain economic clout for his church in Southeast Queens, Mr. Butts has a stake in the economic development of Harlem. His church's development corporation was incorporated in 1989 to build affordable housing, improve the delivery of social services and stimulate the local economy. Among its projects are the controversial Pathmark in East Harlem and rental apartment units like the Hattie Dodson Houses.
Heretical as it may sound, coming from a Democrat who has championed the concerns of the poor, Mr. Butts argues that promoting economic growth is more important than preserving social services.
"I think the Republicans are in an excellent position to make the argument and demonstrate that you can do as much through economic development as you can through social welfare programs -- in fact more," he said. "Because you break a dependency cycle, you increase responsibility, people have a greater sense of ownership and you create jobs."
Mr. Butts says he is also prepared to see the Republicans succeed where Democrats have failed, and suspects they may earn some converts in the process. "I think that the Republicans have an opportunity to make tremendous headway," he said. "All the Republicans have to do is get something done and you know what? I think they will."
Nevertheless, working closely with the Republicans makes some ill at ease. "Am I unnerved? Yes, absolutely, because this is going to be a departure from tradition," said State Senator David A. Paterson. "But the reason I'm anxious to work with them is because I need Pataki to succeed. I need Giuliani to succeed. Our communities can't take much more disaffection."
Representative Charles B. Rangel, too, says the moment calls for putting common economic goals ahead of political differences and that his main concern is the Empowerment Zone, in which the city, state and Federal governments have each pledged $100 million to Harlem and the South Bronx. "You might ask, 'Aren't they the same forces that crippled your community, closed the hospitals, cut the schools?' " he said. "I am talking about getting development into Harlem. How can I not work with them?"
To some extent, Democrats have no choice but to work with the Republican leadership. But some say such teamwork strengthens the hand of a party whose larger ideological agenda can offset any incremental economic benefits to the community.
"You're talking about people who want to cut social services that people of color need," said Assemblyman Keith L. Wright of Harlem. "There is no getting around the horrific and tyrannical policies of the Republican Party.".
But Mr. Butts, who says he is considering running for mayor, insists that protest and collaboration are not incompatible. "We're still as outspoken as ever," he said. "But I think it's good not to make people angry, because you never know who you will have to pick up the phone and call."
 
IN HIS OWN WORDS
 
The Quotable Butts
 
ON BLACKS AND THE DEMOCRATIC PARTY: "I hope it will set a fire under the electorate to begin to think more clearly about what they're getting for their 'loyalty.' We've been so loyal to Democrats, what are we getting for it?"
 
ON SENATOR ALFONSE M. D'AMATO: "Do I agree with Aflonse D'Amato? Absolutely not. He said some things that absolutely infuriated me. But when it came time to saving some people's money at Freedom Bank, Alfonse D'Amato did it."
 
ON HIS OWN ACTIVISM: "There is room for the uncompromising, belligerent, nasty, guerilla activist. But you change when you are responsible for an institution. I got folks I got to pay. I got families."

HEADLINE: Defending Harlem: Residents Weigh In

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As an African-American who has lived in Harlem for 10 years (I moved to New York from Ohio to attend business school at Columbia University), I read Lisa Anderson's report of her year in Harlem with interest, dismay and anger ("Harlem on Her Mind," Nov. 19). Not until the last three paragraphs of a page-and-a-half story does she concede that some of her negative reactions could be due to herself rather than the community. 
 In Harlem I have found a church where I have been welcomed, an apartment at a reasonable price, a job I can walk to from home and friends I am anxious to return to when I am away.
I work in the field of community development, and therefore I am as familiar as anyone with the problems of poverty, unemployment and drugs that face Harlem. But there are people who have moved in, or never left, who are living their lives in a community where they feel comfortable while trying to make positive contributions toward improving it.
 
KEVIN MCGRUDER
Harlem

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

Monday
 
The Indian state government of Maharashtra is expected to make its final decision on whether to let the Enron Corporation build a much-disputed multibillion power plant. An approval is probable, but not certain.
 
Tuesday
 
A House subcommittee on financial institutions is to hold another hearing on Daiwa Bank. The chairmen of the Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation are to testify, along with the Comptroller of the Currency.
 
Ford will release its sales for November. Chrysler had a strong month, but General Motors' sales fell. Both reported on Friday.
 
Wednesday
 
Three important reports come out on the economy in October, with a mixed view expected. The index of leading indicators fell three-tenths of 1 percent, according to a consensus estimate, after falling one-tenth of a point in September. Construction spending was expected to have risen six-tenths of a point, for its fifth straight rise. Spending was up 1.2 percent in September. And factory orders were probably flat for the month, after rising 1.5 percent.
 
Thursday
 
The Fed will report consumer credit for October. Consumers added an estimated $6.3 billion to their debt, after piling on $5.4 billion in September.
 
Venezuelan oil workers, who have been threatening a strike in a pay dispute, could begin their walkout today. It would affect oil deliveries to the United States, and a shortage could drive up prices.
 
Friday
 
The Labor Department will report November employment figures. The overall jobless rate is expected to edge up one-tenth of a point, to 5.6 percent. But the number of nonfarm jobs created in the month is expected to rise by 192,000, after gaining 116,000 during October.

HEADLINE: Bridgeport's Dog Track: Other Views

 BODY:
In the article "A Dog Track to Help Revive Bridgeport," Shoreline Star manager James F. Gartland asserts that the "activists are disseminating information from 20 years ago" and that accusations of mistreatment of greyhounds are "not accurate now."
The dog racing industry stands to gain the most from a public kept ignorant of the issues. We continue to support the belief that it is in the public's best interest to know the facts.
The facts include very real, very recent documented cases of abuse and neglect compiled by the Greyhound Protection League since the group's inception in the late 1980's.
The greyhound racing industry contributes to this carnage because it fosters overbreeding at greyhound farms in an attempt to produce the next champion.
Julia Barnes, a member of the greyhound racing industry herself and the author of "The Complete Book of Greyhounds" (Howell Books, 1994) states that 30,000 to 40,000 greyhounds a year are destroyed. The industry does not make "every effort to find these dogs homes."
The dogs that are not profitable make up these huge numbers. Unprofitable greyhounds include those not fast enough to win money, dogs with a low chase drive or dogs who have raced (average racing career length: 2.5 years, tops) and are now retired at the ripe old age of 4.
Every greyhound one day will eventually fall into at least one of these categories. Though they make wonderful pets, only 13,000 to 15,000 greyhounds a year are able to find homes in an increasingly saturated adoption market. The overbreeding cycle continues year after year.
The public has a right to judge for itself. Is it acceptable in this day and age that tens of thousands of greyhounds die every year for amusement? If gambling is Bridgeport's only perceived economic strategy for growth then let it be in a more humane form.
 
MELANI NARDONE
Stamford
 
The writer is a member of the Greyhound Protection League.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Outsiders Gone, Cambodia Unravels

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia

 BODY:
THE offices of a struggling independent newspaper are ransacked by ax-wielding villagers, and the Prime Minister applauds. A new opposition party is declared illegal before it is formally launched. Grenades explode at the office of an independent-minded senior politician, and in the courtyard of a Buddhist temple that has been sheltering his supporters.
This is newly democratic Cambodia. 
 Barely alive after decades of civil war, genocide and foreign occupation, Cambodia is inching toward the precipice again. But this time, the stakes are not limited to the future of this land alone. The reputation and judgment of the United Nations will also be on the line if the world's good intentions come to grief again in a small place where old habits and hatreds are stronger than new constitutions adopted to foster peace, and where the world intervened with its alarm clock already set to the moment when it would withdraw.
So Cambodia's experience offers a cautionary tale about the setting of clockwork deadlines by outsiders for the achievement of their good intentions -- a tale worth considering as NATO ventures onto the ground in Bosnia, on the basis of President Clinton's prediction that a year's time will be enough before the 20,000 truce-monitoring G.I.'s can be brought home.
It seems particularly worth studying as another deadline approaches -- for the departure of United Nations peacekeepers from Haiti in February, amid ominous signs that home-grown distrust, poverty and demagogy in that country may yet overwhelm the calm instilled little more than a year ago with the arrival of another expedition of 20,000 American troops.
In Cambodia, the deadline came two years ago, when the United Nations Transitional Authority wound up the most ambitious and costly (at about $3 billion) experiment in rebuilding a nation ever attempted by the organization.
The two-year operation was certainly no failure -- it had forestalled a threatened political resurgence of the murderous Khmer Rouge -- and it was hailed as a model for other collapsed countries.
More than 360,000 refugees were returned to their homeland, thousands of development experts and peacekeepers descended from all corners of the world, and Cambodians got a crash course in civics and held a national election in 1993, as had been promised by the U.N. operation's viceroy, Yasushi Akashi.
But, like President Clinton in Bosnia, Mr. Akashi was working under a deadline, and when the peacekeepers went home, it was not by any means the end of the story. Today, there are still more than two years to go before the next national election, the first to be run by Cambodians. And politicians are already engaged in a high-stakes struggle for power to which lives and reputations are being sacrificed.
Political thuggery is on the rise and a precarious economy is swamped in corruption; the economy, in fact, is expanding more on laundered money -- including cash from a flourishing narcotics trade -- than on aboveboard investment. Cambodians and foreign security officers say that drunken soldiers from an undisciplined, underpaid army cause much more violence in the countryside than the remnant bands of Khmer Rouge that are still on the loose.
The situation is such that last week, the Associated Press reported, King Norodom Sihanouk wrote in a letter to a British journalist: "I am very sad that I cannot save either democracy or the monarchy in my country."
Where did the United Nations falter, if the fault lies there? What can the organization, which still maintains a large presence here through its agencies, do now? How long should it be responsible for this country's fate?
Part of the problem was intractable from the start: Cambodia is in a bad neighborhood for democracy, standing almost alone in Southeast Asia as a near-democratic state. One-party dominance is more the rule than the exception in the region, and corrupt business practices and venal politicians are the norm.
But other problems might have been foreseen. For example, the United Nations saw fit not to take over and reform key ministries; instead, it left in place a civil service, police and military dominated by a former Marxist regime with no history of political pluralism, no understanding of judicial independence and no concept of civic administration beyond party rule. Given the time constraints of the deadline for withdrawal, which was set to follow the 1993 election, this seemed reasonable at the time.
But one result is that Cambodia remains largely administered by the often corrupt and autocratic cadres of the Cambodian People's Party, led by Second Prime Minister Hun Sen, a former Khmer Rouge official who had led the pre-agreement Government installed by the Vietnamese Army. It was Mr. Hun Sen's loyal gang that attacked the newspaper, New Liberty News.
Mr. Hun Sen's party did not win the 1993 election. It was edged out by the royalists, whose Prince Norodom Ranariddh is First Prime Minister and Mr. Hun Sen's senior partner in a coalition. But the large constituency of the popular royalist party is not represented fairly in the administration or the courts. Its secretary general, Prince Norodom Sirivudh, half-brother of King Sihanouk and a former foreign minister, was arrested two weeks ago and accused of plotting to kill Mr. Hun Sen. The arrest was political, Prince Sirivudh said, and diplomats and Amnesty International were quick to agree.
For opposition leaders -- Son Sann, whose Buddhist Liberal Democratic Party was attacked with grenades, and Sam Rainsy, a former finance minister sick of corruption who formed the new Khmer Nation party -- the road to the polls looks hazardous indeed in such an atmosphere. And so, hopes for a true multiparty election in two years are dying.
 
More Cards to Play
 The United Nations still holds a few important cards, and how these are played will be instructive. After the Transitional Authority withdrew in 1993, the United Nations Center for Human Rights in Cambodia was opened in Phnom Penh, with the task of training local officials and compiling reports. "We're not here just because we want to be," said Daniel Premont, the center's director, just after releasing a tough report in November to which the Government took exception. "Cambodia has been absent from the international community for 20 years, and they didn't realize that they needed training on how to abide by their international obligations and meet international standards."
At the province level, the center works with local groups to stiffen the resolve of weak magistrates and judges in the face of police terror. The United Nations, which has learned the importance of involving traditional authority in democratization, also applauds the support the democratic process has had at crucial moments from 73-year-old King Sihanouk, who reclaimed his throne in 1993. At the grassroots level, the center tries to reach out to Cambodia's influential monks, to build understanding of universal rights and to counter criticism that the United Nations is inflicting Western ideas on Asians.
A number of Cambodians say the United Nations may have to defend the center more vigorously and publicly to save it. And many of these advocates of democracy want the U.N. to return in force to run the next election.
All of this has ominous echoes for any certainty that a year from now, Bosnia will be able to stand tranquilly on its own.
Cambodia and Bosnia are very different places, and a polyglot United Nations force has far less power to accomplish its mission in a short time than does a heavily armed NATO force in its own backyard. But in both cases (if for different reasons) the idea of restarting national life according to a fixed schedule has become an end in itself. And in both situations, there has been much fuzziness about how sketchily-drawn political institutions are to operate once the troops withdraw.
Chea Sokha, who became a liaison at a Western embassy after surviving the Khmer Rouge's reign of terror, fleeing the Vietnamese occupation and spending eight years in a refugee camp in Thailand, sums up Cambodia's experience this way: "The United Nations planted the seeds of democracy. But someone has to be here to fertilize and care for it. Cambodian democracy is still a very fragile thing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, shown at a ceremony last April, fears for democracy's future. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: COMPASSION PLAY;
Less Is More: Faith and Facts in Welfare Reform

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE liberals' War on Poverty has been an unmitigated disaster. While the Government has thrown trillions of dollars at the problem, the misery has only grown. The cities are filled with 14-year-old mothers and 30-year-old grandmothers and 45-year-old drug addicts who never held a job. Never have so many suffered so much at the hands of "compassionate" government.
These are the arguments that Republicans are using to drive American social policy toward a historic U-turn. As the House of Representatives voted this fall for unprecedented cuts in the antipoverty budget, its ebullient members claimed the mantle of compassion. "Today, what we have shown is that we are a caring country," said Christopher Shays of Connecticut. "Instead of giving the food, we are going to help people learn to grow the food." 
 Cuts are compassionate; less is more. "We committed to reform welfare because what we are doing to the poor in America is destructive and immoral," House Speaker Newt Gingrich said last week, in railing at what he calls "30 years of absolute failure in Washington." In other words: Things couldn't possibly get worse.
Or could they?
It's true that for two decades the fight against poverty has, at best, looked like a draw, its successes forgotten and its failures on painful display. From housing to Head Start, programs have stagnated, bureaucracies have ossified, and new ideas seem scarce. Liberalism has courted its own loss of credibility, and no program is more discredited than Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the nation's main cash welfare program.
It's also true that the Republican plan to abolish A.F.D.C. rests on a huge -- and risky -- leap of faith. The plan heading for President Clinton's desk would turn over welfare to the states, with less money and strict time limits on benefits. (Most people could receive no more than five years of aid throughout their lives, and most states would probably set limits much lower.) Those changes would be accompanied by significant reductions in food stamps, Medicaid, housing and disability programs.
 
Early Evidence
 While the Republicans promise that the poor will prosper, the evidence does not. Indeed, most suggests the opposite: whether the economy or poor people are ultimately to blame, most will fail to replace their lost benefits. If the past is a guide, less will not mean more. Less will mean less, for those who already have little.
Consider the closest thing the country has to a test case. In 1991, Michigan abruptly cut off aid to 80,000 adults. Gov. John Engler argued that the move would motivate them to find work. But two years later, only 20 percent had steady jobs, according to researchers at the University of Michigan, while another 17 percent had found informal work like raking leaves.
If the bulk of the others skirted catastrophe, that was mostly by turning to other government programs. Some people did advance, says Sandra K. Danziger, the study's lead author. But half lost their health insurance, many doubled up, and "most were worse off two years after welfare ended."
 
Expensive Repairs
 No one likes the current system, which insults taxpayers and poor people alike. But most of the evidence suggests that fixing it for the long term requires more money -- to subsidize jobs and provide child care to those required to take them. The House Republicans' proposals of just a year ago recognized as much, proposing to spend an extra $10 billion to put recipients to work. Then budget-cutting fever took hold, and with it the idea for the largest reduction of public aid in American history.
What follows are four tenets of the abolitionists' faith, and some relevant findings:
The programs don't help much anyway.
From afar it often seems that way. No one on welfare is prospering. But the system, flawed and reviled as it is, may confer unrecognized benefits. Kathryn Edin, a sociologist at Rutgers University, tried to gauge them through extensive interviews with women in high- and low-benefit states.
Women in low-benefit states were nearly twice as likely to become homeless, lose their utilities, go without food or experience one of seven other hardship conditions. "The way the political discourse is being spun, we're forgetting that if you lower benefits, children could go without food," she said.
International comparisons yield similar conclusions. Europe and Canada offer higher payments to low-income families, and they have markedly lower levels of poverty.
But the poor will be better off by working.
Or will they? No one knows how many of the five million women on A.F.D.C. will be able to find and keep work. Many have few skills and lead the kinds of chaotic lives that interfere with full-time work: sick kids, dangerous neighborhoods, abusive boyfriends, broken cars.
Federal law would allow states to exempt 15 percent of the caseload from the five-year limit. Will that be enough?
Last summer, the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation of New York released figures on the most successful welfare-to-work program to date. The program, run in Atlanta, Grand Rapids, Mich., and Riverside, Calif., forced recipients to look for jobs. Two years later their earnings had risen 26 percent -- but to a level still alarmingly low: an average of $285 a month.
That figure includes those not working at all -- more than half of those in the program. Assume a best case: without welfare to fall back on, many more women do find work. How will they fare? Ms. Edin's work is again instructive.
In addition to the welfare recipients, she studied comparable mothers laboring away as cashiers and clerks. Most expressed the psychic satisfactions of making it on their own. But while their incomes went up, so did expenses for child care and transportation. In the end, many had even less than their welfare counterparts. To Ms. Edin's surprise, the working mothers were 45 percent more likely than those on welfare to experience one of her listed hardships.
 
A 6-Cent Raise
 But earnings will improve with time.
So burger flipping doesn't pay. But stay on the job, gain some experience, and a supervisor's job awaits. Or does it? Again, the evidence is not conclusive, but it is discouraging. Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, tracked a group of welfare recipients from 1979 to 1990. Their wages rose each year by about six cents an hour, or a little less than one percent, after accounting for inflation.
Not all had stayed on the job continuously -- no such study exists -- but Mr. Burtless says the figures show that most unskilled laborers can expect their earnings to rise "very, very slowly."
Rebecca Blank, an economist at Northwestern University, notes that welfare recipients are sailing into a headwind, since wages of low-skilled workers have been falling for nearly two decades. If anything, competition among millions of former recipients may depress wages further. "There's little evidence that women with few skills can expect to see big wage increases, even if they stay in the labor market long term," Ms. Blank said.
We're really after the next generation.
O.K., adults on welfare may be too far gone, but eliminating welfare will push kids to stay in school, avoid pregnancy, marry and work. Here is where hope is highest -- and evidence on all sides is thinnest.
Maybe the poor will show new depths of resolve, as most Americans have through two centuries of boom, bust, war and peace. Or maybe, lacking welfare, they'll turn to panhandling, drug sales, child neglect or prostitution. No one really knows.
But one way to look at ending welfare is this: it proposes to make the cost of failing so severe that the poor will have no choice but to shape up. It's the social policy equivalent of a gun to the head, and for some, it may just work. But if misery alone were motive enough, wouldn't the failures of the past -- the legacy of neediness and despair that the Republicans rightly criticize -- already have done the trick?

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Cuba, a Tax On Capitalism

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
IT was Jan. 1, 1959, when Fidel Castro seized power and initiated Cuba's transformation into a Marxist-Leninist state. But when the 37th anniversary of the Cuban Revolution rolls around next month, it will be accompanied by the restoration of a staple of capitalism -- the personal income tax.
In an official statement of this officially classless nation, the Ministry of Finance and Prices said last week that the tax would "permit a just redistribution of income to finance social programs that benefit all the population, with a greater contribution from those who have a superior economic capability." 
 In blunter terms, the Government is going after newly affluent Cubans who earn money in dollars and other foreign currency, and recognizing that Cuban society is increasingly divided between those who have access to dollars and those who don't.
 
The Greenback Gap
 Until 1993, it was not legal for Cubans to possess, much less earn salaries in, dollars. Now, as part of Mr. Castro's reluctant embrace of some market policies to arrest the decline in living standards that followed the Soviet bloc's collapse, several hundred thousand Cubans do. They range from hotel and restaurant employees in the flourishing tourist sector -- who are prosperous by Cuban standards -- to workers in industries like mining and sugar who receive small hard-currency bonuses on top of peso salaries that amount to as little as $5 a month.
This summer, the Government also made it legal to open small privately run restaurants, known as paladares, that do business in dollars. It sometimes seems that new paladares open daily on every block in Havana, so eager are Cubans to go into business for themselves.
Since the new income tax does not apply to peso salaries, it is likely to affect few Cubans, at least at first. Those who earn up to $2,400 a year in foreign currency will pay 10 percent of their salaries, with the rate rising to 50 percent for the tiny number who earn more than $60,000.
Significantly, the decree does not apply to the dollars sent to Cubans by relatives abroad. Those remittances, most from the United States, are estimated at more than $400 million a year and have become a key support of Cuba's economy. By some calculations, 40 percent of families in Havana and 20 percent in the provinces receive some support from family members overseas.
Cubans, who have not paid income taxes since the truly unequal pre-1959 days, join Russians and Poles, Czechs and Slovaks and other citizens of newly capitalist countries who are now paying income taxes. Even China has adopted an income tax, aimed at the rapidly commercializing coastal areas.
With Mr. Castro traveling this week in China, which has increasingly become Cuba's model of how to open an economy without ceding political control, a search for additional sources of revenue can be expected. The Finance Ministry plans to tax rental income, and a new graduated system of taxes for Cuba's 200,000 self-employed, who now pay a fixed monthly quota regardless of what they make, is in the offing.
Enforcement may prove more complicated, however. The legislation permitting taxation of foreign currency earnings was passed during the summer of 1994, providing ample time for those Cubans fortunate enough to be earning dollars to figure out ways to evade taxes.
"Sure, they can withhold money off the top from the poor suckers who work in the hotels or restaurants," said an architect who earns more in one evening as an unauthorized taxicab driver than he does in an entire month at his official job. "But that's no reason for me to declare every last cent."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Consult Polls. Choose Phrase. Repeat.

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT was sometime in late summer that President Clinton began talking almost incessantly about values.
"We have to think anew about what our basic values are, what kind of people we are," he told an elderly audience in Miami during a cross-country swing in September. 
 Since then there's hardly been a speech by the President that doesn't in some way incorporate the V-word. In one oratorical flight last week, in the very same address, Mr. Clinton said, "I hope we can balance the budget in a way that is true to our fundamental values," and later added, "Peace in Bosnia is important to America, to both our values and our interests."
Yesterday in Germany, he repeated the refrain, telling American troops, "It is in our nation's interest and consistent with our values to see that this peace endures."
Mr. Clinton, of course, is hardly the first person in politics to discover that the word "values" resonates in a Pavlovian way with the American public, causing the same kinds of good feelings as words like patriotism or family.
The Republicans, after all, have been talking about family values for years. When Senator Bob Dole proposed several months ago that English be made the nation's official language, he said, "Language, history and values: these are the strings that bind our hearts to America."
And Ben Wattenberg, the neoconservative author, has just written a book called "Values Matter Most."
But why does Washington sound like an echo chamber? In part, it's because there are now scores of consultants in both parties who test market concepts, mood, and even individual words through polls and focus groups. But it is also because through all these mounds of research Democrats have found that Republicans, who first began talking about values, are onto something. Maybe it's really not the economy, stupid.
It is generally agreed among political professionals that Michael Dukakis lost the Presidential race in 1988 by talking determinedly about programs and policy while George Bush's campaign kept hammering away at the idea that Mr. Dukakis was out of step with American values.
Since then, both parties have found that the public's preoccupation with values, its feeling that something has gone morally wrong in society, has only deepened.
"Something we've seen over many years is that values, the decline of values, is one of the core concerns of the American public," said Mark Mellman, a Democratic political consultant who works for the Democratic leadership in Congress. "There's no question about that. And we Democrats have been at the short end of that stick. We've been unwilling to talk about values and left the playing field to the Republicans."
The longing for a simpler time of old-fashioned values is so pervasive that pollsters say people will respond more positively to complex issues like health care policy or the containment of Medicare spending if they are presented as fundamental questions of values rather than simply as matters of public policy.
"When we talk about education, we make the argument stronger when we talk about the value we put on education," Mr. Mellman said.
Mr. Clinton in 1992 was one of the first Democrats to tread squarely onto Republican turf and start speaking about values, setting out the theme that he would provide a "New Covenant" between Government and its citizens.
 
It Started in '94
 The President's aides say he started refocusing heavily on values and the need to have a Democratic values agenda in the wake of the Republican sweep of the 1994 Congressional elections.
But he didn't immediately start using the word "values" as his core rhetorical device. Instead, Mr. Clinton tried to tap into the public dismay at partisanship and political gridlock that has given rise to the third-party movement.
His phrase of choice from spring through summer was "common ground," with its connotation of centrism, togetherness and community. So when discussing the budget fight with Congress, he said, "I have shown we can't balance the budget without retreating from our common ground on education, health care, on the environment."
Of religion in the schools, Mr. Clinton said, "The First Amendment keeps us all on common ground." Republican proposals to slow the growth in Medicare were to be condemned because they "will break up America's common ground."
To make the contrast between himself and the Republicans, he also took care to brand them as far outside the mainstream. The Republican budget "is too extreme" he said, and of Republican positions on abortion, "This seems to be to be extreme."
The phrase common ground still shows up occasionally in Mr. Clinton's speeches but it stopped striking quite the right tone after Labor Day when the White House began an all-out public campaign against the Republican budget priorities.
And so Mr. Clinton switched to values, and to what amounted to a linguistic war to define the values at work in the budget debate. Americans might think that balancing the budget represents an important value. But the White House wanted them to think that "honoring our obligations to our citizens through Medicare and Medicaid" is also an important value.
Republicans simply dismiss the possibility that Mr. Clinton, who has been haunted by questions of marital infidelity and the impression that he changes positions along with the polls, will really be able to make much headway by talking about values.
 
'A Difficult Sale'
 "President Clinton is a curious choice to address problems with morality," said Whit Ayres, a Republican pollster who is working for former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, a Republican Presidential candidate. "I think it will be a difficult sale for him to make."
Kathleen Hall Jamieson, the dean of the Annenberg School for Communications at the University of Pennsylvania, calls values "the cliche of the discourse of the 1996 campaign" and thinks the word has already lost potency.
"When a phrase becomes a common place of political discourse," she said, "it loses its ability to convey meaning. It runs the risk that Kleenex runs when it becomes the generic word for tissues."
