HEADLINE: Welcome Mat Is Wearing Thin for G.I.'s in Asia

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Half a century after American troops waded ashore on Japan and liberated Korea, a growing number of people are suggesting that it is time they left.
There appears to be the beginning of a broad debate about whether the United States still needs nearly 100,000 troops based in Japan and South Korea. 
 It is not that college students are marching about chanting "Yankee imperialists go home," as they did in the 1960's. Rather, people are simply asking aloud who the enemy is in the post-cold-war world. And they are chafing at the crimes by American soldiers, the cost of their presence, even the noise of the fighter jets zooming overhead.
Some Japanese, Koreans and Americans alike worry that a far-reaching dynamic is under way that may lead to a dramatic reduction in the United States troop presence in Asia. They fear that this would be a disaster for the region, setting off an arms race and major new wars that might ultimately involve the United States.
The starting point for a growing number of Japanese and South Koreans is that in security relations the United States has too good a deal.
"We've been yes-men, a yes-country," said Lee Chul, a member of the opposition in the National Assembly in South Korea. "It's about time that the U.S. listened to the voices of the South Korean Government and the South Korean people."
In Japan, the irritations were evident in a recent magazine headline that said the recent rape of an Okinawa schoolgirl, in which three American servicemen were charged, proved "Japan Is Still a Colony." The magazine added that "in the face of such humiliation" Japan should not increase its payments for the American troop presence.
American critics of the bases agree that security relations are unfair, but in a different way. They protest that it is unjust that the United States not only provides troops who risk their lives for Japan and South Korea, but also pays tens of billions of dollars for the privilege.
To be sure, most Japanese, South Korean and American officials alike want to keep a presence by American troops. The United States now has 37,000 troops in South Korea and nearly 47,000 in Japan, plus 13,000 sailors whose home port is in Japan.
"The importance to East Asia, to the Asia-Pacific region, and to the entire world of a continued U.S. presence here, and the continuation of the strong security relationship between the United States and Japan, can scarcely be overstated," Vice President Al Gore said during a visit to Japan last month.
Yet a growing self-confidence and nationalism in Asia are leading to demands that the United States adjust its presence in ways that it may find difficult to accept. Some South Koreans are demanding that American military personnel pay Korean taxes. Americans, however, have trouble understanding why they should send their soldiers to Korea, pay most of the bill and then pay again in the form of taxes.
 
Lessons of Manila Haunt Seoul and Tokyo
 In the back of everyone's mind is the memory of what happened in the Philippines a few years ago.
The United States wanted to keep Subic Naval Base and Clark Air Field. But negotiations between the United States and the Philippines broke into bickering over minor matters, and rising nationalism led to a vote in the Philippines' Senate to evict the American bases. So in 1992, the United States closed Subic and Clark.
Very few people expect that to happen in Japan or South Korea, but many will not rule out the possibility either.
"There is a trend, both within Japan and in the United States, with the end of the cold war, with budget cutbacks, with a younger generation of Americans and Japanese, that the necessity of having 47,000 troops stationed in Japan is seeming less and less viable in both countries," said Glen S. Fukushima, a former American trade official who is now a business executive in Tokyo.
Mr. Fukushima said that the most likely scenario is that public support will decline but that elites in both countries will continue to support the Japanese-American security alliance and that most American troops will remain in Japan.
Concerns about criticism of the American bases was one of the reasons that President Clinton planned a state visit to Japan -- now postponed until sometime next year -- to reaffirm the security relationship.
Japanese and South Korean leaders have been reluctant to come out in the same way and build support for American bases, perhaps because they do not want to be seen as being on the wrong side of a delicate nationalistic issue. As a result, the perception among ordinary Japanese and South Koreans is that it is really the United States that is pushing for the military presence.
"Japanese leaders have not really explained things to the people," said Yukio Okamoto, a former diplomat who runs a consulting firm in Tokyo. He noted that President Clinton had urged support for the security alliance in a television interview broadcast to Japan a few days ago, and he added, referring to Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama, "President Clinton was doing the job that Murayama should have been doing, and that's a shame."
A recent poll in the Sankei Shimbun, a Japanese newspaper, found that only 5 percent of those surveyed said they believed that the American bases are primarily for Japan's benefit. About 46 percent said they are in Japan primarily for the benefit of the United States. Most of the rest say the bases benefit both countries.
<HB >An Old Refrain: Yankees Go Home
 The irritation at the American bases is not ideological as it was in the 1960's, when university students dabbled in Marxism and waved their fists at American troops and their involvement in the Vietnam War. Now the opposition is less deep, but polls suggest it is broader.
The Sankei Shimbun poll suggested that 44 percent of Japanese favored the withdrawal of American troops. Only 31 percent favored a continued American military presence.
A poll by another newspaper, the Asahi Shimbun, found that 76 percent of Japanese say they believe that American bases on the island of Okinawa should be reduced gradually.
When the Liberal Democratic Party, Japan's largest party, was choosing a leader in September, one of the two candidates even said in a television debate that American bases were no longer essential. That candidate, Junichiro Koizumi, said the problem was that the United States was asking Japan to pay more of the costs of maintaining the troops.
"Japan has been paying as much as it can," Mr. Koizumi said. "If the United States cannot bear the stationing costs of the U.S. forces in Japan, then we will have to ask them to reduce military personnel and bases."
Mr. Koizumi lost the race, but the winner -- Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Trade Minister and a strong contender to become the next Prime Minister -- also has a reputation as a nationalistic and assertive leader. Mr. Hashimoto has endorsed the American troop presence, but not in ringing terms.
In both South Korea and Japan, part of the yearning for change is the result of a generational shift and a desire for greater national dignity.
"The Korean War generation is dying out, and 70 percent of Koreans were born after the war," said Lee Young Duk, an editor at Chosun Ilbo, a major Seoul newspaper. "We have a more stable economy as well, and so we're talking about matters of pride. There are more voices calling for an increasingly equal relationship with America."
Shin Myung Soon, a professor of political science at Yonsei University in Seoul, said: "Koreans are beginning to think that we can do what we want. People don't see North Korea as such a lethal threat, so they don't feel so dependent on the U.S. presence."
 
Rape Has Become A Foreign Policy Issue
 The demands for adjusting the American military presence take many forms. There are periodic calls to move American bases out of populated areas -- one base is in Seoul, and Naha, the Okinawa capital, is an American military port.
In addition, South Koreans and Japanese complain about crimes by American military personnel. The latest outcry in Japan against the bases was set off by the rape of a 12-year-old girl, in which three American servicemen are charged.
All three servicemen have pleaded guilty to conspiracy to abduct and rape the girl, although only one has admitted to forcibly having sex with her.
Many Japanese and Koreans demand that Americans suspected of crimes be handed over immediately to face local justice. But to Americans, local justice sometimes seems like an oxymoron.
There are no jury trials in either Japan or South Korea, and police interrogators are often accused of using harsh methods of questioning to induce confessions. Nonetheless, the United States agreed recently to consider handing over troops suspected of rape or murder in Japan, and a similar agreement -- with some procedural protections for Americans -- is being negotiated in South Korea.
At present, American military personnel are handed over to local authorities in Japan upon indictment of a crime and in South Korean upon conviction.
 
Resentment at the PX: Cheap Cars and TV's
 Some South Koreans complain that American military people can import duty-free household goods, and that the United States military does not pay rent for the land it uses. But any changes in those policies would add to the American cost of keeping soldiers in South Korea.
By official calculations the United States already pays 88 percent of the costs of the American presence in Korea. As for Japan, Tokyo claims to pay 70 percent of the costs of the American forces in Japan, but that calculation excludes the troops' salaries; when salaries are included, Japan's share drops to half.
The Pentagon justifies the bases in Japan by saying it is cheaper to base troops here than to keep them in the United States. But much depends on how the figures are calculated, and the Cato Institute in Washington figures that the United States pays vast amounts -- about $40 billion a year -- to keep troops in Asia.
Americans sometimes complain that Japan is cutting its own armed forces at the same time that it is asking the United States to keep troops in the region. Just a few days ago, the Japanese Cabinet approved a far-reaching plan calling for a 20 percent cut in the ceiling of troops in the Japanese military.
Congress has supported the cost of maintaining 100,000 American troops in the region. But there are some rumblings of discontent from the United States, based in part on the expense involved.
"The existing U.S.-Japanese security relationship is simply not sustainable in the long term," declares a report issued last month by the Cato Institute.
In the United States, a recent poll found that 7 percent of those surveyed favored an immediate withdrawal from American bases in Japan, while another 49 percent supported a gradual withdrawal.
 
American Troops As Cops of Asia
 Yet the Pentagon and almost all countries in Asia fervently want the American bases to remain. One danger of an American pullout they cite is that North Korea or China might become militarily adventurous -- an invasion by China of Taiwan, for example, would send shock waves through all of Asia.
Walter F. Mondale, the American Ambassador in Tokyo, was anything but hawkish as a politician. But now he argues vigorously for maintaining American bases in Asia.
"Asia does not have a NATO-type security alliance, and none seems to be possible for some time," Mr. Mondale said. "So the real basis for stability in this crucial and historically unstable region is the U.S.-Japan alliance, which provides for the defense of Japan and permits us to forward deploy our forces."
Mr. Mondale says the bases are so widely viewed as essential that ways will be found to maintain them. He sees little chance of a scenario like the one that unfolded in the Philippines, leading to a major cutback.
The other argument often made for the bases is that they not only protect Japan, but also protect against Japan. The idea is that if the United States withdrew its troops, Japan would rearm and perhaps even acquire nuclear weapons.
Such a development would horrify almost everybody in Asia. The former Singapore leader, Lee Kuan Yew, expressed the concern when he warned that allowing Japan to send troops abroad would be "like giving a chocolate liqueur to an alcoholic."

HEADLINE: Rise in Cigarette Tax Planned To Finance Care for the Poor

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Facing a Dec. 31 deadline to replenish a state fund for hospital care of the poor, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the Legislature's Republican leadership have agreed to raise some of the money by increasing the cigarette tax by as much as 25 cents a pack.
The Republican lawmakers, who control the Legislature, had put off action on the issue during the election season. But while increasing the cigarette tax is not expected to create a public furor, the Republicans hope to limit any political damage by enlisting Democrats with the argument that the hospitals most in need of the state money are in Democratic districts. 
 "This must be a bipartisan solution," said the Assembly Speaker, Chuck Haytaian, a Warren County Republican who did not run for re-election and will be leaving at the end of the 206th Legislative session on Jan. 8. "The revenues are going to urban, inner-city hospitals and therefore, those legislators who have the most to gain or lose are the Democrats because they represent those areas."
But Democratic lawmakers have been reluctant to support any new taxes since they were badly punished by the voters for approving former Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax package in 1990. Republicans used that tax increase to take control of the Legislature and roll back a portion of the tax package.
"It would be a very difficult decision," said Assembly Minority Leader Joseph V. Doria Jr., a Hudson County Democrat, of the proposed cigarette tax increase. "We would not be that supportive, but nobody has given us any of the actual facts of the case."
A 25-cent tax increase would bring the average price of a pack of cigarettes in New Jersey to about $2.50. In the Republican-controlled upper chamber, State Senator Jack G. Sinagra, a Middlesex County Republican who is chairman of the Senate Health Committee, argued that the new source of income was urgent.
"I have no problem with the cigarette tax because there is no question that there is a direct correlation between tobacco and health care costs," he said. "We're talking about health care and jobs in urban areas. The hospitals that receive the most charity care have the most critical cash flow needs. I think the Democrats would be very foolish for them not to participate."
The Republican argument is intended to mute any Democratic criticism of Mrs. Whitman's reversal on the tax cuts for which she has become so famous, though Carl Golden, chief spokesman for Mrs. Whitman, said the Governor had never said she would never raise taxes. "Here you have a program that takes care of the working poor," he said. "The Legislature and the Governor, obviously, want to see the program continue."
Because New Jersey has no public hospitals, care of the indigent in private hospitals is subsidized by the state. Almost $400 million has been distributed this year to 84 hospitals to help pay for treatment for people who are not eligible for Medicaid but who cannot afford to pay. Although state officials insist that the money is badly needed, a Health Department spokesman said the department did not know how many people had been served by the program.
Since 1993, New Jersey has financed the program by diverting almost $1.6 billion from the state's Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund, virtually wiping out much of the fund's surplus. The Governor and Legislative leaders, under pressure from organized labor and business leaders to stop draining the unemployment fund, agreed this year to consider alternatives before the authorization for the present system expires on Dec. 31.
State officials say that about $300 million is needed in the coming year to finance the hospital care program. An additional $100 million to $150 million is needed to pay for Health Access New Jersey, a state-subsidized health insurance program for residents who meet certain income requirements and are not eligible for employer-sponsored health coverage or Medicaid. For example, a family of four with an income up to $37,875 is eligible to buy insurance through the program, which was authorized by the Legislature in 1992 and started this year.
In addition to raising the cigarette tax, expected to bring in between $100 and $125 million in new revenue, the Governor and Legislative leaders are discussing several other options to pay for the two programs. Those options include a smaller diversion from the unemployment fund and possibly up to $75 million from the state's general funds. Legislative leaders have dismissed a Whitman administration proposal outlined to hospital officials last month that would impose a 1.5 percent tax on hospital revenues.
Even though the deal on the tax increase has been fashioned, the newly elected Speaker of the Assembly, Jack Collins, a Republican from Salem County, said he is not happy about the increase.
"I believe that there are some people whose only enjoyment in life is a cigarette and a beer," Mr. Collins said. "That is all they can afford. They can't go to Bermuda. They can't go skiing in the Rockies. This is it. We are going to say to them, well, we are going to make you pay more money for your enjoyment, you one select group of people. That just bothers me."

HEADLINE: Showing Europe That U.S. Still Cares

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 2

 BODY:
One goal of President Clinton's trip to Western Europe is to dispel a growing anxiety that America is losing interest in its long-time trading partner and ally.
With the fall of Communism, and vast new markets in Asia and Latin America beckoning, Washington has focused away from Western Europe. Politically, Americans and their lawmakers are looking inward. 
 But on Sunday in Madrid, Mr. Clinton will move to strengthen American relations with Europe. He plans to sign a document specifying more than 120 joint studies, initiatives, projects, proposals, agreements, goals and expectations, with the aim of freshening the American-European alliance and reconciling old friends.
While the agreement should make it easier to sell foreign-made goods in the United States or Europe, it will not do all that much to promote an accord along the lines of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
On the political front, the agreement nearly spans the globe, calling for joint efforts in the Middle East, the former Soviet bloc, Bosnia and Korea. It also calls for closer cooperation on fighting drug trafficking, illegal immigration and organized crime.
In the trade area, it is to create a Trans-Atlantic Marketplace, where tariffs and nontariff barriers between the United States and Europe will be reduced.
"There was real concern in Europe that the United States was downgrading its relationship with its allies, concern the relations were going to atrophy," said Stuart E. Eizenstat, United States Ambassador to the European Union in Brussels. "I think this shows Europe remains our most important market and the region where we have the most common ground."
Mr. Eizenstat said that under the agreement, tariffs on European imports of computer equipment and semiconductors would be cut by as much as half, and both sides would commit themselves to harmonizing testing standards across a host of industries. For example, a pharmaceutical approved and tested in Europe could be sold in the United States without further testing.
But many economists and political analysts are already asking whether the agreement represents a lot of words aimed mainly at soothing hurt feelings, or an initiative that will open up business flow and genuine political cooperation.
One aspect is clear: it is by no means what some initially envisioned. Many leaders called for the creation of a Trans-Atlantic Free Trade Zone. They included Prime Minister John Major of Britain, Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada, senior political leaders like Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of Germany and business leaders like Edzard Reuter, former chairman of Daimler-Benz.
The logic seemed impeccable. The United States and Canada created such an accord with Mexico, hoping to extend it to all of Latin America. In Europe, United States business involvement is much higher, tariffs are much lower and business practices so similar that a trans-Atlantic free trade zone, or Tafta, as it came to be called, would be far easier than negotiating Nafta. Even the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said it would support such a deal because wages in the two continents were so similar.
"But it soon became clear that neither side, neither the United States nor Europe, was ready for a free trade area," said Sir Leon Brittan, the European Union's trade commissioner. "But that doesn't mean that the agreement does not keep that hope alive."
One reason there was little enthusiasm for a free trade agreement was that after the seven years of recent negotiations to create the World Trade Organization to succeed the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, there was little desire to begin another protracted round with Europe.
France, in particular, ruled out any negotiations on changes in its vast agricultural subsidies and continued to insist that broadcast programming include a majority of European shows. Most trade experts agree that a free trade agreement would be meaningless if these two areas were not included.
And business leaders began arguing that lower tariff barriers were not their top priority. The average tariff between the United States and Europe is a meager 3 percent.
"We really don't worry about existing customs duties," said Hanns Glatz, head of European affairs for Daimler-Benz in Brussels. "Currency fluctuations are far greater concerns to us than tariffs. What we really are interested in are identical regulations."
Corporate heads told political leaders on both sides that the end of duplicate testing requirements and cutting through a hodgepodge of regulations were far more important to their competitive needs than reducing tariffs.
For example, to sell cars in the United States, European manufacturers have to install different headlights, as do American makers selling in the European market. Cars that have gone through a set of tests in Europe have to be put through other tests in the United States and adjustments made before they can be sold. Peugeot, for example, has given up selling cars in the United States in large part because of the costs of testing.
Mr. Eizenstat said that under the Trans-Atlantic Marketplace, the two sides planned on trying to open the European market to many biotechnology products now banned here but fully tested, approved and considered safe in the United States. These would include beef hormones that make cattle produce more milk and grow fatter, and a number of bioengineered pharmaceuticals.
In the end, only time will tell whether the trans-Atlantic accord will be as much as the politicians bill it to be.
"Everyone is asking, 'Where's the beef?' " said James Elles, a member of the European Parliament and president of the Trans-Atlantic Policy Network, a Brussels-based association to promote trade. "I think it is there. I don't think this is an empty declaration."

HEADLINE: U.N. Fields Odd Allies As It Wages AIDS Battle

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The director of a new program to coordinate and strengthen the work of the United Nations in battling the spread of AIDS has an odd assortment of allies: a prostitutes' union in Calcutta, the Thai Army and a grass-roots group in Uganda that is teaching women to move beyond their traditional roles and become militant in the name of prevention.
Such pockets of hope are small and scattered, said the director, Peter Piot of Belgium, but they demonstrate the lesson he wants to deliver to the developing world, where more than 90 percent of H.I.V.-infected people live. 
 "We now have very good evidence that prevention brings real results," Dr. Piot said in an interview on Thursday. It works best, he added, when programs fit the needs of people in specific cultures. Dr. Piot was in New York to speak about the program in a United Nations panel discussion on World AIDS Day on Friday.
In Thailand, where discussion of sex is frank and open, business leaders and military officers have successfully promoted AIDS prevention programs in a country that once seemed headed toward a health catastrophe. Now, Dr. Piot said, Thailand has areas where no new infections are occurring in men under 25. But he cautioned that in general Southeast Asia still has one of the world's fastest growing infection rates.
India remains another high-risk area, he said. But in Calcutta, where political and labor militancy is strong, prostitutes enlisted the support of public health officials for their organization by advocating a campaign against unprotected sex.
The intersection of AIDS prevention and women's rights is inevitable, Dr. Piot said, as is the recognition that AIDS prevention cannot be separated from overall development in poor countries.
"It's not enough understood that AIDS is more than a health problem," he said. "All agencies involved in development should have AIDS on their agenda. You have to be blind not to see the connection."
He said United Nations officials are often in as much as a state of denial as governments that say AIDS is a "foreign" disease.
Dr. Piot said one of his primary goals is to introduce AIDS awareness in all the United Nations agencies connected to his program: Unicef, the United Nations Development Program, the United Nations Population Fund, Unesco, the World Bank and the World Health Organization. They will be urged to pool resources to avoid what he calls "overlap, gaps and turf fights."
Dr. Piot is to open an office for UNAIDS, as the program is called, in Geneva in January and it plans to station teams of experts in individual countries or regional centers to advise governments and local private organizations as well as to provide technical and financial support.
Thirty-six nations have already established centers for coordinating AIDS efforts, he said.

HEADLINE: Weary of Political Noise, a Senator Sees a Peaceful Farm in Her Future

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The final art of elective politics is to go cold turkey, leave the scene behind and head home to an ordinary life. "To Kansas," says Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, her smile as serene and honest as anything ever is in the Capitol.
"It's important for anybody in politics to be able to go home," the Republican Senator advises in the terse, tidy way that has been her oratorical trademark in the political career she never expected. It will last three terms in Washington and not a minute more. She intends to leave in a year and go live in a small, white farmhouse in the middle of Kansas where there are cows and no C-Span Congressional debates flickering endlessly in life's foreground. 
 "I will get a satellite dish -- to watch the basketball," says the University of Kansas alumna, drawing the line of her tolerance firmly, as she did in 1986 when she bucked President Ronald Reagan and led the fight for economic sanctions on South Africa in the final push to end apartheid.
The political art of walking away from such winning moments will be multiply tested in 1996, with a score of representatives and senators packing in their new ideas and old nostrums. Many may never leave town, opting for second careers in lobbying, lawyering and the sort of spectator-sport commentating that Senator Kassebaum warns is a noisomely discouraging aspect of modern politics. No chance that she will be among those risking spiritual gout at the Beltway's power-lunch trough after she quits next year.
"You know, 'Crossfire' and all that, the higher the decibel level gets, the more it's like a boxing match," she explains. "It's really different from when I came here.
"Today, there's an almost information overload, a bombardment by news, by faxes. Everything is instantaneous," she says, describing the descent of politics to infotainment, shallow and kaleidoscopic.
"Kind of a Roman circus in which people would rather watch politicians go at it," she continues, wary of a new "couch potato" electorate. "Politics as channel surfing. We want a new idea a day, a new person a day. There's no willingness to sustain, even though it may not be as exciting over a period of time to stick with something that needs to be done in a constructive way."
As she leaves, Mrs. Kassebaum is warning about the outsized, ravenous factor of money in politics and piteous Presidential candidates trapped in "the perpetual campaign." "By the time we do focus several months before the election, people are worn out," she says. "Even now there's another great search for who might be 'new.' "
In rather dreamy counterpoint, the 63-year-old Senator declares, "I always wanted that farm." She recalls girlhood days spent minnow fishing in the farm creek outside Burdick, a town as plain and compact in style as Mrs. Kassebaum in a Senate debate. "I never dreamed I would be here."
At the age of 42, in the midst of mothering four college- and high-school-aged children, she ventured hesitantly from Kansas and school board civics, indulging a one-year adventure as a Capitol political intern. She became intoxicated enough to dare to run in a nine-person crapshoot of a Senate primary fight that suddenly developed in 1978.
She won the Senate seat, she admits, on the middle-name recognition of being Nancy Landon Kassebaum, the daughter of Alf. Her father, after winning terms as Governor of Kansas in 1932 and 1934 against the Democratic trend, was the 1936 Republican Presidential nominee. He happily stayed home after losing and taught his daughter at the dinner table about issue-driven, pre-infotainment politics, a world she dearly misses.
"What better coattails than his?" she asks, confident now that she has carved her own respectable record in such specialties as the devolution of block grant powers to the statehouses. She has been a centrist of sometimes contradictory convictions, proposing, for example, that the states have more power over welfare while turning all Medicaid financing over to Washington. She has voted for gun controls. She is in favor of the right to choose abortion while allowing for state restrictions on abortion. She creates consensus, and she is not at all defensive about walking away from the chairmanship of the Labor Committee -- the first major committee chairwoman in 40 years.
The Senator is shocked that, even in Kansas, her successor will expend an estimated $2 million to win next year, five times the cost of her last campaign under self-imposed spending limits. She promises a final year's value, intent on finishing elaborate overhauls of the Federal drug law and workplace regulations.
Mrs. Kassebaum is misleadingly mild-looking and she knows it. Bordering on adopting a refreshing sneer, she notes that near the top of the list of campaign cliches she will not miss is the corny comparison of her to sweet, innocent Dorothy, the farm girl idealist who found herself far from Kansas in Oz.
"And no more of that question, 'What's it like to be a woman in the Senate?' " she says, using a ding-dong parody worthy of someone tired of all the media moves.
"We're here as senators and should be judged on our ability to deal with economic issues, foreign policy," she says with finality. "There are so many women who are running and bringing credentials to campaign debates and winning now that it's no longer a big deal."
It follows that it's not a big deal to go home. "What dad gave me that I always value was that his roots were always in Kansas," the Senator says, recalling the morning she first announced her candidacy 17 years ago. "I heard him on the radio, saying he hoped I wouldn't do it. I saw him later, sitting with the press, and I said, 'Dad, you've had your chance.' "
Now, the Senator notes, she has had her chance, too, and thus does the farm beckon.

HEADLINE: In Iowa, Buchanan Tries to Convince Conservatives That He's Their Man

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: DUBUQUE, Iowa, Dec. 1

 BODY:
It's the tail end of the morning rush hour, and Patrick J. Buchanan, the cultural-values warrior and 1996 Presidential candidate, is in K LIVE 105's FM studio, whooping it up with Dan Tooker, a G-rated, west-of-the-Mississippi version of Don Imus.
Mr. Tooker tweaks Mr. Buchanan for having a bigger campaign Winnebago than other Republican candidates, and Mr. Buchanan retorts that actually his R.V. is nothing compared to the "mobile homes" he says Morry Taylor, another Presidential hopeful, rides on the campaign trail. Then Mr. Buchanan, who traveled in a dark green van this week, raises the ante with this slice of campaign life about Mr. Taylor: 
 "He came up to the Iowa straw poll. He came up. They had these 50 babes -- excuse the terminology. They were on motorcycles. They were on Harley-Davidsons and driving in there. And someone said that is not the Federation of Iowa Republican Women, folks."
That on-the-air repartee may be harmless, but it is certainly not irrelevant when it comes to getting the attention and then trying to win the hearts and minds of the more than 100,000 Iowa Republicans expected to vote in the state's Feb. 12 caucus, the nation's first bona fide test of Republican Presidential candidates.
Mr. Buchanan, now in his second run for the Republican Presidential nomination, is in something of a pickle. Unlike Pat Robertson, who won the support of social conservatives in the 1988 caucus and captured second place, finishing ahead of George Bush, Mr. Buchanan does not have a lock on his natural constituency.
This time out, there are a lot of Republican Presidential candidates running as conservatives, including Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the front-runner; Senator Phil Gramm of Texas; Alan Keyes, the commentator, and Representative Robert K. Dornan of California. Mr. Buchanan is constantly on the lookout for ways to separate himself from the social conservative pack as he campaigns in the cities and hamlets of Iowa.
Whether Mr. Buchanan is on Mr. Tooker's KLYV-FM show displaying a kinder, gentler Pat or down the hall half an hour later on WDBQ-AM arguing against sending American troops to Bosnia and trumpeting his campaign's "800" number, his scrambling could have significance beyond his Presidential aspirations. The reception Mr. Buchanan receives in the coming weeks will tell a lot about what social conservatives outside Washington are thinking: do they want the kind of gradual change symbolized by Mr. Dole or the dramatic shakeup of the system reflected in Mr. Buchanan's candidacy?
Steffen Schmidt, University Professor of American politics and political behavior at Iowa State University, said many of Mr. Buchanan's supporters were "angry people, angry Americans who aren't interested in hearing about incremental changes." But Mr. Schmidt also said it was possible that a certain amount of pragmatism was creeping into Iowa conservatism. "They're angry, but they're not crazy," he said. "That's an advantage for Dole."
When Mr. Buchanan is campaigning person-to-person, he is apt to be enthusiastic but blunt in explaining what he says sets him apart from other conservatives. In caucus-organizing meetings in the homes of Buchanan supporters in Cedar Rapids on Tuesday and Waterloo on Thursday, Mr. Buchanan tied the success of his candidacy to issues he holds dear: the anti-abortion movement, a smaller central Government and other conservative causes.
"I win the nomination and carry the agenda forward or it's not carried forward," Mr. Buchanan told a group of abortion opponents gathered in the living room of Barbara and Bernard Sand in Waterloo on Thursday. In Cedar Rapids, where Mr. Buchanan gave a pep talk to supporters at the home of Robert and Marilyn Ask, he asked each of his backers to find 10 more like-minded conservatives and get them to the caucus to vote for him.
If provocative policy planks were the focal point of voter interest, Mr. Buchanan would be seen as a breed apart for his advocacy of tariffs against nations whose markets are not entirely open to American products and for his opposition to the North American Free Trade Agreement and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. His belief that the Government's free trade policy is partly responsible for destroying family farms and encouraging corporations to move high-wage American factories overseas is a novel populist position for a cold-war wordsmith who devoted so many years to promoting democracy and free market economies.
Nowadays Mr. Buchanan, a former speechwriter for President Richard M. Nixon and communications director for President Ronald Reagan, sounds much less gung-ho about capitalism and more like an advocate of the "small is beautiful" philosophy of the economist E. F. Schumacher.
"We have to ask ourselves as conservatives what is it we want to conserve in America," he said in an interview during which he placed family farms and other family businesses high on the preservation list. "I believe in the market system, but I don't worship the market system. I don't worship at the altar of efficiency as I believe some so-called conservatives do. To prefer a 100,000-hog confinement to hundreds of family farms, it seems to me, is not conservatism. I mean, that's to worship at a supermarket civilization."
In the same interview, Mr. Buchanan said that the rise in corporate profits and the stock market was a positive development so long as workers, middle management and white-collar employees shared in the prosperity. But, he said, "middle-class income is stagnant or going down at the same time these corporate profits are soaring."
Mr. Buchanan places the blame for that income stagnation on what he calls unfair trade deals that export high-paying jobs abroad, legal and illegal immigrants who work for less than Americans born in the United States and his new nemesis: corporate America. "I think it's corporations who have gone global, who have lost all loyalty to America," he said. Their "loyalty is to the bottom line on a corporate balance sheet." That loyalty, he said, leads them to move their plants to places like Singapore and Mexico, hire workers there for low wages "and fire Iowans who make $9.50" an hour.
Wherever Mr. Buchanan campaigned this week -- Des Moines, Newton, Mason City, Cedar Rapids, Waterloo, Cedar Falls, Dyersville and here -- he pushed his 10-point bill of rights for family farmers. At a speech to the influential Iowa Farm Bureau convention in Des Moines on Wednesday, his call for abolishing the inheritance tax and the capital gains tax on farms worth less than $5 million was politely received; so was his proposal to relax wetland regulation.
But knowledgeable Iowans say his promise to be a trade hawk in the White House really did not go over well with Hawkeye farmers. Like all farmers, they want greater access to consumers in Asian markets, but not at the price of rounds of retaliatory tariffs that they say would hurt Iowa's agriculture and agriculture-related industries, said Hugh Winebrenner, a professor of public administration at Drake University in Des Moines. The notion of a tariff fence around the United States, he said, "doesn't sell well in Iowa."
From a demographic point of view, Professor Winebrenner said, Mr. Buchanan's family farmer bill of rights, however heartfelt, also amounts to a dubious vote-getting strategy, since 43 percent of all Iowa Republicans are in 10 metropolitan counties, with a huge concentration around Des Moines.
"Every candidate has to operate on family farm rhetoric," he said. "There are family farms." But, he said, it is hard to define the line between a family farm and an incorporated business.
Nor should anyone think that Iowa's "Field of Dreams" landscape is an accurate picture of the state's economy. Agriculture-related activities may dominate here, but Iowa's economy is diverse.
"Manufacturing generates between three and five times as much personal income for Iowans as does agriculture," the Iowa Caucus Project fact book says. Job gains are in factory employment now, and Iowa's industrial base includes machinery, food products, insurance, financial services and electronic and electrical equipment.
After another bill-of-rights news conference in snow-covered Cedar Falls on Thursday, though, the photo opportunity won out. Without hesitation, Mr. Buchanan climbed behind the wheel of a green 1956 John Deere tractor on the four-acre Kellner Farm for the cameras.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Republican Presidential candidate Patrick J. BUchanan, on a swing through Iowa, checked out a tractor on a farm near Cedar Falls. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Deficit Partnership

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Like rival clans locked in some ancient feud, Democrats and Republicans have now been arguing for so many years over the budget deficit that the origins of the dispute have gradually been forgotten.
Democrats in Congress have repeated for years the mantra that President Reagan pushed the deficit out of control by cutting taxes while raising military spending. Republicans have recited just as regularly the view that Democrats voted for ever larger deficits during their 40 years of control in the House. 
 But among experts who have studied the history of the American budget deficits, there is fairly broad agreement that both sides are partly right. Neither party has clean hands and the slower economic growth over the last 20 years has made the situation worse.
The current budget negotiations between the Republican Congress and a Democratic President, stalled in large measure over handling the deficit, are a reminder that budget policy in the United States is made by compromises. And those compromises have put politically popular tax cuts and spending programs ahead of mundane but important matters, like whether there are enough tax revenues to cover spending, particularly over the last two decades.
Some of the biggest decisions that continue to feed the budget deficit were made by Republican Presidents with Democratic Congresses, notably during the Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan Administrations.
During the 1980's, when the annual deficit soared from $72 billion to $278 billion, President Reagan and Democrats struck a series of compromises in which tax revenues did not come close to covering spending. Each side vied with the other to say how unhappy it was with the deals, and many liberal Democrats voted against them. While President Reagan bore much of the responsibility for drafting these budgets, ultimately Congress voted for the budget bills and the President signed them.
"You can take a substantial amount of responsibility and dollop it around to everybody in this process," said Norman Ornstein, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute here. "The glib charges -- that it was President Reagan cutting taxes and raising military spending or that it was Democrats who spend, spend, spend -- are not accurate, but part of what was going on."
Both sides were reluctant to cut popular entitlement programs like Social Security and Medicare, for which recipients are guaranteed money if they meet certain criteria. Those programs grew rapidly during the 1980's and now account for half the budget. Unwillingness to cut them, not just among Democrats but also among Republicans, meant that cuts had to be twice as deep in other spending programs to accommodate tax reductions. Those deeper cuts simply were not made.
"Why did the conservative, anti-spending party (GOP) end up ratifying a half-trillion-dollar-per-year welfare state?" David A. Stockman, who was President Reagan's first budget director, wrote in his book "The Triumph of Politics." "In the answer lies the modern dirty little secret of the Republican Party: the conservative opposition helped build the American welfare state brick by brick during the three decades prior to 1980. The Reagan Revolution failed because the Republican Party decided to stick with its own historic handiwork."
While President Reagan's budgets remain controversial, probably because they are fairly recent, it was during the late 1960's and early 1970's that some of the costliest decisions were made. It was then that Democrats and Republicans created the Medicare system and made Social Security payments much more generous.
A rivalry between President Nixon and Wilbur Mills, the Democratic chairman of the Ways and Means Committee who made a brief bid for the Presidency in 1972, contributed to the decisions to increase payments to Social Security recipients by 15 percent in 1969, 10 percent in 1970 and 20 percent in 1972. In each case the Administration advocated a generous increase and the Congress added a little more.
Both sides also agreed to set Social Security payments in 1972 to rise with inflation. The effect was to lock in large payments -- right before the oil crisis sent prices in the United States soaring.
While Social Security is technically excluded from calculations of the Federal budget deficit through an accounting device, the program's expansion has had a big effect, particularly when coupled with the parallel growth in the Medicare system. As Social Security payments have climbed over the last quarter century, payroll taxes to support them have nearly doubled as a share of employees' income. That has reduced the room for increases in other taxes to cover many other Federal programs.
As Medicare and Social Security costs have grown, they have squeezed out Federal spending on other programs like transportion and education. Exclude military spending and interest on the national debt, and half of what is left in the budget now goes to people over 65, said Rudolph Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office. The portion that goes for everything else represents a smaller share of the nation's economic output than on the eve of World War II.
Apart from all the compromise budgets created by Presidents and Congresses, the booms and busts and growth rate of the American economy have had at least as great an influence on the size of the budget deficit.
The big social spending commitments of the late 1960's and early 1970's were made with the assumption that economic growth would not falter. Economic growth per person averaged about 2.4 percent a year from World War II until 1973. But growth per person has averaged only 1.4 percent since then.
To be sure, the American economy has had some strong years since then, including last year. But when times are good and most Americans have jobs, tax revenues naturally rise and spending for unemployment insurance and food stamps drops. The budget deficit narrows sharply on its own, weakening the political consensus for further deficit reduction.
That is exactly what has happened over the last year. The deficit has plunged to about $160 billion this year, down from a peak of $340.5 billion in fiscal 1992. Part of the drop reflects the combination of tax increases and spending cuts that the Clinton Administration and Congressional Democrats enacted in 1993.
Administration officials, led by Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, have pointed to the steep narrowing in the deficit over the last two years as evidence that Federal spending is already coming under control. Yet most economists believe that the bulk of the improvement has come from the robust health of the American economy, with millions more Americans working than there were when President Clinton took office.
Cutting deficits during recessions is much harder. The deficit expands rapidly as unemployed Americans stop paying taxes and put much heavier demands on Government services. Corporate profits drop, further reducing tax revenues.
Worse budget problems may still lie ahead, when the Baby Boom generation begins to retire early in the next century. The number of people turning 65 each year and becoming eligible for Medicare and full Social Security benefits is fairly low right now. These are Depression-era children born when birth rates were fairly low.
"The 90's is an era of reprieve," said Eugene Steuerle, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a Washington research group. "This is an easy period to get the deficit under control. What are we going to do when the crunch comes?"

HEADLINE: Finance Chief Is Appointed By Giuliani

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, to be Commissioner of Finance yesterday, making his third major appointment of the week in the areas of budget, finance and economic development.
Mr. Cerullo replaces Joseph J. Lhota, whom the Mayor appointed as his new budget director on Wednesday. Mr. Lhota will be the Mayor's third budget director in two years, reflecting an unusual turnover in an administration whose core appointees have largely remained in place. 
 On Friday, Mr. Giuliani appointed Charles Millard, a Republican member of the City Council who represents the Upper East Side of Manhattan, to be the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, an agency that offers incentives and tax advantages to encourage business growth and attract or retain private-sector jobs.
In yesterday's announcement, the Mayor said that Mr. Cerullo would have a dual responsibility as the head of the city's Department of Finance: the traditional one of overseeing the collection of almost $18 billion in taxes and other revenues, and an advisory role in the shaping of fiscal policy at a time when the city faces persistent budget gaps.
Although he has no background in municipal finance, Mr. Cerullo oversaw a drive at the Department of Consumer Affairs to streamline the licensing of businesses and the collection of fines from violators.
The Mayor said that made him well qualified for the job in the Finance Department, where Mr. Giuliani has proposed consolidating many of the city's collection functions to increase revenues without "becoming oppressive in the ways in which laws are enforced."
Mr. Giuliani's proposal, which would merge the city's administrative tribunals under the department, has for two years been stalled in the State Legislature, which must approve the changes.
"I can't think of anyone else who would be better in this very, very critical role," the Mayor said.
Mr. Cerullo, who is 33, was born in Brooklyn and raised on Staten Island, where he lives. He is a graduate of St. John's University and St. John's School of Law. In 1990, he was elected to the City Council, where as the only Republican he automatically became its minority leader, a position he held until taking the job at Consumer Affairs last year.
Mr. Cerullo said one of his goals as Commissioner of Finance would be to ease the summonses and fines for myriad violations -- from keeping sidewalks clean to parking -- that many business owners have complained are onerous. "I know that there's a very important element of working with the public and to develop a customer service element as to how the Department of Finance's reputation works in our neighborhoods," he said.

HEADLINE: Saving Science as Budgets Are Cut

 BODY:
In a memorable scene from the movie "Apollo 13," a space official dumps replicas of every item aboard the crippled spacecraft onto a table and orders the gathered scientists and engineers to figure out how to combine the debris into a workable exhaust system. They do.
Solving complex, unanticipated problems is what America's scientific community does uniquely well. Last week a panel of the National Research Council, a private group that advises Congress, proposed sensible ways to preserve the nation's scientific acuity in the face of steep projected declines in research budgets. 
 It urged Congress to adopt a coherent process for setting scientific priorities throughout the Government before separate committees vote on funding individual programs in separate agency budgets. It also recommended that Congress adopt a more accurate method for calculating spending, so that research is not mindlessly cut in the belief it is awash in money. Congress thinks it spends $70 billion on research and development, but the panel pointed out that about half of that is for maintaining armaments or for other purposes that create no knowledge and improve no technology.
The panel's most controversial recommendation was also its most important. It urged Congress to favor academic institutions over Government laboratories. Even after discounting the self-interest of a panel dominated by academics, this is a sensible suggestion. University-based research is more likely to be of higher quality because grants are awarded through a competitive process of peer review, whereas Government laboratories are generally guaranteed large lump sums that can support many less-capable scientists. University research is more likely to trigger a bigger impact because the results are widely disseminated and the projects train graduate students, the next generation of scholars.
The panel makes the important point that the purpose of university-based research is not only a startling discovery or application, but also the training of a skilled scientific community. Some of the most valuable research projects Government undertakes are those that have almost no chance of leading to applications but keep smart, creative and highly motivated scholars at the top of their profession. The return for the country is that it has created generations of scientists who fan out into the economy to solve hard problems wherever they arise -- even on a spaceship.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
