HEADLINE: THE RADICAL CENTER OR THE MODERATE MIDDLE?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LIND; Michael Lind is a senior editor of The New Republic and the author of "The Next American Nation: The New Nationalism and the Fourth American Revolution."

 BODY:
COLIN POWELL'S DECISION NOT TO SEEK THE PRESIDENCY HAS left an opening for the emergence of a new leader or a new party in the center of the political system. Whether or not there is an independent or a third-party challenge, the Democratic and Republican Presidential nominees in 1996 will have to court centrist voters who are repelled both by traditional liberalism and radical conservatism.
This is the conventional wisdom. It is half right. A substantial number of Americans (as much as a third of the electorate, in some polls) are indeed alienated by a two-party system that tends to present only two options -- conservative Republican or liberal Democrat. But the growing number of disaffected voters do not form a cohesive bloc with a shared viewpoint that might serve as the basis for a third party. On the contrary, alienated voters tend to divide into two distinct and incompatible camps: the moderate middle and the radical center. 
 Paul Tsongas declared after Powell's decision not to enter the race that "there is a clear consensus and it's right in the middle -- socially liberal, fiscally conservative, pro-environment, pro-campaign reform." The "clear consensus" Tsongas describes is that of the moderate middle (which Powell called "the sensible center"). Members of the moderate middle tend to be old-fashioned Eisenhower and Rockefeller Republicans alienated by the supply-siders and religious right activists who, since the 1970's, have taken over the G.O.P. The moderate middle also includes neo-liberal New Democrats based in the suburbs and successful in the private sector. The ranks of the moderate middle are heavy with managers and professionals with advanced degrees. They tend to combine liberal views on social issues like abortion and gay rights with concern about excess government spending on welfare and middle-class entitlements. The standard-bearers of the moderate middle include Democrats like Bill Bradley, Gary Hart and Paul Tsongas as well as former Republicans like John Anderson and Lowell Weicker.
The moderate middle, however, is only one of the two "centers" in American politics. The "radical center" (the name was coined in the 1970's by Donald Warren, a sociologist) consists largely of alienated Democrats, who broke away from the New Deal coalition to vote for George Wallace in 1968, Nixon in 1972 and then, in 1980, for Ronald Reagan. These former Wallace-Reagan Democrats tend to be white, blue-collar, high-school-educated and concentrated in the industrial Middle West, the South and the West. They are liberal, even radical in matters of economics, but conservative in morals and mores. Ross Perot, Pat Buchanan and Jerry Brown, while not spokesmen for the radical center, have espoused ideas and sentiments that are attractive to this constituency.
The moderate middle, by and large, is satisfied with the American private sector, to the extent of viewing its accounting procedures and organizational structures as a model for good governance in the public sector. The radical center hates big business (and big labor) as much as big government. Not infrequently, this hostility extends to the two big parties, between which, as George Wallace famously suggested, there isn't a dime's worth of difference.
The moderate middle could not be more different, in style and goals, than the radical center. It is hard to imagine Paul Tsongas slow-dancing, as Perot has, to the strains of Patsy Cline's "Crazy," or to picture Warren Rudman joining Pat Buchanan in summoning the country to "religious war" and "cultural war." The belligerent and often colorful oratory of today's self-described populists of the radical center echoes the oratory of the Jacksonian Democratic and Populist spellbinders of the past, like William Jennings Bryan, and Huey P. (Kingfish) Long.
The political spectrum, like American society in general, is divided by class, so that the rationalistic meliorists of the moderate middle, in socioeconomic terms, are "above" the angry populists of the radical center. The difference is reminiscent of the class and cultural divide between upper-middle-class metropolitan Progressives and rural and small-town Populists at the turn of the century, who viewed each other with suspicion even though they shared many criticisms of the existing order.
 THE ANGRY CENTER, ON CLOSER INSPECTION, turns out to consist of two groups so unlike as to doom any project of uniting them in a single third-party movement. The platform of Perot's new Independence Party stresses reforms of campaign finance and the budget process that both radical centrists and moderate middlers, for different reasons, can approve, but takes virtually no stand on contentious social and political issues that divide the two centers. Perot himself, in spite of his Texan populism, resembles a classic good-government progressive in his concerns about special-interest influence and bureaucratic inefficiency. However, to judge from the rapturous reception given at Perot's recent Dallas convention to the Nafta opponents Patrick Buchanan and Representative Marcy Kaptur, Democrat of Ohio, the center of gravity of the Perot movement is the radical center, not the moderate middle.
A more logical alternative, then, to today's two-party system would be not a three-party system but a four-party system, with parties representing liberalism, conservatism, the moderate middle and the radical center. More likely, however, the two centers will transform American politics by influencing one of the existing parties, or perhaps both, to adopt the most important parts of their agenda.
Given the deep contradictions between the radical center and the moderate middle, Democratic and Republican strategists may have no choice but to pursue one faction while writing off the other. Interestingly, the Republican and Democratic parties for some time have been pursuing the centrists who have defected from the other party, rather than trying to lure their own defectors back into the fold. For example, Republican strategists since Richard Nixon in 1968 have been willing to abandon liberal and moderate Republicans in order to court ex-Democratic members of the radical center by stressing social conservatism, while ignoring the economic populism that is dear to the hearts of the same constituency. In a memo for the 1984 Reagan campaign, Lee Atwater made this strategy explicit: "Populists have always been liberal on economics. So long as the crucial issues were generally confined to economics -- as during the New Deal -- the liberal candidate would expect to get most of the populist vote. But populists are conservatives on most social issues. . . . When social and cultural issues died down, the populists were left with no compelling reason to vote Republican."
Meanwhile, "New Democrats" like Bill Clinton have written off the radical center (most notably, during the Nafta debate) while reaching out to the business-class members of the moderate middle, many of them with liberal Republican roots, by supporting deficit reduction and good-government reforms like "reinventing government."
Of the two strategies, the Republican so far appears to be more successful; Buchanan's Presidential campaigns may even help weld the radical center to the G.O.P., as a wing of the party comparable in importance to the religious right (a sectarian coalition quite different from the radical center). Clinton, however, has managed to alienate working-class radical centrists with his moderate-middle synthesis of free trade and cultural liberalism, without inducing a mass conversion of John Anderson Republicans to the Democratic party.
 WHICH OF THE TWO RIVAL CENTRIST movements is more likely to succeed -- either as an independent party, or (more likely) as a wing of one of the two established parties? The answer might be sought in the historical precedent of the Populists and the Progressives. Progressive politicians enacted many of the reforms on the Populist agenda, from government relief for farmers to child labor laws. The Progressives, though, rejected radical Populist economic ideas, like the nationalization of the railroads and the re-monetization of silver. More concerned with good government than with popular government, Progressives also rejected the radical democratic ideal of the Populists; though they sometimes supported measures like referenda as tools to combat political machines, their favored alternative to government corruption tended to be the extension of government centralization by educated elites, not the extension of grass-roots Jacksonian democracy. The Populists fizzled out at the turn of the century; the Progressives, and their heirs, the New Deal liberals, proved to be the dominant force in 20th-century American politics, reshaping state and society alike.
If this parallel holds up, then the moderate middle (today's Progressives) may adopt some of the reforms of the radical center (today's Populists), while rejecting the most extreme radical-centrist approaches to economic nationalism and direct democracy. Because the moderate middle tends to be composed of disaffected members of the political, economic and intellectual establishments, it has an enormous advantage over the less-educated and less-sophisticated radical center. The moderate middle has prestige, connections and access to institutional power and wealth; the radical center tends to have none of these.
The long-term odds, then, are stacked in favor of the moderate middle -- particularly if its spokesmen adopt, and domesticate, a few ideas from the radical center (like campaign and lobbying reform, or trade sanctions on countries that exploit labor). Even if some of its favorite reforms are co-opted, though, the radical center may not be appeased. If wages continue to stagnate or decline for most Americans, the accumulating resentments of the radical center could energize a destructive anti-system populism, an American form of Argentine-style Peronism that would make Buchanan's right-wing populism look tame by comparison. The stability of the American political order may depend on its ability to reassure angry populists -- and yet the elitist bias of that very political order may insure that the interests of the working-class members of the radical center continue to be sacrificed to the ideals of the affluent and suburban moderate middle. If so, a new "South American" politics of outsiders versus insiders or of bottom versus top may replace the traditional American left-right spectrum -- and, with it, the very notion of a "center" at all.

LENGTH: 1171 words

HEADLINE: Forbes the Candidate: Different Hat, Same Message

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
When Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., the chief executive of Forbes Inc. and the editor in chief of Forbes magazine, announced on Sept. 22 that he would seek the Republican nomination for President, relatively few people had heard of the self-effacing and somewhat shy 48-year-old candidate.
Mr. Forbes, known as Steve, had never been elected to office, though he had gained attention as the architect of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's tax-cutting program in New Jersey. And for years, as a rising executive in the family publishing business, he was overshadowed by his flamboyant, motorcycle-riding father, Malcolm, who died in 1990. 
 Though hardly a household name, Steve Forbes is even with or ahead of most rivals, other than Senator Bob Dole, who leads the Republican field by a large margin in most polls in New Hampshire and Iowa. Mr. Forbes's rise from obscurity is credited less to his rhetoric than to the $7 million of his personal fortune he has spent on TV and radio advertising in pivotal states. He is now trying to get on the ballot in New York.
But as he traverses the country calling for a flat tax and term limits for politicians, Mr. Forbes's views are eminently recognizable to readers of his magazine, in which he has long propounded them. He continues to write his Fact and Comment column for the magazine, though he has turned over other corporate duties to his brother Timothy for the duration of the campaign.
At a time when many politicians are better known for shifting political beliefs than for firmly held convictions, people in the magazine industry say Mr. Forbes stands out as a man with a conviction: that economic values are the driving force in the country and that his supply-side proposals would carry the nation into a period of real growth.
"What you see in Steve is what you get in the sense that he deeply believes in those issues and writes about them all the time," said Stephen B. Shepard, editor in chief of Business Week, the archrival of Forbes.
Some editors, however, raise the question of whether Mr. Forbes has politicized the magazine with his strongly held views.
"It's abundantly clear that Steve, like his father, has a very strong point of view and that point of view is reflected in the pages of the magazine," Marshall Loeb, a former managing editor of Fortune, said. "Whether the other side is given a fair hearing would be a debatable point."
As an executive and publisher, Mr. Forbes is credited with vigorously expanding the business he inherited from his father. In 1992 Forbes became the No. 1 magazine in the industry in the number of advertising pages, ending the 17-year reign of Business Week. It was a crown Malcolm Forbes had never been able to attain. Last year Forbes was the only magazine of the 185 tracked by the Publishers Information Bureau with more than 4,000 advertising pages.
"The magazine is solid and he is solid; I wouldn't be surprised if it makes more money than when Malcolm was there," said Martin S. Walker, the chairman of Walker Communications, a magazine consultancy. Mr. Forbes is described by colleagues and employees as an old-fashioned editor with a clear vision of what he wants his magazine to be. He makes little use of marketing surveys to discover what his readers want. He does his homework, listens attentively to other opinions and then makes up his mind quickly.
In a brief telephone interview recently, Mr. Forbes said his experience as an editor had served him in good stead in campaigning.
"It's knowing your readers, sensing their needs, recognizing that what some may need may be different from what others need," he said. "It underscores the need for a clear purpose, whether it's for the magazine or whether it's knowing what are the obstacles standing in the way of voters.
"If they don't feel it's something done on conviction, they don't believe you," he said, speaking of voters and readers alike.
His decisiveness is one of his strongest attributes, people who work with him said.
"Pa would decide things very quickly but you could probably get him to change his mind, whereas Steve is more deliberate," said one of his brothers, Christopher. "Although there may have been more meetings leading up to it and much more taking of everyone's opinion, once he has made up his mind I would not want to change it."
Rich Karlgaard, the editor of ASAP, a Forbes magazine supplement about information technology, spoke of the clarity with which Mr. Forbes first described his vision for ASAP before it was introduced in 1992.
"Steve's notion of the information revolution was that it was doing deep systemic things to the economy and that information technology was going to change profoundly the way business was being done," Mr. Karlgaard said.
"He employs a sort of Socratic method in which his vision gets fulfilled but he makes you feel you concluded it, so you feel really good about it."
When Malcolm Forbes died, he left Steve, his oldest son, with a 51 percent share of Forbes Inc. and named him president and chief executive. Though Steve Forbes is in charge, the business is run by all four of Malcolm's sons: Steve, Robert, Christopher and Timothy.
They are not only close personally but by all accounts work surprisingly well together in running the business, which also owns a chain of 14 suburban weekly newspapers in New Jersey.
Since Malcolm's death, the company started FYI, an irreverent life-style publication that, like ASAP, is sent out with some editions of Forbes, and three foreign-language editions of Forbes. (The German one ceased publication earlier this year.) In 1986 the company acquired American Heritage magazine, which has since doubled in circulation and quadrupled in ad pages. The American Heritage Custom Publishing Company, a publisher of custom textbooks, was started in 1992.
One of the people who has known Mr. Forbes the longest at the company is James W. Michaels, the longtime editor of Forbes and Mr. Forbes's first boss when he started as an editorial trainee in 1970 after graduating from Princeton.
"If I had to characterize Steve it would be as an intensely serious person," Mr. Michaels said. "I think Steve has trained himself over the years quite consciously to be a good speaker, and I think the shyness that he sometimes exhibits in personal encounters vanishes when he gets up on his feet."
Mr. Forbes has also won respect as an economic prognosticator. He is the only writer to have won four Crystal Owl awards, prizes formerly given by the USX Corporation to the financial journalist whose economic forecasts for the coming year proved to be the most accurate.
What Mr. Forbes is not good at, however, is small talk.
"I won't say he has no small talk," said Christopher Buckley, the editor of FYI. "But his small talk is always consequential. You say to Steve, 'Gosh, haven't the leaves turned a lovely color?' and I can almost guarantee that you will be having a conversation about the gold standard within three minutes."

HEADLINE: Death and Deficiency in Kidney Treatment

SERIES: MISMANAGED CARE: The Perils of Dialysis - First of three articles.

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Two hours into the medical treatment that was cleansing her blood, Sue Ellen Coffin screamed, pulled at her hair and vomited.
Pandemonium spread at the Albuquerque Kidney Center as Mrs. Coffin's screams were followed by those of five other people in intense, unexpected pain. The nurses on duty shut off the kidney dialysis machines hooked up to the six people. Most of the patients recovered. But Mrs. Coffin died within six hours. 
 The terrifying episode 15 months ago was attributed to human error: a technician had thrown a switch to rinse the dialysis machines while patients were hooked up to them. The rinse, rather than the appropriate blood-cleansing solution, had been sent into their bloodstreams, causing a breakdown of cells.
But some experts argue that responsibility for the accident may lie with the kidney center and its parent, National Medical Care Inc. The New Mexico clinic used older dialysis machines that distribute solution to many patients at once, rather than through individual stations as in newer versions. Worse, the system did not sound an alarm to warn when the wrong solution was being used, as some newer machines would.
"It's very surprising that such equipment would still be in operation," said Dr. A. Peter Lundin, a prominent New York kidney specialist. "It can be extremely dangerous, as this episode makes evident."
Such problems are nothing new for National Medical Care, by far the biggest company in an industry that offers a striking anomaly: in a medical system that is in many ways the envy of the world, an American dialysis patient is as much as twice as likely to die in a given year as a patient in Western Europe or Japan.
What has happened? How can a country that prides itself on top-flight health care perform so badly with a treatment that means the difference between life and death for 187,000 Americans?
To find out, The New York Times examined the American dialysis business, particularly that of National Medical, the most influential company in the field. The investigation included interviews with doctors, administrators and Government officials, as well as a review of medical, court, government and company records.
The investigation found an industry that uses equipment and procedures that cut costs and raise profits, often at the expense of patients' health; that operates with few rules to assure high-quality care, and that has induced doctors to play along by giving them a share of the cash.
The case of National Medical provides more than just a window on troubles in the dialysis business. It also reinforces the concerns of some patients, doctors and policy makers about the increasingly common delivery of health care by for-profit companies facing tight cost controls from private insurers and the Government.
Over the last decade, National Medical Care, a division of W. R. Grace & Company, has been accused in legal proceedings and by patients, medical experts and some Government investigators of a variety of shortcomings. These are among the actions by the company, critics say, that have led to deficiencies in care:
*Shifting the duties of doctors and registered nurses to lesser-trained and poorly supervised technicians and medical staff.
*Allowing the use of outdated, poorly maintained equipment.
*Manufacturing equipment that has not met Federal standards.
*Keeping patients on dialysis for too little time.
*Re-using disposable equipment that manufacturers -- including, for many years, a division of National Medical itself -- recommended be used only once.
*Diverting Federal money that could be spent on patient care to enrich its doctors for little work and to finance other businesses.
In lengthy interviews, executives with Grace and with National Medical Care, based in Waltham, Mass., said the company's practices were perfectly proper. The executives -- including Dr. Edmund G. Lowrie, president of National Medical, and Dr. Edward E. Berger, corporate vice president -- strongly denied accusations that patients' health might be suffering, saying that none of the company's cost-saving policies had affected its patient care. They also pointed to numerous studies the company has undertaken of patients, with the intent of improving care.
Many practices of National Medical affect even dialysis patients who are treated elsewhere. Indeed, as the industry pacesetter, National Medical, with one of every five American dialysis patients, has seen its methods copied by many competitors.
And the industry's record is not enviable. Annual mortality rates for dialysis patients in the United States hover above 23 percent, more than twice the level of Western Europe or Japan, where rates are closer to 10 percent, according to the National Kidney Foundation. Even when adjusted for age, severity of illness and other factors, the American death rates remain far above those overseas, medical experts said.
Still, some experts say National Medical and its competitors do not bear sole responsibility for this troubling record. They say that these companies have simply responded to the perverse economics of the American dialysis system.
Since the early 1970's, the Government has paid 80 percent of the bill for dialysis patients of all ages through the Medicare program. But as the cost of the Government's good intentions outstripped its willingness to pay, Washington cut reimbursements for the treatment. Today Medicare spends more than $6 billion annually -- or more than $30,000 a patient -- on dialysis treatments. Yet it pays less for each treatment than it did 22 years ago, even as inflation has more than tripled consumer prices.
Government officials attribute the decline in compensation largely to the industry's ability to thrive even with relatively low payments. It does not help that dialysis patients, as a group, have relatively little political power; almost 40 percent of them are poor enough to qualify for Medicaid, Government statistics show.
Added to that mix is the prominent role played by for-profit clinics like those run by National Medical. More than 60 percent of the dialysis clinics in this country aim to make money, according to Government figures, and each of these clinic operators can keep as profit every dollar that is not spent on treatment.
In essence, cutbacks in payments have pushed National Medical to find ways to reduce its dialysis costs. And competitors of National Medical, seeing its financial success, have mimicked its policies.
The result, the critics say, has been a lowering of standards that has damaged the entire field.
"National Medical Care has largely destroyed the dialysis industry," said Perry Ecksel, president of the National Kidney Patients Association, a group organized to improve the quality of dialysis. "I think they are one of the reasons the field is suffering so intensely."
But despite the problems in the industry, Wall Street views the dialysis business as a valuable investment. A number of National Medical's competitors have sold shares to the public, and their stocks have performed strongly.
Hoping to capitalize on that enthusiasm, W. R. Grace has been preparing to spin off National Medical as a publicly traded company in the next few months. At the same time, several companies are trying to persuade Grace to sell it to them.
"The good will and benevolence of Congress has slowly been manipulated into an extremely profitable business, which Wall Street thinks of as an extremely good investment even though, clearly, the results in terms of patient health are not as good as they are in other economies," said Dr. Stanley Shaldon, a noted kidney expert who is a former professor of medicine at the University of Montpellier in France.
While National Medical executives do not dispute the fact that the American dialysis industry has a mortality rate higher than those of other countries, they argue that their company's rate is among the lowest in the nation. Indeed, Government statistics show that National Medical has a slightly lower death rate than most of its domestic competitors. Even some of those rivals agree that despite all the problems at National Medical, the company is still among the best for-profit dialysis providers in the United States.
Still, National Medical's operations have attracted the attention of the Justice Department. Federal prosecutors in New Jersey are examining whether the company manufactured and sold defective products in violation of an earlier settlement with the Government.
In the biggest investigation, Federal prosecutors in Massachusetts are examining whether the company illegally awarded lucrative profit-sharing contracts to doctors. They are also examining potential illegal billing procedures by the company. A third investigation, in Virginia, is also studying the company's financial relationship with doctors.
National Medical says that it is cooperating with the investigations, and that it does not believe it has violated any laws.
Regardless of the investigations' outcomes, medical experts said the company and its competitors should be closely studied as more for-profit health care companies operate under heavy price pressures. They say that based on the experience at National Medical, this trend offers strong reasons for concern.
"National Medical Care is sort of a harbinger to look at in terms of what is coming in the future of health care," said Dr. Lundin. "And that is somewhat ominous."
 
The Business
A Company Tied To U.S. Payments
National Medical got its start in 1968, when Constantine L. Hampers, a young instructor at the Harvard Medical School, decided to go into business. Dr. Hampers, widely known as Gus, had completed his training in nephrology, the branch of medicine dealing with the kidney, only two years before. Still, he and a colleague attracted enough investors that year to open a dialysis clinic, which became the foundation of the company.
Dialysis is a life-saving treatment first demonstrated as effective in 1960. Patients with kidney failure cannot cleanse their bodies of the wastes normally flushed by the kidneys in urine. During the treatment, a patient's blood is conveyed from the arm through plastic tubing to a plastic artificial kidney, known as a dialyzer. The dialyzer removes wastes like salt and urea from the blood, which is then returned to the body through a second tube.
Dialysis in this country usually lasts about three hours and is performed three times a week. Two-thirds of the Americans on it are under the age of 65; about a third are black, and slightly more are men than women. Without the treatment, or a kidney transplant, patients with kidney failure will die.
When National Medical opened its doors, dialysis was expensive, and so primarily benefited the wealthy. But in 1972, Washington mandated that the Government pay most of the cost for the dialysis of everyone who needs it. And National Medical was the company best prepared to take advantage of the new rules.
Today, mostly through its 624 clinics, National Medical provides dialysis to more than 40,000 people in the United States and 6,000 abroad.
In turn, the company, which W. R. Grace fully acquired in 1990 after many years as its largest shareholder, has earned handsome profits. In 1994, National Medical's dialysis-treatment division alone had revenues of more than $1.3 billion and an operating profit of $250 million, nearly 75 percent better than its earnings two years before. Its growth has come from acquisitions of competitors and growth in the number of patients requiring dialysis.
But efforts by the Government to control medical costs have made it more difficult to maintain both profits and high-quality dialysis care. In 1973, the Government fixed the maximum rate for a treatment at $135, which had it kept up with inflation would now be more than $450. Yet today, 22 years later, that fixed rate has fallen to $126 a treatment.
That has increased the pressure on National Medical and its competitors to lower their costs to remain profitable. In essence, the less a treatment costs the companies to deliver, the higher the profit.
The doctors who oversee the clinics also have strong reason to insure that costs are held down. For more than a decade, National Medical offered many of its part-time doctors a percentage of profits from the clinics, and it still bases their compensation partly on their ability to keep costs low. Those policies, which have been adopted throughout the industry, give doctors incentives to spend as little as possible on everything from equipment to clinic staffs.
Critics contend that the financial arrangements have contributed to problems at National Medical. "Based on the evidence I have seen in litigation, I must conclude that this company is driven by economics, and not by any overriding concern for the welfare of its patients," said Omer L. Rains, a lawyer in Sacramento, Calif., who has brought two antitrust suits against National Medical on behalf of competitors.
 
The Staffing
Lack of Standards For Technicians
Even with that potential incentive to cut corners, no standards on what procedures constitute good-quality treatment -- or even minimum qualifications for technicians and nurses -- have been established by the Government or the industry. Indeed, as recently as last year, the National Kidney Foundation was calling for the creation of such standards to reduce dialysis patients' death rate.
The standards for clinic staff would seem particularly important. While dialysis was once considered a complex procedure handled by doctors and registered nurses, it is now largely the domain of technicians who receive no formal medical training. A 1990 medical study found that doctors spent only about eight hours a week in dialysis clinics, and that registered nurses have increasingly been replaced by technicians and nurses with less training, a trend that troubles experts.
"We've seen some data that the number of registered nurses is directly inverse to mortality rates in dialysis," said Dr. Eli A. Friedman, chief of the division of renal disease at the State University of New York Health Science Center.
 
The Equipment
System Failures At Some Clinics
Problems began to emerge many years ago in National Medical's operations. For example, hospital records show that on the morning of Dec. 29, 1983, an alarm sounded in the intensive-care unit of Paradise Valley Hospital in National City, Calif., warning that one of National Medical's dialysis machines there was exposing patients and doctors to the possibility of electric shock.
"If this was an isolated problem we might be able to overlook the problem this one time, but this is an ongoing problem," Ed Ewing, the plant superintendent for Paradise Valley, wrote to the company. The problem "negates the protection that is built into the system to protect our patients' lives," he wrote.
As early as 1984, officials at the company's San Diego clinic, called Biomedical Artificial Kidney Centers, were warning executives at National Medical that equipment was out of date and dangerous.
Loren Macey, an administrator at the clinic, said in a letter to National Medical executives that the equipment being used to treat patients was "over 20 years old and riddled with problems." She said the equipment was not receiving any preventive maintenance and was flooding rooms with water and posing the danger of electric shock.
"The nursing and technology staff have become apathetic about working because the equipment is frustrating and embarrassing," she wrote.
Problems, from mild to severe, cropped up at National Medical clinics around the country. For example, in 1986, health inspectors cited a clinic in Washington for a range of problems that included repeated flooding from bathroom pipes. The flooding closed the clinic and left patients looking for treatment elsewhere. That same year, a patient at a company clinic in Louisville, Ky., was given the wrong blood type when the medical staff performed a transfusion. He later died.
In 1990, Medicare officials cited a National Medical center in Delaware as having poorly maintained and rusted dialysis equipment and dirty and poorly stocked emergency carts for treating patients in cardiac arrest. The regulators also found debris -- including a cigarette butt -- in the tanks of solution used to clean the equipment.
Health inspectors also found problems last year at the company's clinic in Albuquerque, which are the focus of a lawsuit on behalf of the husband and estate of Mrs. Coffin, the patient who died. After the mistake in which patients were infused with cleaning solution, health inspectors cited the clinic for failing to comply adequately with health and safety rules. In particular, the inspectors noted that the clinic failed to properly maintain equipment that could be hazardous to patients, and did not have adequate supervision by doctors.
In interviews, National Medical executives said that while isolated problems have happened, the number is small in light of the company's size. "We're dealing with hundreds of facilities, performing millions of treatments a year," Dr. Berger said. "Unacceptable events will occur. But the frequencies are small when taken against those sizes." The executives added that they moved quickly to fix problems when they are discovered.
But while quality problems like these may have involved lapses only at individual clinics, rather than system-wide, most every clinic affiliated with National Medical was touched by another problem: the manufacturing of medical supplies that fell short of Federal requirements.
 
The Manufacturing
Pricing Questions And Quality Woes
Each time a kidney patient is hooked to a dialysis machine, there is a new opportunity to make money -- and not just for the company providing the treatment. Dialysis involves an array of medical equipment, much of which has to be bought again and again. And ever since the company was young, National Medical has been getting a piece of those profits.
National Medical has long operated its own manufacturing division. For much of the company's existence, the treatment division of National Medical was required to buy much of its equipment from the manufacturing division.
The manufacturing division makes plastic dialyzers and tubing, home dialysis machines and other products, although not the larger pumping machines used in clinics. Owning the division makes sense for National Medical. As the nation's largest user of such equipment, the company can cut out the middleman by making its own equipment, lowering the cost of treatments.
But in fact, the opposite has happened. According to court testimony and company officials, National Medical's manufacturing division has for years charged its clinics above-market prices for some equipment.
In sworn testimony in 1985, Dr. Lowrie, National Medical's current president, said the higher prices were used to make the manufacturing division's profits appear plumper to satisfy Wall Street analysts.
In essence, the company transferred Federal money intended for patient care to another business for the company's benefit.
These days, National Medical has another reason for charging the higher prices. Senior executives said the higher prices charged to the National Medical clinics have allowed the manufacturing division to offer lower prices to other companies buying the equipment.
But using that equipment had drawbacks. The Government has found that National Medical frequently manufactured items that did not meet Federal manufacturing and quality requirements.
In January 1994, the Food and Drug Administration announced that it had found "a corporate-wide pattern of serious manufacturing violations" at National Medical. Specifically, the Government cited deficiencies that had resulted in 18 recalls by National Medical since 1987.
To resolve the case, National Medical, along with Dr. Hampers and two other senior officers, entered into a consent decree with the Government. That agreement required the company to meet regulatory standards in its manufacturing division. Under the agreement, equipment manufactured at two of the company's plants -- in Dublin and in Reynos, Mexico -- was banned from the United States.
Company officials said the F.D.A.'s findings were a result of new, stricter enforcement by the Government agency. They added that they thought the company maintained a strong relationship with the Government, and was now working toward being a model of compliance in the dialysis industry.
But in two inspections late last year, the agency discovered that National Medical still had problems.
For example, the inspections uncovered evidence that the company had previously found that its blood-line tubing frequently kinked, which could cause serious health problems for patients. A solution to the problem was approved by the company in March of last year, but according to Government documents, the solution had not been put into effect more than eight months later. During that time, 31 patients complained of problems caused by kinking in their blood tubing.
In recent interviews, company officials said that they were working to solve the problem of kinking lines, and that the F.D.A. had accepted their new timetable.
The F.D.A. found other problems as well. Early this year, after inspecting the Dublin plant, the agency informed National Medical that it was still in violation of regulations. To this day, equipment from that plant is not allowed in this country.
The F.D.A. also informed Dr. Hampers that the company's plant in Rockleigh, N.J., was not in compliance with standards and could be putting patients' lives at risk. In particular, the Government found that the company failed to properly identify and solve quality deficiencies in its products. Blood filters that had to be sterile were not. And F.D.A. records show that chemical residues were found in dialyzers, and had already caused health problems for at least four patients.
In a letter in March, the F.D.A. informed the company that it had violated the 1994 consent decree, and that its manufacturing problems posed a medium to high risk of causing cramps, burns, seizures, infections and other health problems.
 
The Treatments
Time Is Limited On the Machines
 Dialysis is an unpleasant and often boring process. The patients at National Medical clinics are hooked up to dialysis machines for an average of slightly more than three hours a day, three days a week.
But some experts contend that the patients would be better off if they remained on the machines even longer. A number of medical studies have reported that the longer the dialysis, the lower the death rate.
But in the American dialysis business, time is a precious commodity. Medicare pays the same amount for a three-hour dialysis treatment as it would for one that lasted five hours. The result, medical experts say, is that American companies like National Medical would be unwilling to provide longer treatments even if they thought they were needed.
"The dialysis industry in this country does not want to confront the necessity to increase the time of treatment because it decreases their profitability," said Dr. Raymon Hannah, the head of dialysis at Kaiser Permanente of Southern California. "And the people running it have told me so themselves."
Indeed, a 1991 medical study found that patients who received shorter dialysis were disproportionately treated in for-profit clinics.
The United States has the shortest average dialysis treatment of any industrial nation. American dialysis patients receive, on average, about 10 hours a week, medical experts said. German patients were treated for an average of 12 hours, and Japanese patients for 14 hours. The mortality rates in both countries are far lower than the American rate.
National Medical itself reported a level of dialysis for a substantial number of patients that was below the levels indicated as appropriate by a 1983 national study of dialysis, a 1991 company memo shows.
Company officials have acknowledged that the push to hold down costs has affected patient care. "Economic decisions can and do entail clinical compromises, and the patients will bear the cost," Dr. Lowrie and Dr. Berger wrote in an article that accompanied the 1991 study that found a link between length of dialysis and mortality..
In their article, the two doctors said dialysis providers had been pushed toward shorter treatments because of financial pressures resulting from the decline of Medicare reimbursement rates.
Still, National Medical executives said that while compensation rates did push companies to shorten dialysis, the company had conducted studies that found the length of dialysis was not a significant factor in patients' health. Instead, they said, dialysis intensity, as measured by the reduction of urea in the blood, as well as factors like patient nutrition, are more important. They said the company had led efforts to improve dialysis by closely monitoring those two areas.
Other experts remain unconvinced. "National Medical Care's position of advocating shorter hours of dialysis is resulting in premature deaths, in my opinion," said Dr. Shaldon, the kidney expert in France.
 
The Recycling
Disposable Items, Repeatedly Used
For years, the side of disposable dialyzers made by National Medical Care's manufacturing division bore a simple instruction, in capital letters, "SINGLE USE ONLY."
But despite the recommendation of its own manufacturing division, National Medical has spearheaded the re-use of disposable dialysis equipment, including dialyzers, blood lines and other equipment. And it has continued to re-use the equipment despite instances in which patients were infected, and even died, as a result of used dialyzers that were poorly cleaned.
Overseas, where the dialysis mortality rates are lower, many countries frown on re-use. For example, the practice is not allowed in Japan.
The National Institutes of Health, in studies completed in late 1992, found an increased incidence of death among dialysis patients treated at centers that re-used equipment. In response, the F.D.A. called for more studies.
National Medical has already experienced numerous problems in patients as a result of re-use. According to court records and company documents, after disposable equipment was cleaned for re-use, residues of bleach and formaldehyde were pumped into patients' bodies. One time, a doctor stopped a dialysis treatment seconds before it was to begin when he noticed a fruit fly had climbed into a re-used dialyzer during the cleaning process.
Indeed, some patients have even died as a result of equipment re-use, according to lawsuits and Government records. In 1982, at a National Medical clinic in Baton Rouge, La., 15 patients died and 12 became seriously ill after being infected by bacteria that grew inside improperly cleaned re-used dialyzers.
"Once you had a re-use procedure, it increased the risk of infection unless the equipment was properly sterilized," said Charles Moore, a lawyer who won a wrongful-death case against the company in 1988. "They didn't do that."
While the Government allows re-use, some manufacturers still caution that dialyzers be used only once. But National Medical has removed the admonition from its dialyzers, now simply warning that the equipment is sterile for only one use.
If there are potential dangers from re-use, why do National Medical and other companies do it? Critics say the driving force is money.
"There is nothing about re-use that helps the patients," said Larry Wolford, a former National Medical regional administrator who failed in an attempt to begin a company that did not re-use equipment. "It's just a matter of corporate bottom line and profitability. N.M.C. was the first to push the interests of patients aside in favor of profits."
For each treatment, the amount saved is small. Dialyzers range in price from about $8.50 to more than $30, while other disposable equipment, like blood tubing, can cost as little as a few dollars.
But in practice, the policy has a huge effect on the bottom line. According to company documents, National Medical clinics are allowed to re-use a dialyzer as often as 30 times, which saves huge sums.
For example, if the company paid an average of $20 for dialyzers, and re-used them an average of 15 times, National Medical would save about $130 million annually compared with what it would have to spend if it used a new dialyzer for each of its almost seven million treatments. That amount is more than the company's total after-tax profit in 1994. And that does not include the savings from re-using other equipment, like tubing.
National Medical's practice of re-using disposable dialyzers is now accepted in most of the industry as a necessity, given the limits on Government compensation. Indeed, the F.D.A. is putting together standards for the proper ways to re-use disposable dialysis equipment.
For their part, company executives said that if done properly, re-use is safe. They also said that the practice prevents a problem in patients called first-use syndrome, a reaction occasionally caused by the initial use of a dialyzer.
But critics contend that first-use syndrome is little more than an excuse by National Medical and others to justify the expense-saving re-use of disposable equipment. First-use syndrome is rare, they say, and is virtually eliminated if dialyzers are properly cleaned before use.
In a 1994 letter to the Food and Drug Administration, 18 foreign kidney specialists agreed that there was little evidence that first-use syndrome should be a concern. On the other hand, the doctors noted, re-use has been shown to result in an increased incidence of chronic low-grade infections among patients.
Even Dr. Shaldon, a doctor who in the early 1960's pioneered the idea of re-use for dialyzers, says he now thinks the procedure should be prohibited. "The sole reason for re-use is economic," he said. "And when done badly, it can kill you."
Some experts noted that the re-use of other disposable equipment, like blood lines, had not been studied sufficiently. "I have concerns about the safety of re-use of blood lines," said Dr. Hock Yeoh, chief of nephrology with Kaiser. "They are difficult to clean, and I'm not sure it is worth saving $2 to $3 at the expense of the safety of the patient."
Experts added that with the quality of the medical staffs in clinics going down, the dangers of re-use grow. "The average re-use procedure is done by people who have not much more training than a McDonald's hamburger flipper," said Dr. Friedman of the State University of New York. "And it is far too easy to have confusion or a mistake."
Despite the controversy, patients have no choice but to re-use dialyzers at National Medical clinics. Under Medicare rules, dialysis providers cannot accept offers from patients who want to pay for new dialyzers out of their own pockets. And experts and patients say that those who refuse to allow the re-use of disposable equipment are told to take their business elsewhere.
"National Medical Care has had the attitude that if you don't like what we're doing, then leave the unit," said Mr. Ecksel of the National Kidney Patients Association. "But usually, there is no place for most of these patients to go."
Next: A dialysis giant's competitive power.

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Helping Cities to Revive Industrial Sites

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
With the support of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, state legislators, local officials and real estate developers in scores of cities have begun to redevelop thousands of acres of urban industrial land that was long neglected because of concerns over legal liability for pollution and contamination.
These so-called brownfields, which are concentrated in the Northeast and the Midwest, have lingered as trash-strewn eyesores while businesses have shifted their operations to pristine locations in the suburbs and the countryside. 
 Government officials, with few objections from environmentalists, say that many old industrial sites, which are close to transportation and communication hubs, can be easily cleaned and transformed into attractive commercial properties.
"Brownfields affect a community's sense of hope," said Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. "There is something depressing when a block is fenced off and desolate for years."
Redevelopment has begun in scores of sites across the country, still only a fraction of the land idled by environmental concerns. A Congressional study this year concluded, "The range of estimates of brownfield sites in the United States varies from tens of thousands to nearly 450,000 sites, and the associated number of acres involved is equally uncertain." Chicago alone has identified more than 2,000 brownfields in its metropolitan area, while Cuyahoga County, Ohio, which includes Cleveland, estimates that 167 parcels qualify as brownfields.
To move these efforts along, 25 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, have adopted laws or regulations that ease the threat of liability and adjust pollution treatment standards. And the Environmental Protection Agency has taken a series of administrative measures, including removing thousands of less-polluted properties from its list of possible Superfund sites, in an effort to spur commercial development.
One of the most potentially valuable brownfield sites is a former steel mill here on the South Side, a nearly square-mile tract of vacant lakefront property with a spectacular view of downtown skyscrapers. If the USX Corporation, which owns the property, can navigate the environmental, bureaucratic and political obstacles ahead, the company believes the site could command an $80 million price tag.
Other projects are under way across the nation. Private developers are working on a paper recycling mill on the site of the old Harlem River rail yards in the South Bronx. In Ohio, Cuyahoga County has helped convert an old Cleveland factory into a bustling warehouse. And the Environmental Protection Agency is backing demonstration projects in cities like Bridgeport, Conn., Baltimore, Rochester, N.Y., St. Louis and Sacramento.
 
Overall Enthusiasm, And a Few Concerns
Environmentalists generally applaud the efforts to reclaim brownfields, noting that anything that helps slow urban sprawl eases air pollution by reducing driving. But some of them are concerned that in the rush to develop old industrial properties, some environmental safeguards may be brushed over.
"One thing to be concerned about is the issue of future use of a property," said Carol Andress, an economic development specialist in Washington with the Environmental Defense Fund, a New York-based advocacy group. "If a property is cleaned to industrial standards, what is to prevent it from flipping to residential use? That may involve deed restrictions or zoning restrictions."
Another issue, Ms. Andress said, is posed by brownfields next to residential properties. "Will contamination from the site affect nearby housing and will kids play on it?" she asked.
Until this year, developers and lenders had particularly avoided 38,000 sites listed as possible targets of action under the Federal Superfund law, which says that anyone involved in the management of a property can be responsible for the entire cost of cleaning. While these sites were, theoretically, the most severely polluted in the nation, many had in fact long since been passed over by the Environmental Protection Agency as not contaminated enough for its attention. But as long as they remained on the list most real estate executives and lenders considered them untouchable. "It's like a bad credit rating that never goes away," Ms. Browner said.
Lenders were particularly skittish, fearing that they could be forced to pay for cleanups or end up saddled with worthless property if the developer disappeared. A survey by the American Bankers Association in February 1993 showed that 83 percent of smaller banks had refused to make loans to projects because of concerns about environmental liability.
 
At Every Turn, The Superfund Issue
To help the reclamation effort, the environmental agency this year removed 25,000 of the least-polluted sites from the list, a step that local officials have hailed as a great leap forward. The sites would still require some type of cleanup, but by being removed as targets of the Superfund, they would not be subjected to that program's tougher standards.
"The problem is the whole issue was framed by Superfund," said Henry L. Henderson, Chicago's environmental commissioner. "The shadow of crushing liability and the fear of lenders made it impossible for small businessmen to get loans to develop urban properties."
The result, Mr. Henderson said, was an unintended effect of a law designed to protect the environment: the abandonment of urban areas by businesses that built factories, warehouses and commercial centers on unspoiled greenfields in rural areas, draining badly needed jobs from inner cities.
"Brownfields are largely artifacts of regulation," said Joseph Dufficy, a Superfund specialist, in the E.P.A.'s Chicago office. "Until we change, people will continue to go to greenfields."
Meanwhile, economic development specialists as well as representatives of environmental groups have been depicting urban sprawl as a waste of natural resources and a means of depriving low-income city dwellers the opportunity to grasp the lower rungs of the economic ladder.
"The economic distress of America's inner cities may be the most pressing issue facing the nation," said Michael E. Porter, a professor who specializes in economic development at Harvard Business School. "The lack of businesses and jobs in disadvantaged urban areas fuels not only the crushing cycle of poverty but also crippling social problems, such as drug abuse and crime."
Professor Porter said inner cities have some natural economic advantages, like a strategic location, with transportation and communications facilities already installed. The South Works steel mill, with its prime lakefront location, is seen by many as a prototype. For more than 100 years, it produced the structural beams used in the high-rise buildings of Chicago and other cities in the Midwest. But its steel production ended in 1992 and since then the owner, USX Corporation, has been tearing down factory buildings and preparing for cleanup.
Despite the tract's size, USX officials said they did not expect particularly difficult contamination problems. It had never appeared on the Superfund list.
"There was common ownership here for 100 years so we knew what had happened there," said J. David Moniot, general manager for environmental affairs at USX's steel subsidiary. He said the company found what it expected: underground fuel tanks, electrical devices contaminated by polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, and some areas with excessive amounts of lead.
"There are five areas with lead levels in excess of the standard we negotiated with Illinois E.P.A.," Mr. Moniot said. He said the company plans to clean the entire 600-acre site to a level suitable for residential development, at a cost of about $8 million and expects to get a "no further action will be taken" letter from the state agency next year.
Under an agreement with state officials in the Upper Middle West, regional officials of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency have issued a memorandum of understanding saying that if state standards are satisfied, the Federal agency will have no further interest in a site.
While not legally binding, the Federal assurance offers comfort to buyers and lenders.
"So much of the problem has been fear," said David L. Rieser, who is a lawyer with Ross & Hardies, a Chicago law firm, and represents industrial groups like the Illinois Manufacturers Association. "If you can get past fear to reality, you can solve problems. If you can reduce environmental problems to a dollar amount, then it just becomes a part of the development process."
 
Tackling the Problems With 'Common Sense'
Local, state and Federal officials have been cooperating to get some prime but polluted sites back into operation.
In Cleveland, for example, an old plant that cleaned metal parts sat idle, despite its proximity to two interstate highways because the owner of the bankrupt company lacked the money to remove a solvent, trichloroethylene, that had leaked into the soil. Like many such chemicals, the solvent poses a number of risks to humans, but technology has been developed to remove it while meeting standards established by the Ohio environmental agency.
The site was attractive to a prospective tenant, a warehousing operation, because of the transportation links. Under the terms of a new state law, officials of the Cuyahoga County Planning Commission, developed a cleanup plan the owner could afford based on rent payments from the warehousing company.
"We have no regulatory power, so we just helped the owner through the process," said Virginia Aveni, a program manager with the commission. The treatment program, which involves pumping ground water and removing the solvent, will take about a year to complete, Ms. Aveni said.
When the clean up is completed, the Ohio E.P.A. is expected to issue a "covenant not to sue." And, under the agreement with the Federal E.P.A., Federal officials have said that they will accept the Ohio ruling.
Concerned that stringent environmental regulations not be degraded, some representatives of environmental groups say pollution is just one of a host of problems that tend to inhibit brownfield development. "You cannot say that malfunctions of the Superfund are the main problem," said Allen Hershkowitz, a senior scientist with the National Resources Defense Council, who is involved with a paper recycling project in the South Bronx.
Mr. Hershkowitz explained: "A developer is usually facing much higher energy, water, construction labor and waste disposal costs in urban areas than in the suburbs. And there is usually a lengthy, labyrinthine permitting process in cities. In rural areas, you do not even have to file an environmental impact statement."
Ms. Browner said she views brownfields as a "common sense" matter. "We look at them and ask, 'What makes sense here?' " The agency has financed 50 demonstration projects nationwide at a cost of up to $200,000 each, to explore cleanup methods.
"We are going to learn more about how the redevelop these properties," she said. "We are going to develop tools that can be applied across the country."

HEADLINE: Price Wars on Personal Computers Are Already Heating Up Sales for Holiday Season

BYLINE: By LAURIE FLYNN 

 BODY:
There may have never been a better Christmas to buy a computer. There may have never been a Christmas when it was such a bruising battle to sell one.
Seductive prices and consumers' eagerness to be on the Internet have set off a stronger-than-expected start for home PC sales this holiday season. But the intense competition among computer makers is putting the squeeze on companies like Packard Bell Electronics, which is fighting to maintain its lead against companies with better-known names and deeper pockets, like Compaq Computer and Hewlett-Packard. 
 The latter are offering machines comparable to Packard Bell's at only slightly higher prices.
And on Friday, there was a new round of price-cutting by Apple Computer, whose machines once cost much more than other brands, but can now compete head-on in the home PC market.
"People typically spend about $2,000 on a home PC, and it's been that way a few years," said Larry Mondry, who is executive vice president of merchandising for CompUSA Inc., the nation's largest computer retailer. "What's changed this year is how much you get for your money."
Last year Packard Bell dominated the home market because of its low prices and because it was one of few retail providers of PC's using Intel's Pentium chips. A top-of-the-line Packard Bell home PC sold for about $2,500 and had a 90-megahertz chip, 8 megabytes of random-access memory and a hard drive with a storage capacity of 540 megabytes.
This year, Mr. Mondry said, a comparable Packard Bell model sells for $1,600. And that buys a 100-megahertz Pentium chip, which means faster processing time, the same 8 megabytes of RAM, and a full 850 megabytes of hard-drive capacity.
Much of this price trend is simply in keeping with the traditional movement of the silicon economy, where technology's costs fall while performance soars. But this season, more companies are competing in the home PC arena, a fast-growing segment -- although that growth has cooled to about 25 percent, compared with last year's 50 percent rate.
When the final 1995 sales figures are available, experts expect that sales of PC's to homes in the United States will approach the 10 million mark -- with half of those sold in the last three months of the year.
There were no firm sales figures yet for the season, but the anecdotal evidence indicated that consumers were not hesitating to open their wallets. A survey of stores conducted last week by the trade magazine Computer Retail Week found that 76 percent said that business was better than anticipated.
Last holiday season, a flood of new multimedia software titles helped propel the sale of PC's equipped with CD-ROM drives. Multimedia capabilities are still in demand, but this season everyone is intent on exploring the Internet and its World Wide Web, so the modem -- crucial for electronic communication -- has emerged as a standard component of virtually all new home PC's.
"Anything that has to do with the Internet is selling," said Abe Brown, spokesman for J & R Computer World of New York, one of the largest independent computer superstores in the nation. "More and more people are flocking to buy computers to get on it."
In addition to wanting to use the Internet, home PC buyers are buying high-performance systems to run Microsoft's new Windows 95 software, as well as games and entertainment software.
And consumers are demanding that these systems last. Unlike business buyers, who replace their computer systems every few years, consumers expect to own the same machine five years or longer, and so tend to buy machines with high-performance microprocessors that can accommodate future advances in software.
"Customers seem to be saying, 'Whatever you buy is obsolete the minute you buy it, so why not get as much bang as you can for your buck?' " said Andrew Neff, an analyst for Bear, Stearns in New York, who said that the weekend after Thanksgiving he saw people buying computers "like groceries" at the CompUSA store in White Plains.
Another factor in the surge in sales of powerful PC's is the fact that many customers are already buying their second or third home PC's, according to the research firm IDC/Link Resources.
In the past, computer makers and sellers underestimated consumer demand for powerful machines. In 1994, supplies of the Pentium-powered models tended to sell out early.
"Everybody was scared to death by what happened last year," said Larry Sennet, a spokesman for Hewlett-Packard, which began selling PC's to the home market this year. "We see no indications there are going to be huge shortages."
Mr. Mondry of CompUSA agreed. "This is the most plentiful Christmas season on record," he said. Still, if purchases accelerate this month, supplies of the most popular equipment could run low, analysts said, and regional independent stores could find themselves unable to restock as easily as big chains like CompUSA that have more influence with manufacturers.
The few spot shortages so far have tended to be of the higher-performance models -- Pentium machines or Apple Macintosh's with PowerPC chips.
Analysts said last week that Packard Bell had built more of the less powerful 75-megahertz Intel computers than consumers were buying. And several analysts said that Packard Bell's financial problems had forced it to fall into arrears with Intel -- to the tune of $470 million.
Packard Bell issued a statement last Thursday saying that it was having "a great year" and denying that it had an oversupply of 75-megahertz machines -- but skirting the Intel question.

HEADLINE: Clinton Showing Strength Among Michigan's Voters

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: LINCOLN PARK, Mich., Dec. 2

 BODY:
This state may be known for automobiles, soul music and Big Ten football, but it also has an impressive record as a political mirror: For decades, the vote for President in Michigan has been nearly identical to that of the entire nation.
That is why politicians are taking special note of a small renaissance for President Clinton here. After two years of slipping and sliding, Mr. Clinton is enjoying newfound popularity in the state, according to interviews with politicians, academics and voters as well as the latest opinion polls. In a whimsical sign of the President's rising acceptability, a bumper sticker spotted near here proclaimed, "Clinton! At Least He Cares," instead of the more familiar, "Impeach Clinton." 
 Mr. Clinton's standing in Michigan, a racially mixed microcosm with heavy industry and substantial agriculture, is important not only as an indication of how he is doing elsewhere. Michigan, which the President won, with 44 percent of the vote in the 1992 election, is also one of a handful of pivotal states where White House officials say he must prevail if he is to be returned to office.
"For the first time since December of 1992, the majority of Michigan voters say Clinton is doing a good job -- that is a major shift to go from a negative job rating," said Ed Sarpolus, a leading Michigan pollster based in Lansing.
In the latest poll by Mr. Sarpolus's organization, EPIC/MRA, released this week, respondents in Michigan who described themselves as likely to vote gave the President a 52 percent positive rating, while giving the Republican Congress only a 34 percent positive rating. Much of the growth in support for Mr. Clinton, Mr. Sarpolus said, has been among moderates, women and the elderly -- voters who might find the Republicans' budget proposals threatening.
These findings are all the more significant because this is a state where Gov. John M. Engler, a conservative Republican, swept to re-election last year and helped elect Spencer Abraham, the state's first Republican Senator in 16 years.
Nowhere is the increased comfort with Mr. Clinton better demonstrated than in this working-class enclave in what is called the "downriver" area south of Detroit, which was established as home to automobile workers in the 1930's and 1940's. Once overwhelmingly Democratic, and still home to many conservative Democrats, the residents have tended to split their votes more in recent years and, in 1992, helped Ross Perot win a respectable showing.
In interview after interview here in Wayne County, people approached at random were so full of praise for Mr. Clinton that they sounded like they were actors paid by the Democratic Party. Many said that six months ago or so they were not as effusive.
"It seems to me right now that the Democrats are for senior citizens and Medicare," said Dominic Mazzola, 72, a retired steam engineer for the local school system, who added that while he "could go either way" he expected to back Mr. Clinton next year. "The way I read it, the Republicans want to do away with everything that helps the little person."
Understanding of the President's earlier missteps, Mr. Mazzola said: "He's been serving an apprenticeship. Whoever we put in there is going to have to start from the bottom and work his way up. He's going to get himself in a mess also."
More than anything else, the increased support for Mr. Clinton seems to stem from the Democrats' public relations offensive to convince voters that he would protect them from what he depicts as Draconian budget cuts proposed by Republicans. It is also a big help to Mr. Clinton that the automobile industry has bounced back. Unlike last year when the President seemed to get no credit for the economic recovery, voters here now seem willing to give him at least a grudging pat on the back for it.
But the President's support is all the more striking because of the enormous popularity of Governor Engler, whose programs are widely credited as an inspiration for Speaker Newt Gingrich's economic and welfare proposals. Many people were disdainful of Mr. Gingrich and the Republicans in Washington, but had no criticism for the Governor.
Fresh from the day shift, Chuck Inman, an electrician from Ford, put on his bowling shoes at the Fort Park Bar & Bowling here and explained that he backed Mr. Perot but may well vote for Mr. Clinton this time. "He's starting to look better," Mr. Inman said. "He's looking more like a President. I'm glad he's standing up to the Republicans on the budget."
While voters' feelings were mixed about Mr. Clinton's plan to send troops to Bosnia, Mr. Inman, 41, said, "I'm all for that if it helps keeping the peace. But if people get hurt, the opinions about Clinton might change."
Bruno Bucca, 49, the owner of a hairdressing salon who also voted for Mr. Perot in 1992, has recently become a booster of Mr. Clinton. "He's the most underrated President we've had in years," he said. Using words that in the past have not been commonly associated with the President, except among hard-core Democrats, Mr. Bucca added, "I like that he stands for what he believes in -- like with the budget. It took a lot of guts."
One sign of the Republicans' growing concern about Michigan is that the Republican National Committee last week bought additional advertising time on television in the state to run a commercial that ridicules Mr. Clinton as only offering what the announcer describes as "double talk" about balancing the budget.
"They've decided that Clinton is just doing too well in the polls compared to where they thought they had him a year or two ago," said William S. Ballenger, editor of Inside Michigan Politics, a nonpartisan newsletter. "Republicans are nervous -- and they should be."
Republicans acknowledge that they have suffered here, but dismiss Mr. Clinton's rise as fleeting. "We know in the short run you may suffer negative ratings," said Suzy Heintz, the Michigan Republican chairwoman. "But once people see the good that comes out of the balanced budget, and interest rates going down, they're going to be extremely happy with what's going on in Congress and in Washington." Noting that Governor Engler recovered from rock bottom approval ratings after making hefty budget cuts, she added, "We've been through this before. The Governor bounced back."
Michael W. Traugott, a professor of communication at the University of Michigan who specializes in media and politics, noted that even with Mr. Clinton's strength, he faced a hard fight given that the Governor and the Republican majority in the Legislature are against him. "John Engler is not going to ease up and be complacent," he said.
But for now, Mr. Clinton's rise is of concern to candidates like Representative Dick Chrysler, a freshman from central Michigan who was the only Republican in the state to pick up a House seat last year. He faces a strong challenge from a former Democratic state Senator, Debbie Stabenow. Recent polls show that Mr. Chrysler, a former automobile manfacturing executive, could be in trouble, and analysts say he is not helped by his association with Speaker Newt Gingrich.
"Dick Chrysler is trying to establish an independent persona," said David W. Rohde, a political science professor at Michigan State University. "But if somehow the Republican difficulties went away, Chrysler would be in better shape."
Things do not look any better for the top of the ticket. The EPIC/MRA poll of 600 likely voters, conducted Nov. 15 to Nov. 21, found that if the election were held today, 53 percent of Michigan voters would lean toward Mr. Clinton and only 40 percent toward the leading Republican candidate, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points.
But it is a long, and no doubt rocky, path to next year's elections, and Democrats are well aware that their improved fortunes may be short-lived. Much depends, of course, on the resolution of the budget machinations on Capitol Hill and events that no one can predict.
Whatever unfolds, some voters here say they are sticking to Mr. Clinton not out of great admiration but because of their dislike of Mr. Gingrich. Jackie Milot, who works at Mr. Bucca's hair salon, rated Mr. Clinton "a fair President" but said she will probably vote for him.
Referring to Mr. Gingrich's complaint that Mr. Clinton ignored him on Air Force One during a trip back from Israel after the funeral of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, she said: "What sticks in my mind is this thing of Gingrich coming out of the back door of the plane. He's a man in a good position. He doesn't have to act like a child."
