HEADLINE: Panama Changes Tune to 'Yankee Don't Go Home'

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
Almost from the day they first arrived here in 1903 to build the Panama Canal, Americans have contended with chants of "Yankee Go Home!" But now, with the United States actually poised and apparently eager to leave, Panamanians are suddenly having a change of heart.
The turnabout stems from the growing realization here that when the United States leaves on Dec. 31, 1999, as required by the Panama Canal Treaties of 1977, Panama will, for the first time in its history, be left to fend for itself. 
 As a result, the desire to eliminate the last remnants of a colonial enclave in the heart of this small nation is giving way to fears of losing the economic and political stability the American presence has long guaranteed.
"Who do we know, and who has always protected us from our own mistakes and given us prosperity?" asked Ramiro Chang, a 28-year-old accountant here. "The gringos, that's who. We're used to having them around, and if they stay, that would be the best safeguard against any future problems."
According to a poll published in mid-October by the newspaper El Panama America, 86 percent of Panamanians now want United States military bases to remain here after the year 2000. Those in favor said a continuing American military presence was necessary both for "the security of the canal" and of Panama itself, as well as for the economic benefits the installations confer.
Studies by the United States military and other economic analysts estimate that the 8,800 American troops here, plus the even larger number of dependents with them, generate 22,000 jobs and inject more than $350 million annually into the Panamanian economy. The Panama Canal, currently run by a binational commission but scheduled to pass to Panamanian control at the end of 1999, yielded $462 million in revenues last year, most of which was immediately reinvested in the 52-mile waterway.
Bowing to those realities, President Ernesto Perez Balladares has put aside ideology and cautiously agreed to "exploratory talks" with Washington starting some time next year about extending the American military presence here. His party, the Revolutionary Democratic Party, or P.R.D., was founded by Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, the nationalist strongman who negotiated the canal treaties, and later, under Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, became even more virulently anti-American.
[The talks were originally scheduled to begin on Nov. 30, but on Nov. 22 the two sides announced a postponement. That action followed two weeks of protests by university students here and the internal resistance of some P.R.D. leaders, but Panamanian officials maintain that has no connection with the delay.]
With the cold war over and bases in the United States being closed as a result of budget pressures, the Clinton Administration has shown little enthusiasm, at least in public, for remaining here. Gen. Barry McCaffrey, the senior officer of the Southern Command, the United States military's regional headquarters for Latin America, recently said there was "no vital U.S. interest" here that would require a military presence into the 21st century.
In another sign of Washington's hardball approach, General McCaffrey has also said he wants to move the Southern Command from its headquarters in Quarry Heights, overlooking the capital here, to a new site in Miami well before the departure date set by the treaties.
"We expect to be there on July 4, 1998, at the latest," he told reporters here in September, adding that he thought a September 1997 withdrawal would be even better.
Panamanian officials say they have been told that other military sites, ranging from bases to schools, may also be handed over ahead of schedule. That saves the Pentagon money, but, more pointedly, also serves to remind Panama of the importance of the American presence here and of the benefits that will accrue should the two countries agree on a prolongation.
"There are a lot of guys at SouthCom who say Panama needs to feel the pain of us leaving," said an American civilian who works closely with the military. "They are really enjoying this, watching the Panamanians squirm, after so many years of being told they weren't wanted here."
The relationship with Panama is one of the most intimate and complicated the United States has anywhere in the world, and has been from the very start. This country owes its very existence to an act of imperialism on the part of Theodore Roosevelt, who on Nov. 3, 1903, engineered Panama's secession from Colombia to win approval to build the Panama Canal.
"If not for Roosevelt's chicanery, we would still be the most remote and backward province of Colombia, instead of the prosperous trading society we have become," a prominent businessman here said. "But it is hard to admit to ourselves that an American President is the father of our country."
Since then, thousands of Americans have settled and married here, becoming a minority group as easily recognizable as the Chinese, Arab, Jewish and Indian merchants who also help give Panama a cosmopolitan character. Nearly a century of United States presence here has also left Panamanians with distinctly American tastes, ranging from a passion for baseball and basketball to grocery stores that stock items like maple syrup and root beer.
In addition, many Panamanians fear that their country, which last year abolished its army, would be defenseless against foreign threats without a continuing American security blanket.
"I'd rather have a dictator imposed by the gringos than one imposed by the Cali cartel, and I fear that is what could happen," said one of the country's leading businessmen, speaking on condition of anonymity.
During a trip Mr. Perez Balladares made to Japan in September, Asian investors indicated to him that they too would welcome an American military presence beyond 1999. The Panamanian Government has increasingly been looking to companies from Japan, Taiwan, Korea and Hong Kong to fill at least part of the economic gap the American departure is expected to cause.
For those reasons, even Panamanians who do not want the American military to stay on understand the deep-seated appeal of the idea.
"It's hard to get out from under Daddy when Daddy has been around so long," said Roberto Eisenmann, the founder of La Prensa, the country's leading newspaper. "But we have to become adults some day."
In an interview, Mr. Perez Balladares said he saw no contradiction in his party's sudden willingness to sit down and haggle with Washington. The Panama Canal Zone, he noted, has passed into history, and with it the discriminatory features that fed nationalism here, like separate pay scales for Americans and Panamanians and the authority of American police, laws and courts.
"Torrijos did away with a colonial situation, which is totally different from what we have today," he said. "Now we are partners with the United States, with mutual interests in the area, and we want to build on that."
Some within his party have accused Mr. Perez Balladares of betraying the legacy of General Torrijos, but he dismissed those charges. "I lived closer to Torrijos than almost anybody else in Panama, and I know for a fact that if he were in my shoes today he would be doing exactly what I am doing," he said.
The presence of American bases after 2000, he argued, would not prevent Panama from being sovereign and self-sufficient. "Does that mean Japan has an umbilical cord to the United States because it has bases?" he asked. "No, of course not."
Panamanians now recognize, he said, that the relationship between the two countries is so intertwined that it resembles "a mixed marriage between a very tall guy and a very short girl" in which both are willing to overlook their disparity in size.
"I don't want my people to be left out of the world," he added. "I want them to get on the train to development, and obviously that requires the United States."

HEADLINE: Bronx Group Signs Recycling Company for Mill Project

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
After a court battle stalled its plans for a year, a group seeking to have a paper recycling mill built in the South Bronx has taken the first step toward construction of the $400 million operation at the old Harlem River Rail Yard, officials said last week.
The group, the Bronx Community Paper Company, has signed an agreement with the Prins Recycling Corporation of Fort Lee, N.J., to build and operate a $25 million wastepaper sorting plant on a 19-acre tract just north of Randalls Island, said Allen Hershkowitz, a senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, the environmental group that has been seeking developers for the project. 
 "The agreement is a demonstration of serious interest by an established recycling company and formalizes the negotiating process," said Randy Daniels, a project manager of the Empire State Development Corporation, the economic development arm of the state. The corporation has been working with the Bronx group on the project, which would recycle office paper from New York City's trash.
The sponsors of the project, however, still have to complete a deal with a paper company to build a main recycling plant before they can get the financing to proceed with the entire project.
The mill, which has been embraced by residents, environmentalists and government leaders, is expected to bring 700 jobs and other economic benefits to the South Bronx. It also includes a plan to provide housing, day care and health services for the workers.
The project had been stalled for a year by a lawsuit brought by a Manhattan lawyer who is a railroad buff. The lawyer, John McHugh, objected to the plan because he said the yard should be used as a transportation hub. By the time a judge ruled against the suit in August, the mill's two principal investors had withdrawn from the project.
Now, supporters of the project say they have taken a small but major step toward getting their plans back on track by signing the agreement with the Prins Corporation. Many of the project's environmental, zoning and building permits had been issued by the city and state after a lengthy public review process.
The Bronx group is negotiating with two international paper mills to build the main plant and hope to strike an agreement with one of them by the end of the year, according to officials with the city's Economic Development Corporation, which has been working with the group to revitalize the South Bronx.
The sorting plant would be built in conjunction with the larger recycling plant, and construction could start by the spring after financing is arranged, city officials said. Pulp from the sorting plant would be used to run the $375 million mill.
Fred L. Prins, chief executive officer of Prins Corporation, one of the largest waste paper processors and brokers in the Northeast, said he is confident that the rest of the project will fall into place.
The Bronx Community Paper company was created by the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, a leading community organization in the South Bronx, and the Natural Resources Defense Council. The groups came together when Yolanda Rivera, chairwoman of Banana Kelly, approached the council to help lure nonpolluting industries to the South Bronx.
But Mr. McHugh, who has appealed the court decision, is not convinced of the project's viability.
"I don't know how this justifies using the last piece of property in all of New York state west of the Westchester County line that can be developed as a rail intermodel as a paper mill. It's ridiculous."

HEADLINE: New Effort by U.S. and Vietnam to Return Boat People Home

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Seeking to end a long epilogue of the Vietnam War, Washington is working quietly with Hanoi to create a program that would persuade the remaining 40,000 Vietnamese boat people in Southeast Asian refugee camps to return home.
The initiative is being undertaken by the National Security Council and the Departments of State and Justice in hopes of avoiding more public debate and violent protests in the camps by detainees who do not want to return to Vietnam. 
 The plan comes in response to legislation sponsored by Representative Christopher H. Smith, a New Jersey Republican, that would bar the United States from providing about $25 million to the United Nations to help resettle the Vietnamese. The migrants fled their homeland, many in rickety boats, after the defeat of South Vietnam in 1975.
In talks that began one month ago in Hanoi, "we laid out an approach to the Government of Vietnam, and they made clear that they shared our goals and would try to come up with a workable way to do it," said a Clinton Administration official working on the plan. A formal response from Hanoi is expected this month.
Sergio Vieira de Mello, a senior official of the United Nations refugee-relief agency, called the American initiative "most welcome."
Under the plan, the Vietnamese would be transported to Ho Chi Minh City under the auspices of the United Nations. There, they would be guaranteed interviews with United States immigration officials.
Those who qualify as political refugees -- like people who worked for the United States or its allies during the war, or who were religious leaders, or who were imprisoned in "re-education camps" after the war -- would be allowed to come to this country. Others, like North Vietnamese fishermen who fled for economic reasons after the war, would have no choice but to try to make a new life in their old country.
Administration officials say as many as several thousand of the Vietnamese in the camps worked for United States military and intelligence services during the Vietnam War and have reason to believe that they will be allowed to resettle in the United States.
Tens of thousands of others may be persuaded to return to Vietnam, if they can be convinced that they will not be persecuted. The United Nations, which is responsible for monitoring the treatment of the tens of thousands of Vietnamese who have been returned home, says it has not documented any cases in which returning migrants have been treated harshly.
In a statement this year, Representative Smith said he had proposed the legislation because of concerns that many of the Vietnamese in the camps had been unfairly denied refugee status, but the United Nations has denied this.
The Vietnamese are the last of the so-called boat people, more than one million of whom fled their country in crowded vessels after the war's end. Most resettled outside of Asia, mainly in the United States. Those still in detention camps in Hong Kong, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines eke out an unhappy existence.
Their homeland, once a symbol of endless war and impoverished communism, now has one of the world's fastest-growing economies. And the time has passed when the United States and other wealthy nations willingly open their arms to immigrants. Refugee officials say it is unlikely that new migrants will receive the unconditional and generous welcome once accorded the Indochinese.
Rejected for resettlement after extensive interviews by United Nations refugee officials, thousands of the boat people in the Hong Kong and Southeast Asian camps had accepted the inevitable and were returning home voluntarily under United Nations supervision until this summer.
Then word of the Smith legislation created a stir in the detention camps, creating new hope among some Vietnamese there that they would not have to go home. Some renewed violent protests, and others reconsidered their plans to return voluntarily. Refugee officials worried that it could not only set off another exodus of boat people but also could create false hopes among the migrants that they would be allowed to come to the United States.
The House of Representatives passed the legislation, earmarking $30 million to bring some of the Vietnamese to the United States. But the legislation, part of a foreign affairs appropriations bill, is now languishing in the Senate.

HEADLINE: Ciudad Juarez Journal;
At U.S. Door, Huddled Masses Yearn for Better Pay

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico

 BODY:
Sometimes Ana Serratos pauses outside a McDonald's restaurant here, but she resists the temptation to stop in. Fast food is way beyond her means.
A Big Mac, medium Coke and fries cost $3.05, and for Ms. Serratos, who earns 35 cents an hour wrapping tape around bundles of electrical wires in one of Juarez's assembly plants, that is a full day's wages. 
 "What people in your country make in an hour, we work a whole day for," Ms. Serratos, 32, said to an American visitor during a recent family gathering in one of Ciudad Juarez's dirt-street suburbs. "These companies from the United States and Japan don't pay people what they ought to. They come to kill us with work."
Then she paused, reflecting. "But we have to recognize that they're important for Juarez."
During the last 25 years, 310 mostly foreign-owned assembly plants, called maquiladoras, have set up operations to take advantage of cheap labor and special tax breaks. They have come to dominate life in this sand-blown city across the Rio Grande from El Paso. Like Ms. Serratos, six of her siblings work in maquiladoras, and there are thousands of other families also marching to the daily rhythm of the assembly plants, which employ more than 150,000 of Juarez's 1.2 million residents.
The city is growing fast, and Juarez's 40-year-old Mayor, Ramon Galindo, who belongs to the pro-business National Action Party, says he hopes to attract still more maquiladoras to Juarez. But in an interview in his City Hall offices he also said the fact that a vast majority of taxpayers earn the minimum wage of about $18 a week or not much more is a critical problem for the city.
"We're creating an enormous mass of wretchedly poor people," he said.
Mexico's minimum wage, which varies from region to region, is to increase by 10 percent on Dec. 4, bringing Juarez's minimum up to about $20 a week. The increase comes after a 30 percent decline in Mexican wages this year.
Because most Juarez residents have little to give, and the maquiladoras are required to give little, the city raises only meager tax revenues, Mr. Galindo said. And to make matters worse, the federal Government keeps 90 percent of the minimal taxes the maquiladoras pay to Mexico City.
"Our problem is, where is the money going to come from to provide services for all these people?" Mr. Galindo asked.
Juarez's entire 1995 budget was just $37 million, said Jesus Abrego Lopez, Juarez's economic development director. Even if the city were not to grow at all and were to spend its entire budget for 15 years on paving projects, many streets would still be unsurfaced in 2010, Mr. Abrego said.
Other huge challenges confront the city. Juarez's working-class sections, where many residents already must buy their drinking water by the jug from tank trucks, now sprawl across the desert horizon, and the water is running out.
"We need huge investments to dig deeper wells, but the city doesn't have the money," said Vicente Jaime, managing editor of the newspaper Norte.
Along a potholed track off the main highway near the Juarez airport, five young men, all maquiladora employees, were repairing a car. Their wages, they said, ranged from 68 cents an hour, which Gerardo Hernandez earns for punching holes in electric motor covers, to the $1.06 an hour Ivan Villanueva makes as a maintenance mechanic in a seat-cover factory. Theirs were good jobs, they said. And what is attractive about Juarez, they said, is that there are plenty more available.
"If you don't like one job, you can walk down the street and get another," said Ruben Hernandez, Gerardo's brother.
Cesar de la Rosa, 26, a foreman in an appliance repair plant, listed the benefits of maquiladora employment: workers qualify for membership in Mexico's social security system, which provides low-cost medical care, and another Government agency extends accessible home loans. Mr. de la Rosa said he also gets five days of vacation each year, with his full $37-a-week salary paid.
Two miles away in another working-class enclave, seven of the Serratos siblings were listening from the edges of their father's cramped living room as Ana talked about life in the maquiladoras. The smell of sausage and chiles wafted from the kitchen, and Ana's brother Jorge, 24, moved from glass to glass, pouring beer.
Jorge betrayed a hint of bravado when he said that as a fork-lift driver in a plant called Productos Electronicos Diversificados, he earns a good deal more than a mere assembly line worker: 53 cents an hour.
A visitor asked whether there were unions in Juarez, and Jorge looked puzzled.
"What's a union?" he asked.
A brother-in-law, Ramon Lopez, helped out from a couch. "That's a situation where if you have a problem at work, people try to help you out with the boss."
There was a pause.
"No, I haven't heard about anything like that," Jorge said.
Ana described her commute to her plant, a two-hour battle that involves two ramshackle buses and requires her to rise at 4 A.M. to arrive at 7.
Her older sister, Leticia, said, "Look how you have to suffer to earn a few pennies!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers in Ciudad Juarez have plenty of jobs to choose from in foreign-owned assembly plants there, but most of the jobs pay little. The wages of these workers -- Jose Luis Hernandez, Gerardo Hernandez, Ruben Hernandez, Cesar de la Rosa and Ivan Villanueva -- range from 68 cents to $1.06 an hour. (Bruce Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;
The Rand Corporation salutes E-mail as the new foundation of democracy.

BYLINE: By Denise Caruso 

 BODY:
DESPITE open hostility in today's political arena toward new taxes, a well-known public policy research organization has bravely published a sweeping thesis: not only does every American citizen need access to electronic mail to fully participate in a democratic society, but the Federal Government should make sure that industry helps foot the bill.
That proposal by the Rand Corporation comes in a newly released report, "Universal Access to E-Mail: Feasibility and Social Implications." It can be found on the World Wide Web at http://www.rand.org/publications/MR/MR650/. 
 The report is the result of a two-year study begun before the current budget-cutting Congress was elected and at a time when Vice President Al Gore and many other people in the Government were calling for a National Information Infrastructure -- also known as (wince) the "information superhighway" -- a new public network that would change the way business was conducted around the world.
While most of the attention was on building a network to support commerce, Rand began to examine how access to a critical technology like E-mail might affect American society. Its study questioned what would happen if E-mail was a key feature of the National Information Infrastructure initiative, widely available "at modest individual effort and expense to (almost) everyone in the United States" -- much as telephone and postal services are inexpensive and easy to use.
Based on Rand's study of on-line communities (like Latino Net in San Francisco and the Blacksburg Electronic Village in Virginia), and what it discovered about how citizens use E-mail today, the report concluded that "use of electronic mail is valuable for individuals, for communities, for the practice and spread of democracy, and for the general development of a viable national information infrastructure."
Even if one is willing to accept the report's basic premise -- that access to E-mail will promote democracy -- there are still many practical considerations to be addressed before launching the entire United States population into cyberspace.
The biggest sticking point is how to pay for it.
Tora Bikson, one of the study's authors and a psychologist in Rand's Social Policy Department, said that an amount equal to about $100 a household, or about $1 billion a year, would be sufficient to amortize E-mail service (and the required computer equipment) for the poorest 10 percent of the nation's population.
To raise that money Rand proposes a system in which communications and information service providers would be charged an E-mail tax that would go into a special fund. The Federal Government would then dispense vouchers from this fund that qualified low-income individuals could use for signing up for an E-mail service or buying the necessary computer equipment.
Even though a new Federal tax is likely to find few proponents in industry or Congress, Dr. Bikson contends that an E-mail tax could go a long way toward helping the Internet achieve "universal" status quickly. "The assumption is that if businesses can really operate through the Net and reach almost everybody in the country, everyone benefits," she said.
But assuming we agree on how to finance universal access, who then provides every citizen in the nation with a unique E-mail address? Do we each get a national E-mail identity card, or maybe require that our E-mail address be our Social Security number?
Dr. Bikson concedes that that is a mind-boggling problem. "The report didn't recommend a specific addressing mechanism, just that one was needed," she said. "In fact, we encouraged the U.S. Postal Service and possibly the Federal Communications Commission to consider some mechanism to make sure that there is a always a default address for people."
Even if the addresses could be assigned, a larger question remains. Are we ready, as a society, for ubiquitous Government-mandated electronic communication? Not yet.
E-mail today does not have the same constitutional free-speech and privacy protections already afforded our other two ubiquitous communications vehicles: telephone calls and first-class letters. Business E-mail can be -- and often is -- read by employers. And while commercial E-mail providers promise not to read their customers' mail, there is currently no law against their doing so.
And unlike other countries, particularly those in the European Union, the United States does not restrict marketeers from compiling and selling data bases filled with information about how individual consumers use on-line services.
In addition, free speech on the Net is far from assured. There are several bills pending in Congress right now (see Voters Telecom Watch at http://www.vtw.org/billwatch/) that would severely restrict what people can say in either private or public forums on the Internet. Despite Rand's finding that virtual communities are powerful tools for democratic discourse, it will be difficult for communities to form under constant threat of censorship.
Dr. Bikson says that Rand is "not trying to turn a blind eye to the darker side of cyberspace." But the optimistic bent of the Rand study's conclusions is provoking controversy in various electronic forums, where telecommunications and public policy experts are debating everything from the study's central thesis -- that universal E-mail is indeed a boon to society -- to related issues like economic and racial equality, taxation, literacy and employment.
Ideally, these critical and clarifying discussions will soon find their way beyond the Net and into the mainstream. We all might learn something by inviting the millions of Americans who don't yet have E-mail to take part in the debate.

HEADLINE: IN BUDGET TALKS, NO HINT OF PACT ON HEALTH ISSUES

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER and ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Less than two weeks before the next budget deadline, President Clinton and Congress have yet to begin serious discussion of compromises on Medicaid or Medicare, issues that are essential to reaching a budget accord.
The shape of the nation's health policy is at the heart of the debate between the White House and the Republicans. After a week of fruitless budget negotiations, the two sides are expected to return to the table on Tuesday, just 10 days before the expiration of the Government's temporary authority to spend money, when the prospect of another partial Government shutdown looms. 
 There can be no deal without some grand compromise on Medicaid and Medicare, the health programs for the poor and the elderly, which are growing much faster than the budget as a whole. Thirty-seven percent of the savings the Republicans seek to balance the budget by 2002 come from those two programs, which many conservatives see as dinosaurs from the Great Society.
G. William Hoagland, the Republican staff director of the Senate Budget Committee, said tonight that "there has been absolutely no discussion that has gotten into the specifics of policy for Medicare or Medicaid" in the budget negotiations.
The committee chairman, Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, still hopes for an agreement, Mr. Hoagland said, but detailed discussions will not begin until the Congressional Budget Office re-estimates Federal spending for various programs in the light of new economic assumptions.
The disagreements on health issues in some cases result from political posturing and in others reflect deep philosophical divisions. Medicare has generated the fiercest public disputes, but some experts consider the disagreements over Medicaid to be much greater, and perhaps unbridgeable.
On Medicaid, the biggest question is whether to preserve a basic Federal guarantee of health coverage for the needy, as the Administration insists, or whether to let each state design its own program with a lump sum of Federal money, as the Republicans propose.
In the midst of the shouting, it is easy to overlook areas of potential agreement. In their plan to overhaul Medicare, the Republicans encourage competition among private health plans, both to control costs and give consumers greater options.
These are the principles President Clinton tried to apply to the entire health care system in his ill-fated health plan in 1993 and 1994.
Still, the two parties come to the current negotiations from very different starting points. Republicans bring a fervent commitment to scale back the Federal Government and eliminate its deficit in seven years. The Clinton Administration, while acknowledging current political realities, still remembers its heady dream of universal health insurance coverage, a vast expansion of the social welfare system.
"We still hold fast to our goal of expanding coverage," said George Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser to the President. "The worst thing you can do is begin to take coverage away."
Republicans see their Medicaid plan as a chance to return power to the states while saving money. The Administration says the proposal will rip holes in the safety net, causing the number of uninsured to soar.
This is a huge disagreement about money. The Republicans want to cut projected spending on Medicaid three times as much as President Clinton. Republicans would curtail it by $163 billion, or 17 percent, over seven years; Mr. Clinton would reduce it by $54 billion, or 6 percent.
It is also a dispute about the role of the Federal Government. In keeping with their campaign to shift power to the states, the Republicans would give each state a fixed amount of Federal money to finance health care for the poor, with few Federal requirements. These block grants would make Medicaid costs more predictable for the Federal Government, and give states much more flexibility. But coverage for the poor would become less certain, largely at the discretion of the states and ultimately determined by how long the money holds out.
Medicaid is now an entitlement, guaranteed to anyone who meets the Federal and state eligibility criteria, based largely on income and assets. Mr. Clinton sees the preservation of that safety net as an appropriate Federal role. By contrast, the Republicans' budget bill says the Medicaid law "shall not be construed as providing for an entitlement."
There are safeguards in the Republicans' budget bill. It says states must provide Medicaid to three groups: poor pregnant women, poor children under the age of 13 and disabled people. But the bill does not require states to provide any particular health benefits.
The White House and Congress have different ideas about how to control Medicaid costs. The Republicans would impose annual limits on total Medicaid spending. But Mr. Clinton would, for the first time, limit the growth of how much the Federal Government spends, on average, for each Medicaid recipient.
A limit on per capita spending would help control costs and allow Medicaid to expand if necessary because of a recession or an epidemic. In other words, poor people would still have a right to coverage.
White House documents show that the President's proposal would calculate the average amount of Federal Medicaid money spent on a beneficiary in each of four eligibility groups: children under 21, adults 21 to 64, elderly people and the disabled.
The average Federal payment for each category would be allowed to increase each year by the average annual change in economic output over the previous five years, before adjusting for inflation.
Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, said: "Block grants would lock in existing inequities in the distribution of Medicaid money. On a per person basis, New Hampshire gets more than three times as much as California." By contrast, he said, the President's proposal for a "per capita cap" controls costs while guaranteeing health care.
But Republicans in Congress and Republican governors vehemently oppose the idea. Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., a Virginia Republican who supervises Medicaid as chairman of the Commerce Committee, said: "The per capita cap would create the worst of all possible worlds. It keeps the entire Medicaid program intact -- mandatory entitlements, a mandatory package of benefits and Federal micromanagement of the states -- at the same time it limits Federal spending.
As for Medicare, the program for the elderly and disabled, President Clinton and Congressional Republicans will find it difficult to compromise after exchanging angry charges and countercharges for six months. This issue has generated some of the angriest standoffs, like the dispute over how much Medicare premiums should increase.
But the policy differences on Medicare, while numerous, are not as profound as on Medicaid.
The Republican budget promises to preserve the traditional Medicare program, which allows patients free choice of doctors and hospitals. But it would also offer Medicare beneficiaries new options, encouraging the use of health maintenance organizations.
The ultimate goal, Republicans say, is to control Medicare costs, which have been rising 10 percent a year, and to prevent the bankruptcy of Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund. Supporters of this approach say H.M.O.'s will be less expensive because they discourage unnecessary services and emphasize ways to prevent disease and disability. The Government would give private health plans a lump sum of Federal money for each Medicare beneficiary they enroll, eliminating the commitment to pay for whatever services the person requires.
The Administration has supported managed care for the population at large, and White House aides suggest that there is room to talk about the Republican proposals for structural changes in Medicare, if the negotiations ever get to that point. But these aides also assert that the Republicans' safeguards fail to protect the people who prefer the standard Medicare program, or to insure that the private marketplace works.
Democrats say they fear private health plans will woo the healthiest people, leaving the traditional Medicare program as the last refuge of the sickest and oldest Americans, many with high health care costs. This will happen, the Democrats assert, while the Medicare program is coping with major cutbacks mandated by the Republican plan.
The White House and Congress also expect a fight over medical savings accounts, one of the new Republican options. Under this proposal, elderly people could use their share of Medicare money to set up tax-free savings accounts to pay routine medical bills, while purchasing a high-deductible, catastrophic plan to pay the rest. Critics say this could become a huge giveaway to the healthiest, wealthiest Americans, who could then use the standard Medicare program when they got sick.
Democrats say they want more consumer protection for the elderly in the new health care marketplace. A lobbyist close to the Administration said: "Clinton, having been through this before, understands the paradox -- that as you move to a more market-oriented approach, you need more regulation, not less."
Some analysts say there should be a compromise on the savings expected from Medicare. President Clinton has proposed $124 billion of savings over seven years, while the Republicans have proposed $270 billion.
Gail R. Wilensky, an economist who was in charge of Medicare and Medicaid under President George Bush, said, "Conceptually the ability to compromise is there," probably with savings of about $200 billion.
But compromise will be difficult for the Administration. Many Democrats on Capitol Hill are implacably opposed to Medicare reductions of that magnitude; some are even uncomfortable with the Administration's target.
In addition, many health policy experts are cautioning the Administration about the cumulative impact of the cutbacks in Medicare and Medicaid, saying that they could force hospitals to close and services to deteriorate. "How much do you want to pull out of the health system in terms of dollars?" asks Stuart H. Altman, a professor of national health policy at Brandeis.
This is where the pre-1994 Clinton, driven by a grand vision of health care reform, meets the post-1994 President, on the defensive with a Republican Congress bent on balancing the budget.
Advocates for the elderly say they keep reminding Administration officials what their legacy will be if they acquiesce in these cutbacks.
"These are the issues that have been raised very sharply and very privately: that we can't go back, we can't lose ground, we've got to hold on to the coverage we have," said Jeff Eagan of the Long-Term Care Campaign, a coalition of 143 organizations from religious groups to advocates for the disabled.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Sends Mixed Signals on a New Shutdown

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Senior Republican lawmakers and their majority leader, Senator Bob Dole, sent varying signals today about the chances of a new Government shutdown over the budget. But all seemed to back away somewhat from optimistic remarks Mr. Dole made on Saturday.
About 800,000 Federal workers were sent home last month when their departments and agencies were without money because Congressional Republicans and President Clinton were at an impasse over the budget. After a week Congress and Mr. Clinton agreed to a temporary financing bill to return the Government to full operations. 
 That accord ends on Dec. 15, and with budget negotiations apparently going nowhere some politicians are discussing the possibility of a new shutdown.
In South Carolina on Saturday, Mr. Dole said that people should not worry about a shutdown's ruining their holidays. Today, he qualified that while remaining optimistic.
"I can't predict what the President may do, but as far as Bob Dole is concerned I think it'd be a mistake" to shut down the Government, Mr. Dole said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." "But if he doesn't come forth with anything and make any serious offers, then we have to face up to a shutdown on the 15th. I don't think it should happen. I don't believe it will happen. I'm going to ask the President to be as serious on the budget as we've been on Bosnia."
Even with another partial shutdown, essential services would continue. Congress has passed 7 of the 13 appropriations bills, including one for the Defense Department.
Republicans say they want to balance the budget in 2002 by reducing spending on historically Democratic efforts like Medicare, Medicaid and farm programs. The Republicans are also proposing to cut taxes $245 billion.
Mr. Clinton says cutbacks would devastate essential social programs. He and other Democrats contend that the tax cut would be too big and would help mainly the richest Americans.
The two sides met last week but were so divided that the talks were canceled for Friday, Saturday and Monday. Leaders said the negotiations would reconvene only after the Republicans had new economic projections.
The senior Democrat on the House Budget Committee, Martin Olav Sabo of Minnesota, said on "Meet the Press" that he believed that the budget could be balanced in seven years, but that Mr. Clinton should hold out for a better deal.

HEADLINE: Blaze Suspect Held in Death Of Firefighter

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC 

 BODY:
A man who said he set fire to his bed because his wife had left him, then walked away as the flames consumed his Queens tenement, has been charged in the death of a firefighter who was killed in the blaze, officials said yesterday.
The man, Moises Antonio Blandon, 27, an unemployed auto mechanic, was arrested late Saturday and charged with two counts of second-degree murder and arson in the death on Oct. 8 of Peter McLaughlin, 31, a firefighter with an elite rescue unit, Fire Department officials said.
If convicted, Mr. Blandon faces a maxi 
 mum penalty of 25 years to life in prison.
Mr. McLaughlin was searching for anyone trapped in the Long Island City building when a wave of flame roared over him inside the fourth-floor bedroom where the blaze had been set, Fire Commissioner Howard Safir said.
"Blandon admitted to setting the fire," Commissioner Safir said. "He has admitted that he set fire to a mattress in the apartment."
Mr. Blandon told investigators that depression over the breakup of his marriage drove him to set the fire, officials said.
"He tried to put the mattress out, he claims, and when he could not, he just closed the door and left," Mr. Safir said. "He notified no one. And this resulted in the death of a hero."
Rescuers found Mr. McLaughlin's body huddled behind a door, his arms raised as if to fend off the flames. Eight other firefighters were hurt battling the flames in the building at 40-04 36th Avenue.
A native of Northport, L.I., Mr. McLaughlin was the third firefighter to die this year from injuries suffered in the line of duty. An unmarried Marine Corps veteran, he had been with the Fire Department for seven years and was the youngest member of Rescue Company 4, a Woodside-based unit whose members search through burning buildings for victims.
Fire officials said Mr. Blandon told investigators that he started the fire by throwing a match on the bed.
"He certainly was trying to hurt somebody," Commissioner Safir said when asked whether Mr. Blandon intended to harm his wife. "We're not sure exactly what his motivation was. That will come out as the investigation continues."
Michael Vecchi, the department's Chief Fire Marshal, said Mr. Blandon's wife and two children were not living in the apartment at the time the fire was set.
The blaze was started about noon on that Sunday. It burned for 45 minutes before smoke set off an alarm in another apartment and firefighters were summoned, the Commissioner said.
"When you close a door in an unvented apartment and the fire continues to burn without anybody being notified of it, it can extend very quickly to the rest of the building," the Commissioner said. He said the fire spread into the space between the building's ceiling and roof before the Fire Department arrived.
Commissioner Safir said that forensics specialists from the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms had pinpointed the place in the building where the fire began.
"They determined that it was indeed an arson fire," Mr. Safir said. The Federal investigators routinely join city fire marshals in investigating possible arson fires, he said.
Mr. Vecchi said mattresses and other items, including a bunk bed, were stored in the room where the fire originated because it was the only part of the apartment where water was not leaking through the ceiling.
Commissioner Safir refused to say where Mr. Blandon had been between the time of the fire and his arrest. "He didn't come forward," Mr. Safir said.
Mr. Blandon is from Nicaragua and has been in the United States about seven years. His family had lived in the apartment about six months before the blaze.
The news of Mr. Blandon's confession seemed to do little to raise spirits at Rescue Company 4, where Mr. McLaughlin had worked for about three years.
"The wounds will never heal," said Joseph Tufano, a firefighter chosen to speak for the rest of the members of the Rescue Unit. "The scars will always be there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Moises Antonio Blandon, center, was arrested on charges of setting a Queens tenement fire that led to the death of Firefighter Peter McLaughlin. If convicted, Mr. Blandon faces a penalty of 25 years to life in prison. (Robert Miller for The New York Times) (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: Gore Visit To Signal New Status For Pretoria

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore is not signing any earth-shaking accords on his trip here this week, but senior diplomats say his visit is meant to signal a more serious United States attitude toward the new South Africa.
Washington, they said, intends to treat South Africa not as another aid-hungry African nation but as a continental powerhouse and an emerging multiracial democracy that could serve as an example to smaller countries overwhelmed by ethnic hatreds, from Rwanda to Bosnia. President Nelson Mandela, for instance, recently led the international criticism of Nigeria for executing human-rights activists. 
 "Now there's a Government we like -- big on human rights and diplomacy, and also a country that carries weight in Africa," a senior diplomat said.
The diplomats said the Clinton Administration would see South Africa in much the same light as it does Russia, a view that implied an understanding that such countries will have rough spots on the road to democracy.
Mr. Gore, who is to arrive on Monday night, is officially here to discuss with Deputy President Thabo Mbeki ways to strengthen the relationship between South Africa and the United States.
The two men are meeting as part of a new binational commission and will sign agreements creating committees to discuss business development, the environment, energy, education and science. The United States has similar binational commissions, which are essentially vehicles for regular meetings between vice presidents, with Russia and Egypt.
They will also sign an agreement allowing the Peace Corps to operate in South Africa for the first time. One diplomat suggested that the seemingly routine accord would be the most important item signed.
"In 10 years, those Peace Corps volunteers are going to be in crucial positions in the media and in Washington," he said. Their South African contacts and expertise, he added, will help cement relations between two countries that now barely know each other.
Also, once completed, an agreement between civil aviation negotiators could allow more direct flights between Johannesburg and New York, he said. More flights could increase tourism and help spread favorable word of mouth about the country.
Mr. Gore's delegation includes Commerce Secretary Ron Brown, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary and Mark D. Gearan, director of the Peace Corps.
Mr. Brown's committee is already holding talks about commercial ties. American investment in South Africa, after a slow start in 1991, has surged this year, according the Investor Responsibility Research Center in Washington.
On average, five new or returning companies are opening offices here every month. Levi Strauss, Nike, Heinz, Pepsi, Coca-Cola, Chrysler, Dell Computer and Ebony magazine have all recently announced expansion plans.
But substantial barriers to American investment remain. Chief among them is the general poverty of Africa that makes investment in Asia or Latin America easier.
Other barriers are more malleable. As McDonald's recently found out, South African trademark laws still reflect the era of sanctions, when preserving South African companies was the rule of the game. So do the high tariffs and tight laws that keep currency in the country. And the economy is still dominated by monopolies and cartels, like the mining companies and South African Breweries.
The Clinton Administration has selfish reasons for wanting private investment to succeed in South Africa. It is committed to providing $600 million in aid over three years -- mostly for education, health care and democratic institutions -- but Congress wants to pare that back.
Mr. Gore is also planning to visit Botswana to reassure smaller African nations that they will not be forgotten in the shadow of South Africa, which has a bigger economy than all of the rest of southern Africa combined and the only formidable military.
Military talks are deliberately not part of the scope of the binational commission, diplomats said. But South African officers are training with American troops in Europe, and the United States may sell South Africa some C-130 transport planes.
The Clinton Administration accepts that the South African Government will keep up ties with countries like Cuba and Iran, a diplomat said.
"The Iran tie is economic -- it's about oil," said the official. "The Cuba one is emotional -- they supported them during the liberation struggle."
There is one regret a senior diplomat expressed: "The Russians' offering to put a South African in space. That was a beauty. Wish we'd thought of that."

LENGTH: 500 words

HEADLINE: Governor Pataki's Jobs Shuffle

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki is trying to take state jobs away from Democratic urban centers like New York City and move them to Republican areas upstate. His administration calls it reinventing government. Political payoff seems much closer to the mark.
The plan, which has been percolating for nearly a year, involves transferring state workers to empty I.B.M. facilities in Kingston and Binghamton. The Governor says he wants to save money by merging the state's far-flung data-processing operations in these buildings. Efficiency and cost-cutting are always desirable. But Mr. Pataki's aides went about it in a most peculiar way. 
First they picked the sites that would receive the transferred workers -- two areas that had given Governor Pataki substantial support in the last election. Then they told the workers they were being moved. Then they requested bids for a feasibility study on whether merging the data-processing operations was a good idea. The study is still underway.
The Governor claims his plan will save $50 million, a figure he has stuck to resolutely, even though he has reduced the number of workers to be transferred and promised to add new state jobs to the mix. In fact, the only solid figures so far are the $13 million Mr. Pataki has agreed to pay I.B.M. for the buildings and $37 million he has committed for renovations.
New York City, which has the fewest state workers per capita of any area in the state, is scheduled to lose 500 jobs to Binghamton. Since Binghamton also has an unemployment rate about half the size of New York's, this makes Mr. Pataki a sort of reverse Robin Hood of economic development.
Any nonpartisan gloss on the plan was shattered when Governor Pataki quickly retreated on a plan to move 4,100 Albany jobs to Kingston. Albany may be a Democratic stronghold, but those state workers lived in the suburbs, and were represented by the State Senate Republican leader, Joseph Bruno.
Senator Bruno howled, and the Albany workers are now to be left alone, unless they volunteer to be transferred. Instead, Mr. Pataki convinced an Albany bank to relocate several thousand workers who are employed under a state tax-processing contract. Losing those jobs may also hurt the city of Albany, as much as losing the others, but the tax workers are not represented by the powerful state employee unions.
New York City's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, does not have Mr. Bruno's clout with the Pataki administration, but the Governor should back off from this inept plan anyway. If the empty I.B.M. facilities are a drain on the upstate economy, the Governor should get his economic development authority to work on finding commercial tenants for them. But the data-processing workers should not be moved anywhere until that feasibility study is conducted.
If merging the operations does turn out to be a good idea, the new sites should be chosen objectively, using criteria other than the number of voters who went Republican in the last election.

HEADLINE: 'Insurance Capital' Hartford Finds Itself Without Its Net

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 2

 BODY:
A decade ago, the idea that Aetna Life and Casualty Company would sell the heart of its business, its casualty and property divisions, would have been unthinkable.
"To put it delicately," said Paul Shipman, an aide to Hartford's Mayor, Michael P. Peters, "people would have thought you were crazy." 
 But on Wednesday, when Aetna announced that it was doing just that, selling those divisions to its crosstown rival, the Travelers Group Inc., meaning a net loss of up to 1,500 jobs, few experts in the insurance industry were surprised. It was just the latest slide in the business landscape of this city, which still proudly boasts of being the "insurance capital of the world," even though that claim is beginning to ring hollow.
The change can be seen in numerous small daily examples. At 5 P.M, there is no longer the parade of insurance employees walking to their homes in the Asylum Hill and Frog Hollow neighborhoods surrounding the insurance giants. Longtime employees like Lorenzo DeBenedictis, an Aetna systems administrator, no longer speak proudly about where they work. "We used to refer to it as Mother Aetna," he said. "We don't anymore."
The local United Way collected less money this year than it did four years ago. When Michael Douglas's character in the movie "An American President" referred to Hartford as the world's insurance capital, the audience at the Showcase Cinemas in nearby Berlin laughed bitterly.
Today, at least one of every 10 Hartford buildings is abandoned.
"We're a ghost town," said Nick Carbone, a leading city developer and a former Deputy Mayor.
The 1994 census data show that Hartford's population has fallen to its lowest level since World War I: about 124,000, down from a high of 177,000 in 1950. According to the United States Bureau of the Census, Hartford had the largest rate of population loss of any major city in the country, losing 11.1 percent from 1990 through 1994.
The slump is partly a result of a general exodus to the suburbs and layoffs in the military and banking industries, but equally significant are the deep cuts that have swept the insurance companies here, a move that ended the long-held conviction that a job at a Hartford insurance company was a job for life.
Over the last five years, the city's coterie of blue-chip insurance companies, once thought immune to severe turns in the national economy, have made their first extensive layoffs here in their history.
State labor statistics show that insurance employment, which is found predominantly in the Hartford region, dropped 12 percent, to 70,400, this year from 82,600 in 1991.
There have been other setbacks that will be difficult to overcome. The Travelers, once a pillar for the region, was bought in 1993 by Sanford I. Weill, the Wall Street investor, who moved the company's headquarters to Manhattan and has on occasion threatened to transfer more operations from Connecticut.
Another industry stalwart in Hartford, Connecticut Mutual Life, is merging with Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, of Springfield, Mass.; the new company is to be based in Springfield.
In the coming months, Aetna is expected to announce more reductions, following layoffs and consolidations costing more than 5,000 jobs over the last few years.
To be sure, the decline in the industry's presence here should not be interpreted as its death knell.
Top political officials and business leaders say that the national wave of mergers and acquisitions has naturally affected Connecticut companies. A result, they add, is that many of the Hartford-area concerns are completing a retooling and are poised for new growth.
Aetna's sale of its property and casualty businesses is a case in point. The company now has $4 billion in cash to expand its more profitable health care and financial services operations. In turn, if projections bear out, the new company to be formed by the merger of the Travelers and Aetna's property and casualty divisions will have the third largest total of property and casualty premiums in the country. Travelers plans to keep the business in Hartford.
"What makes a strong local economy is to have strong local companies," Joyce Oberdorf, an Aetna spokeswoman, said. "As we grow, employment opportunities should be strengthened. We've been here 150 years, and we're not leaving."
Still, it is widely acknowledged that the city and state can no longer take the industry for granted, and that it needs a policy to encourage its growth here. Gov. John G. Rowland and Mayor Peters remain confident that this can happen, and they have been meeting with insurance leaders to find ways. "I think we are at a turning point," Mr. Rowland said. "If we are not responsive and pro-active, then we lose."
Yet even those who are most optimistic about the industry's future here admit that it will never return to the days of a few decades ago, when an Aetna employee could walk to the bank across the street and get a mortgage just by showing his company identification.
The chief executives of the insurance companies, along with the top executive of the United Technologies Corporation (owner of Pratt & Whitney), were known for decades as "the bishops," aggressively looking after the city's welfare and regularly meeting to discuss its future.
The lives of thousands of employees were based on the principle that the company would take care of them. "It's a radical change," said Mr. DeBenedictis, 43, who joined Aetna right out of high school in 1971.
Mr. DeBenedictis is unsure whether his job will exist next year, and he said that his fears are shared by many in the company. "Doom and gloom" is the way he described the morale at work.
Employees once felt a tremendous loyalty to the company, he said: "Now, you feel loyalty to yourself." He said he once felt proud to tell people he worked at Aetna; now, he sometimes ducks the question.
The change can be seen on the streets of the city. Veronica Airey-Wilson, a Hartford City Council member, recalled that at the start of the 1990's, she would see as many as 60 acquaintances walking from the three big insurance companies to their homes nearby. "None of those people are here anymore," she said.
In 1991, the United Way of the Capital Area collected $26 million; this year, $21 million. "Many of those who contributed are now on the receiving end," Susan Dunn, its vice president, said.
Mr. Carbone, the real estate developer, who now is president of the Connecticut Institute for Municipal Studies, said that the pain caused by the downsizing was too often being overlooked. Several friends, he said, have died from heart attacks that he attributed to the stress from the failing local economy. He suffered a heart attack himself when Aetna stopped leasing a building from him last year.
"If I were Mayor of Hartford, I would hire the best lawyers out there and make it clear that there'd be no mergers unless the companies make an explicit commitment to Hartford," he said. "These people have an obligation to employees, and they have to be forced to meet it."
Indeed, Governor Rowland has scheduled a meeting for Mondaywith the heads of Aetna and Travelers to discuss the proposed sale, which needs state approval, and to insure that adequate steps are being taken to protect employees.
Ms. Oberdorf, the Aetna spokeswoman, said that the agreement includes a strong safety net for all its employees who may be affected. A spokeswoman for Travelers said the company was unable to provide an executive to discuss its future commitment to Hartford.
Yet there is also a sense that the insurance industry's downsizing here is driven by forces that go beyond the state's control.
Lewis Mandell, who as a professor at the University of Connecticut Business School issued a report on the Hartford insurance industry earlier this year, said he did not expect substantial future job growth.
Dr. Mandell, now a dean at Marquette University, noted that some companies found it difficult to recruit young people to Hartford and that several executives' remarks suggested they had little commitment to the area.
"There's one thing keeping them in Hartford," Dr. Mandell said: "They have big pieces of real estate that no one wants to buy."
His study, which included an analysis of labor trends and confidential interviews with executives from eight local companies, showed that the higher-end jobs were staying in Hartford and increasing in pay, but that less-skilled jobs were being transferred to other states or countries with lower labor costs. Those jobs were also being "out-sourced" to local contractors that provide the services at a cheaper price.
Hartford's claim to being the insurance capital was never that it controlled a dominant share of the business -- both New York and London have much more -- but that the concentration of major companies was so high in such a small area. While insurance accounts for 1.9 percent of jobs nationally, it constitutes more than double that in Connecticut, with 4.7 percent, and far more in the Hartford area, where most of the Connecticut insurance jobs lie.
While many argue that Hartford's pool of skilled labor will attract new insurance business, Dr. Mandell was less confident. Many tasks, like forms processing and sales, no longer need a skilled work force at headquarters, he noted. Insurance companies are increasingly opening satellite offices to be closer to customers around the nation, he said.
In recent years, a number of other insurance centers have emerged, most notably in Des Moines, and in some respects, they have eaten into Hartford's pre-eminence.
"Is there a single city in the United States that has a greater insurance concentration than Hartford?" Dr. Mandell asked. "I think the answer is no; it still has the crown."
"But I don't know how many of these jobs will remain there," he added. "The Hartford area is still very much at risk."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 7, 1995, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the decline of the insurance industry in Hartford referred incorrectly to the abandonment of buildings. Hartford officials say 1 building out of 30 has been abandoned -- not 1 in 10, a figure supplied by Nick Carbone, president of the Connecticut Institute of Municipal Studies.

HEADLINE: Orange County Bankruptcy: The Poor Feel the Most Pain

BYLINE: By By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Dec. 1

 BODY:
One year after startling America by declaring its improbable bankruptcy, Orange County is stumbling through a fiscal recovery that has generally placated its affluent middle class and faraway Wall Street but has shifted much of the burden to the county's growing numbers of poor.
The initially frightening predictions of a financial calamity that would spread across the land have proved overblown. Instead, Orange County has passed through phases of shock and defiance and has entered a comfort zone that many here say is part denial, part business as usual and part pushing the costs of the crisis on to those who have the least voice in civic affairs. 
 The county has settled into what many experts here describe as a kind of ominous stability. "I'm not sure we've dealt with some of the fundamental problems that caused this bankruptcy," said William J. Popejoy, a retired banking executive who served as the county's chief executive for several months after the crisis erupted. "We haven't improved accountability in the government; we haven't shared the costs very evenly."
In the aftermath, the county has tried to recoup its losses in a lawsuit against Merrill Lynch & Company, its main securities firm. Indeed, Merrill Lynch, which denies any wrongdoing, is the target of more than 10 lawsuits as a result of the bankruptcy. [Page D1.]
The county's bankruptcy was the result of an attempt to avoid a harsh fiscal reality: With property taxes falling, the county pushed to maintain services by increasing its interest income from investments. Its treasurer bet aggressively -- and ineptly -- in the bond market, losing $1.7 billion when interest rates turned upward early last year. Rather than express remorse at having fumbled away such a vast sum, the county has faced down Wall Street's threats and forced many of its bondholders to accept at least a one-year delay in repayment.
Last April, a newsletter published by James Grant, a New York bond market expert, warned that Orange County might not be able to sell new bonds for a decade. In fact, it has been back to the market already, backed by an expensive form of bond insurance, and investors are likely to buy even more next year. "Markets don't hold grudges," Mr. Grant now says.
Those who successfully opposed a sales tax increase last spring predicted as much, saying the county could muddle through without more cash. Indeed, lawyers for the county say the government is likely to emerge from bankruptcy by June. Credit rating agencies are already saying they will consider raising the junk grading of the county's bonds to an investment grade at that time.
"I suspect that five years from now this will be just a blip in financial history," said Zane Mann, publisher of the California Municipal Bond Advisor, a newsletter. "And believe me, this will happen all over again somewhere. Nothing really has been learned."
But the bankruptcy has exacted a price. The county government has made sharp spending cuts of more than $180 million and has tried selling off everything from office buildings to landfills. Voters in June rejected a half-cent increase in the sales tax that would have helped repay $800 million in bonds coming due. The resulting austerity drive has created the spectacle of one of America's most affluent counties slashing programs for the poor.
"It's been the disadvantaged, the poor, the incarcerated who have felt what this bankruptcy is about," said Marian Bergeson, one of five county supervisors. "They have been the losers, and will continue to be."
At a crowded welfare center here on Walnut Street on Friday, Susan Fogarty, the district manager, said layoffs had increased employees' case loads to 216 new food-stamp recipients a month from 137.
"This is a stressful job to begin with," she said, motioning toward the lobby, where five sheriff's deputies stood near a metal detector, keeping order. "All this just makes it a lot more tense."
 
Programs Are Cut For Homeless and Others
The county's probation department has had to shut down a program that allowed 110 low-risk prisoners to maintain jobs while living in halfway houses. There are no longer outreach programs for the 12,000 homeless people who subsist in the county. A program that trained and found jobs for 250 people with severe mental impairments has closed.
"Those people had the hope of a job on their horizons," said Tim Mullins, director of the county's mental health and alcohol and drug abuse programs. "That door is now shut."
Out of the 1,600 county jobs that were eliminated, half came from the Social Services Agency. The agency was also forced to halve the number of its contracts with community therapists that counsel and monitor thousands of families at risk of child abuse, a move that its former administrator, Gene Howard, called "most devastating, and most dangerous."
With ordinary channels of providing food and medical care to the poor being squeezed, private charities are also feeling the pinch. On Thanksgiving Day alone, the Orange County Rescue Mission in Santa Ana handed out 19,000 meals, a fivefold increase over last year, said James E. Palmer, executive director.
In the past, the mission's mobile medical unit attracted only a handful of patients. But last week, when the van showed up at a park, it was mobbed by 150 people in an hour, he said.
 
Middle Class Takes The Crisis in Stride
Kathryn L. Ditch, a coordinator for Friends in Service to Humanity in Newport Beach, said the crisis was overwhelming her organization, which grants emergency loans to low-income renters. "People we see are living on the edge," Ms. Ditch said.
But if the poor are hurting, the middle class is sailing through the fiscal belt-tightening with relative ease. The most serious economic consequence for many has probably been the slump in housing prices. Two big local real estate companies, the Santa Margarita Company and the Western National Group, recently scrapped a merger plan in part, they said, because the bankruptcy had weakened the housing market.
But over all, the county -- like the rest of the state -- is growing again after the long California recession. Tens of thousands of new jobs have been created. Meantime, the middle class is rallying to the support of one cause it holds dear, public schools.
Schools throughout the county will benefit from money raised from a Jan. 2 raffle for a donated car at Fashion Island, a Newport Beach shopping center. A spring convention of businesses that caters to children raised $5,000 for school districts from ticket sales. Joe MacPherson, a car dealer, who pledged $50 from each car sold toward schools, ended up contributing $170,000. Parents even rushed to supermarkets and warehouse stores and bought giant packages of toilet paper to resupply the Venado Middle School in Irvine after it ran out.
Such grass-roots action "absolutely didn't occur before the bankruptcy," said Elizabeth A. Thomas, executive director of the Irvine Education Foundation, which raises funds for Irvine schools.
There are other silver linings. Mr. Mullins, the director of the county's mental-health and substance-abuse programs, said he had to cut 14 percent from his budget in one fell swoop. While painful, the reductions and layoffs were necessary, he said, to bring his costs in line with those of the private sector, with which he competes.
"I used the situation to do some downsizing that I could never have done otherwise," Mr. Mullins said. "In the long term, in some ways, I'll be better off."
 
Official Under Pressure For Higher Returns
The unraveling of Orange County's finances built up over several years but came to a head quickly. Robert L. Citron, its Treasurer for 24 years, had been under pressure to produce higher returns from a county-run investment fund in part because California's taxpayer revolt was putting a lid on property taxes. He placed about two-thirds of his investments in complex financial instruments known as derivatives. These bond-like securities are structured so that their value rises -- and falls -- much faster than ordinary bonds.
In the spring of 1994, Mr. Citron was up for re-election, and he was criticized by his opponent for the risky investments. Mr. Citron dismissed the criticism as partisan bickering and even the Orange County edition of The Los Angeles Times declared in an editorial, "The cloud drawn over Citron increasingly looks like a bum rap."
The Securities and Exchange Commission met with Mr. Citron in April and May of 1994 to review his investments, but took no actions. The rating agencies also examined the county's finances. In August, Moody's Investors Services gave Orange the highest county investment rating in California.
But Mr. Citron had bet on lower interest rates, and instead they kept rising. County officials, growing increasingly alarmed, finally brought in a consultant, who informed them on Nov. 16 -- a month after Mr. Citron had issued a generally bullish annual report -- that the county's $7.4 billion investment fund had suffered at least a $1.5 billion loss. The county disclosed the news on Dec. 1 and declared bankruptcy five days later.
For the most part, that has placed much of the responsibility for sorting out the county's problems into the hands of its lawyers and consultants, who will have earned about $50 million by the time the bankruptcy ends, the county estimates.
The bond rating agencies missed all the early warning signs. Barbara Flickinger, an official at Moody's, said the agency now looked more closely at municipal investment practices, but her agency had not altered its basic procedures to catch such problems in the future.
The county has sued Merrill Lynch for more than $2 billion, contending that Merrill sold the county inappropriate securities and misled Mr. Citron.
Recently released tapes show that Merrill's broker, Michael Stamenson, warned Mr. Citron as early as 1992 that his investment strategy carried terrible risks, but Mr. Stamenson continued to sell him the securities. Merrill says that Mr. Stamenson remains an employee in good standing.
 
Budget Is Reordered, And County Goes On
As for the county government, the bankruptcy has reordered its budgetary priorities. Since a new tax was rejected as a way of repaying bondholders, the county and state agreed on a plan to take $15 million a year away from the county's transportation agency, which would mean sharp cuts in bus service. Several million dollars more will be diverted for more than a decade from flood control, harbors and parks.
Many of the politicians who were supposed to have been overseeing the county's finances have resigned or said they will not run for office again, but the wholesale reorganization of the government many people had promised in this highly conservative county looks like a distant dream.
As for Mr. Citron, he has pleaded guilty to six felony counts related to his financial mismanagement, but has not been charged with taking a penny for himself. He is scheduled to be sentenced on Dec. 29. His defense has been that he suffered from dementia. That is a strange twist for the proud man who lorded over the county's finances with the kind of cockiness the county itself had once demonstrated. A year ago, withdrawn and slightly incoherent, Mr. Citron signed a letter of resignation in his living room here, then waited for a psychologist sent by his colleagues to arrive.
