HEADLINE: As Larger Cities Gain Ground on Ills, Smaller Ones Lose

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Increases in violent crime, infant mortality the spread of AIDS and other urban problems have begun to recede in some of the nation's largest cities, while they are continuing to rise in smaller cities, a new report by a public-health research organization said today.
The report, issued by the nonprofit National Public Health and Hospital Institute, was based on census information, Federal crime statistics and health-care surveys from the nation's 100 largest cities. It found, among other things, that from 1980 to 1990, the number of children living in poverty increased nationally by 12 percent, while in the 25 largest cities, the ranks of poor children increased by 9.4 percent. 
 The study also found that violent crime over the same time increased nationally by 46 percent, while the rise was 36.4 percent in the largest cities.
Referring to programs that had lowered the incidence of disease, the report said that since 1980 "the largest 25 cities are doing better" than the United States generally.
Dennis P. Andrulis, the institute's president, said the group's report should be taken into consideration by Federal lawmakers in drafting legislation that would turn programs like Medicaid into block grants administered by states.
The Republicans' plan to balance the budget would establish block grants for welfare, child care and Medicaid, and, in some cases, food stamps. Mr. Andrulis said he was concerned that block grants would not take into consideration specific needs of individual cities, adding, "Proposed block grants, with their fixed-funding formulas, may not be well-suited to what cities need."
President Clinton has said he will veto the budget bill, but he has not specifically objected to the idea of using block grants for cash assistance to poor people, though he has objected to the Medicaid block grants.
Mr. Andrulis said that many of the largest cities were finding some solutions to intractable problems simply out of desperation and that their approaches should be studied by smaller cities with similar problems.
For example, the report found that local health officials in Cleveland, the country's 23d largest city, had made significant strides in combatting the incidence of tuberculosis, gonorrhea and AIDS.
"Cleveland may serve as a model of disease control for other U.S. cities," Mr. Andrulis said.
The report said the country's most populous city, New York, was a prime example of a large city's having rates of violent crime, infant mortality, teen-age pregnancies, high school graduation and households headed by women among others that were better than the national averages.
By comparison, the report found that in Mobile, Ala., the 79th most-populous city, the increase of violent crime was almost triple the average of the 100 cities; the decline in the rate of infant mortality was a third of the national average; the decline of teen-age pregnancies was less than half the national average, and the increase of high school graduations lagged behind the national average by about a fifth.
The number of households led by women in Mobile increased by almost 26 percent, a rate two-thirds above the national average.
"The overall perception of large cities is that they are dens of iniquity while smaller cities have more of a main street ideal with a veneer of respectability," said Sara Rosenbaum, director of the George Washington University Center for Health Policy Research and an adviser to the report. "But if you put aside the assumptions, underneath, the problems are often far worse in smaller cities."
Officials from cities with smaller populations than the 100 examined by the report say urban problems are finding their way into suburban towns and villages. John DeStefano, the Mayor of New Haven, said in an interview that communities around Connecticut's largest cities, Bridgeport, Hartford and New Haven none of which are among the 100 most populous cities, have begun encountering the same problems found in New York and Los Angeles.
And just as necessity has forced big-city mayors to devise solutions to these problems, officials in the smaller towns have also been pressed to find creative programs.
"We do much better with crime and violent crime than towns around us," Mr. DeStefano said. "We had to. You tend to see more aggressive response in areas of greater challenge."
The report, which was financed in part by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, found that smaller cities struggling with one problem were not necessarily suffering others to the same degree. El Paso, for example, 22d in population, experienced no appreciable improvement in poverty rates from 1980 to 1990, but over the same time moved into the lead among the largest cities in its AIDS prevention rate.
While no city distinguished itself as the worst in all categories, Detroit, the seventh-largest city, came dramatically close, ranking No. 100 for unemployment and poverty, No. 99 for infant mortality and No. 97 for the murder rate.

HEADLINE: As Logging Returns, Recrimination on Why

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 1

 BODY:
Loggers have returned to the old-growth forests of the Pacific Northwest this fall, bulldozing roads into pristine areas and leveling 200-year-old trees in a manner that was illegal until four months ago.
The leveling, or clear-cutting, will damage rivers and streams, set back a $1.2 billion Federal program to restore overcut national forests and could eradicate some runs of Chinook salmon, President Clinton has said. 
 But, whether by bad fortune or design, the President now finds himself in the position of criticizing something he helped to create. The act he recently attacked for its potential to cause "grave environmental damage" is one he signed into law last summer, after initially vetoing it. It has turned out, Mr. Clinton said, to be far more damaging than he or many members of Congress anticipated.
The green light to cut big swaths of centuries-old trees came about because of a Congressional rider to a popular budget-reduction bill that suspends all environmental laws in some areas of national forests in Washington and Oregon through the end of next year.
The rider was promoted by Western Republicans, like Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, as a way to cut fire-scarred or bug-infested salvage timber and promote forest health.
But a single paragraph in the rider had nothing to do with damaged trees. It directed the Government to lift all environmental laws in a few areas so that some old-growth timber could be cut.
The timber industry, which, along with other development interests in the West, has strongly opposed Mr. Clinton as being too sympathetic to environmentalists, asked Congress for a suspension of the laws, saying they were being used in court to virtually shut down logging in national forests. After Republicans took control of Congress this year, they approved the rider.
Mr. Clinton initially vetoed the budget bill, saying the rider "would basically direct us to make timber sales to large companies subsidized by the taxpayers." After some changes were made -- changes that the President said would provide adequate protection -- he signed the bill with an amended rider.
A day later, the timber industry went to court, arguing that the crucial paragraph in the rider permitted unregulated logging of forest lands throughout the Pacific Northwest that were long thought to have been protected. A Federal court in Oregon has agreed.
Now, even as Mr. Clinton has embraced environmental values as a rallying cry for his re-election campaign -- "I will not compromise on the environment," he declared last week -- environmentalists say the President has already betrayed them. Although the Administration says it was misled about the rider's intent, environmentalists say the intent was clear and by signing the bill, the President risked the very thing he now criticizes.
"Most of Congress, the President and the American people were duped," said Patti Goldman, an attorney with the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund. "A few watchful timber industry advocates knew exactly what they were doing when they wrote this rider into the law. This is political payback to the industry."
Before the President signed the bill, environmentalists had flooded the White House with more than 50,000 letters and calls urging him to veto it again. Ever since he signed it, on July 27, they have been furious.
"The timber industry bought Congress and in essence got them to remove all citizens' rights, barring them from the courthouse door," said Tim Hermach of the Native Forest Council in Oregon. "To be kind, you can say President Clinton was naive to go along with them. To be less than kind, you can say it was stupidity or a cave-in."
To critics in both parties, the twist of events shows the danger of using obscure side-amendments to change some of the nation's basic environmental laws. Republicans in Congress have attached riders to the budget reconciliation that would open the Arctic National Wildife Refuge to oil drilling and increase logging elsewhere.
The logging rider was attached this summer to a bill that cut 1995 spending by $16 billion and that included money Mr. Clinton had urgently sought for relief of disasters like the Oklahoma City bombing and the California earthquakes.
Since then, the price of wood has declined due to a slump in the housing market, and the timber industry has not shown as much interest in cutting salvage timber. The Forest Service has offered thousands of acres but have not gotten a single offer in the last three months.
The real action is with the healthy, valuable stands of old-growth forest that had been protected both by the President's 1993 forest plan and by litigation, which has kept them off-limits to logging for the last five years. These stands are home to endangered fish and birds, and in some case hold most of the water for entire river systems.
Now that they are exempt from environmental laws, including statutes that protect clean water, timber companies are trying to get as much of this wood as they can during the period when they do not have to comply with the law.
The Clinton Administration had said the rider applied only to a few select areas of some national forest, according to Jim Lyons, assistant Agriculture Secretary for forestry.
But Federal Judge Michael Hogan of Oregon, who is hearing the suit by the timber industry, agreed with the logging companies' interpretation. He ordered the Forest Service and other agencies to offer for sale old growth timber in areas of all national forests in Oregon and Washington. The Administration has appealed, but an appeals court has refused to grant an injunction.
So, after five years of relative peace, the timber wars have returned to the Northwest, with protesters blocking logging roads and interest groups pointing fingers.
The Forest Service now estimates that nearly twice as many trees will fall under the special rider as was estimated by the Administration when the President signed the bill. They say more than 600 million board feet of mostly old-growth timber will be cut. By comparison, less than 100 million board feet of older forests have been been cut in the last three years. About 10,000 board feet of timber are used to build the average house.
The numbers are crucial, say people who have been working to restore national forests in the Northwest, because more than 90 percent of old-growth forests, a term that describes stands that have never been cut, have been logged.
"This is not what we had in mind when the President signed the bill," said Tom Tuchmann, who is overseeing the new forest plan for the Administration. "But you have to put this in perspective. These are the last of the big old-growth sales. Over all, it will have small impact. The President's plan still protects 80 percent of the remaining old growth."
Timber industry officials say Mr. Clinton is being disingenuous in his recent statements about the intent of the rider.
"The environmentalists for the first time are not getting their way," said Chris West, spokesman for the Northwest Forestry Association, which represents timber companies. "They are beating up on the President, so his recent statements are just a way to show them that he's green."
Mr. West said the old-growth logging is "a drop in the bucket" compared to years ago, and he said it will not significantly harm the environment. When asked whether loggers would comply with requests by Federal biologists that they try not to harm some streams with endangered salmon and trout runs, Mr. West said, "that's a call left up to the individual companies."
He said Federal environmental laws had been used to shut down virtually all logging in the remaining old-growth areas on public land and until the laws are changed, the industry is likely to need protection from lawsuits.
Logging company owners, after years of losing court battles to environmentalists, are happy to finally have some Federal timber back in the mills. The owners of Hull-Oaks Lumber in Monroe, Ore., say the new timber will allow them to keep their small mill -- which depends almost exclusively on old growth -- running for another five months.
Throughout the Northwest, much of the new clear-cutting will take place in the very areas where the Government is spending millions of dollars trying to restore streams and woodlands to protect fish and wildlife. It is, for the most part, the old-style logging that the Forest Service, since the early 1990's, has condemned -- felling every tree in a given area, logging right to edge of streams that may be spawning grounds for salmon and trout.
In southern Oregon, logging will begin taking place any day in forest areas near the Umpqua River, the centerpiece of a $36 million sports-fishing industry. Federal biologists have recently written memorandums saying that the new logging in the area, because it does not have to comply with environmental laws, could severely damage cutthroat trout and salmon runs in the river basin.
Also, a thriving tourism business has developed around rafting and sightseeing along the Umpqua, portions of which are part of the nation's Wild and Scenic River system.
Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon said much of the new Federal logging went too far and could damage the state's thriving economy.
Mr. Kitzhaber was one of several Democrats who earlier had said they thought the rider would be relatively harmless.
After Mr. Clinton vetoed the initial version, some changes were made after negotiations. The period when loggers could ignore all environmental laws was reduced by a year. And Forest Service supervisors were told that they could enforce good stewardship standards in the sales of burned or insect-damaged timber.
With those changes, the President signed the bill, saying there were adequate protections.
But the key paragraph of the rider dealing with the old-growth timber was never changed. It is that section that has caused the furor.
"Somebody convinced the Administration that it wasn't such a big deal," said Mitch Friedman, head of the Northwest Ecosystem Alliance, an environmental group. "They disguised this all as salvage sales. As it turned out, there was a loophole big enough to drive a parade of logging trucks through."

In the Willamette National Forest in Oregon, environmentalists have built an encampment on a logging road. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Degrees of Separation;
At York College, Race and Generation Etch Tensions

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
On a crisp morning this fall, administrators bedecked in blue satin doctoral gowns and matching mortarboards celebrated the founding of York College in South Jamaica, Queens, with lofty speeches in the school's sprawling auditorium.
But the audience was so small that the ceremony, marking the school's 28th anniversary, could have been held in a lecture hall. And the few students who did attend seemed to be struggling to stay awake, including one young man stretched across two chairs. 
 While administrators attributed the light turnout to a primarily adult commuter population that does not have time for outside activities, student government leaders said it underscored their lack of respect for the administration.
"They alienate us," said Jose Rivas Cinque, 22, the student government president. "We're not interested in attending their ceremonies if they are not interested in listening to us."
For three years now, students at the largely black campus on Guy R. Brewer Boulevard have clashed with administrators over what they see as issues of race and self-determination -- specifically, who can deliver the keynote address on Black Solidarity Day.
The latest incident came on Nov. 6, when police officers and campus guards in riot gear were called in as dozens of students protested loudly outside the school over the administration's refusal to allow a former aide to Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam leader, to speak. Administrators eventually rescinded their decision, and the crowd of 300 at the Solidarity address was almost twice as large as the one at the Founder's Day ceremony a week later.
At first glance, the students appear to be engaged in the kind of questioning of authority typical of youth. But a strong undercurrent of resentment seems to run beneath the surface, compounded by the fact that about 67 percent of the faculty is white and 62 percent of the college's 6,490 students are black.
Many attribute general tensions to the fact that it is a school in transition that is trying to balance dwindling resources. One of the youngest schools in the City University system, the college has seen its $24 million operating budget cut by $2.1 million, forcing a restructuring of the education, remedial and activities programs, and raising fears that the college will be scaled back to a two-year college or technical school, as has been proposed, despite assurances from officials that it will not.
An intensive search is also under way for a new college president. Josephine Davis, the school's first female black leader, resigned in February after being accused by some faculty members of using public dollars to renovate her office and residence, making political contributions with college funds and billing the school twice for certain expenses.
Events leading up to Dr. Davis's abrupt departure illuminated the tensions at the school, causing infighting and pitting local black leaders against the white faculty, whom they charged with waging a campaign of "academic sedition" against Dr. Davis because of her race. Supporters said her efforts to restructure the staff had unnerved some people who had been at the college since it was founded.
Today, six positions are filled with acting administrators, including that of president, which is held by Thomas K. Minter, a former deputy chancellor of instruction for the New York City public school system.
Coming out of retirement to take the temporary job, Dr. Minter, who is black, said he stepped in because he wanted to make a contribution to a school he saw as important to South Jamaica. The typical York student is a black woman around age 28 with a child.
Promoted as the linchpin of the area's redevelopment, the school opened in 1986 on once-blighted land after operating for 20 years out of temporary headquarters, in part because the mid-1970's fiscal crisis delayed construction until 1980.
To some extent, the school has lived up to to its redevelopment promise. Just south of the school, 250 units of two-family houses have been constructed over the last several years and the City University of New York has put forth a plan to turn an overgrown vacant lot into a federally subsidized strip of shops and restaurants with a provision to allow the college to use part of the development for a student center and day care center.
The Food and Drug Administration plans to open on the campus its largest laboratory outside its national headquarters in Maryland, testing batches of food, pharmaceuticals and cosmetics, which would strengthen the school's health and science program.
"The community wanted this college," said F. Carlisle Towery, president of the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, a nonprofit group. "It's a consumer and generator of favorable traffic. What's going on there now I don't see as anything other than a normal college environment. Kids are intellectually curious, learning about political affairs, and they challenge authority."
But Quentin Wolcott, the student government vice president, who brought in the Farrakhan aide, Khalid Abdul Muhammad, said that "to call the conflicts an exercise of intellectual challenge would be simplifying tensions on campus," which have boiled over for three years on Black Solidarity Day. Students butted heads with administrators before Mr. Muhammad's first speech last year and over one the year before by Prof. Leonard Jeffries, who had been deposed and reinstated as the chairman of the black studies department at City College over statements he made that were considered anti-Semitic and racist.
While expressing anger with the school's administration, Mr. Cinque said the CUNY Chancellor, W. Ann Reynolds, was the real target.
"She realizes students are sleeping giants and someone like Khalid Muhammad might incite students to take control of the college and their lives," Mr. Cinque said. "Let us decide who we want to listen to and what to walk away from. Everyone is so focused on Muhammad, but that's not what this is about."
It is also, he said, about recent cutbacks that ended secondary-education programs and consolidated a state-mandated remedial program into mainstream studies. Mr. Cinque said he believed that the cuts are symbolic of larger plans to slash liberal arts programs, a concern voiced by other students.
"There are several technical schools and two-year colleges we could have attended if that's what we wanted, but we came to York," said Dana Palomo, 21, of Rego Park, one of a dozen or so students at the student cafeteria one recent afternoon who expressed fears about York's future. "We need more support from the students to rally against the budget cuts and any plans to turn this into a technical school. We need to fight this, or our degrees will mean nothing."
The source of the concern is a 160-page evaluation in 1993 from Leon M. Goldstein, president of Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn, intended to eliminate duplication of services within the City University system. The report recommended strengthening the school's technical programs.
Jay Hershenson, CUNY's vice chancellor and a spokesman for Ms. Reynolds, said that the recommendation was never seriously considered and that most such fears were a natural outgrowth of the college's being between presidents.
"York College must remain a liberal arts institution that offers professional programs," he said. "It is a college that everyone has viewed from the outset as being indispensable to the economic and educational development of South Jamaica."
But Adolphus Frazier, director of career planning and placement, who has been at the school for 27 years, said the staff itself is worried about the school's direction. He said they remain disturbed about the racial makeup of the faculty.
"York College was established for the community, and I believe its faculty should reflect the community," Mr. Frazier said. "But black males are continually being passed up for promotions, and something has to be done."
W. Hubert Keen, provost and vice chancellor for academic affairs, maintained that the school has difficulty attracting minority faculty.
Mr. Hershenson said: "It is true that during the period when President Davis served, the college had its ups and downs. Now, we're in transition -- and it's not unexpected there will be growing pains -- it is everyone's hope that York College will be positioned for greatness."

HEADLINE: Dole at Forefront of Trade Battle To Aid Donor's Banana Empire

SERIES: THE FINE PRINT: A close look at a debate on trade.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole is a busy man these days. He is running for President. He is immersed in the arcane details of the budget battle, Bosnia policy and the future of Medicaid and Medicare. But when it comes to introducing legislation, one subject has repeatedly turned up at the top of Mr. Dole's agenda: bananas.
Several times in recent months Mr. Dole has tried -- so far unsuccessfully -- to include in the budget bill amendments that would impose sharp trade sanctions on Costa Rica and Colombia unless they pull out of a trade deal involving banana exports with the European Union. At least one major American food producer, Chiquita Brands International, says that deal is intended to reduce its share of the profitable banana market in Europe. 
 Mr. Dole's office says he is acting because the Clinton Administration has "failed to deliver on its two-year-old commitment to resolve this case of blatant trade discrimination, which continues to cause serious injury to U.S. commercial interests."
Other people in Washington have another explanation: One of the largest contributors to the Republican Party these days is the family and corporate empire of Carl Lindner, a multimillionaire from Cincinnati who controls Chiquita. Senator Dole has been flying around to campaign appearances in planes owned by the Lindner family's many corporate interests.
In a statement today, the Senator's office said the contributions, and the airplanes, were irrelevant. "Senator Dole has taken this position because it is right for America, and to suggest any other reason is totally absurd," the statement said.
Without question, Mr. Dole is hardly Chiquita's only friend in Washington: over the years, Democrats have also benefited greatly from Mr. Lindner's largesse.
Senator Dole's efforts have been backed by Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, whose office said today that it was aiding "a constituent with a grievance." The Administration has also opened an investigation into the banana politics between Europe and Latin America.
While that inquiry is not expected to end until early next year, the White House has already made clear that it is a low-priority issue, hardly worthy of the severe trade sanctions against Costa Rica and Colombia that Mr. Dole is proposing.
The problem for both the Senator and the Administration is that the agreement between Europe and several Latin American countries has little direct effect on American jobs.
The pact reserves a share of Europe's banana market to each of several Latin American nations. Those nations largely determine which producer gets the license to export to Europe, and Chiquita's share has been vastly reduced. But there is little direct effect on American jobs, because very few bananas are grown in this country.
Instead, American companies like Chiquita buy or invest in bananas grown elsewhere. And until now, trade retaliation has rarely been a weapon used to protect American investors abroad.
Even the United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, who has a pretty subtle understanding of how political and trade interests merge, had to pause for a minute when he was asked at a news conference the other day to identify any American economic interests at stake in what many in Latin America now call the "banana war." Then, with a broad smile, he said, "If you drive north on the Pacific Coast Highway, I think there's 10 acres of bananas on the right-hand side."
Chiquita and the Lindner family have little to say about Senator Dole's efforts. A Chiquita spokesman did not return calls today about the issue, nor did Mr. Lindner.
Both Democrats and Republicans maintain that Chiquita has a legitimate case: The agreement between the Latin American countries and Europe, where bananas sell for comparatively high prices, probably is a violation of the world trade treaty approved last year. Mr. Dole reluctantly embraced that accord, in a deal with the White House that saved the agreement from defeat.
But Chiquita has been alone in its complaints. Its other major competitors, including Del Monte Foods and the Dole Food Company (with which Mr. Dole has no relationship), have found alternative ways around Europe's restrictive rules by investing in companies in the Caribbean that benefit from the arcane European quota system. Chiquita was slower to move, and so it has turned to Washington to stem the damage.
What surprised many in Congress, however, is the ferocity with which Mr. Dole took on Chiquita's cause. Twice in recent months he proposed an amendment on the Senate floor to impose sanctions on Costa Rica and Colombia, hoping to get unanimous consent to append the action to bills that were far larger.
Those efforts failed. An effort to get the amendment included as part of the broad budget bill now being negotiated with President Clinton also failed after other Republicans expressed fear that including one special-interest trade provision would open the floodgates to others.
Senator Dole has also urged Republicans in the House to act on the issue. The Journal of Commerce reported recently that he raised the issue with Speaker Newt Gingrich when the two leaders were flying to Israel last month to attend the funeral of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin. Whether he struck a banana deal at 30,000 feet is lost to history.
Mr. Dole's aides say that, for a while at least, bananas are off the table. But the search is on to find other, appropriate legislation to append the Dole amendment.
All this, not surprisingly, has hardly drawn much attention in Washington, where bananas do not rate with Bosnia and the budget. But in Latin America, it has been front-page news.
Trade experts say that one reason that Mr. Dole's efforts have not received more attention is that Democrats and Republicans alike are indebted to the Lindner family's generosity.
While estimates vary, groups that track campaign donations agree that the Lindners, companies they control and other senior executives of those companies gave roughly a million dollars to Democrats and Republicans in the last two years, mostly in "soft money" to political action committees. Gopac, which Mr. Gingrich headed until earlier this year, has received contributions, and so has Mr. Dole's committee.
 
The Fine Print
This series of occasional articles examines less-noticed facets of Federal legislation, laws and regulations.

HEADLINE: 25-Year Checkup Shows Gains in Air Quality but a Decline in Trash Disposal

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
In 25 years, New York City has made significant gains in improving its air quality and the cleanliness of its waterways, but the quality of its drinking water has slipped, and disposing of the city's garbage is a persistent problem, according to a report by a leading environmental advocacy group.
The report by the Natural Resources Defense Council, "New York City's Environmental Vital Signs: A 25-Year Checkup," compiled findings from 75 governmental and independent studies to paint a broad picture of the city's environment since the first Earth Day, in April 1970. 
 "It's safe to say that since 1970, there has been gradual improvement," said Eric A. Goldstein, director of the council's urban project. "But that's different from saying that comprehensive environmental health protections are in place or that the city's ecology is in balance."
The report, written by Mr. Goldstein and Mark Izeman, a lawyer with the council, found that while air and waterway quality have generally improved, progress has been little or nil in other major areas. It said, for example, that although all but one of the city's nine landfills operating in 1970 have been closed, the amount of garbage generated by New Yorkers has increased and recycling efforts have had only moderate success.
The amount of sewage flowing into the city's waterways has been sharply reduced, the report also said, but toxic pollutants from past industrial discharges are a lingering problem. And local problems -- like the proliferation of industrial pollution in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Williamsburg and Greenpoint -- persist. Lead poisoning of children, particularly in the poorest communities, remains one of the city's "most pressing" health threats.
The city's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, Marilyn Gelber, called the report "a fair assessment of the environmental protection progress that we've made."
"In particular," she said, "it highlights the importance of the Federal role in regulating and funding these efforts because clean air and clean water have nothing to do with political boundaries."
The report said that in the area of air quality, lead levels in the region have fallen by 95 percent since 1970, and "levels of carbon monoxide have declined from more than two and a half times national health standards in the early 1970's to just below the standard itself today." The levels of sulfur dioxide, which is considered a major cause of acid rain, have also declined significantly since 1970, the report said.
Still, "it goes too far" to suggest that the city's air quality problems have been solved, the report continued. Smog and particulate matter, especially from diesel trucks and buses, remain problems.
The quality of the city's waterways has also shown some improvement since 1970, the report said. The number of beaches open during the summer has increased, and the destruction of valuable wetlands has been slowed.
Only 10 years ago, at least 200 million gallons of raw sewage were discharged daily into the city's waterways. The opening of major sewage treatment plants on the Hudson River in Harlem and in Red Hook, Brooklyn, "largely stemmed these raw sewage discharges," the report said.
"Despite such improvements, significant sewage-related pollution persists in certain sections of the city," the report said. "The primary culprit is the discharge of raw sewage during wet weather periods, a result of the city's combined sewage pipes, which carry both stormwater and wastewater." And certain waterways, like the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, still have significant pollution.
New York City's drinking water is also considered safe, though the report said that "New York can no longer accurately boast that it has the most pristine drinking-water supply in the nation."
Although the upstate reservoirs are generally free of toxic contaminants and heavy metals, data from the city's Department of Environmental Protection indicate that 13 of the 19 reservoirs are eutrophic -- a condition that results in algae blooms and diminished water clarity.
Commissioner Gelber said the recently concluded agreement between the city, the state and eight upstate counties in the watershed would bring a new level of protection to the city's supply of drinking water. But, she added, "while it is a solid foundation for the future, it is not meant to be the last step."
About solid waste, the report noted that poorly controlled incinerators have been shut and several problem-plagued landfills have been closed.
"To be sure, the city remains overly dependent on the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island," the report said.
As late as 1980, the report said, less than 1 percent of the city's residential trash was recycled. A shift occurred after 1989, when the City Council passed a mandatory recycling law. By 1993, recycling reached 15 percent, though it slipped to 13.5 percent in mid-1995.
The report also expressed concern about hazardous waste sites. The State Department of Environmental Conservation lists 26 such sites in New York City on its 1995 Superfund registry. Of those, 19 are designated as posing "a significant threat to the public health or environment."
Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, who served as regional administrator for the Federal Environmental Protection Agency from 1989 to 1993, said the assessment by the council is "really very thoughtful and very well done."
"To me," he added, "emphasis should be on the fact that we have come a long way and have a long way to go."

HEADLINE: Union Capitulation Shows Strike Is Now Dull Sword

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Eighteen months after beginning one of the biggest and longest strikes of the 1990's, Caterpillar Inc. workers will soon be back making the company's giant yellow earth movers. By their own admission, they gained nothing by their walkout and, indeed, still face losing valued rights and benefits.
Over the weekend, about 80 percent of the 8,700 strikers voted to reject Caterpillar's last offer. But their union, the United Automobile Workers, still a rich and muscular giant within the depleted American labor movement, ordered them back. The union had spent $30 million, all for naught, defending them. Caterpillar never flinched. 
 Today, the company said it would take the workers back in its own good time. A Caterpillar vice president, Wayne Zimmerman, said in a statement that management had requested a meeting with union leaders "to determine whether their offer to return to work is being made in good faith." In view of changes in operations during the strike, Mr. Zimmerman said, "an immediate return to prestrike staffing of nearly a year and a half ago is simply not practical."
Faced with the union cutting off their $300-a-week strike benefits, the workers have little choice but to return when they are recalled to work.
Peter Feuille, director of the Institute for Industrial and Labor Relations at the University of Illinois, called the union's return "capitulation without surrender."
"The union has capitulated to the reality that Caterpillar has won the strike," he said. "They're not surrendering their quest for a fair contract. But when you're back at work as a union, what kind of leverage do you have?"
Union officials said that the rejection of the contract offer had proved the spirit of their workers. "We were elated about the vote," said Larry Solomon, president of Local 751 in Decatur, Ill., the site of a plant at which the union ordered an end to the strike. But he conceded that Caterpillar had won. "It's sickening to the stomach," he said.
Caterpillar's rout of the U.A.W. is a stark demonstration of the increasing futility of a weapon with which unions could once paralyze whole industries in promoting their members' interests. It also illustrates the might of the opposition confronting the new leadership of the 78-union American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, which promises militant new responses in trying to rekindle the labor movement.
Now and then, strikes can still hurt management and extract something for workers. A two-month strike by machinists against the Boeing Company is beginning to impede deliveries of new planes. But more and more often, companies succeed in devising strategies that blunt the power of strikes and unions.
Many companies permanently replace strikers, leaving union workers on the street even after a strike ends -- or terrify workers merely by threatening permanent replacement if they attempt a strike. Caterpillar stopped short of that threat and found it could still beat a strike.
So workers instead lay low and take their lumps in an erosion of wages, benefits and union prerogatives. The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service said that work stoppages -- strikes, mostly, and lockouts -- declined to 385 in the 12 months that ended on Sept. 30, from a record of 3,111 in 1977.
Caterpillar workers, said Mr. Solomon, of Local 751, will be returning to the plant under the terms of a management contract offer that, among other things, eviscerates union prerogatives, like grievance procedures, freezes wages except for increases to keep pace with inflation, denies amnesty to 150 strikers who were fired for hostile behavior and gives management more flexibility in scheduling workers' hours.
William Gould, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, which enforces the labor laws, declined to discuss the Caterpillar strike because the board had yet to rule on union complaints of labor practice violations. But he said that strikes, however disruptive, helped to balance the interests of workers with those of management.
"This trend," Mr. Gould said of the decline in strikes, "has brought about a potential for a decline in orderly labor-management relations. Strikes are orderly in that they are a part of a process that produces some resolution." That, he said, raises the question of whether unions will remain credible representatives of worker interests.
Caterpillar invoked the usual reasons why industries shave work forces and wages -- the pressure of foreign competition and the need to meet it with products that cost no more to make than they do in Mexico or Korea. The company also devised a strategy to undercut the union.
It moved white collar workers and temporary workers into its factories and proved the lie to its regular workers' claim that production quality would suffer and that customers would flee.
Two developments served the strategy. The forces of temporary workers, once mostly people with little skill, have grown with the addition of hundreds of thousands of skilled workers laid off in other industries, notably aerospace, and Caterpillar was able to draw on them.
Second, many manufacturing companies are less dependent on highly skilled workers than they used to be. Tobias Levkovich, a securities analyst at the investment banking firm of Smith, Barney, explained that Caterpillar once needed teams of tool-and-die makers, highly expert machinists who could take an engineer's drawing and fashion new machines and models of parts.
But these days, he said, much of the human skill required of tool-and-die making has been replaced by computer-controlled machines. "All they need is a technician, not a skilled tool-and-die guy," he said.
So the strike, he said, "was kind of irrelevant." Caterpillar's production rolled along. Sales rose during the strike. Profits rose. And the stock rose. "From Wall Street's perspective," he said, "they've really done well."
Mr. Feuille, of the University of Illinois, said: "There's no evidence I've seen that products suffered any drop in quality. I never heard any news reports from customers saying, 'You're sending me junk.' The strike was obviously not putting economic pressure on the company. The pressure was on the union and the workers."
There's a worse alternative to returning, union leaders say. They point to cases of strikes, like the one in the 1980's at Eastern Airlines, that ended with the collapse of the company -- and all its jobs.

HEADLINE: A Fidelity Fund Decides Not to Close to New Investors

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
When Fidelity Investments introduced its New Millennium fund in 1992, it said that the fund would employ a process called change analysis to uncover companies "likely to benefit from social and economic trends."
So far, it has done just that. The love for Internet-related stocks shown by the fund's manager, Neal P. Miller, has given New Millennium the best performance this year among all diversified Fidelity mutual funds, with a gain through last Friday of 51 percent. 
 But Fidelity, a unit of the FMR Corporation, had said in 1992 that it would take the unconventional step of closing the fund to new investments when assets reached $500 million, because "the more controllable fund size helps the fund manager to pursue the fund's objective."
When that level was reached last month, New Millennium's board voted to abandon the limit, angering at least one shareholder who said he had specifically invested because of that promise. In changing its mind, Fidelity apparently responded to an old-fashioned urge -- the lure of profit.
Fidelity's action illustrates what to many investors may be an unknown risk: mutual fund companies can change many such marketing promises at virtually any time, without seeking shareholder approval and, as Fidelity did last week, without informing current investors.
"It disturbs me that Fidelity would do this with an apparent lack of consideration for what shareholders might say and no awareness that anybody might be upset," said the disillusioned investor, James G. Taylor of Monterey, Calif., who added that he had bought the shares last month expecting the asset limit to be enforced.
The removal of the asset restriction is unlikely to have violated Securities and Exchange Commission regulations. But the incident was the second case in a week of questionable judgment in shareholder communications.
Last week, the company acknowledged that Jeffrey N. Vinik, manager of Fidelity Magellan, the biggest mutual fund, sold shares of Micron Technology even as a report was being readied for shareholders in which Mr. Vinik praised the stock's potential.
Robyn S. Tice, a Fidelity spokeswoman, said the New Millennium Fund's board voted not to enforce the asset limit because New Millennium was having "no difficulty complying with the fund's strategy." As of Friday, the fund held $540 million in assets, according to Ms. Tice.
When the fund was introduced, Ms. Tice said, Fidelity created the potential asset restriction because it was concerned that "with the trends the fund was seeking to follow and invest in, we weren't certain we would have enough investment choices."
A marketing brochure distributed to would-be investors and stapled around the outside of the fund's prospectus says that the strategy is to "discover unrecognized small and mid-sized companies with the potential to grow and benefit from future social and economic change."
But, Ms. Tice said, the board determined that enough of those potential investments existed.
Fidelity will enjoy greater benefits from higher assets because, as the fund's investment manager, it is paid a percentage of assets under management. Asked if that was a part of the decision, she replied, "The decision was based on our experience in managing the fund the past three years."
She said Fidelity planned to publish a notification of the change in its monthly mutual fund guide, a subscription publication, and to inform New Millennium shareholders in the fund's annual report, to be mailed in January. Until then, each prospectus sent to potential investors will contain a sticker noting the change.
A section on page 2 of the marketing brochure, "Fund Limits to Maximize the Potential," states that "New Millennium Fund seeks to cap its assets at $500 million, after which it will be closed to new investments."
On page 24 of the prospectus, dated Jan. 23, a more detailed explanation notes that the fund "currently intends" to suspend sales if the $500 million asset level is reached, but that "the fund reserves the right to change this limit in the future, and to reopen the fund to shareholders and/ or new investors after the current size limit has been reached."
A restriction that is not classified as a fundamental policy of the fund can be changed without a vote of shareholders, said Bob Plaze, assistant director of the Securities and Exchange Commission's division of investment management, who declined to comment on the specifics of the New Millennium case.
According to the fund's prospectus, the asset limit is not a fundamental policy.
As recently as late September, Fidelity officials said the company was "seriously considering" shutting off the fund to new investments, according to Laura Lallos, a mutual fund analyst at Morningstar. Ms. Lallos wrote an analysis of the fund on Sept. 29, noting the potential closing.
"An investor would have reasons to be disappointed if that was a serious consideration" in making an investment, she said. "Many investors do find a fund that limits its size appealing" because small funds can often benefit from a sharp move in the price of small stocks.

HEADLINE: Whitman Strongly Endorses Programs for Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: EWING TOWNSHIP, N.J. Dec. 4

 BODY:
Already at odds with the Republican Party's leadership for her support of abortion rights, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman put more space between herself and the party's conservative wing today by strongly endorsing affirmative-action programs.
Mrs. Whitman said New Jersey had benefited socially and economically because of public and private programs that take race and sex into account in hiring and promotion decisions. And she warned that the debate over the programs, taking place primarily in the upper ranks of her own party, "may ultimately threaten the progress we have made" toward equality. 
 Republican leaders in Congress have criticized affirmative-action programs, particularly those imposed by government on private industry. Some Republican leaders have said that weakening Federal affirmative-action policies would be on the party's agenda after the budget is passed.
"I know I can't end employment discrimination single-handedly," the Governor said at a conference of affirmative-action officers held at Trenton State College in this Trenton suburb, "but government should set an example of inclusiveness for others to follow."
The Governor made only one concession to new thinking about affirmative action, suggesting that one day the programs should be based on economic status rather than race or sex.
The mostly black audience of affirmative-action officers, largely from state and local government offices, gave Mrs. Whitman a standing ovation after her speech.
But the Governor got no such praise from New Jersey's public employee unions. Union leaders contend that Mrs. Whitman preaches affirmative action in state government while practicing budget policies that result in a disproportionate number of women and minorities being laid off or having their jobs and benefits downgraded.
"I think it's bogus on her part," said Bob Pursell, area director of the Communications Workers of America, New Jersey's largest state employee union. "On the one hand, she preaches diversity and inclusion; on the other, her layoff programs hurt the people she proposes to help. In the privatizing of the Motor Vehicles department, 90 percent of the people affected were women, and maybe 50 percent were minorities."
Mrs. Whitman has cut about 1,000 state jobs since taking office two years ago.
In her speech, the Governor drew a picture of a policy under attack and warned that affirmative action would have to strengthened, in ways she did not specify, to survive.
"If we do nothing," she said, "the whole system could be pulled down around us."
Mrs. Whitman has made a name for herself in national Republican circles as a fierce advocate of pro-business, small-government economic policies combined with a generous social inclusiveness, including a strong defense of abortion rights and a more muted but distinct support for homosexual rights.
Mrs. Whitman has never given evidence of trimming her views to suit her party's right wing. Early talk of her as a Vice Presidential prospect on the 1996 Republican ticket faded not only as the Governor denied interest in the office but also as her liberal views on these issues came into sharper public focus.
At a fund-raiser for moderate Republican candidates held in New York City last spring, several leading Republicans pleaded for tolerance within the party for differing views on abortion rights, but Mrs. Whitman rejected a soothing compromise on the issue, insisting in her speech that respect for abortion rights should be an irreducible element of Republican Party philosophy.

HEADLINE: The Bull, Under Fire;
Merrill Lynch Faces a Barrage Of Orange County Lawsuits

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
One year and more than 10 lawsuits later, Merrill Lynch & Company is in the crosshairs of legal sharpshooters as a result of the Orange County bankruptcy. Merrill's own shareholders are suing it. So are Orange County bondholders. The county itself wants $2 billion. Even a group of Orange County widows and their children have clamored for money from Wall Street's biggest brokerage firm.
To fight back, Merrill, which has denied any wrongdoing, has amassed an all-star defense team. The firm has spent about $40 million on legal fees so far, analysts say, with millions yet to come for litigation that could drag on for years. Novel legal theories are emerging. Merrill remains the most profitable firm on Wall Street and its municipal bond business is strong, but the firm is far more vulnerable on the legal front than any of its rivals that did business with the county. 
 Merrill's exposure comes partly from its size -- it did the most business in Orange County -- but also from the two hats it wore. Merrill-as-broker was the biggest seller of securities to Orange County's Treasurer, Robert L. Citron, who now contends he was suffering from "dementia" when dealing with Merrill. In a suit seeking $2 billion in damages, the county says Merrill sold it "unsuitable" securities.
But Merrill was also a leading underwriter of Orange County bonds. Many bond buyers now say the firm broke securities laws by withholding information from them that it got in its dealings with Mr. Citron about the county's crumbling finances, instead painting a rosy picture.
 A big problem for Merrill is that its defense against the county -- that it warned Mr. Citron repeatedly that his investments were risky -- could boomerang as it defends itself against bondholders. They ask a simple question: If Merrill warned Mr. Citron, why didn't it warn us, too?
"What Merrill offers as its defense in the suitability case," Harvey J. Goldschmid, a securities law professor at Columbia University, said, "may kill them in the underwriting case."
Clearly, the sheer volume of litigation reflects the sour feelings left in the wake of the bankruptcy a year ago. The county's $1.7 billion loss -- a result of bad bets with taxpayer funds on the direction interest rates would move -- shook confidence in the municipal bond market. There has been plenty of finger-pointing: against a county and its politicians, against a deal-hungry Wall Street, and against bond rating agencies and a Securities and Exchange Commission that failed to detect problems soon enough. The debate shows no signs of ending soon.
The main bondholder suit comes from the Kemper Investors Fund of Chicago, which argues that Merrill's disclosures were misleading and fraudulent and asks that it refund $198 million that Kemper invested in county notes. A similar class-action suit seeking unspecified damages has been filed on behalf of all retail buyers of Orange County securities between 1992 and 1994.
To Merrill, the suits are easily dismissed as sour grapes. "These are a bunch of people who suffered financial reverses," said a Merrill lawyer, Dennis J. Block, a partner at Weil, Gotshal & Manges. "Now they are looking to point a finger." Merrill, he added, "will fight has as hard as necessary to demonstrate how wrong these cases are."
To lead that fight, Merrill has assembled about 40 outside lawyers from six law firms. Joining Mr. Block is Harvey C. Pitt, a former S.E.C. counsel now with Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobson. Also on the team are a bankruptcy specialist, Harvey Miller of Weil Gotshal, and Ron Olson, who represented the Exxon Corporation against suits stemming from the Valdez oil spill. Merrill denies the $40 million estimate for its legal bills, but declines to give a number.
Legal experts say the county's $2 billion lawsuit against Merrill seeks to offer a broadened interpretation of "suitability" -- the concept that securities brokers can sell only securities "suitable" for customers' needs. Typically, this is intended to protect unsophisticated investors, the proverbial widows and orphans.
But Orange County's lawyers say "suitability" can also apply to sophisticated institutional investors, who have traditionally been exempt. Adding a special twist is the county's contention that when taxpayer money is involved, brokers have a special duty to know state law and not sell securities that might conflict with it.
"This is very much the cutting edge of the law," Norman S. Poser, a Brooklyn Law School professor, said. "This isn't a case about the little old lady in tennis shoes. The question is whether a firm can be held liable for recommending unsuitable securities when the buyer is a sophisticated institution."
Even Michael Hennigan, Orange County's lawyer, admits his arguments are "unique to municipal finance."
"You are dealing with fundamental restrictions on a government official's ability to speculate with government funds," said Mr. Hennigan, who has won multimillion-dollar judgments in securities matters involving Disney and MGM. "Merrill Lynch encouraged and participated in the process of levering up the county's position."
The only precedent for this argument is a 1990 case involving the City of San Jose, Calif., in which a jury ruled against two Wall Street firms stemming from charges that the firms -- E. F. Hutton and Paine Webber -- had sold securities to public officials that were used to speculate on interest rates. Merrill was one of 11 other firms that settled with San Jose before going to trial.
"This is exactly the area where the suitability doctrine should apply," said Patricia M. Hynes, a lawyer at Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, who won the San Jose case. "A lot of the brokerage community has taken advantage of municipalities. This is a very fertile field for horse play."
Still, Mr. Hennigan may be bucking history. Joseph A. Grundfest, a law professor at Stanford University and a former S.E.C. commissioner, said that "the doctrine of suitability cannot be applied to someone like the Treasurer of Orange County."
Mr. Grundfest noted: "You even have correspondence from him to Merrill saying, 'Deal with me or I'll take my business elsewhere.' In traditional suitability cases, Grandma isn't making threats."
Merrill has yet to file its response. But Mr. Block outlined its argument against suitability: "Does suitability mean the broker just tells a sophisticated investor that he is a moron and that his investment strategy won't work? This buyer made his own decisions, with the support and encouragement of his board of supervisors."
Still, Merrill is vulnerable because different divisions of the firm were doing different kinds of business with Orange County. Merrill has offered reams of letters that it sent to Mr. Citron warning his strategy might go wildly awry if interest rates shifted -- which is exactly what happened. County bondholders now say that if Merrill gave Mr. Citron these warnings, the warnings should also have also been disclosed to investors in Orange County debt.
"Can a firm be doing two, or three, or maybe a dozen different activities, which can put them into a position of conflict?" Mr. Poser asked. "By keeping the letters they wrote to Citron private, it raises a question of their duties to the bond buyers."
Mr. Goldschmid added: "This is not going to be easy for Merrill. They can try to argue they had a Chinese wall" -- a reference to the policy of keeping work for clients separate and confidential -- "but I doubt it will work. Merrill has a lot of letters telling Citron that the county was way overextended. Then, at the same time, they are coming out with an underwriting. How could a diligent underwriter not notice?"
Kemper's lawyers declined to comment. But Alan Schulman, a Milberg Weiss lawyer handling the bondholder suit, is delighted. Merrill, he said, built "a trail of cover-your-rear memos so they could later say, 'We told Citron this was risky.' " He added, "Yet when Merrill was warning the county of these risks, its salesmen were inducing bondholders to buy more Orange County securities."
Mr. Block brushes off Mr. Schulman's comments, saying Merrill relied on the county itself for the information it gave bond buyers. He also said bondholders had been told that the county's investment portfolio had securities that could lose value. And he said many buyers, like Kemper, were sophisticated and would have been aware that investment risk was a core issue in Mr. Citron's 1994 re-election campaign.
"You had sophisticated investors who weren't operating in a vacuum," Mr. Block said. "They knew what was going on in the county treasurer's race."
Besides, Mr. Block added, no county bondholders have been out money yet -- as long as they have held their securities. The $198 million taxable bonds held by Kemper, which were supposed to have been redeemed in July, have been extended a year. And other bonds are still paying their promised interest.
But that is cold comfort to ordinary bondholders, Mr. Schulman said. He notes that anyone who sold an Orange County bond has sustained a loss. Besides, he said, investors who thought they were buying a triple-A security are now holding paper from a bankrupt entity.
"It's like you bought a BMW and now you've got a Yugo," Mr. Schulman said. "Sure, it still gets you from place to place, but you don't know for how long."

HEADLINE: Gains in the Metro-North Settlement

 BODY:
New York City's northern commuters won a reprieve yesterday from the selective strike tactics that plagued the Metro-North railroad last week. A tentative contract agreement with the teamsters local that represents 697 track workers spared riders the daily anxiety of wondering whether the union would pick their rail line for the job action of the day.
The union was wise to test the public's tolerance no further, and to accept at least some modest gains in productivity. 
 Following the wage pattern established in settlements with other Metro-North unions, the track workers agreed to a 10.4 percent rise over four years, lower than the pace of inflation. They won improved sick leave, personal leave and vacation time. Their major concession, allowing the railroad more flexibility to assign night and weekend crews, is the kind of productivity gain Metro-North and its parent, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, need in still greater measure. The M.T.A. has assured both subway riders and commuters that productivity will soften the pain caused by reduced state financing.
By spot-striking portions of the railroad with little warning, the union confounded the workaday lives of passengers and abused its considerable power for a relatively minor bargaining objective, a speedup of an improved vacation package. The union won a partial speedup, but the trauma of those uncertain mornings could lead to a larger benefit for the public.
This brief job action did not cause much of a ripple outside the New York metropolitan area. Nevertheless, Congress should take note and begin giving more serious attention to long-pending proposals to end Federal jurisdiction over labor relations on commuter lines. Jurisdiction would be transferred to the state, allowing New York to treat workers as public employees forbidden to strike. That would produce an even more significant result than the settlement.

HEADLINE: Inching Toward a Budget Deal

 BODY:
The White House and Republicans continue to bicker over the budget. The two sides remain far apart. The White House, though claiming to embrace the Republican goal of balancing the budget within seven years, attacks the Republican deficit-reduction bill for crippling Medicaid, food stamps and other programs for the needy. The Republican leaders accuse the White House of hypocrisy in cynically attacking the Republicans for their cuts while refusing to identify who would lose under White House plans.
The blame game eased a bit last weekend when Democrats and Republicans slipped back from rigid positions. Leaders of both parties began to gravitate ever so slowly toward a compromise plan put forth by a coalition of moderate and conservative Democrats. 
 The coalition would, like the G.O.P., balance the budget in 2002 and cut discretionary spending by almost 30 percent by 2002. But its plan forgoes all tax cuts, choosing instead to soften blows to Medicare and preserve Federal entitlements to welfare, Medicaid and food stamps. The coalition proposes to lower inflation adjustments -- in effect raising taxes and lowering Social Security benefits -- which will only happen if the President joins hands with Republican leaders in announcing collective support.
For all its good sense, the coalition plan cannot pass the House, whose 73 freshman Republicans swear to pass a $245 billion tax cut. That is the gap that the two parties must close. It will not be easy.
Over the weekend, leaders from both parties began groping for compromise. The Senate budget chairman, Pete Domenici, and his House counterpart, John Kasich, signaled that a smaller tax cut and inflation adjustment would be acceptable, as long as the Democrats simultaneously agreed. But even if the tax cut were reduced by half, the compromise plan would be over $100 billion short of balancing the budget.
The Congressional Budget Office will provide some relief when it issues new, probably lower, deficit projections, which could reduce the need to cut spending by between $30 billion and $100 billion. After that, the options are limited. The Republicans appear unwilling to cut needless weapons systems out of the defense budget. The White House, playing to the elderly, appears unwilling to make doable cuts in Medicare. That leaves only two places to find additional savings: non-defense discretionary spending and entitlement programs for the poor. Yet the coalition budget already makes huge cuts in both these areas.
The sobering truth is that Congress will be trapped into a vicious trade-off. Every dollar that Congress gives away in needless tax cuts will be taken from heavily hit discretionary programs or need-based entitlement programs. Here is where President Clinton could display leadership by stepping forward to forswear his own $100-billion-plus tax cut. In return he needs to insist that Congress preserve, at the very least, Federal entitlements to Medicaid and food stamps.
The best plan that will emerge from Congress will not be good. It will make unwarranted cuts in public investments in job training, education and research as well as poverty programs for the arbitrary purpose of eliminating the deficit in seven years. But the damage can be limited if good news from the C.B.O. can be combined with new flexibility by Mr. Clinton and the Republicans controlling Capitol Hill.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: When Is 'Paper Money' Not Real Money?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There you go again! Five times you use the phrase "on paper" in discussing the fortune made by Steven P. Jobs from the marketing of stock in his new company, Pixar Animation Studios (front page, Nov. 30). Of course it was "on paper." 
 I first noted your use of that phrase in an editorial in 1992 in which you pooh-poohed the 50 percent decline in the Japanese stock market as being "only on paper," arguing that such a decline in wealth meant little in that huge and vibrant economy. May I remind you that the Japanese economy has been in recession, if not depression, ever since.
Your use of "on paper" to imply "not real" is ill advised, if not silly. Do you think some might have thought Mr. Jobs was delivered sacks of currency yesterday that he could put under his mattress? Or that Microsoft's Bill Gates, reputedly the world's richest self-made man, goes around with $13 billion in cash in his pockets? That money is more likely represented by electronic data and is not on paper.
 
DANIEL B. TAYLOR
Arlington, Va., Dec. 1, 1995

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Agencies, still in a slump, get predictions of stronger spending.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE leading forecaster of advertising spending has slightly trimmed his estimates for 1995 and 1996. Yet he maintains that "the role of advertising is re-emerging" in the American consumer marketplace.
Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at the McCann-Erickson U.S.A. unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said he expected next year to be the third in a row in which "advertising should significantly outpace" the growth of the economy. Large marketers will continue to shift dollars from promotional efforts aimed at retailers into advertising campaigns directed at shoppers, he added. 
 Those words -- and Mr. Coen's prediction that gains in ad spending would continue to "outpace the economy for the rest of the decade" -- will undoubtedly be welcome along Madison Avenue as agencies strive to emerge from a steep five-year slump.
Mr. Coen spoke yesterday at the opening session of the 23d annual Paine Webber media conference in midtown Manhattan, where he was joined by John Perriss, the chairman of Zenith Media Worldwide, the media services agency owned by Cordiant P.L.C. Both Mr. Coen and Zenith offer predictions every June and December, and both executives presented similar lists of categories yesterday that are helping fuel spending growth, particularly computers and movies.
Mr. Coen is maintaining his optimistic outlook despite reductions in the spending figures he offered six months ago, to reflect the slowing of some advertising activities and adjustments related to the value of the dollar against foreign currencies. Mr. Perriss echoed Mr. Coen's forecasts for 1995 and 1996, but his spectacles were somewhat less rose-colored than Mr. Coen's for the years beyond that.
Mr. Coen, who has been tracking ad spending for 47 years, said that 1995 was expected to end with total ad spending of $161.5 billion in the United States, up 7.7 percent from the $150 billion spent in 1994. A year ago he predicted that 1995 spending would total $159 billion, and six months ago he revised that figure upward to $161.9 billion.
"The last six months are coming in good, but not as good as we thought," Mr. Coen said in a telephone interview after his presentation. One reason was retail advertising in newspapers, he added, "which just can't seem to get off the ground."
Mr. Coen revised his figure for 1995 ad spending outside the United States to $190 billion, up 6.5 percent from $178.4 billion in 1994; that compares with a forecast in June of $193.4 billion. The revised figure puts the 1995 worldwide total at a record $351.5 billion, up 7 percent from $328.4 billion in 1994.
In 1996, total spending in the United States will remain strong, Mr. Coen predicted, at $174.1 billion, up 7.8 percent from 1995. His initial forecast for 1996, made in June, was $175 billion.
Mr. Coen expects the increases next year to be driven by a pair of events that occur every four years, the Presidential election and the Summer Olympics. The "special stimulative conditions should be even greater," he added, because the Games will take place in Atlanta -- the first time they will have been staged in this country since 1984 -- and events on television will be "available for peak prime-time live viewing at premium advertising prices."
"We also expect Olympic-related promotions in other media to further stimulate advertising spending next year," Mr. Coen said.
Mr. Coen predicts that ad spending will total $202.9 billion outside the United States next year -- the first time the $200 billion milestone will be reached, if that occurs. Although that figure is lower than the $210 billion he initially predicted in June, it represents an increase of 6.8 percent from the $190 billion he has predicted for ad spending overseas this year.
Mr. Coen expects spending in the United States and abroad for 1996 to total $377 billion, up 7.3 percent from the $351.5 billion he has projected for 1995.
Mr. Perriss, in offering the latest Zenith forecast, said worldwide ad spending in 1995 would total $353.5 billion, up 6.7 percent from the $331.4 billion spent in 1994. For 1996, he forecast total worldwide ad spending of $378.5 billion, up 7.1 percent from his 1995 figure.
Betsy Frank, executive vice president and director of strategic media resources at the Zenith office in New York, said Zenith, unlike Mr. Coen, is "seeing '96 as being the high-water point in terms of increases" through the rest of the decade."
"We see there are, if not some red lights, some yellow lights that suggest, at least in the United States, the robust ad-spending increases will probably take us through only '96 and might well slow down after that," she added.
A third prediction is closer to Mr. Perriss's than to Mr. Coen's. Jack Myers of Myers Communications in Parsippany, N.J., the publisher of an advertising newsletter, projects an increase of 5.9 percent in domestic ad spending in 1996, which he said would usher in "at least a two-year cycle of sluggish advertiser spending."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips as Mark Advances, Especially Against the Franc

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday as the German mark rose against other European currencies, scoring its biggest gains against the French franc as a result of labor strikes in France.
"As the situation in France deteriorates, people are buying the mark, and that's an anti-dollar move," said David DeRosa, director of currency trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. 
 When the mark gains against European currencies, it generally rises against the dollar, too, as speculators seek all opportunities to buy marks.
"The mark is strong across the board, and that is hurting the dollar," said Tom Hoge, corporate currency trader at Bank of New York.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4390 marks, down from 1.4460 marks on Friday. It also slipped to 101.20 Japanese yen from 101.25 yen.
A rally in the American bond market, which sent the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to a two-year low of 6.02 percent, helped the dollar pare some early losses yesterday. Rising bond prices help the dollar because foreigners generally must first purchase dollars to buy Treasury bonds.
The French franc came under pressure as investors became increasingly worried that Prime Minister Alain Juppe would back down from plans to cut Government spending as public transport strikes entered their second week and employees in other state-owned companies prepared to walk out.
The franc was also undermined by heavy selling in the French stock and bond markets on expectations that the Bank of France might raise interest rates to defend the French currency.
"The franc is very much in the headlines now that the strikes have spread from the transport sector to other businesses," said Jurgen Lindemann, foreign exchange manager at Standard Chartered Bank in London. "The franc looks like it could creep above 3.50" francs per mark.
In New York, the mark was quoted at 3.4708 French francs, up from 3.4557 francs on Friday in New York. But the dollar slipped to 4.9950 francs, from 4.9981 francs.
The dollar also fell to 1.1685 Swiss francs, from 1.1772 francs. The British pound rose to $1.5325, from $1.5310. And the Canadian dollar fell to 73.08 United States cents from 73.23 cents.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Are Fueled By Hopes of Rate Reduction

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bond yields continued to fall yesterday -- actually slipping below 6 percent briefly -- amid continuing expectations of further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The yield on the long bond hit its lowest level since November 1993.
The price rally, now in its fourth day, was fueled by short-coverings, when prices of securities, which move in the opposite direction from their yields, broke above some key technical levels. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 29/32 of a percentage point, to 111 23/32 , for a yield of 6.02 percent, down from 6.08 percent on Friday.
Lacking fresh economic data for guidance, the market was left to its own sentiment, which is that "the economy is kind of soft right now," said Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist at ASB Capital Management, a money management firm in Washington D.C. He said that the slower economic growth would eventually bring on an easing. "It's still early December and my feeling at this point is that statistically an ease in monetary policy in December can still be made between now and Dec. 19, when the Federal Open Market Committee meets. That is, if we continue to get the same kinds of soft economic data that we have had over that last few months."
News of slow holiday retail sales for a second consecutive weekend, during a period that normally accounts for nearly half of the year's retail volume, helped to raise the prospects of a Fed easing soon to reinvigorate an economy that is lossing its wind.
The last rate cut was on July 6, when the Fed lowered the target for overnight bank loans a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.75 percent.
Mr. Carpenter said the market was rallying on a number of beliefs, including the notion that one way or another the budget defficit issue may prove to be constructive for bonds in 1996.
Heavy buying was also apparent in bond furtures trading, as the March bond contract hit a new high of 120 31/32 . Some traders reported that Dean Witter was in the market early and bought about 1,000 Treasury bond contracts at prices between 119 31/32 and 120, giving an early lift to trading.
Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research of Boston, said an example of the futures market's stength yesterday was that the March Treasury bond contract was at a support level that normally represented the outermost daily resistance. "This is the strongest type of rally you can have," Ms. Mesch said. The low for the day on the contract was 119 25/32 ; at the close it stood at at 120 24/32 .
"New resistance seems to piling up at around 122 22/32 , Ms. Mesch said, "but then again I never though we'd get this far. Very long term, it looks like 126 27/32 can be attained."
Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc., said it was obvious that the market had not lost its focus on low inflation and the negotiations for a balanced budget -- not to mention the ever-increasing expectation of an easing by the Fed.
"The rate cut is already priced in, and while the market is clearly over bought it could go alot further before profit taking kicks in, Mr. Guild said.
He said he was not surprised at the low yields. "I continue to expect new lows, as I have all year," he said. "Some people are now hung up on the false notion that 6 percent is some sort of a resistance point. I think next real resistant is the old low of 5.79 percent set on Oct. 15, 1993."
Interest rates at yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills declined, with the average discount rate for a three-month issue down to 5.29 percent, from 5.32 percent last week, and a six-month issue down to 5.19 percent, from 5.25 percent.
The Treasury is currently operating just under its $4.9 trillion debt limit because the Administration and Congress have yet to agree on a budget plan to fully finance the Government. So in an effort to remain under the debt limit, foreign central banks were prohibited at yesteray's auction from buying any bills exceeding the maturing bills they already held.
On Thursday the Treasury will be selling $18.75 billion of new one-year bills, which by late yesterday had a rate of 5.04 percent.
