HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Foreign Business to Put $6.3 Billion in Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 4

 BODY:
For the second time in a week, President Ernesto Zedillo convened a group of business executives at the presidential mansion today to announce hefty new foreign investments in Mexico.
Last Wednesday, 30 of the heaviest hitters in Mexican business -- men like Carlos Slim Helu of Telefonos de Mexico and Claudio X. Gonzalez of Kimberly-Clark -- announced that their companies would collectively invest $6.2 billion in 1996. 
 Today, more than 100 American, Canadian, European and Asian executives, led by Kenneth C. Brown of General Electric de Mexico, Georg Braunleder of Bayer de Mexico, and Masao Horie Yamachika of Nissan Mexicana, paraded in similar fashion into an auditorium at the presidential residence at Los Pinos. There, Commerce Minister Herminio Blanco announced that the foreign companies had promised to invest $6.3 billion next year.
"The President's people are trying to generate a more upbeat mood toward Mexico's economic performance," said Sergio Sarmiento, an economic analyst and syndicated columnist here. "They think Mexico has a confidence problem, and by bringing together these major investors, they're trying to reassure the markets that if they put money in Mexican bonds and stocks, they'll be in good company."
A few weeks ago, the peso was again under great pressure and Mexican stocks were weak. Both have firmed considerably since then, lifting the economic mood. The orchestrated announcements in the last week of billions of dollars of investments -- though some undoubtedly long planned -- and the executives' expressions of confidence in the economy are meant to sustain that optimistic mood. The total of $12.5 billion represents a prodigious investment in this country's $320 billion economy.
The ceremony with Mexican entrepreneurs last week propelled an already surging stock market. But today, the main Mexico City index dropped 13.84 points, or 0.51 percent, to 2,689.58. Analysts said the market had been ripe for profit taking after a rally that lifted the index more than 200 points in two weeks.
Of today's $6.3 billion, about $3.45 billion was pledged by American and Canadian companies, $1.59 billion by Europeans and $1.18 billion by Asians, according to figures released by the Mexican Investment Board, a Government agency.
Some of these investments were included when President Zedillo announced in October in New York that a dozen American and Canadian companies had pledged to invest $12 billion in Mexico over the next five years, the board said.
Mr. Brown of General Electric said in an interview that his company planned to invest $150 million in Mexico next year, much of it in a $650 million natural gas-driven electric power plant at Samalayuca, south of the border city of Juarez. Also investing in that project, Mr. Brown said, were Bechtel, El Paso Natural Gas and Mexico's largest construction company, Empresas.
Among the other foreign companies making commitments today were AT&T, GTE Data Services, Amoco, Hyundai, Mitsubishi, Sony, BMW and France Telecom.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Heating Oil Increases in Price As a Large Cold System Arrives

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Heating oil futures prices surged yesterday as a large cold weather system moved into the middle United States and threatened to increase demand for already tight heating oil supplies.
Natural gas futures also gained. Crude and unleaded gasoline futures prices moved higher in sympathy and on lingering concern over the health of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, Tony Lerner, an oil analyst at Chase Manhattan, said. 
 "People are looking at the weather for the rest of the week," Mr. Lerner said. "And there's a certain amount of jitters in the market over this medical news of King Fahd."
On other commodity markets, lumber futures climbed the daily limit, while soybeans futures rose. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities jumped 1.37 points, to 243.05
Heating oil for January delivery rose 1.36 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange to settle at 54.03 cents a gallon, the highest for the contract closest to delivery since it settled at 54.25 cents on Aug. 1, 1994.
January natural gas rose 0.51 cent, to $2.12 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Forecasters called for a very cold Canadian air mass to plunge into the middle United States and portions of the Northeast, the two largest heating oil markets, and push temperatures as much as 10 degrees lower.
Forecasters said the extremely cold weather might last only a day or two, but it comes at a time when refiners have been producing much less, said Gerald E. Samuels, ARB oil analyst.
Crude oil and its products also rose on lingering concerns about the health of the Saudi King, who reportedly suffered a stroke. His death could lead to a succession battle among Saudi Arabia's royal family, which has some 6,000 princes. Saudi Arabia produces about 12 percent of the world's oil output.
January light sweet crude oil rose 20 cents, to $18.63 a barrel, and January unleaded gasoline rose 0.54 cent, to 53.56 cents a gallon.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, lumber futures prices advanced the daily trading limit as investors bet interest rates would continue falling and would spur renewed home building. January lumber rose $10, to $274.60 for 1,000 board feet.

SECTION: Section C; Page 15; Column 1; Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: America Realizes The Arts Attract Tourists

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
In the competition for tourist dollars, Jonesborough, Tenn., cannot play in the same league with Disneyworld or Yellowstone Park. But in October, Jonesborough (population 3,400) drew about 8,600 visitors from all 50 states and several foreign countries to its annual storytelling festival, generating $5 million worth of economic activity in the region.
Last year, "The Age of Rubens" attracted 234,000 visitors to the Toledo Museum of Art in Toledo, Ohio, more than half of of them from out of state. In August, traditionally considered a dead month for art exhibitions, the Delaware Art Museum in Wilmington opened a two-month show of Pre-Raphaelite art and marketed it to summer vacationers. It pulled an audience from the mid-Atlantic states that raised museum attendance by 434 percent over the same period in 1994. 
 Examples like these have not gone unnoticed by state and municipal officials in charge of economic development or by representatives of the tourist industry, who in the last five years have begun talking to local arts councils and museum officers.
Increasing recognition of the power of the arts to pull in tourist dollars has led to a host of new initiatives, partnerships and pilot development projects across the United States. Most of them are aimed at tapping into the cultural appetites of foreign visitors and the fat wallets of a new kind of American tourist, one who is more likely to seek out an art museum or a music festival than a shopping district or a theme park.
Recent surveys by the Commerce Department, the Travel Industry Association of America and D. K. Shiflet and Associates, a private company specializing in travel research, point to a growing tourist population, with the arts and local history at the top of their agenda.
"For the tourist industry, this is a market that is better educated, spends more time at a destination, spends more money, and is more likely to stay in a hotel than with family or friends," said Bill Moskin, a cultural tourism consultant in Sacramento, Calif., who often works with state arts councils, state tourism offices and convention and visitors bureaus. "For cities, this is a new way of marketing themselves, and for arts organizations, this is a way to diversify revenue."
With an eye to the cultural marketplace, several cities have followed the lead of San Francisco, whose convention and visitors bureau hired a full-time arts officer five years ago. This year, Los Angeles hired one for itself, and San Diego is now searching for one, too. Portland, Ore., and New Orleans, in search of a comprehensive cultural marketing plan, are now putting together consortiums that include representatives from arts organizations, the tourist industry and the local convention and visitors' bureaus.
The mandate is simple. "The purpose is to sell the arts and cultural products that we have to the tourists who come," said Shirley Trusty Corey, the executive director of the Arts Council of New Orleans.
For the arts, increased tourism means increased attendance and ticket sales, a big jump in museum gift shop sales and, in the case of blockbuster events, a gratifying spillover effect, since visitors to a major museum often seek out cultural events at other arts institutions.
But the hurdles are high. Many European countries, especially Britain and France, have long recognized the tourist value of the arts and have marketed them shrewdly. They have also worked hard to develop a tourist infrastructure of information offices, well marked itineraries, printed material in many languages, and small museums that interpret and represent the local culture. The tourist industry and the culture industry work together.
The United States lags far behind, a point made often in late October at the annual White House Conference on Travel and Tourism, which, for the first time, included a daylong session on cultural tourism. The mingling of arts and tourism officials led to some eye-opening encounters.
"Except in isolated cases, there has not been much conversation between these entities," said Edward H. Able Jr., the executive director of the American Association of Museums. "One thing we learned was the vast economic impact of tourism, a $512 billion industry that generates $58 billion in state and local taxes and a $22 billion trade surplus for the United States."
Eduardo Diaz, the director of the San Antonio Department of Arts and Culture, described the culture and tourism industries as ships passing in the night: "We have tended to think of the tourist as the guy with the loud shirt, Bermuda shorts and a camera around his neck, while the tourist industry thinks of artists as unreliable, out-of-it characters, but we have common interests."
In cities that have tried to get the two industries talking, an information void has emerged. "What I heard from tour operators, for example, was that every other potential supplier was in their face all the time, promoting events, but the arts groups didn't do that," said Mary Beth Kavanaugh, the arts and tourism manager of the San Francisco Convention and Visitors Bureau.
Tour operators and convention planners, for their part, did not know much about the arts. Robert Barrett, who was recently named the director of cultural tourism of the Los Angeles Convention and Visitors Bureau, is wrestling with the widespread perception of his city as an extension of Hollywood and nothing else. "The majority of people coming here are not coming here for our wide array of cultural attractions, because the wholesalers are not informing people," he said.
New York floats above the fray. It is the grand exception, because culture has always been central to its image. A 1992 study by the Port Authority found that visitors drawn to the metropolitan area primarily by its cultural offerings created $2.3 billion in economic activity.
Yet the city has no arts marketing plan. No one needs to promote SoHo, for example, because images of the neighborhood and the artists who have put it on the map are disseminated throughout the world every day by newspapers, magazines, television and film.
Elsewhere, the arts and tourist industries realize they need to act if they want to exploit a valuable asset. San Antonio has moved more quickly than many cities have, but its experience is fairly typical.
"It's not like San Antonio wasn't promoting its cultural and heritage inventory, but it wasn't focused," said Mr. Diaz. "It was just sort of thrown in with the Alamo and Sea World."
Then two things happened. First, in 1989 the city began financing the arts from the hotel and motel bed tax, a move that got arts officials and the tourism and hospitality industry talking to each other for the first time. Second, in 1991, the blockbuster exhibition "Splendors of Mexico" at the San Antonio Art Museum, produced so much money in state and local taxes -- nearly $8 million -- that the city began looking at culture with newfound interest.
Mr. Diaz now has an employee who works full-time with the tourist industry, and his office has persuaded the regional transportation authority to include arts institutions on its maps and to print brochures showing visitors how to follow special culture routes. With the city's public television station, his office is also producing a weekly arts guide to be broadcast on a television channel in local hotel rooms.
Small towns have also caught on to cultural tourism. This year, the Connecticut Humanities Council obtained a $1 million state grant, financed by the bed tax, to improve the quality of the exhibitions at museums and historical societies, on the assumption that they would draw more tourist dollars. Grant recipients will be required to work closely with their local tourism offices.
In depressed rural and manufacturing regions, the promise of no-pain economic development has made cultural tourism a new buzzword.
In part, the enthusiasm has been fueled by a series of heritage-tourism pilot projects carried out between 1989 and 1993 in 16 areas, all told, in Indiana, Texas, Wisconsin and Tennessee. The program, financed by the National Trust for Historic Preservation and the National Endowment for the Arts, created heritage corridors, or communities with a history and culture that can be packaged to appeal to tourists.
The idea is seductive, since it suggests that communities and institutions that would not draw tourists on their own can become attractions when placed on an itinerary.
The example of the Mississippi Delta suggests that work remains to be done. The blues music native to the area, as well as the literature and folk art of the region, exert a strong pull for many Americans and even more Europeans and Japanese, who in recent years have been turning up in large numbers.
Yet so far no one has quite figured out how to handle the situation, which was the subject of much discussion at a recent conference on cultural tourism in Greenville, Miss., attended by state tourism officials and scholars from the four Delta states.
"This just sort of backed up on people," said Robert Cogswell, the director of folk arts at the Tennessee Arts Commission. "Busloads of Japanese tourists began showing up in little towns and asking to be pointed to Robert Johnson's gravestone."
When KLM, the Dutch airline, began direct flights into Memphis this year, the city of Memphis and the Mississippi state tourism office quickly created a promotion called "America's Blues Alley." They printed color brochures with an itinerary through Delta blues country. The convention and visitors bureaus in St. Louis and New Orleans recently published a self-guided driving tour that runs 700 miles from St. Louis to New Orleans. Essentially, however, tourists must fend for themselves.
"Millions are being spent by our state to advertise the Delta as the home of the blues," said William Ferris, the director of the Center for the Study of Southern Culture at the University of Mississippi in Oxford. "But should thousands of people descend on the Delta, there is very little, other than a small museum in Clarksdale, to present the culture."
This contrasts sharply with the thoughtful, well developed presentation of Civil War history at places like Vicksburg, Mississippi. The challenge for state tourism officials and arts administrators is figuring out how to bring the blues to an eager audience in the same way.
"We have a culture loved all over the world," said Mr. Ferris, "and now we have to come to terms with it."

HEADLINE: LEADERS OF A.M.A. CRITICAL OF PLAN TO ALTER MEDICAID

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Leaders of the American Medical Association, who endorsed Speaker Newt Gingrich's plans for Medicare eight weeks ago, today expressed grave concern about Republican proposals for Medicaid and said Congress should preserve a Federal guarantee of health insurance coverage for low-income people.
Trustees of the association said they had not endorsed the Republicans' bill, the Medicaid Transformation Act of 1995, submitted to President Clinton last week as part of a wide-ranging measure to balance the budget. The bill would replace the current Medicaid program with lump-sum grants that the states could decide how to spend on health care for low-income people. 
 Mr. Clinton has also asserted that it is crucial to maintain a Federal guarantee of coverage for the poor. He has until next Tuesday to act on the legislation, which he has said he will veto.
Republicans hailed the A.M.A.'s endorsement of their Medicare proposals in October and cannot easily dismiss the doctors' concerns about Medicaid now. Medicare covers 37 million people who are elderly or disabled. Medicaid covers nearly 37 million low-income people, including many children and elderly.
Without specifying a number, and without denouncing the Republicans' proposals, the doctors' group suggested "lowering the level of reductions" in the growth of Medicaid.
Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the medical association, said many doctors wanted to preserve Medicaid as a Federal entitlement, so that certain groups of low-income people would be guaranteed coverage for specific health benefits.
But the Republican bill says that states are not required to cover "any particular items or services," and that Federal law "shall not be construed as providing for an entitlement."
Republicans say the lump-sum payments, known as block grants, would give states new freedom to set eligibility criteria and scope of benefits, so they could run Medicaid programs more efficiently.
Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican National Committee, and Republican governors like John Engler of Michigan affirmed their support for Medicaid block grants today. Ed Gillespie, a spokesman for Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House Republican leader, said he welcomed the doctors' views, but did not think they would change many votes in Congress.
"The doctors' ability to deliver care to needy patients will not be diminished," Mr. Gillespie said.
Critics of the proposal say states will be tempted to reduce the number of people covered or the services provided, especially in recessions, when more people apply for help.
The medical association said it had not openly opposed converting Medicaid to a block grant program because Congressional leaders indicated that this change was "non-negotiable." But Dr. Todd said the policy of the association was to encourage more uniformity in state Medicaid programs.
The A.M.A. says the Federal Government should establish "basic national standards of uniform eligibility" and should prescribe a minimum package of benefits that would be available to poor people in all states -- "basic standards of uniform minimum adequate benefits for Medicaid recipients."
The trustees said, "There needs to be an appropriate balance between states' interests in securing increased flexibility, in light of fewer Federal funds for Medicaid, and the very real needs of the people the Medicaid program is intended to serve, most of whom have no other means of access to health care coverage."
In negotiations with Congress, the doctors' group has spent more time on Medicare than Medicaid, even though the proposed changes in Medicaid are bigger. Aides to Mr. Gingrich said that, in meetings on Capitol Hill, the doctors had not explicitly opposed the idea of Medicaid block grants, but had indicated they wanted more money for the program.
Doctors say that Medicaid already pays less than private health insurance, and they fear that some states will cope with block grants by cutting payments even more. Preliminary studies suggest that many states will be forced to restrict Medicaid eligibility and "cut reimbursement to providers," the association said.
The A.M.A. endorsed the House Republicans' Medicare proposal in October, after receiving assurances that Medicare payments to doctors would be cut less than originally planned. The proposal would encourage elderly people to enroll in health maintenance organizations and other forms of managed care. It would also create new business opportunities for doctors, allowing them to form their own health plans to serve Medicare beneficiaries.
Dr. Daniel H. Johnson Jr., president-elect of the association, said that reports of the endorsement provoked protests from many doctors who thought "it was a deal over money" rather than health policy.
In an interview today, Dr. Lonnie R. Bristow, president of the association, said: "It was initially reported that the A.M.A. made a deal on Medicare. Doctors all across this country justifiably resented that. If I thought the association were doing something sleazy, I too would resent it. There was no deal. What we did was to go in and explain that an unintended problem in access to care was about to be created, and once the House leadership saw that, they made an appropriate adjustment so as to avoid that."
Leaders of the medical association said their group still preferred the House version of the Medicare legislation, parts of which were dropped from the measure ultimately sent to the White House.
Republicans in Congress would cut projected Federal spending on Medicaid by $163 billion, or 17 percent, over seven years. Although Federal spending on the program would rise to $127 billion in 2002, from $89 billion this year, the annual rate of growth would be cut in half, to 5 percent.
Mr. Barbour, said, "We will have very substantial growth in Medicaid, but we will do it in a context that allows the money to go much further."
In an interview, Mr. Barbour said: "States have proven that for less money you can provide better care. States that have had Medicaid reform like Arizona find patient satisfaction is up, and the quality of care is also up. Governors understand that if you keep the current system, you cannot achieve the savings without endangering the quality of care."
Many state officials say they can save money by enrolling Medicaid recipients in H.M.O.'s and other forms of managed care, which provide a wide range of services for fixed monthly payments. But many doctors are apprehensive.
The policy-making arm of the medical association, the House of Delegates, is meeting here this week. A resolution submitted by the American College of Physicians, representing 85,000 internists, says, "There is considerable concern that restructuring of the Medicaid program and rapid transition to managed care could cause serious disruptions in access to health care or reductions in the quality of health care services provided to eligible recipients."
Dr. J. Harold Morris, an internist from Independence, Mo., told the association that the Republicans' Medicaid proposals "would cut back a program that has been quite successful and could well increase the number of uninsured."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "THE DETAILS: Medicaid at a Glance"
 
WHAT IS MEDICAID? -- Enacted in 1965 in the same legislation that created Medicare, it is the nation's major program for providing health insurance to poor people. It is available to anyone who meets the eligibility criteria.
 
HOW IS IT FINANCED? -- States and the Federal Government share the expenses. States receive Federal support according to the state's per capita income, so that the Federal share is larger in poorer states. The Federal share can range from 50 to 80 percent of Medicaid expenditures. States establish their own eligibility criteria within Federal guidelines.
 
WHO IS COVERED? -- Initially intended to provide health care for welfare recipients, Medicaid has been expanded to include some additional children, and some blind and disabled people, pregnant women and many residents of nursing homes. Nearly 37 million people are covered, about half of them children.
 
WHAT IS COVERED? -- Basic services include inpatient and outpatient hospital services; doctors' services; laboratory and X-ray services; nursing homes and home health care; early and periodic screening, diagnosis and treatment for children under 21 years of age; family planning; prenatal care, and rural clinics.
 
WHAT ARE THE COSTS? -- Federal Medicaid spending quadrupled in the last decade and doubled in the last five years, to $82 billion in 1994. For 1995, the Federal share is estimated at $89 billion and state spending at $67 billion. MONICA BORKOWSKI (pg. B9)

Treasury securities prices rallied for the fourth straight day, pushing the yield on the bellwether 30-year bond below 6 percent at one point. It ended at 6.02 percent on traders' expectations that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates this month. [Page D20.]

Although these doctors worked only a few hours a week in the clinics, they largely determined where dialysis patients went for care. [A1.]

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Agency Losing U.S. Aid For Developing Nations

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The United States announced today that it is pulling out of a United Nations agency whose mission is to encourage industry in developing nations.
The United States supplies about one fourth of the $31 million annual budget of the agency, the United Nations Industrial Development Organization, whose annual conference began on Monday. The move is bound to cause a financial crisis. 
 The United States has long complained of inefficiency at the agency, and its withdrawal follows months of pressure in Congress to reduce foreign aid.

HEADLINE: Taiwan Wouldn't Gain From Independence;
World Will Suffer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am writing to commend American journalists like A. M. Rosenthal who point out just how obsequious the United States has been behaving before Communist China (column, Dec. 1). 
 The world will suffer if China gets its way with Taiwan. A Communist occupation of Taiwan will be the beginning of an trend in which the Chinese will reclaim their age-old fantasy of being the world's Central Kingdom.
The Chinese reaction to Taiwan is not, as the Communists claim, a domestic issue. China's desire to blockade Taiwan stems less from nationalistic ideals of unification than from Taiwan's threat as a symbol of success founded on Western ideals of democracy and human rights.
The Communists are aware that if Taiwan succeeds in its first direct popular presidential election in March, the legitimacy of their monopolistic reign on the mainland will be forever threatened.
The West should cease its optimistic belief that China will somehow channel its economic growth toward the institution of Western-style democracy. As any intelligent observer can see, this will never be the case.
There is a clear connection between China's recent anti-Western rhetoric and its escalating verbal condemnation of and military threats against Taiwan. A Chinese blockade of Taiwan is as much a war waged against the legitimacy of American principles as against Taiwan.
 
I-LING MAO
New York, Dec. 1, 1995

HEADLINE: White House Says It Can Avoid a Debt Crisis for Weeks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today that the Administration had found new, though legally untested, methods of keeping the Government solvent "at least through January," giving the Clinton Administration considerably more breathing room in its budget standoff with Congress.
While Mr. Rubin would not discuss how long he could drag out his delicate fiscal balancing act, other Administration officials said that Treasury and Justice Department lawyers had been meeting daily to devise a legally defensible strategy for sidestepping the Congressionally set $4.9 trillion limit on Federal borrowing well into the spring. "A lot of it is open to challenge, because the U.S. Government has never had to do this before," one official said. "But we think we've got some ideas that will work." 
 Mr. Rubin declined to say what method the Treasury had chosen to keep the Government paying its bills and the interest and principal due on Government securities. In the past, he has kept his strategy close to the vest, for fear that Congressional Republicans would try to block the Treasury, in their effort to force Mr. Clinton to choose between default and their budget priorities.
So far the Republicans have not launched a court challenge to the Administration's efforts to avoid the debt ceiling, which is set annually by Congress. But Congressional Republicans say they are clearing the path for such a move. "I would be willing to use the threat of default to say, 'Look, you have to come to some agreement on the seven-year balanced budget,' " said Representative Nick Smith, a Michigan Republican who has been one of Mr. Rubin's leading critics on Capitol Hill. Last week Speaker Newt Gingrich accused Mr. Rubin of "looting" retirement funds under the Treasury's control to exceed the debt limit, and he appointed Mr. Smith to head a "House Debt Limit and Misuse of Trust Funds Task Force."
The Republicans have repeatedly accused Mr. Rubin, a former investment banker, of trying to alarm the financial markets with exaggerated warnings about default, in hopes that a sharp market reaction would scare Republican leaders into a budget compromise. Mr. Rubin insists that he is doing just the opposite -- taking emergency steps to keep the markets from plunging if the United States flirted with nonpayment.
Today it was Mr. Gingrich who used the threat of market disaster in the struggle for political advantage in the budget stalemate. In a speech this afternoon to a medical association, Mr. Gingrich said that if a budget deal is postponed "you will see interest rates skyrocket and the stock market crash, because the fact is, they are counting on us keeping our word because they actually believe we are different."
In managing the debt crisis, Mr. Rubin faces a difficult political choice. In the context of the budget battle, the only way to get Congress to act on extending the debt limit -- an automatic step in ordinary times -- is to provoke a crisis and risk the prospect that the United States could default for the first time in its history. But that assumes that Congress will blink at the last minute, a bet no one in the White House is willing to take.
The other option is to continue to find ways to evade the debt limit, as Mr. Rubin did late last month when he orchestrated an elaborate accounting trick with two Government retirement accounts. By manipulating how the funds are invested, he put the Government about $60 billion under the debt ceiling, enough to enable it to borrow the funds to make it through the month of December. Under a decade-old law, civil servants with funds in those accounts are guaranteed full restitution of any lost interest on their retirement funds.
But the more Mr. Rubin uses such techniques, the more he opens himself up to the charge that he has become the Chicken Little of fiscal policy, threatening imminent disaster, then forestalling the day of reckoning. Mr. Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, have repeatedly questioned Mr. Rubin's credibility, charging that he is creating artificial crises and then solving them.
Mr. Rubin responds that it would be irresponsible for a Treasury Secretary to risk default, and the prospect that it would shake confidence around the world in the creditworthiness of the United States. His spokesman, Howard Schloss, said today that Mr. Rubin had been "quite surprised" over the weekend, while visiting Brazil and Argentina, when several officials asked him whether the United States was in any danger of failing to pay its debts.
"These are not the kinds of questions Treasury officials are accustomed to receiving when they visit developing nations," Mr. Schloss said.
The risk Mr. Rubin runs now is that his strategy of sidestepping the debt limit could come under legal challenge. Government lawyers are betting that Federal judges would be unwilling to push the country to the brink of default -- or that a budget deal would make the issue moot by the time it received a full hearing in court.
But the risk for the Administration remains that the balancing act cannot go on forever, and that the Republicans will begin to make an impression on voters with their claims that Mr. Rubin is manipulating retirement funds. "We can't do this indefinitely," one senior Administration official conceded today.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Recruiting In Shadow Of Bosnia

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
UNLESS you know exactly where it is, you can walk past the United States Army recruiting station near Lincoln Center without giving it so much as a glance. It blends into the background at Amsterdam Avenue and 66th Street, dwarfed by Martin Luther King Jr. High School across the street and no more conspicuous than the hairdresser's shop next door.
No sir, said Sgt. First Class Abelito Solis, the station commander, young men and women are not in the habit of dropping in to sign up. He and his three fellow recruiters really have to pursue them at the 12 high schools and 2 colleges in their district. 
 It is a difficult task, requiring endless patience, especially when they come up against principals and guidance counselors who make clear that the only green uniforms they can tolerate are on the Jets.
"A lot of them are old-timers -- from the Vietnam era," said Sergeant Solis, 32, a polite fellow who might have chosen different words had he known he was talking to a Vietnam-era geezer who left his bottle of Geritol home.
"Those are people," he said, "who don't have a good impression of the Army."
Principals notwithstanding, the military has worked hard since the Vietnam era to improve its image, and with fair success. Recruiters had a fairly easy time after the 1991 gulf war. But they are suddenly back in troubled waters as United States peacekeeping troops get ready to pour into Bosnia.
Sergeant Solis, who earned his Combat Infantryman Badge in Iraq four years ago, is well aware that if American casualties pile up, his own job could become painful.
There is just no way now to predict. But to play it safe, the sergeant doesn't let the word Bosnia cross his lips when he talks to young New Yorkers and their parents.
"I'm in the business of putting people in the Army," he said candidly. "I'm not looking for reasons for them not to join. If it comes up, it comes up. We'll deal with it."
Thus far, even in Lincoln Center, recruiters are doing surprisingly well in a town where military tradition for many does not go beyond guessing who is buried in Grant's Tomb.
The New York City Recruiting Battalion, which includes suburban counties, met its quota and then some, ending the last Federal fiscal year tied for first with its counterpart in Jackson, Miss. Its "mission" -- the professionals do not like "quota" -- was to put 3,546 men and women in the regular Army and the Reserves. It signed up 3,843.
THIS year should also turn out well, said Lieut. Col. Anthony Parker, the battalion commander since last June, and Maj. Gregory Penczak, the chief Marine recruiter in the region, is similarly confident. "Young people are receptive to what the Army has to offer," Colonel Parker said yesterday in his spare office at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn. "It offers career development and a way out of New York, if they want that."
Many apparently do.
No doubt, the New York battalion benefits from its own hard work. But as its recruiters acknowledge, it helps to be in a city with an unemployment rate of around 9 percent, well above the national average. The Army tends to look better to civilians when the economy goes flat. And given the prevailing corporate ethic, which to some seems to hold that success is measured by how many people you toss out of work, there is no local shortage of volunteers, even if recruiters elsewhere in the country have seen their numbers drop.
TO many young people, a big draw is the offer of up to $30,000 in college tuition. It was good enough to lure Arundel Hunte, 18, of Bedford-Stuyvesant -- Private Hunte since his high-school graduation last summer. "I thought I'd go into the Army, straighten myself out, earn the tuition but also get some discipline," he said. "If you don't have discipline, you can't do anything."
In a way, recruiting stations provide a snapshot of New York.
The school system's failings are reflected in the large numbers of young volunteers who wash out after they are screened for basic verbal and math skills. And poor neighborhoods, which in theory should produce an ample supply of recruits, struggle with high percentages of teen-agers having criminal records that disqualify them.
"A lot of people have the wrong idea about us," said Sergeant Solis, who was born in the Philippines. "If they can't make it on the outside, they're not going to in the Army."
Of course, financial incentives cannot outweigh the potential harm of a military nightmare in the Balkans. The coming months in Bosnia, Colonel Parker said, may determine Fort Hamilton's success for years. "If it doesn't go well," he said, "if it starts looking like Vietnam, we could have a hard time."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1185 words

HEADLINE: President, Yielding to G.O.P., Will Offer Plan Erasing Deficit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Acceding to Republican demands, the White House said today that by week's end it would give Congress a proposal to erase the Federal budget deficit in seven years, and offered a detailed description of how it would cut projected spending on Medicare, one of the most crucial elements of the plan.
The development was a genuine if faint sign of movement in a political logjam that has blocked a balanced-budget accord for close to a year. But as budget talks resumed today after a bitter five-day standoff, negotiators on each side continued to charge that the other was blocking progress toward an agreement. 
 In today's talks, the White House said it was ready to provide Republicans written details of the single largest element of its budget proposal: President Clinton's longstanding plan to trim projected spending on Medicare by $124 billion over seven years.
But Republican negotiators -- who had been pressing the Administration for a detailed broader plan, on eliminating the deficit by 2002 -- quickly called that offer insufficient. That led Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, to accuse them of foot-dragging.
"We felt that it was extremely important that we begin to talk about the issues," Mr. Panetta said. "The only way we can begin to understand our differences is start talking about these differences."
Republicans said later that they wanted to see the entire Democratic budget proposal rather than a piecemeal presentation on Medicare. At the same time, they complained that the White House had refused to divulge the economic assumptions behind its Medicare plan, making it impossible to draw any comparison with the Republicans' own proposal to reduce projected Medicare expenses over seven years by $270 billion.
Details of the Administration's Medicare proposal, released publicly by the White House after today's round of negotiations, parallel the Republican proposal in promising beneficiaries new options in health coverage through more managed care plans.
The White House would not, however, allow all the options the Republicans want, like medical savings accounts. Administration officials say this reflects their effort to protect the standard Medicare program.
The Administration also says its plan would keep solvent through the year 2011 the Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills.
And, it says, the plan would achieve its seven-year savings of $124 billion "without undermining the structural integrity of the program or imposing new costs on beneficiaries." The plan also promises a limited number of new benefits, including respite care for families of Alzheimer's patients and expansion of coverage for preventive services like mammograms.
Running disputes over who is and who is not a good-faith bargainer led the glacial budget talks to collapse altogether last week, and on the surface, at least, it did not appear that they were moving any faster today. Republican leaders said the two sides had now put off their next meeting until Thursday, when Mr. Clinton's new budget may be ready.
Congress and the White House have given themselves until Dec. 15, when legislation temporarily financing many Government operations expires, to hash out their differences over annual spending bills for the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1.
But prospects for meeting that deadline faded today when the Congressional Budget Office said that it would be unable to produce a new economic forecast, the yardstick by which any budget compromise will be measured, until Dec. 12.
The Democratic leader in the Senate, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said he hoped Congress could enact a budget deal by Dec. 22, the day many here expect legislators to leave for a holiday recess. But one senior Administration official, who insisted on not being otherwise identified, said it was more likely that the debate would still be smoldering when Congress returns in January.
Still, not everyone sounded discouraged. "Despite the fact that we've had four meetings and they've degenerated into nothing but shouting matches," said Senator Jim Exon of Nebraska, a Democratic budget negotiator, "behind the scenes we're making progress."
The Administration's agreement to offer its own seven-year budget plan, meeting the Republicans' central condition for serious bargaining, is one bright spot, he said. Another is the certainty that the Congressional Budget Office's next economic forecast, however belated, will assume lower Federal spending -- and thus lower deficits -- than the current one.
By current reckoning, the White House proposes to spend some $475 billion more over the next seven years than would Republicans in Congress. Both sides in the budget talks are counting on the budget office's new forecast to erase $50 billion to $100 billion of that gap.
In a letter today, the director of the budget office, June O'Neill, declined to make a specific prediction. But she did say that recent data suggested that over the next seven years, inflation would be slightly lower, Medicare and Medicaid spending would rise more slowly, and welfare spending would be less than earlier projections had forecast.
"Although taken individually some of these changes increase the Federal deficit and others decrease it, their total effect is likely to be a more favorable budget outlook," Ms. O'Neill wrote in her letter, addressed to the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico.
The President, meanwhile, is embarking on his third 1996 budget proposal so far this year. The first, issued in February, contemplated deficits averaging $200 billion annually for the foreseeable future. The second, a rough outline made public in June, proposed to balance the budget within 10 years.
Although most details of Mr. Clinton's latest plan have not been disclosed, Mr. Exon said today that in addition to holding Medicare and Medicaid spending at the same levels as in the President's 10-year budget of June, it would focus many remaining cuts on so-called discretionary programs like road-building, defense and housing.
Mr. Exon and others said the White House proposal would include a tax cut for working families of perhaps $100 billion over seven years, well below the $245 billion in cuts that the Republicans propose.
Other money may be found by closing tax loopholes and recalculating the Consumer Price Index, the Federal inflation gauge that is used to automatically adjust Social Security and welfare checks and other benefits, Mr. Exon said. Most economists agree that the index overstates inflation, and the Republican plan would reduce it by 0.2 percentage point.
Mr. Clinton's proposal has been under discussion among House and Senate Democrats for days, and some details were presented to legislators on Monday. Still, Mr. Daschle, the Senate Democratic leader, appeared taken aback today by White House plans to offer it to the Republicans. He told reporters that the President had made clear that the White House's 10-year budget proposal of June "ought to be the basis for a beginning" of negotiations.

HEADLINE: White House Documents Reveal Similarities to G.O.P.'s Plans for Medicare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The White House proposals to revamp Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, are in some respects remarkably similar to those in the Republican budget bill passed by Congress, according to documents obtained from the Administration.
Both promise Medicare beneficiaries a variety of new insurance options, including coverage through health maintenance organizations and health plans organized by doctors and hospitals. But the White House proposal would allow more growth in Medicare spending than the Republicans would, and President Clinton appears more willing to use Government regulation to protect beneficiaries against erosion in the quality of care. 
 Under current law, Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, which pays hospital bills, is expected to run out of money in 2002. Mr. Clinton said his proposal would assure its solvency through 2011. Republicans said their plan would keep the trust fund going through 2017.
Administration officials met today with Congressional leaders in another effort to see if they could agree on how to balance the Federal budget in seven years.
Ed Kutler, an aide to Speaker Newt Gingrich, said tonight that he could not comment on Mr. Clinton's Medicare proposals because he and other Republicans had not seen them. "Administration officials come in with piecemeal proposals," he said, "but we are waiting for their entire plan to balance the budget in seven years. We will look at the Medicare proposals in the context of the entire plan."
It is difficult to compare the savings that would be achieved by Mr. Clinton against those projected by the Republicans. The White House has estimated the savings from each of its proposals, but most of the numbers were deleted from documents made available tonight.
The White House numbers are based on calculations by the White House Office of Management and Budget. The Republicans' savings were estimated by the Congressional Budget Office. The two agencies have different assumptions about the economy and the effects of various proposals, so their figures are not directly comparable.
Thus, for example, President Clinton said tonight that his proposals would cut projected spending on Medicare by $124 billion over seven years. The Republicans say the President's proposals would actually cut $192 billion from the amounts that would otherwise be spent, according to the projections of the Congressional Budget Office. The Republicans say their own Medicare proposals would save $270 billion.
President Clinton said he would keep monthly Medicare premiums lower than the Republicans had proposed. The monthly premium is now $46.10. Under Mr. Clinton's plan, it would drop to $42.50 in January, then rise gradually to $77 in 2002. By contrast, the Congressional Budget Office says that under the Republican plan, the premium would rise to $53.70 next year, then climb gradually to $88.90 in 2002.
In most years, the monthly premiums would be $8 to $11 higher under the Republican plan.
The idea of offering new insurance options to Medicare beneficiaries was a major part of the Republican plan. Administration officials said they had tried to strike a balance: they would open the program to more H.M.O.'s and other types of managed care, but they ruled out some Republican options on the ground that they could pose a threat to the standard Medicare program.
The Administration criticized the Republican proposal for medical savings accounts. Under this proposal, beneficiaries could use their share of Medicare money to set up tax-free savings accounts to pay routine medical bills, while purchasing a high-deductible, catastrophic insurance plans to pay the rest.
The Administration, like the Republicans, wants to establish a new method of paying H.M.O.'s that enroll Medicare patients. The documents said Congress should "limit the wide geographic fluctuations in H.M.O. payment rates.".
The White House proposed new restrictions on Medicare payments to hospitals, doctors, nursing homes and home health agencies. The cutbacks appear, in many cases, to be more modest than those proposed by the Republicans.
To exploit Medicare's power as a big purchaser of goods and services, the White House wants to establish a system of competitive bidding. In each geographic area, it said, the Government would buy medical equipment, CAT scans and magnetic resonance imaging services from companies that offered the best price and met Government standards for quality.

HEADLINE: Guatemala Journal;
Left's Hero Is Home (but Then, He's Long Dead)

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: GUATEMALA

 BODY:
He was an icon of the Latin American left and an early victim of the cold war. But more than 40 years after being ousted in a coup sponsored by the Central Intelligence Agency, and nearly a quarter of a century after he died in exile, Col. Jacobo Arbenz Guzman has finally come home.
"So that we may advance toward national reconciliation," as President Ramiro de Leon Carpio put it, Arbenz's remains were exhumed from a cemetery in El Salvador and returned to Guatemala and a hero's welcome on Oct. 20. 
 To shouts of "Welcome home!" and "Long live Arbenz!" thousands of people crowded into the streets and National Palace to catch a glimpse of his horse-drawn coffin.
Arbenz had been forced to leave Guatemala in humiliating circumstances in June 1954, stripped to his underwear at the airport by his enemies. The son of a Swiss immigrant pharmacist, Arbenz joined the army as a teen-ager and was elected President in 1950 on a platform of social reform, but was overthrown after trying to carry out a land redistribution program that alarmed the Eisenhower Administration and the powerful United Fruit Company.
For those reasons, the former President's tomb here, a simple white pyramid just to the right of the main entrance of the General Cemetery, has quickly become a magnet for Guatemalans who seek an alternative to the four decades of right-wing rule that have followed.
On a recent Sunday afternoon, the Davila family, four generations strong, was among those who came to pay their respects to the man popularly known as "the Soldier of the People."
"There has never been another like him, with such great ideals," Gerardo Davila, 93, told his great-granddaughter, Ana Lucia Bran, 8. "Since his fall, there has been no progress in this country, only stagnation."
Soon, the Davila family was joined by Matias Perez, 83, and his son and daughter-in-law. Had Arbenz been allowed to remain in power, Mr. Perez said somberly, Guatemala might have been spared its 35-year civil war, still unresolved, in which more than 100,000 people have been killed, mostly by the Guatemalan military.
"In Arbenz's time there were no guerrillas, because he loved the people and worked for them," he said.
Mr. Perez paused, and then began to sob. "I loved him very much," he said, wiping his eyes. "And I hate that other one over there," he added, gesticulating toward a large gray mausoleum about 50 yards away.
There, bunches of wilted flowers and a metal tablet mark the burial place of Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, who was recruited by the C.I.A. to overthrow the Arbenz Government and who ruled until he was assassinated in July 1957. "To the Liberator of Guatemala, Anti-Communist Martyr," the plaque reads.
Those who had a hand in bringing the remains of Arbenz back to Guatemala deny that his placement so close to Castillo Armas was a posthumous act of revenge. But Arnoldo Ortiz Moscoso, the Arbenz family lawyer, acknowledged, "There is a certain irony in the fact that Arbenz is on the right when you enter and Castillo Armas on the left."
To the National Liberation Movement, the political party of Castillo Armas, Arbenz's mere presence in the cemetery is an affront. The return of the "cowardly" leader of a "bloodthirsty" Government can only "bring bad results and national discord," complained the right-wing group's longtime leader, Mario Sandoval Alarcon, who took part in the 1954 coup.
But nearly every other political force in Guatemala now seems to be rushing to stake a claim to the Arbenz legacy. Former President Vinicio Cerezo, a Christian Democrat, has just published a largely favorable assessment, and during the recent presidential election campaign the main slogan of the left-wing New Guatemala Democratic Front was a vow to resume the tasks that Arbenz left unfinished.
Somewhat surprisingly, the Guatemalan military has also made an effort to link itself to Arbenz. Gen. Marco Antonio Gonzalez, the Defense Minister, went to the military airport here to receive the remains, made a point of announcing that the former President had recovered his military rank and medals, and sent a cadet to speak at burial ceremonies.
"This is an army that is trying to reinvent itself because it has a terrible image problem and is going to have to find something new to do once peace comes," said a foreign official here. "Arbenz provides one of the few positive memories people have of the armed forces."
Even some of the children of wealthy landowners whose estates were confiscated by the Arbenz Government have found good things to say about their former foe. Business leaders have recently praised him for building a dam, a port and a highway to the Caribbean coast, projects that were intended to break the hold of the United Fruit Company over the Guatemalan economy and are now cited as models of modernization and "nationalist development."
Further efforts to rehabilitate the image of Arbenz are under way. Mr. Ortiz Moscoso intends to organize an Arbenz Foundation to "perpetuate his memory through a center of documentation," and intellectuals are calling for his restoration to the history books from which he has been largely stricken.
"Ours is a country that lacks leaders the people can believe in, that does not have a Washington, a Jefferson or a Lincoln," Mr. Ortiz Moscoso said. "I'm convinced the Arbenz phenomenon is in part an answer to this need to find heroes and symbols -- the deader the better, because then they do not disturb people."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: The Curtain Drops on a Career at Sony;
Trouble at American Entertainment Operations Prompts a Resignation

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
It may have been only a matter of time.
Michael P. Schulhof, the head of the Sony Corporation's American operations resigned under pressure yesterday, apparently unable to inspire confidence in Sony's Japanese management that he was doing enough to revive the company's businesses in the United States. 
 The resignation of Mr. Schulhof as president and chief executive of the Sony Corporation of America unit came almost exactly 12 months after Sony, which is based in Tokyo, took a $2.7 billion write-off to account for losses in its Hollywood film business. Since then, the film division has had only a mixed record and Sony's other major American entertainment holding, its music business, has lost market share. Meanwhile, some new ventures under Mr. Schulhof, including an electronic-publishing business, have suffered relatively large losses.
In the 1980's Sony was among the first foreign companies to make big acquisitions of American entertainment operations -- CBS Records for $2 billion in 1987 and Columbia Pictures for $3.4 billion in 1989. And Sony has stayed the course longer than some of its compatriots.
But yesterday, Sony took the unusual step of replacing the head of its American business with Japanese executives who will run the company from Tokyo. Sony's chairman and chief executive, Norio Ohga, who played key roles in acquiring and initially overseeing the American entertainment properties, will add to his titles those of chairman for the Sony Music and Sony Pictures Entertainment units. And Nobuyuki Idei, Sony's president, will add the titles of vice chairman of Sony of America and chairman of its Sony Electronics unit.
"You can think of it a symbolic move," said Daniel Lucas, an analyst who follows Sony for Towa Securities in Tokyo. "The overseas subsidiary have been brought to heel because Sony is trying to become a leaner and meaner organization. When Idei first came in, he said the first thing he would do was take a good look around. I would imagine this is part of his push."
Sony gave no explanation yesterday for Mr. Schulhof's resignation. But several people close to the company said that the lackluster performance of the American operations in the last year, coupled with Mr. Schulhof's propensity for heavy corporate spending and his own extravagant standard of living, grated on executives in Tokyo, where an economic downturn has forced new measures of austerity on Japanese companies. Mr. Ohga and Mr. Schulhof have been colleagues for years, but Mr. Idei, who became Sony's president in April, is said to be highly critical of Mr. Schulhof's spending habits and informal management style.
Sony issued only a brief release, thanking Mr. Schulhof, who had been with the company for 21 years and was its highest-ranking American, for his contributions and saying only that he was leaving to "pursue new business interests." Mr. Schulhof also declined to comment.
Mr. Schulhof was a vice chairman of Sony's American operations when the company acquired the music business in 1987 and ascended in the corporate hierarchy as the Japanese company pursued a strategy of expanding in the American entertainment business.
Mr. Schulhof spearheaded Sony's acquisition of Columbia Pictures in 1989, a move that first raised the question of excessive corporate spending.
Some critics contended that the $3.4 billion Sony paid for the studio was too much -- a criticism that grew more intense after the company spent $200 million to acquire the film production company of Jon Peters and Peter Guber, paid more than $400 million to buy their contracts with Warner Brothers and then agreed to give them each a salary of $2.75 million to jointly run Columbia.
Mr. Schulhof became president and chief executive in 1993 and since then has operated the company's Madison Avenue headquarters as something resembling a pricey private club. He hired Barry Wines, the founder of the celebrated Quilted Giraffe restaurant in Manhattan, to oversee the headquarter's dining rooms, including a sushi bar that has an artificial stream running through it.
Mr. Schulhof also lives like an entertainment mogul, attracting attention earlier this year when he bought a multimillion-dollar estate in Southhampton, L.I., then decided not to live there and quickly put it on the market again.
Instead, he decided to remain in his existing home in Easthampton, L.I. -- but only after acquiring the house next to it, turning it into a guest house and screening room.
Personal extravagance would probably not have been an issue, industry executives said, if Mr. Schulhof had produced better results with Sony's businesses -- not only movies, but especially on video games, CD-ROM's and other multimedia efforts that several industry executives estimate have perhaps lost as much as $100 million in recent years.
 For many years Mr. Schulhof had the support of Sony's chairman and co-founder Akio Morita. He also had a patient superviser in Mr. Ohga, who as president under Mr. Morita played a more direct role in overseeing the American operation. But Mr. Morita, in poor health after a stroke, retired late last year.
Mr. Ohga subsequently assumed the chairman and chief executive titles and surprised nearly everyone in the electronics and entertainment industries in April by selecting Mr. Idei -- a managing director with experience primarily in advertising and corporate communications -- to become president. And Mr. Idei, analysts and executives said, has been much less patient with the lackluster performance and spendthrift image of the American business.
Some industry executives speculated yesterday that Sony had forced out Mr. Schulhof in a show of fiscal and management discipline intended to attract an entertainment-industry partner to invest in the American business. There was also conjecture that an American executive would soon be found to run the United States business. But several executives close to Sony denied that finding a partner or hiring a new manager were imminent moves.
"Mr. Idei's arrival," said an executive close to Sony, "has made a big difference at the company."


GRAPHIC: Michael P. Schulhof was vice chairman of the Sony Corporation's American operations in 1987, when the Japanese company embarked on an ambitious strategy of combining its strength in the consumer electronics business with American entertainment "software." Despite Sony's problems in successfully implementing that strategy, Mr. Schulhof rose to the top of Sony's entire United States operations -- until resigning under pressure yesterday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Pesticide Kills Foreign Fruit Pickers' Hopes

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: NARANJAL, Ecuador

 BODY:
Half a lifetime ago, when Mario Brito Dumas was a young man with a bride and a peasant's head of modest dreams, he tended the lush banana plantations outside Naranjal. If he had any plan, it was the common one that keeps a man toiling through his best years: to make enough money to raise a family.
But a few years after his first son was born in 1972, Mr. Brito's plantation began using a pesticide both miraculous and terrible. It killed off a microscopic worm that would prevent the bananas' export to the United States, but it also killed pigs, frogs, birds and other creatures that drank water running from the field. 
 What Mr. Brito and the other men who worked with this powerful new chemical could not guess was that it was also destroying their chances to have children.
In 1977 the chemical, dibromo chloropropane, or DBCP, was found to cause sterility in men working at an Occidental Petroleum plant in Lathrop, Calif., prompting an immediate ban on its use in California, and sharply restricting its use elsewhere in the continental United States.
But American-based food growers continued to use the fumigant in countries without the United States standard of environmental, legal and occupational protections. And now, emerging from the anger, the ruined marriages and childless houses across the globe, some 25,000 workers from 12 developing countries are suing manufacturers and fruit growers.
 
No U.S. Law Prohibited Export of the Chemicals
Contending that they were exposed to a known hazard without any warning that the pesticide could cause sterility and possibly birth defects and cancer, the workers are suing Dow Chemical, Shell Oil -- a unit of Royal Dutch/Shell -- and Occidental Petroleum, along with Del Monte Fruit, Chiquita Brands and Dole Food.
"Even though they knew the risk of the product -- they didn't use it in their own country," Mr. Brito said, "but they used it here in the third world, despite the damage to humans and animals. The ones who produced this chemical bear absolute responsibility for this disaster."
The manufacturers deny that they sent the pesticide overseas after 1979. They also point out that they followed all United States laws governing the labeling, sale and use of DBCP, rated a probable human carcinogen by the Environmental Protection Agency.
And that is perhaps the most unbearable element of all for people here, for no American law prohibits exporting chemicals that are banned from use in the United States.
Charles S. Siegel, a lawyer who represents more than 20,000 workers, said that exports of DBCP to Africa and Ecuador continued at least until 1981, two years after the E.P.A. banned its use in the continental United States, and to the Philippines until 1986, he said.
"They sent the product to Latin American countries as if they were a toxic dump, without regard for the health of the people living in them," said Guillermo Touma, an Ecuadorean who organizes farmworkers.
When the forerunner of DBCP was developed in the 1940's, it was hailed as a solution to the pests that were killing many American crops. The Andrews Sisters sang a ditty to the breakthrough pesticide called the "D-D Hop" on rural radio stations.
Scientists at Shell and Dow, which developed DBCP independently, sent the relevant research data to Washington, but suggested in discussions and memos with Federal officials that the effects the chemical produced in laboratory animals -- elevated levels of cancer and shriveling testicles -- would probably not be repeated in humans.
 
Agriculture Department Abandoned Misgivings
The Agriculture Department, which was responsible for registration and labeling at the time, abandoned its misgivings over the new product after the companies provided data that showed no damage to plant employees.
It was not until 1977 that the links between DBCP and sterility prompted restrictions on the chemical's use in the United States. But the makers of DBCP had stocks of the product on hand, and growers still considered it an important tool in the arsenal of pesticides, fungicides and fumigants that produce the unblemished fruits American consumers prefer.
According to documents obtained by lawyers for the banana workers, Standard Fruit told Dow Chemical that halting shipments of DBCP would be considered a breach of contract, and in early 1979 it agreed to indemnify the chemical manufacturer for any damages it would face for selling its stocks to Standard Fruit.
Patrick Nielson, a lawyer for Dole Food, said the food grower had received assurances from Dow that because they were working outdoors, agricultural workers would not face the same risk of sterility as the employees of Occidental, which had begun manufacturing DBCP under license. The indemnity agreement, he said, was demanded by Dow as a condition for providing the DBCP, and Mr. Nielson said that Dole stopped using DBCP in plantations it owned once the E.P.A. banned its use in 1979.
Officials at Dow say the company knew the fruit growers would be using DBCP in Latin America, and printed labels in Spanish that advised using protective gear and warned of the danger of sterility.
"There was a specific understanding between Dow and the customer that the product would be used within these safe handling guidelines," said Gennaro A. Filice, a lawyer representing Dow.
Burt Ballanfant, an attorney for Shell, said the company had stopped selling DBCP to any of the growers or countries named in the litigation well before the 1977 ban, though lawyers for the banana workers have shipping orders showing Shell subsidiaries delivering the product to third-world countries through 1981.
Shell also cited two recently published studies that showed no significantly elevated levels of cancer in workers exposed to DBCP, but other scientists said the research was seriously flawed because one study included employees exposed to many different chemicals, along with those who had worked in administration and other divisions that had no exposure to DBCP, while the other study used only a small sample of workers.
Executives at Del Monte and Chiquita did not answer repeated requests for comment.
 
Protective Gear Was Often Not Used
David Weir and Mark Schapiro, who examined the export of pesticides barred for use in the United States in their 1981 book, "Circle of Poison," said that after the United States ban, DBCP shipments grew more difficult to follow.
When large chemical corporations stopped exporting the fumigant after the 1979 ban, smaller manufacturers stepped in, paying royalties for every shipment sold.
Many growers, similarly, stopped buying the pesticides directly, but continued imposing the use of DBCP on banana plantations where they bought crops from local farmers.
In Hawaii, where DBCP continued legally to be used on pineapples until 1985, the E.P.A. required ample protective gear to prevent the chemical from seeping into the skin or respiratory systems of laborers. But in the plantations where Mr. Brito and others worked, the banana leaves make a thick canopy that traps vapors in the air that workers breathe, and the protective gear and other precautions that American employees use were rarely used here.
Some of the men said they wore only shorts and shoes to work in the searing heat, and many complained of headaches and trouble sleeping when they worked with the product.
"We were thirsty, sweating, our eyes were red and we felt like we had the flu," said Mr. Brito, who said that from 1975 to 1980, he filled enormous injectors with DBCP each day and pumped it into the root systems of banana plants. "Everything I ate tasted bitter, and gave me stomach aches."
On a recent visit to one of the countless banana plantations near Naranjal, there was no sign of basic occupational safety or labor standards. Children worked picking the shriveled black flowers from the bottom of each banana, while shirtless workers carried pesticides in backpack-style sprayers.
A small mountain of rejected fruit grew steadily -- bananas either blemished or too wide, too long or too small for American consumers.
Alejandro M. Garro, a professor of Latin American law at Columbia University who testified on behalf of the banana workers, said that allowing developing countries to import chemicals that are known health hazards presumes that foreign governments have the desire and the mechanisms to protect their citizens.
Barring that, he said, it assumes a court system where people who are damaged by harmful substances can seek redress.
"Without courts that function well, you cannot have a free-market economy functioning well, and this is a clear case where this is reflected," Mr. Garro said. "You will have the big fish eating the small fish, without any kind of fairness or justice being implemented."
While the lawyers representing the workers say they will not abandon their suits, the obstacles to pursuing them will be formidable. Many third-world countries have no laws allowing lawyers to represent clients in exchange for a share of any eventual award -- the usual system for such cases in the United States -- and the courts have little experience dealing with the liability issues the DBCP cases raise.
 
A Victim Trusts God and U.S. Courts
Mr. Brito, now 50 and out of the fields, works renting out a pickup truck he bought a few years ago. He does not hold much hope for redress in Ecuador, partly because of the corruption that seems to permeate every level of government, and partly because multinational companies are so important to the small country's economy.
"Here, you can't believe in our justice system," he said, asserting that judges could be paid off to decide the case in the company's favor.
With his lawsuit ahead of him, Mr. Brito is hoping that some day the companies he blames for erasing the family he could have had will answer for what happened.
"We'll have to trust in God, and in the courts of the United States," he said.
The son born before he began working with DBCP is now 23 and in his fifth year of studying marine biology. Across the generation, Mario Brito can see progress, but he said he still wonders, sometimes, if it had to cost so much.

HEADLINE: With One Disease Nearly Erased, Assault Is Planned on Another

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Armed with a new confidence that it is possible to wipe out diseases that have plagued humans for centuries, international health and development officials announced today a final assault on one debilitating tropical malady, river blindness, even as they celebrated the imminent demise of another, Guinea worm disease.
United Nations health organizations, the World Bank and private groups announced a 12-year international program to control and eventually wipe out river blindness in Africa, an effort they said should save millions from the blindness and disfigurement of the disease formally known as onchocerciasis. 
 The new program is modeled on the highly successful Onchocerciasis Control Program that since 1974 has largely eliminated river blindness as a major health problem in an 11-country region of West Africa. Under the initiative, community treatment programs will be established in parts of 16 nations not included in the original program, officials said.
James D. Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, said several countries and organizations had pledged $20 million of the $124 million needed for the river blindness program.
Former President Jimmy Carter, whose Carter Center in Atlanta is coordinating the effort, said the United States, which is cutting back on foreign aid, refused to contribute.
The new attack on river blindness follows an announcement on Monday that Guinea worm disease, another parasitic condition, should be entirely eliminated within a year.
Guinea worm disease occurs when people drink water containing tiny water fleas that have ingested microscopic Guinea worm larvae. The larvae mate in the intestine and the females move to the outer parts of the body. A year after infestation, mature worms up to three feet long emerge through painful blisters, sometimes causing muscle damage and crippling similar to polio.
Guinea worm disease has been controlled by use of a chemical that purifies contaminated water and by educating infected people not to wade in sources of drinking water.
The Guinea worm has been eliminated in the Indian subcontinent and most of Africa, with remaining cases in Nigeria, Niger and the Sudan.
River blindness is caused by a parasitic worm that is spread by the bites of tiny black flies that breed in fast-moving river water. Larvae produced by adult worms migrate in the skin of humans, causing lesions and blindness when they reach the eyes.
This disease is fought by spraying to kill the flies and treating victims with the drug ivermectin, which kills newly hatched worms with an annual dose. Merck & Company of Rahway, N.J., which developed the drug, has donated it to eradication programs, a contribution Mr. Carter said was worth $250 million over 12 years.

HEADLINE: Man Found Guilty of Raping His Wife

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
Every year, the Manhattan District Attorney's office brings a few dozen cases against men accused of raping their wives. In all but a few cases, the men are not convicted, often because the woman decides not to pursue the case.
But on Monday, one of the cases prevailed, in part because the woman was upset that her husband never expressed any remorse over the attack. 
 The man, Jose Santos, a 37-year-old resident of Washington Heights, was convicted of first-degree rape, first-degree sodomy, first-degree sexual abuse and second-degree assault in the May 9 attack, which prosecutors said was so violent that his wife's ankle was broken.
Linda Fairstein, chief of the Manhattan District Attorney's sex crimes unit, said many of the marital rape cases her office handles never go to trial.
"We lose the victims before the trial," Ms. Fairstein said. "The victims withdraw, choose not to prosecute, some because of fear of reprisal, some because of the psychological feelings involved."
Ms. Fairstein, the author of the book "Sexual Violence: Our War Against Rape" (William Morrow & Company, 1993), said that a wife who has been sexually abused or battered approaches the criminal justice system "with a lot of ambivalence," partly because of "societal attitudes."
"I think the perception has been nationally as a result of the Simpson case that these cases don't do well in the system," Ms. Fairstein said, referring to domestic violence cases in general.
She said the victim of a marital rape may have a love-hate relationship with her spouse and still hopes to resume the relationship. Also, she may not want to see the father of her children go to jail, or is fearful of financial hardship if the wage-earner receives a prison sentence.
In this week's case, the victim, a 35-year-old home-care attendant, saw the prosecution through to the end because her husband denied he had done anything wrong and never showed remorse, said Martha Bashford, the prosecutor handling the case.
"I think she got very indignant at that," Ms. Bashford said.
Since the woman was a rape victim, her name was omitted from the court record. The victim has a different last name than her husband.
Mr. Santos, an unemployed guitar teacher, testified that his wife slipped and broke her ankle as she attacked him with a kitchen knife. He said that he delayed calling an ambulance for three hours, even though she claimed to be intense pain, because she was getting dressed and putting on her makeup.
"You know how women are," he said on the stand.
The victim testified that she and Mr. Santos had been married about a year when they became estranged and he moved out. Several days later, after her two young children by another man had left for school, her husband showed up at her door and began choking and pushing her. She fell, her leg folded awkwardly under her, and her ankle broke.
According to her testimony, Mr. Santos grabbed a kitchen knife and began yelling that it was too late for both of them and they both were going to die. He began to rip her clothes off, she said, but when she screamed in pain he ordered her to take them off. Then he sexually abused her. Throughout the ordeal, he was drinking alcohol and talking incoherently about their relationship.
At one point, Mr. Santos tried to stab her but she moved aside and the knife pierced the mattress. Then he broke down and asked her forgiveness. She finally convinced him to call an ambulance about 11:30 A.M., about three hours after she broke her ankle.
At Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, the victim called a friend who worked for the Department of Correction. When the friend arrived, she got Mr. Santos to leave his wife's side and got a hospital social worker to interview the victim, prosecutors said.
"If he had been willing to admit what he had done and expressed remorse, she would have had a different view" about prosecuting, Ms. Bashford said. "But he kept saying it was her fault."
Mr. Santos faces a minimum of 4 1/2 to 9 years and a maximum of 12 1/2 to 25 years in prison when he is sentenced by Justice Franklyn R. Weissberg of State Supreme Court on Dec. 20.
