HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Stay Above 6% on Yield

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the first time in five sessions, as yields again tested the 6 percent level but failed to stay below it.
"The market's failure to crack 6 percent was a signal to take profits." said Tony Crescenzi, director of fixed-income trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company, a New York brokerage firm. 
 To crack 6 percent may require more signs of softness in the economy and a cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, traders said. Once that happens, perhaps in a few weeks, the rally will resume, they predicted. In the meantime, yields could remain at these levels, which represent two-year lows.
The 30-year bond fell yesterday by 7/32, to a price of 111 16/32 to yield 6.04 percent, up from 6.02 percent on Monday. The yield was below 6 percent briefly for the second consecutive day but bounced back.
Mr. Crescenzi said that breaking 6 percent and staying there was proving to be a challenge.
He said that not even a weak report on retail sales by Johnson Redbook, which saw a 1.6 percent decline in the works for December from November, was enough to stop the selling. Normally, market participants buy on signs of economic weakness, on the hope for lower interest rates.
"The market needs to see some validation of its current price levels through a rate cut by the Fed and also see the potential for a budget deficit agreement," Mr. Crescenzi said. "Currently the market is a little ahead of itself," he said, with favorable news already priced into the market.
"But that's O.K. when the Fed is lowering rates," he said.
The March 30-year bond contract in futures trading climbed as high as 120 29/32 before sliding back to 120 11/32 at the close when people reversed bets that the rally would continue without interruption. Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research of Boston, said there was a possibility that the contract price could fall some more.
Some traders attributed part of yesterday's slide in prices to profits taken before today's release of the Fed's beige book survey of business conditions by region. Traders hope the report will shed light on the central bank's posture ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Dec. 19, when the Fed could lower rates.
However, this week's most important report remains the November employment data scheduled for Friday. According to analysts surveyed by Bloomberg Business News, the data will probably show that the economy added 178,000 nonfarm jobs.
In the municipal market, the good news for investors is that the forward calendar of new issues coming to market, measured by the Bond Buyer's 30-day visible supply, recently hit a 1995 high on Nov. 13 of more than $6.4 billion. "In other words," said Michael S. Appelbaum, a senior vice president at Paine Webber, "investors will have a wider selection of new issues to choose from over the next month than at any point this year."
Mr. Appelbaum said that this big supply of new issues was coming at an opportune time for investors, since municipal redemptions, including interest rate payments, during the combined months of November and December were expected to reach $51.6 billion.
Yesterday, in the week's largest sale, the Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority sold $404.56 million in revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Good investor demand allowed the issue to be repriced and restructured, with the yield on a number of maturities lowered as much as 5 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Serial bonds with shorter maturities are priced to yield from 4.40 percent in 1998 to 5.30 percent in 2009. Bonds due in 2012 were priced to yield 5.40 percent and those in 2013, 5.45 percent. A 2015 maturity offers a yield of 5.48 percent, while the longest maturity in 2019 yields 5.52 percent.
The issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's, with the exception of about a half-dozen maturities that are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation and rated triple-A.

HEADLINE: Shift Is Sought In Financing For Hospitals

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
A task force appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday recommended sweeping changes in the way health care is financed in New York State, proposing that the state stop setting the rates that insurers pay hospitals to care for their patients.
The proposal follows a growing trend across the country, as states that had once sought to contain the growth of health-care costs by setting prices have decided to let market forces perform that role. 
 For 25 years, the state has determined -- hospital by hospital and procedure by procedure -- how much insurers should pay for patient care. The formula was based on the actual cost of providing care at each hospital and a comparison with the costs of such care at similar hospitals.
The state has also imposed a surcharge on insurance companies to help hospitals pay for the costs of caring for poor people, a process the task force recommends continuing.
The task force proposed yesterday that hospitals and insurance companies negotiate individually to set rates, saying that such a system would provide economic incentives to contain costs. The State Health Department provided a six-page outline of the group's report, saying the full proposal would be available tomorrow.
Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono, the State Health Commissioner and the chairwoman of the task force, said that such a fundamental overhaul presented a risk to certain hospitals, but she said that the move was necessary to make the health care system more efficient.
"We are now at a point where we need to move on and forward," Dr. DeBuono said.
But health care providers and analysts of the health care industry said they worried that teaching hospitals and hospitals that serve large numbers of uninsured patients would struggle to stay afloat if the transition to the new system were too swift.
"Reforming the system isn't wrong," said Raymond Sweeney, executive vice president of the Health Care Association of New York State, a trade organization representing hospitals. "But in a negotiated rate system, inevitably institutions will be forced out of business, and the ones most at risk are the ones serving populations most at risk."
In addition to the task force recommendations, New York hospitals face proposals in Congress that would significantly reduce the Federal subsidies they get for training doctors and providing care to the impoverished and uninsured.
Under the task force's proposal, the state would continue to provide about $675 million annually in subsidies for graduate medical education, although the money would be gradually diminished over time.
That money would go primarily for the salaries of hospital residents and would be focused on training programs that emphasized primary, outpatient care and those that successfully retained their graduates to work in the state. Now, about half the nearly 15,000 residents who train each year in New York leave the state after their training is completed.
The task force recommended that the state help reduce doctor training costs by cutting the number of residency programs in the state by 30 percent over the next three years. It also said the state should no longer guarantee the indirect costs of training doctors. The state now helps hospitals cover these costs -- like extra lab tests ordered and the supervision of doctors in training -- by setting rates for insurers that take such expenses into account.
Instead, hospitals would have to negotiate those costs -- which last year totaled about $1 billion -- as part of the deals they make with insurers.
Hospital industry officials questioned whether, in an unfettered system, insurers would agree to higher rates to cover medical training expenses.
"Payers looking to reduce their premiums are not easily going to negotiate so that they cover collectively $1 billion in graduate medical education costs," said Kenneth E. Raske, executive director of the Greater New York Hospital Association, an industry group. "This will be like an avalanche overnight. There will be major dislocation."
The task force said that the state would continue to subsidize charity care for the poor and uninsured, but that it would shift its emphasis from compensating hospitals that care for large numbers of such patients to increasing opportunities for the uninsured to get insurance.
Among the programs that would be expanded is Child Health Plus, which subsidizes low-cost insurance for the children of the working poor, and the Employer Incentive Program, which helps small businesses insure their employees.
"Coverage is what's going to get people to see doctors," Dr. DeBuono said, adding that access to preventive care would "ultimately keep them out of the hospital" and reduce health care costs.
The money for such so-called uncompensated care would come from some kind of tax or surcharge to payers, but the task force did not determine the mechanisms for setting and collecting the money.
Money from such a pool -- which the task force estimated at $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion annually -- would also be used to help financially unstable hospitals make the transition to the new market-based system.
The state first began to experiment with the limiting of rate regulation eight years ago, when the Legislature voted to allow health maintenance organizations and other managed care companies to negotiate their rates with hospitals. That move was done to encourage the growth of managed care in the state, which was still at very low levels.
Recent studies have shown that managed care has made significant gains in the state in recent years, with about 25 percent of New Yorkers now covered through such programs.
The task force said that for now, the state should continue to set the rates for Medicaid patients who are not enrolled in managed care programs. But it has recommended that the State Health Department also be allowed to negotiate rates for Medicaid recipients receiving care through the traditional "fee for service" program.

HEADLINE: Charles Gillett, 80, the Creator Of the 'Big Apple' Ad Campaign

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
Charles Gillett, who was credited with creating the Big Apple tourism campaign when he was president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, died on Monday at his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 80 and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.
The cause was a heart attack, the bureau said. 
 Mr. Gillett worked for the bureau for more than 40 years and was its president from 1964 until he retired in 1988. He helped to plan such tourist events as the 100th anniversaries of the Brooklyn Bridge and the Statue of Liberty, and the bicentennial visit of tall ships in 1976.
He was also involved in negotiations to bring the Democratic National Convention to Madison Square Garden in 1976, the first national political convention held in New York since 1924.
But perhaps his greatest success came with turning the term "Big Apple" into a tourist draw. A jazz fan, he remembered that musicians in the 1920's and 30's had an expression for playing the big time after gigs in one-horse towns: "There are many apples on the tree, but when you pick New York City, you pick the Big Apple." Damon Runyon had popularized the term in the 1920's.
By the early 1970's, New York City was facing a fiscal crisis and nightclub comedians and television talk-show hosts were getting big laughs from jokes about New York. Mr. Gillett started handing out Big Apple lapel stickers.
Soon Tom Snyder, who was a news anchor on WNBC-TV at the time, was wearing one on the air, and the comedian Alan King and the New York Knicks star Dave DeBusschere were passing out the little red pins.
Mr. Gillett's duties as head of the not-for-profit bureau went well beyond cheerleading. He was, in effect, the city's chief salesman for tourism, fighting for conventions and the hotel and restaurant revenues they generate. Sometimes the negotiations for conventions also generated headlines, as when the American Medical Association agreed to return to New York in 1976.
In making his case to the A.M.A., Mr. Gillett had consulted the bureau's files, which showed, convention sponsor by convention sponsor, who made the decisions about where conventions were held, what those people thought about New York and what problems may have kept them out of New York in the past.
When he retired, he received the first New York State Governor's Award. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo cited Mr. Gillett's "long and distinguished service in promoting New York as the premier travel destination in the world" and for moving the bureau into the front ranks of local travel promotion agencies.
He was a former chairman of the Travel Industry Association of America, a past president of the International Association of Convention and Visitors Bureaus and served on the advisory board of the United States Travel and Tourism Administration. He was elected to the American Society of Travel Agents' Hall of Fame, and was a delegate to the 1995 White House Conference on Travel and Tourism.
Mr. Gillett graduated in 1937 from the University of Cincinnati, which in the 1980's gave him its Award for Excellence for developing tourism as a social and economic force. He served as a captain with the Ninth Armored Division in World War II and was awarded the Bronze Star.
He is survived by his wife, Virginia; one daughter, Valerie, of Manhattan; two sons, David, of Mendocino, Calif., and Peter, of Felton, Calif., and one granddaughter.

HEADLINE: School-Lunch Discord Stalls the Welfare Bill

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Republicans today stepped up the pressure on President Clinton to sign their welfare bill but acknowledged that the legislation was now delayed by a bitter dispute among Republicans themselves over the future of the national school lunch program.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said last month that Mr. Clinton would veto the legislation, in part because the President believed that it would cut too much from projected spending on social welfare programs. 
 But today Republicans said the latest version of their bill addressed many of the Administration's concerns. And they said that by vetoing the bill, Mr. Clinton would be killing tough new provisions that would force delinquent parents to meet their child-support obligations.
The House passed its version of the welfare bill in March, the Senate passed a very different version in September, and Republican negotiators from the two chambers announced agreement on a compromise on Nov. 14.
But because of the dispute over the school lunch program, they have still not filed a conference report with the text of their agreement. As a result, neither house has taken final action on the bill.
The House's chief negotiator on the school lunch issue, Representative Bill Goodling, a Pennsylvania Republican who is chairman of the Economic and Educational Opportunities Committee, insists that states be free to design and run their own school lunch programs with fixed amounts of Federal money known as block grants. Under that approach, he said, states would have "substantially greater flexibility" in spending money for child nutrition. Mr. Goodling said Senate staff members had told him that Senate negotiators were amenable to this proposal.
But the chief Senate negotiator on school lunches, Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican who is chairman of the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry, and Senator James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont, firmly oppose the idea of such block grants. They want to keep the school lunch program as an entitlement, under which Federal subsidies would grow automatically with the number of eligible children.
"We should retain a safety net for child nutrition programs," Mr. Lugar said. "We have not repealed the business cycle. When another recession occurs, states that choose block grants will have serious problems meeting a rising caseload."
Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., a Florida Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, said he hoped the dispute would be resolved so that the full House could vote on the legislation, including the tough new provisions on parental child support, by Dec. 15.
But Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California, said: "It's not necessary to destroy the social safety net and the entitlement to welfare benefits for poor people in order to improve child-support enforcement. We could pass a separate child-support bill tomorrow."
The Department of Health and Human Services said today that states collected $9.9 billion of child support from delinquent parents in the 1994 fiscal year, a significant increase from $8.9 billion in 1993 and $8 billion in 1992. But that 1994 figure, the department estimates, was less than a third of the amount owed in child support that year.
Under the welfare bill, the Federal Government would establish a nationwide system to match child-support orders issued by the courts or state agencies with employer records showing the locations of all people hired after Oct. 1, 1997. Using such information, a state where a mother and her child live could send to the father's employer an order requiring that employer to deduct child-support payments from his wages.
The bill would also require the states to adopt uniform laws to simplify the handling of child-support cases when mother and father live in different states. States would also have to set up a procedure to suspend or restrict drivers' licenses and professional licenses of parents who refuse to pay child support.

HEADLINE: Making the System Work In Kidney Patients' Favor

SERIES: MISMANAGED CARE: The Perils of Dialysis -- Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Each time patients receive kidney dialysis at Kaiser Permanente in Los Angeles, they see something rarely found in most American dialysis clinics: a doctor.
At other clinics, part-time doctors drop by for a few hours a week, leaving treatment largely in the hands of poorly supervised technicians and low-level nurses. But Kaiser's dialysis unit in Los Angeles is staffed full time by at least two of its six kidney specialists, as well as by registered nurses, dietitians and social workers. 
 And unlike those kidney specialists elsewhere who often have a stake in the profits of dialysis, the Kaiser doctors cannot enrich themselves by cutting back on the amount of money spent on patient care. Instead, most are paid a salary of about $150,000 a year, far less than they might make under the profit-sharing or similar deals struck with the part-time doctors at other clinics.
"Here, you're not driven by how much money you can get from the patient," said Dr. Hock Yeoh, the medical director for the Kaiser unit. "You just do what is best for them."
Kaiser's Los Angeles clinic stands out as but one example of how dialysis could be done better in the United States, a country with an annual mortality rate for dialysis patients that is twice that of Japan and some European nations. With the American annual mortality rate above 23 percent, more than 40,000 of this country's 187,000 dialysis patients will be dead next year.
An investigation by The New York Times of the kidney dialysis business and its leading company, National Medical Care Inc., found an industry that has used equipment and procedures to cut costs and bolster profits often at the expense of patient health. National Medical Care denies that patient care is suffering and says it is committed to quality care.
Among the biggest problems identified by kidney patients, medical experts and Government officials are that patients are kept on the machines for too short a time, that equipment that some experts think should be disposed of is re-used, that companies at times fail to replace outdated machines, and that the duties of doctors and registered nurses have been shifted to employees with less training.
The industry also operates with few standards to assure quality care. And because many dialysis companies compensate their kidney specialists only by paying them a share of any profits, the doctors face a conflict between their own financial interests and providing the best care for their patients.
Some industry executives argue that such payment systems are necessary to hire the best doctors and improve quality. National Medical, which pioneered such profit-sharing arrangements, revised its payment system earlier this year, and now pays its doctors a fee. But that fee is based in part on the doctors' ability to hold down costs, thus creating the same potential conflict of interest.
Kaiser's clinic plays by different rules, with very different results. According to Government statistics, Kaiser patients are hospitalized for less than a third as many days annually as the average dialysis patient in this country. Compared with the average, patients at Kaiser are close to twice as likely to work or attend school full time -- a fact that has won the clinic awards from medical groups.
And, even though Kaiser treats a larger-than-average number of diabetics -- a group with a higher death rate among dialysis patients -- its annual mortality rate is 16 percent, almost a third below the national average for all patients. Indeed, if its percentage of diabetics was in line with the average in this country or overseas, Kaiser's death rates would probably be comparable to the best of rates in foreign countries, medical experts said.
Kaiser's unit departs from most American dialysis clinics in more than just the way it staffs its clinics and pays its doctors. Kaiser patients receive treatments longer than the national average -- and are given extra treatments if needed. Kaiser will not re-use blood lines, as National Medical and others do. In light of some reports of adverse reactions to the first use of new devices, it allows patients to choose whether to be treated with a new plastic kidney, known as a dialyzer, or with a used one that has been cleaned. And it uses some of the newest dialysis machines available, replacing them about every five years.
 
A Possible Model
Tying Payments To Overall Health
Some medical experts say programs like Kaiser's should be a model for efforts to improve the quality of dialysis care in the United States. The key, they say, is that unlike many of the companies providing dialysis, Kaiser has a financial stake in keeping dialysis patients from developing illnesses that lead to hospitalization. That is because Kaiser, as a health maintenance organization, is responsible for all of the medical bills of its members. So Kaiser spends more on care for its dialysis patients, recognizing that in the long run it will save money.
By contrast, companies like National Medical Care do not pay the bill if their dialysis patients end up in the hospital; Medicare and private insurers bear the cost of hospitalization, which accounts for about half the total cost of care for dialysis patients. So the dialysis companies, which are paid a fixed amount by the Government for each treatment and are allowed to keep every penny they do not spend on care, stand to profit if they cut costs, even if patient health suffers.
"The incentives are in the opposite direction from quality care," said Dr. Ramon Hannah, the doctor in charge of dialysis and transplants at Kaiser. "There is no incentive to do the best you can possibly do. All the incentives are doing what you can make the most money off of."
Take the re-use of dialysis equipment that some experts say should best be used only once. That may save money for National Medical Care, but it raises the bill for the taxpayer, experts said.
"The real cost of maintaining a dialysis patient on re-use is higher than it appears, because of the increased number of hospitalizations" that can result when patients get fevers or other side effects linked to re-used equipment, said Dr. Stanley Shaldon, a kidney expert who pioneered the concept of re-use but who now opposes the procedure. "But the providers are not bearing that cost."
To change the financial incentives, some medical experts support creation of a system in which companies that keep their patients healthy would make the most money.
Under such a system, the Government would pay a set amount each year to cover all the medical costs of a dialysis patient. It would cover everything from a patient's dialysis treatment to checkups to hospitalizations. Whatever was not spent, the companies could keep as profit. Providers would then have an incentive to improve their dialysis treatment, to lower their overall costs.
With this approach, known in the medical industry as capitation, or risk-sharing, the dialysis providers would in essence become health maintenance organizations, or would have to team up with an H.M.O.
Some experts suggest that such a system would lead the industry to focus on ways to improve care that have largely been ignored in the industry. "The H.M.O. structure is what should be done," said Dr. John De Palma, chief executive of Hemodialysis Inc., a dialysis provider. "It would lead to patients being instructed on diet and blood pressure. That hasn't happened in 20 years. Instead, the industry just slaps everybody on dialysis and screams about only getting enough money to earn a 25 percent return per year."
As with any health maintenance organization, there is still the danger that patients will be shortchanged in an effort to cut costs. In kidney care, a potential such problem could come from dialysis providers' being reluctant to hospitalize patients who need it. So the industry, possibly with Government involvement, would have to establish comprehensive standards of care that would be reviewed and enforced by the existing Federal system.
The effects of this kind of system are apparent at Kaiser in Southern California. To a degree, Kaiser, with its financial power and millions of members, can be seen as a proxy for the Government in terms of the effects it could have on pushing the dialysis industry toward quality.
In addition to running its own Los Angeles clinic, which treats about 160 people, Kaiser sends almost 1,900 other patients with kidney failure to other dialysis providers in Southern California. And in recent months Kaiser has declared that it will no longer stand for business as usual in the dialysis business.
In June Kaiser announced what dialysis providers said was the first comprehensive effort to establish broad-based standards to measure the quality of care. Those standards, which every dialysis company contracting with Kaiser would have to meet, are based on 450 objective indicators, from blood-pressure level to the amount of urea in patient's blood. The standards are by far the strictest in the industry, providers said. No comprehensive standards have been set by the Government.
While this program has been advanced by Kaiser in Southern California, it has not yet been adopted by its divisions elsewhere.
Dr. Hannah of Kaiser's Southern California division said that a number of university kidney specialists had reacted to the proposed standards with dismay, saying that they were impossible to meet. But at the same time, a number of doctors from dialysis companies have told him they will meet the standards, if Kaiser gives them a contract to serve its patients.
Such a system would almost surely affect the quality of the training and supervision of the dialysis staff, as well as lead to improved education about dialysis for kidney specialists, changes that are sorely needed in the industry, experts said.
 
The American Way
System Promotes Cutting Corners
Of course, increasing the amount the Government pays for dialysis treatments would also have a big effect, experts agree. The United States spends significantly less for each dialysis treatment than do other industrialized nations. Since the early 1970's, the Government, through the Medicare program, has paid 80 percent of a maximum cost it sets for the care of dialysis patients of all ages. But the amount the Government agrees to pay has fallen by more than 70 percent since 1973 (after adjusting for inflation), increasing the incentive to provide treatment as quickly and as cheaply as possible.
Given the budget-cutting pressure in Washington and the profits made by the dialysis industry at the current reimbursement rate, a rate increase is unlikely. But, even without the large-scale change represented by risk-sharing, medical experts say that improvements in quality can still be accomplished by manipulating reimbursement.
For example, by setting a maximum amount -- about $126 -- that it will pay for each treatment, the Government compensation system has created financial incentives to make each dialysis treatment as short as possible, despite growing evidence that longer treatments make patients healthier. Experts said dialysis clinics should be paid at least partly according to how much time each treatment lasts. Japan, which has the lowest mortality rate for dialysis patients in the industrialized world, already does that.
"The Japanese system of reimbursement is what we should be using in this country," said Allan R. Hull, a kidney specialist in Dallas who is the president of the National Kidney Foundation. "That provides the incentives to do what is right for the patient."
There is no better proof of the effect of changing Government reimbursement policies than the dialysis industry's experience with a drug called Epogen, better known as EPO. The medication, a genetically engineered hormone developed in 1989 by Amgen Inc., stimulates the production of red blood cells, helping to alleviate the anemia frequently found in dialysis patients.
When the drug first became available in August 1989, the Government paid a fixed amount for each EPO injection. At National Medical, as well as in the rest of the industry, doctors began using the drug, and saw sharp increases in the levelof red blood cells in patients. Despite the improvement, doctors did not try increasing the dosage given at each dialysis treatment.
Then, in December 1990, the Government changed the compensation policy for EPO, and began reimbursing dialysis clinics based on the amount of EPO they used, instead of the number of injections. Overnight, EPO usage jumped. As of early this year, the amount of EPO used in each treatment had more than doubled, and the patients' levels of red blood cells had significantly risen, albeit at a higher cost.
No one's medical judgment had changed. The doctors were simply reacting to financial incentive. Indeed, some critics contend that doctors may well be overusing EPO now, to make up for the low compensation rate paid for the rest of the dialysis treatment.
Among other changes being advocated, some patients say that dialysis clinics should be consistently required to routinely disclose their annual mortality rates, average days of hospitalization, and other statistical data so that patients can better decide where to go in communities that have competing clinics.
Experts agree that changes in the American system of dialysis are essential. They say that after almost a quarter of a century of Government influence over treatment, the mortality rates and poor health of patients demonstrate a need for an overhaul that will allow this life-saving treatment to finally meet its promise.
"Clearly, there has to be a better way and we have to try to find it," said Perry Ecksel, president of the National Kidney Patients Association, a group organized to improve the quality of care for dialysis patients. "After all, we're talking about people's lives."
 
Questions to Ask
Here are some questions that kid ney patients can ask to compare the quality of care at dialysis clinics:
 What is this clinic's annual standard mortality rate? How does it compare with regional and national averages?
 What is either the clinic's aver age kt/v or its average urea reduc tion ratio, as measured in its pa tients' blood? Those two ratios guage the amount of waste that has been removed from the blood by a dialysis treatment, and are indicators of quality of care. Kidney experts say that a kt/v number should be at least 1.2 and a urea reduction ratio should be at least 60 percent.
 What is the average length of each dialysis treatment? Longer is bet ter, studies show. The American average is about 10 hours a week.
 Does the clinic have full-time doctors? And is the doctors' pay unrelated to the clinic profits?
 What is the ratio of registered nurses to patients? Does the clinic provide dietitians and patient education?
 Does the clinic re-use blood lines? Can patients refuse re-used of dialyzers?
 
More information about dialysis and living with kidney disease is available from the National Kidney Foundation, (800) 622-9010, or the American Association of Kidney Patients, (800) 749-2257.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Backs Transfer Of State Jobs Out of City

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Other New York City politicians have blasted Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to move up to 500 state jobs out of the city, calling it "geographical patronage" at the City's expense. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he had no quarrel with the move, noting that it would save money for the state.
Asked about the plan at a City Hall news conference, the Mayor took the occasion to describe in detail the new cordiality between the two chief executives, who only last fall were at each other's throats. The Governor, Mr. Giuliani said, has surprised him by being eminently fair to New York City and the result has been an unusually cooperative relationship. 
 "The Mayor and the Governor have probably worked out the best relationship that a Mayor and a Governor have had in a long time," Mr. Giuliani said. "We have worked very well together, to help both the city and the state."
Yesterday's kind words by the Mayor marked the latest in a series of political favors the two men have done for each other in the year since Mr. Pataki's election, which Mr. Giuliani openly opposed. Though a lingering personal bitterness makes it unlikely they will ever star together in a buddy movie, their political philosophies and fiscal predicaments are so similar that they have found themselves, as if by accident, on the same side of issue after issue.
When the Mayor needed the Governor to veto a bill that would undermine the merger of the local police forces, the Governor was there. When he needed the Governor to broker an landmark agreement on the city's watershed that would save the city billions of dollars, the Governor was there. When he needed the Governor to support his plan to abolish the Board of Education, he got that, too.
Though the Mayor has not had as much currency to offer Mr. Pataki, he was only too happy yesterday to step out of the way of the jobs-transfer debate. The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, along with other state legislators and public employee unions from New York City, have pleaded with Mr. Giuliani to join them in fighting the transfer of jobs to the Binghamton area, a move they say is a payoff by the Governor to loyal Republican areas.
But Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that the Governor was well within his rights to make the move.
"It really is the kind of thing that you have to have the flexibility to do, if you run a state or run a city," the Mayor said. "I have to move jobs sometimes from one borough to another, because in fact you can save money, if it's more convenient and agencies are going to reorganize. And to pick on the Governor for this is not the best way to get the kind of help that the city needs."
Most of what the Mayor has provided the Governor has been the praise Mr. Pataki needs in a city that decisively supported his opponent, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Just 395 days ago, the Mayor stood on the steps of City Hall and said that if Mr. Pataki were elected governor, "ethics will be trashed" and the city would be hurt. There followed a brief period when the two men did not speak to each other, but recently the compliments have been unstinting.
"This is a Governor that has grown, I think, in office more than anyone I've seen in a short period of time," Mr. Giuliani said in October. "He understands what it means to be the governor of the entire state."
Yesterday, he went even further, saying he would have predicted a year ago that the Governor would have taken completely different stands on most major issues affecting the city.
"On the big issues, he came through for the city," the Mayor said. "And on the biggest issue of all, the watershed issue, he was able to step beyond the political situation he had been in before. So on balance I would say he's been very fair to the city of New York."
Mr. Pataki has been somewhat more muted in his compliments. Asked yesterday if the two men actually liked each other, Zenia Mucha, the Governor's spokeswoman, paused for a long few seconds before responding diplomatically.
"They have mutual respect for what each is trying to accomplish," she finally said. She went on to acknowledge that they have a good business relationship, agreeing with each other on the need to cut the size of government and stimulate the economy.
Their alliance, however, came as a crushing disappointment to the public employees union that represents many of the state workers who would be transferred upstate.
"Maybe he's been misinformed," said Denyce Duncan Lacy, a spokeswoman for the New York State Public Employees Federation. "Perhaps we can still find a way to change the Mayor's mind."

HEADLINE: Record Rally Continues in Blue-Chip Stocks

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks extended their record-setting rally to a third consecutive session yesterday. But the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index retreated from the high it set on Monday.
"We are in the middle of replacing leadership," said Louis Ehrenkrantz, president of Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum, a securities firm in New York. "This proves there is something called the law of gravity." 
 After soaring 52.39 points on Monday, the Dow Jones industrial average surged 37.93 points, to 5,177.45, marking its 67th record of 1995. For the second consecutive session, this important indicator advanced at one point more than 50 points, setting off the New York Stock Exchange's collar on computer-programmed trading for the 14th time this year. Such collars are meant to stabilize the stock market.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which increased 6.70 points on Monday, gained 4 points, to a record of 617.68. But the Nasdaq slipped 3.90 points, to 1,065.89.
Advances far outnumbered declines on the Big Board, 1,410 to 979. Trading rose to 437.4 million shares, from 406.8 million shares Monday and the most recent three-month daily average of 362 million shares.
The stock market rally has been bolstered in part by expectations that short-term interest rates will soon be lowered by the Federal Reserve. Those expectations held fast yesterday even as the bond market consolidated after a long run. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond tested the psychologically important level of 6 percent before inching back up to 6.04 percent, from 6.02 percent on Monday. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
A standout stock sector was drugs, which have been steadily gaining momentum in recent sessions. Eli Lilly increased 1, to 100 3/4; Johnson & Johnson rose 1 3/4, to 89 1/2, and SmithKline Beecham advanced 3/4, to 54 5/8.
Shares of Value Health rose 8.1 percent after the company announced that it would buy Medintell Systems, which sells a pharmacy data system, for $28 million in stock. Value Health rose 2 1/8, to 28 3/8.
Major oil companies were also strong players in yesterday's rally. Mobil closed at 109 1/2, up 1 1/2, and Exxon closed at 79 3/4, up 1 1/8.
Once again, Internet-related stocks surprised many analysts by maintaining their sharp ascent. Netscape, which went public on Aug. 9 at 28, spiked 21 1/2, to 171, and Spyglass added 4 3/4, to 114 1/2.
But some of the well-known names in the technology group slumped. Microsoft fell 1 7/8, to 86; Intel lost 3/8, to 61 3/8, and Acclaim Entertainment, which restated its earnings on the advice of its accountants, plunged 6 7/8, to 12 5/8.
Shares of Pixar, which jumped 77 percent on its first day of trading last week, dropped 5 3/4, to 28 1/2, after falling 6 on Monday. The company provided a three-dimensinal computer animation program for the hit motion picture "Toy Story," but some investors are concerned that its next film will not be released until 1998.
Bausch & Lomb declined 2 5/8, to 35 3/8. The company projected that its fourth-quarter profits would be below analysts' forecasts.
On the plus side, International Flavors and Fragrances, perceived as producing big earnings gains next year, rose 1 1/4, to 53 1/2. Hercules, which completed the sale of its electronics and printing division for $130 million, advanced 2, to 58 5/8. And General Motors class H stock, which represents its successful Hughes Electronics unit, increased 1 1/4, to 48 1/2.

HEADLINE: France's Pain

 BODY:
Like the Republican Congress in Washington, the French Government has proposed huge spending cuts to reduce the Federal deficit. Only Paris would accomplish its surgery over about two years, rather than the seven the Republicans plan.
Little wonder, then, that France's public employees have gone on strike, crippling Paris for almost two weeks by shutting down mass transit and reducing telephone and mail service. Yesterday at least 30,000 workers and their supporters marched through the city in an effort to force the Government to back down. 
 French citizens, who have tried to get on with business, are unhappy that the Government they elected to energize the economy and generate more jobs has adopted policies that in the near term are likely to produce just the opposite.
But the truth is that French voters brought fiscal austerity upon themselves when they decided in 1992 to drop the franc and adopt a single European currency by 1999. European Union rules stipulate that countries that adopt the single currency must bring their monetary and fiscal policies under tight control -- for example, reducing their deficits below 3 percent of gross domestic product by 1998. France's deficit is now above 5 percent.
Prime Minister Alain Juppe proposes to meet the deficit target by raising taxes, reducing France's high welfare benefits and lengthening the number of years public employees must work before becoming eligible for social security. Over the long term France would need to adopt such measures to control its deficit and to attack unemployment, which hovers around 11 percent.
America has no particular stake in how quickly France deals with its deficit, or even whether the franc survives. America's interest is a prosperous France and prosperous Europe, and the best way to assure that is to knock down trade and investment barriers, which the European Union is already doing. That does not require a single currency.
A common currency does have political appeal. France has long maintained that the best way to keep Germany tied to Western Europe is to imbed it in European institutions, including a European currency that would also replace the German mark. But a common currency also comes with a high price: lost control over monetary and fiscal policy that could otherwise be used to fend off recession.
The dislocation in France may give other countries pause about a common currency and the economic discipline that goes with it. The coalition governing Austria collapsed in October over disagreements about how to cut its deficit. Now President Jacques Chirac of France is under pressure to pull back and reconstitute his Government.
The architects of the European Union underestimated the pain of reaching their goal. But the troubles in France and renewed doubts about a single currency need not unravel the vision of a united Europe. The most important steps are already being taken, and can continue, whatever France and other nations ultimately conclude about their tolerance for the pain of one currency.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
France's Turmoil Center Stage, The Dollar Is Generally Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against leading European currencies yesterday as traders took profits while hoping for a resolution of the broad strikes hobbling France.
Traders lacked significant economic data or other reasons to push the dollar up against the German mark, especially given the reluctance to risk losing profits booked so far this year. The dollar also failed to benefit from a rally in the American stock markets. 
 The dollar meandered in Japanese yen trading, finishing slightly higher.
"In the absence of firm views, people are sitting on the sidelines," said John Rothfield, an international economist at the Chicago office of Nationsbanc-CRT. "You don't want to put on a bet at this time of the year."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 101.26 yen, up from 101.20 yen late Monday. It sold for 1.4338 German marks, down from 1.4390 marks.
Traders kept their attention on the situation in France, where 50,000 people took part in a demonstration in Paris calling for the resignation of Prime Minister Alain Juppe. Other demonstrations took place in Nimes, Lyons and several other big cities.
The strikers want to make sure that the Government does not abandon social spending programs in trimming France's $65 billion budget deficit. A reduced deficit is an important requirement for entry into the European monetary union planned by 1999.
France has been committed to a policy of keeping the franc strong, but it must do so while cutting the deficit or risk undermining plans for European economic unity.
The French commitment to the franc "is stretched to the limit," Mr. Rothfield said.
Still, the franc rebounded somewhat against the mark and the dollar yesterday when Mr. Juppe reaffirmed the Government's commitment to sweeping changes in the health and welfare system.
In New York trading, the mark fell to 3.4561 French francs, from 3.4724 francs on Monday. The dollar fell to 4.9545 French francs, from 4.9950 francs
In other trading, the dollar fell to 1.1664 Swiss francs from 1.1685. The British pound rose to $1.5430, from $1.5325.
"We continue to look for reasons to buy" the dollar, Mr. Rothfield said. "It's very dead, though."

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
The office building in lower Manhattan that housed Delmonico's changes hands for $3 million.

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein 

 BODY:
TIME EQUITIES INC. and a group of private investors have paid $3 million for the 1891 office building in lower Manhattan that was the home of Delmonico's, the restaurant credited with introducing haute cuisine to the United States in the mid-19th century.
The 12,500-square-foot, wood-paneled and elegantly decorated restaurant, at 48-56 Beaver Street, two blocks south of Wall Street at South William Street, is vacant. But Francis Greenburger, the chairman and chief executive of Time Equities, said he hoped to find a restaurateur willing to bring 21st-century cuisine to the once-fashionable 19th-century site, where Charles Dickens dined on such fare as agneau farci a la Walter Scott. 
 Mr. Greenburger said that with the downtown office market still weak -- the building is less than 50 percent occupied -- he planned to transform the office space into 39 residential rental units, at a cost of about $1.5 million. He credited Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Downtown Revitalization Plan, which is to provide tax abatements for converting underused office buildings into residential space, with laying the foundation for the conversion.
Previous owners had spent $6 million in the early 1980's to turn the building, with 62,000 square feet of space, into 30 luxury condominiums. But the residential condominium market turned soft and the apartments were rented as office space. At the same time, Delmonico's was recreated from turn-of-the-century photographs; that restaurant closed about three years ago.
Delmonico's was founded in 1827 by Swiss-born brothers, Peter and John Delmonico. After their original dining spot was destroyed by fire in 1835, they put up a four-story building at Beaver and South William. In 1891, that building was replaced by the current eight-story one, designed by James Brown Lord.
The Renaissance Revival building, of orange terra cotta and brick, is up for landmark designation, and a hearing is to be held Tuesday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. "It's a beautiful building," Mr. Greenburger said, "and it probably should be landmarked."
 
Brokerage Firm on Move
 Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, an investment bank and brokerage firm, has taken 100,000 square feet on four floors at 590 Madison Avenue, the I.B.M. Building at 57th Street.
The company plans to move in late spring from about 70,000 square feet on eight floors at 540 Madison. It will at first occupy the 33d, 34th and 35th floors, about 75,000 square feet, and will pick up the 32d floor gradually over the first 10 years of the 15-year lease, said Jeffrey Lichtenberg of the Edward S. Gordon Company, who handled the deal for Ladenburg. The lease is valued at more than $80 million. The Gordon company also represented the building.
Just below Ladenburg, Caspian Holdings Inc., a newly established investment banking and securities firm, has taken the 31st floor -- 24,300 square feet -- for its United States corporate headquarters. (It has also opened an office in London.) The 11-year lease is valued at more than $10 million. Bruce Mosler and Andy D. Simon of the Galbreath Company represented Caspian; Scott Gottlieb of Gordon represented the building.
 
City Agency Relocates
 The New York City Financial Information Services Agency, the office that processes checks and payrolls, has leased 130,000 square feet at 450 West 33d Street, between 9th and 10th Avenues.
The agency is moving from about 100,000 square feet at 111 Eighth Avenue, between 15th and 16th Streets. The 20-year deal is valued at more than $40 million. The move is expected by late spring.
Robert Alexander of the Edward S. Gordon Company, who with his colleague, Louis Buffalino, represented the agency, said it was attracted to the site in part because of its 16-foot ceilings and floors larger than 100,000 square feet.
Mr. Buffalino said the space, a former Citibank data center, had a raised floor with many of the systems the city needed already in place.
Richard Karson of Gordon, who with David Levinson represented the owner, the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, said that the 1.5 million-square-foot building was about 70 percent rented.
 
Fitness Center Expands
 The exercise boom continues. The American Fitness Center has leased its third Manhattan site, 22,000 square feet at 200 Madison Avenue, a 26-floor, 525,000-square-foot office building between 35th and 36th Streets. It is expected to open Feb. 1.
Russell Henis, the fitness center's president, said the lease was for 16 years with an average annual rent of $25 a square foot.
Faith Hope Consolo of Garrick-Aug Store Leasing, who handled the deal for the fitness center with her associate, Marc Leber, said the idea was to find a location near both offices and residences. "This space fit their needs by being near the Murray Hill area as well as several major office buildings," she said. The other two centers are at 128 Eighth Avenue and 131 East 31st Street. The 200 Madison Avenue building was represented by Peter Duncan and Matt Coudert of George Comfort & Sons.

HEADLINE: There Is No Blame for Budget Deficits

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Quoting selected experts, you say (news analysis, Dec. 3) that neither political party "has clean hands" on the issue of Federal budget deficits. This narrow view of history and public policy is misleading. 
 Deficits and increases in national debt have been chronic since the Great Depression of the 1930's, not merely recent decades. The national debt increased 600 percent during World War II, with annual deficits ranging from 20 percent to 31 percent of national output that finally ended the Depression. The deficits of the 1930's and recent decades are relatively trivial. For the past five decades, moreover, the United States was preoccupied with the cold war.
If the designated experts, members of Congress and the President believe that deficits are a major problem, let them condemn the victories of World War II and the cold war, the real impetus for deficits.
You might also ask them to explain why the budget-balancing and national debt reductions throughout the 1920's produced only economic disaster. In the cold light of history, and contrary to economic myth, there is no blame to assess, and no problem.
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Visiting Prof., Public Administration
George Washington University
Washington, Dec. 3, 1995

HEADLINE: Testifying to the Ravages of Granddad's War

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Twice the age and perhaps twice as wise as when she started writing fiction in the late 1960's, Pat Barker now understands why her first three books were never published. "I was writing things that I shouldn't have been trying to write," she recalled. "I was writing sensitive middle-class lady novels, and it's not what I am."
At the time, of course, she had good reason to believe she had joined the English middle classes. She had a degree in history and economics from the London School of Economics, she was married to a university professor, she was herself a teacher and she had given birth to the first of her two children. Her working-class roots had seemingly disappeared. 
 But a passing contact with the late English novelist Angela Carter nudged her back to her past. She should write about what she knew best, Ms. Carter told her, about the tough working women of northern industrial towns, about her upbringing by her grandparents, about her memories. It worked. "Union Street," a story about assembly-line women, was published in 1982 and three other novels followed.
Then, just as suddenly, Mrs. Barker switched her attention to World War I. With "Regeneration" (1991) and "The Eye in the Door" (1993), she was noticed in London's literary circles. Now "The Ghost Road," the acclaimed final novel in her World War I trilogy, has won her the Booker Prize, Britain's top literary award. It has just been published in the United States by Dutton.
But what, one might ask, was "an ordinary mum from up north," as the 52-year-old writer delights in describing herself, doing writing about British Army officers being treated for shell shock in the Great War? After all, born in 1943 in the northeastern industrial town of Thornby-on-Tees, she was too young to remember even World War II.
Memories, though, were again at work. She was the result of a wartime liaison and never knew her father, who, she was told, died in the war. When her mother married seven years later, young Pat remained with her grandparents. And in that home, it was World War I that mattered. Her grandfather had been a soldier and his war stories seemed all the more real because of a bayonet scar on his back that she was occasionally allowed to touch.
Decades later, through her husband, David, a professor of zoology at Durham University whose specialty is neuroanatomy, she learned about William H. R. Rivers, a psychologist who experimented with new neurological techniques for treating soldiers suffering breakdowns in the horrors of trench warfare in northern France. Armed with the emotional link to her grandfather and extensive research, Mrs. Barker then wrote "Regeneration," which focused on the relationship between Rivers and the writer Siegfried Sassoon, a patient at a hospital at Craiglockhart, near Edinburgh. Reinforcing the literary connection, the poet Wilfred Owen was also at Craiglockhart, although not under Rivers's care.
After "Regeneration," Mrs. Barker realized that her story was not over, that a trilogy would be necessary. In "The Eye in the Door," with the madness of the war again permeating the story, the focus turns to Sassoon and the author's own creation, Billy Prior, a bisexual officer of working-class extraction who is also a Rivers patient.
Finally, "The Ghost Road" becomes Prior's story as he prepares to return for his fourth stint in the trenches, with Rivers eager to know how he will react. Refusing the chance of staying home on medical grounds, Prior is himself no less curious about his own reactions. And he passes the new test of nerves.
Perhaps surprisingly, Prior's recovery from shell shock was not unusual. Using analysis, neurological surgery and electric shock treatment, Rivers and other doctors were often able to eliminate such common symptoms as mutism, paralysis and hysteria. "Most people were cured enough to do something of service to the war," Mrs. Barker noted. "In 1917, when Owen had his breakdown, 80 percent of shell-shock cases were dealt with within sound of gunfire and 80 percent were back in the line within 14 days."
Accompanying Prior's story, Mrs. Barker shows Rivers reliving memories of his prewar work among the headhunters of Melanesia in the Pacific. Based on Rivers's writings, these stories of ritual death and psychological enslavement to evil spirits in turn serve as mirrors of the physical carnage and mental devastation wrought by the set-piece battles of World War I.
Yet while at first sight "The Ghost Road" is an antiwar novel, in many ways it tells more about the dysfunctional nature of British society. And in that sense, Mrs. Barker's fascination with Prior is understandable. Like the author, who raises a rare northern working-class voice in a London-dominated literary world, Prior is an outsider. He is an officer who does not belong to the officer class; he is engaged to be married but is actively bisexual.
"He straddles every possible divide," Mrs. Barker said, sipping a gin and tonic in a Kensington hotel during a brief visit to London. "His chameleon qualities interest me. I think I was mainly interested in the core of identity. He returns to France with the expectation of dying, yet not with the intention of dying. I think even his form of sex is connected with his death. It is mechanized commercial sex in a mechanized commercial war."
Her book also makes clear that Prior chose to return to the front not out of any great sense of duty, but rather because of his aversion to a Britain in which he could find no place for himself. Once again, perhaps this parallels Mrs. Barker's own preference for her orderly life "up north" and her undisguised distaste for the glitter and media exposure of London's literary scene.
"I'm not interested in an international-author type role," she said. "What use are writers to other writers? Really. You can have a good moan about your royalties and your rotten publishers and all the rest of it. That's all they do. Writers talk about money to the exclusion of all other topics, including themselves."
Still, after "The Ghost Road" won the Booker Prize on Nov. 6, beating out novels by Salman Rushdie, Barry Unsworth, Tim Winton and Justin Cartwright, Mrs. Barker was thrust into the limelight. The prize and accompanying publicity also made her book a best seller in Britain. But she was keen to return to Durham, where, she said, her neighbors congratulated her and said "that was nice" and changed the subject, "which is what I would do if anything embarrassing happened to them."
Now her mind is on her next book, which will be set in a rundown housing project where wild young joy riders known as Twockers ("Taking Without the Owner's Consent") rule the night. "They do these marvelous hand-brake turns and, in the evening when they have finished, they burn the cars to destroy the forensic evidence," she said with delight. Evidently, behind her genteel exterior, the subversive in Mrs. Barker is stirring anew.

HEADLINE: PATAKI PROPOSING TO BREAK UP LILCO

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 5

 BODY:
Under a complex plan endorsed by Gov. George E. Pataki, a state utility board has proposed dismantling the Long Island Lighting Company to reduce electric rates by up to 12 percent. Financing would come from a $4.5 billion bond sale, the largest in the history of the municipal bond market.
The Republican Governor's unusual plan, which relies less on government than proposals made by Democrats have, calls for Lilco to sell its natural gas operations and its power plants to private companies. The state utility board, the Long Island Power Authority, would then take over Lilco's transmission lines and hire another company to operate them. 
 The Governor commissioned the plan three months ago in an effort to find financial relief for the 2.7 million residents of Long Island, who pay one of the highest utility rates in the nation, especially since Lilco shut the ill-fated $5 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant in 1989.
A 22-page memorandum describing the plan, however, leaves many critical questions unanswered, and it is unclear whether in the end this solution will be able to provide financial relief to residents of suburban Suffolk County, an important political constituency for the Governor.
Suffolk County now owes $80 million for property tax overpayments that Lilco made on the Shoreham plant, and pending lawsuits could push that figure as high as $500 million. The memorandum does not specify any mechanism for forgiving those payments -- unlike a Democratic plan that called for a state takeover of the company and the writing off of the debt. The report simply says that an "equitable" solution, like imposing a surcharge on Suffolk County residents, should be reached.
Mr. Pataki, who is to formally announce the proposal on Wednesday at a news conference at Adelphi University in Garden City, today described it as a "well-thought-out, detailed long-term plan that is going to provide for a double-digit reduction in utility rates in Long Island."
But even fellow Republicans seemed to respond cautiously. The Suffolk County Executive, Robert J.Gaffney, who had strongly supported the Democratic proposal for a government takeover, declined to comment today. And the chairman of Suffolk's Republican Party, John Powell, a close ally of the Governor's, said that while he was optimistic that the Governor would be able to fill in the details, he was concerned that the proposal fell short of meeting Suffolk taxpayers' needs.
"There has to be something or some mechanism that is built in for the protection of Suffolk County taxpayers," Mr. Powell said. "We should identify it before we approve this plan."
To win final approval, the plan needs the support of the Governor; the State Senate Majority Leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican, and the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, who expressed reservations today.
"The local tax issue seems to have been lost in all of this," Mr. Silver said, referring to the tax increase Suffolk would inevitably face if it must pay back the taxes to Lilco. "I think that is critical to the overall plan. There are people who are going to be forced to move if their property taxes rise to reflect the court judgment.
"I'm concerned that there's an attempt to make this proposal the conclusion," he said, adding, "I have a lot of questions."
An important difference between the new plan and another Democratic plan, one offered by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo during last year's election campaign, is how it reimburses shareholders. Mr. Cuomo's plan proposing to buy the company outright for $21.50 a share, or $5 more than the selling price at the time, was warmly greeted by Lilco executives and shareholders.
The plan endorsed by Mr. Pataki makes no offer for the stock. Instead, Lilco would be paid for its assets, such as its power plants and transmission lines, and would then have the option of liquidating itself and paying off stockholders at some unspecified future price. Lilco has made no comment on the new plan.
Lilco common stock closed at $16.50 today, down $1, as details of the report became known.
The memorandum describing the plan was based on the recommendations of Bear, Stearns and Company, which LIPA had hired as its consultant. The chairman of the board, James F. Gill, a Pataki appointee, declined comment today.
One of the unknowns of the new plan is how such a large bond sale would fare. The report notes that Bear Stearns expects a temporary adverse impact on the market for New York tax-exempt bonds because of the size of the offering. Such a large bond offering could drive up the interest rate that the Long Island Power Authority would have to pay to attract buyers.
But Duncan Smith, senior managing partner in charge of trade for Lebenthal and Company, said the market of individual investors, mutual funds and insurance companies would quickly absorb the bond issue.
"The market is starving for them," he said. "There is no question that the market is looking for bonds, and more than just $4.5 billion, I might add."
According to the authority report, the board would issue almost $4.5 billion in tax-exempt debt and assume about $2.25 billion in Lilco's outstanding tax-exempt debt for a total finance package of $6.75 billion.
"This is a big experiment," said Ashok Gupta, an energy economist for the Natural Resources Defense Counsel in New York. "What type of ratings are they going to get? And all this to get a 10 percent rate reduction? It may be politically important, but is this really how you want to spend $4 billion of state financing?"
Also left unanswered in the report was who would manage and operate the utility for the power authority. Two New York utilities, Brooklyn Union and Consolidated Edison, have submitted proposals to the authority in connection with the restructuring. Spokesmen for both companies declined to comment on their role today.
Proposals aimed at increasing competition are among other recommendations in the plan. For instance, Lilco would sell off its power plants in four or five "bundles" to separate companies while offering up its gas operations to a buyer that would not have anything to do with the electric system.
But some utility analysts said they feared that such a system could create small high-priced monopolies on Long Island, where the transmission system is so limited that some areas rely on one generator for power.
"I question how real competition can be on Long Island given the limited capacity of the transmission lines," said James Rothschild, a private consultant on utility financial issues who has advised consumer groups on Long Island. "Competitors who are really the only game in town can end up pressuring a company to pay higher rates than they do now."
Despite such concerns, the political capital from a Lilco restructuring is clearly worth the effort to Mr. Pataki.
As details of the report started to leak out this week, Mr. Gill, the board chairman, continued to insist that its main committee meeting on the issue should be closed to the public.
"I'm going to maintain all the confidentiality that I can," he said. "What's salvageable, I want to salvage."
Lilco, which lost a bitter, decades-long fight to open Shoreham, remains the object of ratepayers' scorn, and criticism of the company is an effective tool for local politicians in search of votes.
Last month, the power authority collected 31 proposals from independent power producers, investment banking firms, citizens groups and management consulting firms interested in participating in a Lilco takeover. Many of them had advised the authority to refinance the debt from Shoreham -- advice it followed in its report. But the authority was silent on suggestions from consumer groups to increase conservation and make the system more efficient.
Mr. Silver said he would like the authority to do a comparison study of the proposals instead of settling on one. "I would like to see an independent analysis and these other plans," he said. "The board received 31 responses, but no one has addressed them. I would like to see what's feasible."
Lilco serves about a million electric customers in Nassau and Suffolk counties and on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens. The electric service territory is 1,230 square miles. The company also provides natural gas to about 442,000 customers.


GRAPHIC: A board appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki has developed a plan to dismantle the Long Island Lighting Company. Here is a description of the proposal and its impact.
 
The Plan

Photo: "Logistics of Pataki's Proposal to Dismantle Lilco"
 The Long Island Power Authority would sell at least $4.5 billion in tax-exempt bonds to buy Lilco's transmission and distribution systems and assume the $4.5 billion debt for the defunct Shoreham nuclear power plant.
 Another energy company, possibly Consolidated Edison, would contract with the authority to manage the distribution of electricity to retail customers. Lilco's power plants would be sold to separate companies, which would sell power to the authority. In addition, Lilco would sell its gas business to another company, most likely Brooklyn Union.
 
The Impact on Rates
 The authority says rates would drop by at least 12 percent. But even with the reduction, Lilco rates would remain among the highest in the nation.
 
The Savings
 A large portion of the savings to ratepayers would come from refinancing the Shoreham debt with tax-exempt bonds at an interest rate substantially lower than what Lilco currently pays.
 In addition, revenue from the transmission and distribution system would be exempt from Federal income taxes because these systems would be owned by LIPA. And dividend payments to Lilco sharelolders and corporate profit-making would also be eliminated.
 The authority believes that competition between the new owner of Lilco's gas operations and the companies that buy the power plants would also produce savings.
 
Lilco's Future
 Lilco would be out of the utility business on Long Island and might be liquidated. Stockholders would be paid off from the money Lilco receives from the authority for the Shoreham debt and its distribution network, as well as the proceeds of the sale of Lilco's gas business and power plants.
 
Lilco's Employees
 Lilco's workers would go to work for the new owners of the generating plants or for the company that contracted to deliver electricity. Some executives and managers would probably lose their jobs.
 
The Hurdles
 The plan faces several formidable hurdles. First, if Lilco rejects the deal, the state would have to condemn the company.
 The plan also requires the approval of the State Public Authorities Control Board, whose three voting members represent Governor Pataki, the State Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, and State Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican. Each has veto power, and Democrats, who have criticized the way the plan was drafted, have hinted that Mr. Silver is prepared to block the plan if he finds it unsatisfactory.
 Also, Suffolk County would probably oppose any plan that failed to settle on favorable terms a major tax case involving assessments on the Shoreham nuclear power plant. Lilco is seeking more that $500 million in a current case and won $83 million in an earlier proceeding.
 
The Timetable
 Authority officials estimate the plan could be completed in one to two years, with 18 months the target. (pg. B7)

HEADLINE: PATAKI PLANNING A GRADUAL REPEAL OF A UTILITY TAX

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The Pataki administration and the Republican leader of the State Senate say they intend to push for the gradual repeal of a utility tax that brings the state almost $1 billion a year and adds several dollars a month to the average New Yorker's gas and electric bills, state officials said today.
The gross receipts tax, as it is called, has few if any supporters in the state. A 4.25 percent tax on utility companies' gross sales of power, which is passed along to customers, it is a regressive tax that hits poor New Yorkers especially hard, and large manufacturers say it adds tens of thousands of dollars to the cost of doing business in New York. 
 But the tax brings in about $950 million a year, so Democrats and some Republicans may fight its repeal in 1996 because they worry about the budget cuts that would be required to make up for the tax cut.
Administration officials said that Gov. George E. Pataki did not plan to include the utility tax cut in his budget proposal for the fiscal year beginning April 1, which he will introduce on Dec. 15. Mr. Pataki's aides said that he was concerned about closing a projected $4 billion shortfall next year, and they said it may be politically untenable for the Governor to support new tax cuts now.
But the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, Mr. Pataki's main legislative ally, said he would make eliminating the utility tax, along with several other business taxes, a priority in the coming budget talks. And the Governor's aides said Mr. Pataki could support cutting the utility tax in 1996 provided legislative leaders find savings to make it possible.
In any case, the administration says it definitely intends to push for the tax cut in 1997 if it is not enacted in 1996.
A spokeswoman for the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat of Manhattan who will be Mr. Pataki's main adversary in the budget negotiations, questioned whether it was realistic to propose tax cuts when the state was facing major fiscal problems.
"Every proposal will be judged as part of an overall economic package," said the spokeswoman, Patricia Lynch. "Does it create jobs? And is it affordable?"
Pataki administration officials said they planned to eliminate the tax gradually, phasing in the repeal over five to seven years.
"Whatever else happens, it is clear that New York's gross receipts tax on electric and gas corporations has got to go," said Michael H. Urbach, State Commissioner of Taxation, during a legislative hearing on Tuesday. "It is not a question of whether or if. It is a question of when and how."
Cutting taxes was one of Mr. Pataki's central campaign pledges, and it now seems clear that tax cuts will be a central part of the impending budget talks, which most officials here had already expected to be unusually contentious.
Senior state officials said the Governor had also discussed with legislative leaders the possibility of cutting two other taxes as part of next year's budget: the estate tax and a capital gains tax on real estate transactions of $1 million and more.
This comes as Mr. Pataki already faces a projected $4 billion shortfall for the fiscal year that begins in April 1996, even before accounting for any new tax cuts. He is expected to propose spending cuts nearly across the board to close the gap.
Even with that, there is broad bipartisan support for eventually eliminating the gross receipts tax because power companies pass it directly to their customers, increasing the state's already high utility costs for poor tenement dwellers and wealthy suburban homeowners alike. A person with a $100-a-month gas and electric bill now pays about $5 a month for the gross receipts tax.
The tax is particularly costly for large manufacturers who pay hundreds of thousands of dollars a month in power bills, and business leaders have long argued that high utility costs are a major reason behind the decline in manufacturing jobs in New York State.
But there is also support among Democrats who represent the urban poor for phasing out the tax. Like the sales tax, the gross receipts tax is passed on by utilities at the same rate to customers of all incomes. That means its impact is regressive: it takes a larger percentage of a low-income person's income than a wealthy person's income.
Advocates for the poor said, however, that the state could not possibly afford new tax cuts next year. Mr. Pataki is already planning to propose deep cuts in welfare and health care programs, and more tax cuts would require further reductions in those programs, they said.
Shelly Nortz, director of state policy for the Coalition for the Homeless, said Mr. Pataki's proposal to place a 60-day time limit on welfare for single adults would increase homelessness. Without more money for shelters, many of those newly homeless people will end up on the streets, she said.
"They enacted an incredibly irresponsible tax cut last year that positions us to have a huge deficit this year," she said, referring to an income tax cut passed earlier this year that will reduce state revenues by $2.2 billion in the 1996-97 fiscal year. "I can't fathom why they think it is prudent policy to add to that."
Aides to Mr. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer County, said he would push strongly in budget talks for gradually reducing the estate tax and eliminating the real estate capital gains tax.
The real estate tax is a 10 percent tax on profits from sales of $1 million or more in real estate. A person who buys a building for $1 million and sells it for a $500,000 profit pays a state tax of $50,000. The tax, which raises nearly $100 million a year, is not imposed on transactions involving the seller's personal residence.
The tax was created in 1983 under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to help close a budget shortfall and has been derisively known as the Cuomo tax ever since. Opposition to it has been led by Manhattan real estate developers who contend it has worsened an already bad real estate market.
Under another proposal supported by Senate Republicans for reducing the estate tax, the state would also raise the minimum level at which it begins imposing inheritance taxes, to $600,000 from $250,000. Now, the inheritors of an estate worth $600,000 pay at least $12,000 in state taxes, state officials said. But under the Republican proposal, they would pay nothing.
