HEADLINE: Stocks Reach Record, With Dow Near 5,200

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks continued to set records yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average coming within a fraction of finishing above the 5,200 level during a seesaw session.
With blue chips gaining for the fourth straight trading day, the Dow jumped 21.68 points, to 5,199.13, after crossing 5,200 during the day, notching its 68th record close of the year. It first topped 5,100 on Nov. 29, just eight days after it passed the 5,000 mark. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also achieved a new high, rising 2.50 points, to 620.18. But the Nasdaq composite index, laden with computer-related issues, fell for the second straight day, losing 4.16 points to close at 1,061.73.
"The high-yielding stocks are continuing to outperform the market," said John Hammerschmidt, a partner of Turner Investment Partners in Philadelphia. "People are continuing to move into companies with international exposure."
Mr. Hammerschmidt added that yesterday's stock market followed the bond market, which closed on the up side, although well below its high for the day. The price of the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond rose 5/32 , sending its yield down to 6.03 percent, from 6.04 percent on Tuesday. It had briefly dipped below 6 percent for the third day in a row.
Analysts noted that market movement was affected by the release of a Commerce Department report for October that construction spending increased a higher-than-expected 2.7 percent, the biggest increase in more than three years. However, Bruce Steinberg, manager of macroeconomics at Merrill Lynch, said that recent housing and retail sales data pointed "to a slowdown in the consumer sector, due to weak job and income growth and heavy consumer debt burdens."
Advancing issues exceeded declines on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,277 to 1,098. Big Board volume dropped to 418.8 million shares, from 437.4 million shares Tuesday.
Nondurable stocks, defensive issues that usually do well in a favorable interest-rate environment, were strong yesterday. Philip Morris increased 1 1/8, to 90 7/8; Coca-Cola rose 2, to 79 3/8, and Procter & Gamble advanced 1 1/4, to 88.
Some energy stocks benefited from favorable crude oil prices. Exxon closed at 80 1/2, up 3/4, and Royal Dutch rose 1, to 131 3/4.
The drug group once more showed that large-capitalization growth stocks with international exposure were attractive to traders. Johnson & Johnson gained 1 1/4, to 90 3/4; Eli Lilly added 2 1/4, to 103, and Abbott Laboratories was up 1 3/8, to 41 3/4.
Microsoft, which plans to discuss its Internet strategy today, climbed 4 5/8, to 90 5/8. And Gucci, which forecast record sales in 1995, surged 1 5/8, to 38 1/2.
However, a number of network service stocks moved lower on profit taking. Cisco dropped 25/16 , to 7913/16 ; Bay Networks fell 3 1/4, to 43, and Cabletron Systems declined 1 7/8, to 77 5/8.
The Dow Jones transportation index slipped 5.50 points, to 2,086.61, with railroad issues participating in the slump. Union Pacific closed at 68, down 1/4, and CSX closed at 87 1/4, down 3/4.

HEADLINE: Such a Doable Deal

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
In private, when they are not wailing about Republican cheeseparing or molar-gnashing about Democratic profligacy, some of the parties to the balanced-budget talks on Capitol Hill will concede a secret: If they really tried, they might quickly cut a deal on Federal spending.
So far, they have not really tried. A lot of evidence now suggests that this may be the week in which they finally start. 
 Nobody in Congress underestimates the difficulty of bridging a chasm between Democratic and Republican bargainers that is not only $500 billion wide but as deep as political ideology can run. Still, politics is the art of compromise, and budget experts on both sides already see the elements of a seven-year deal to erase the deficit so clearly that they can almost trace them in the air.
These elements include acceptance by President Clinton of considerably greater savings from Medicare and Medicaid than he currently calls for, and Republicans' acquiescence to a smaller tax cut, less military spending and slightly more money for welfare, education and the environment than they now want.
Throw in a rosier economic forecast and a shrunken inflation factor for Government programs and tax brackets, both of which already appear likely, and voila: The Government is in fiscal balance by 2002.
That this or some other deal has not already occurred is a tribute to politics and ideology, the two forces that drive Federal policy and have worked so far against compromise. Democrats do not just believe fiercely in the programs Republicans seek to restrain; they have had one of their rare field days by asserting that the Republican budget would force old people from their sickbeds and starving children into the gutters.
For their part, Republicans not only have anointed smaller and stingier Government as political gospel, but have tried to wield it to wipe out six decades of Democratic social philosophy.
Common sense says those political and ideological forces will only flow more powerfully as election campaigns heat up and candidates in both parties are forced to calcify their stands on the issues.
But curiously, both currents may have begun shifting in favor of an accord. The first indication came on Tuesday, when the White House decided to propose a seven-year budget like the one Republicans have touted for weeks. By doing so, the Administration scored political points, negating the Republican leadership's main argument against serious bargaining -- that Democrats had no specific ideas.
More important, a Democratic seven-year budget should speed negotiations by offering the first chance for a side-by-side comparison of the two parties' fiscal plans and beliefs.
The second indication of a shift surfaced today, when President Clinton vetoed the reconciliation bill, with its restraints on Medicare and other entitlement programs, that is the Republicans' main budget-balancing vehicle. A veto was no shock; it has been a certainty for months. But as an expression of politics and ideology, it was positively cathartic -- a sort of marker that the President has now laid down, clearing the way for serious dickering to begin.
"Now we've not only said what we're not for," said Senator John Breaux of Louisiana, a member of the Democratic leadership, "but tomorrow or Friday, we'll say what we are for."
Speaker Newt Gingrich raised a third factor on Tuesday when he told a roomful of doctors in a speech that failure to reach a deficit-cutting agreement would touch off a stock market crash and reignite inflation. Market experts say Mr. Gingrich exaggerates; one leading analyst suggested today that a collapse of negotiations would cause a "correction" in the high-flying stock market and raise bond rates by about a half of a percentage point.
But from a political angle, Mr. Gingrich was on the mark. Mr. Clinton's re-election hopes rest in no small part on a healthy economy and low inflation. With signs of a slowdown emerging, the Administration's impetus will be to avoid dragging the economy down any further.
For their part, Republicans have always believed they would gain politically by pressing for a seven-year budget accord. They have succeeded beyond most outsiders' wildest predictions, so far, by taking a hard line against Democrats and moderates on virtually every spending issue.
But that, too, may be changing as the White House's assault on the Republicans' Medicare and welfare proposals has begun to bite. Both Republican legislators and Mr. Gingrich, their ideological leader, would now benefit from a bipartisan agreement that spreads the blame for spending cuts.
Even the 73 Republican freshmen in the House, who rode into office on promises to cut without political favor, face re-election with a choice of delivering a balanced budget or blocking an agreement for reasons of ideological purity.
All these shifts augur well for successful deficit talks, but they hardly guarantee them. Mr. Clinton's new budget would reduce projected spending on Medicare by $124 billion over seven years, and although a direct comparison is difficult now, it is by any measure far from the $270 billion that Republicans want.
Moreover, Mr. Clinton takes a different fiscal course: Much of his savings comes from pinching payments to medical providers, while Republicans would get a healthy chunk of theirs by raising Medicare premiums and placing a cap on annual spending.
The two sides have a deep and fundamental disagreement over how to run the Medicaid program, which is now a Federal entitlement extended to anyone who meets the income and eligibility guidelines. Mr. Clinton would keep it that way. Republicans want to abolish the entitlement and turn the program over to the states with a lump sum of money to spend as they wish.
The White House and the Republican Congress are divided almost as much over taxes. Mr. Clinton and Congressional Democrats would direct about $100 billion in tax relief over seven years to middle-class families. Republicans are adamant in demanding a capital-gains tax cut as well.
Republicans in the House will be loath to give up any military spending. The two sides are probably not far apart on welfare spending, and money for education, job training and the environment are small potatoes as Federal programs go. But they are huge ideological issues with conservatives, who see them as part of a Democratic legacy that must be cut out of Government root and branch.
All the dealmaking must be done more or less at once, for the sake of comity, so that everyone at the bargaining table can see that everyone else is suffering, too. An agreement demands that both sides be able to declare victory, no easy matter in a winter when they all are girding for an electoral battle to the death in 1996.
Yet now that the two sides have engaged, like wrestlers in a ring, they may actually work it out. They may have no choice, for to admit defeat now could lead to a worse political fate than making a less-than-perfect deal.
"If they don't have a substantial progress on a package by Christmas, I think it'd be hard to get one together," said Robert Reischauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office and the capital's most respected budget analyst.
But he added: "I don't see how they get out of this set of negotiations without some agreement. The only way either the White House or the Republicans can get out is to force the other side to walk away, or blow themselves up."

HEADLINE: Gingrich Made an Issue in a California Race

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 6

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich is not running for Congress from a district here in the high-tech Silicon Valley. It just looks that way.
Democrats are so determined to make the Speaker an issue in the special election here on Tuesday that they feature him far more prominently in a torrent of campaign commercials than even their own candidate. (His name, for the record, is Jerry Estruth). 
 Eager to tar the Republican candidate, Tom Campbell, as a Gingrich clone, Democrats conveniently overlook the fact that Mr. Campbell is a centrist who balks at the Speaker's social agenda. In fact, when Mr. Gingrich appeared in San Jose recently for a Republican fund-raising event, Mr. Campbell stayed away.
No matter how tenuous it may be, Democrats have found that highlighting a Gingrich-Campbell connection has helped Mr. Estruth attract the donations and the attention to mount a competitive race and chip into the once-intimidating lead of Mr. Campbell, a state Senator and a law professor at Stanford University. The race is to fill the seat of Representative Norman Y. Mineta, a Democrat who resigned in September.
Win or lose, Democratic Party officials say the race here is a warm-up for a nationwide campaign to transform House contests next year into a referendum on one issue -- or one man. Some Democrats are counting on Mr. Gingrich as their best hope in the uphill battle to regain to control of the House next year.
Representative Martin Frost of Texas, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said his party had never had a better villain. "We had a group of challengers in for a seminar," Mr. Frost said, "and I told them I have one piece of advice: their opponents' middle name is Gingrich."
Mr. Frost's coaching is certainly evident here. At campaign events, Mr. Estruth, a 52-year-old stockbroker, rarely mentions Mr. Campbell as he opens with this mantra: "Do you want to continue what Newt Gingrich has been doing in Congress? Or do you want to say 'no' to Newt Gingrich's agenda?"
With his sinking poll numbers, Mr. Gingrich is a far juicer target than a previous Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, was in 1978, when the Republicans pushed the slogan "Repeal O'Neill" and tried with little success to transform House races into a referendum on the Speaker's liberal policies.
But even Democrats acknowledge that California's 15th District -- a Democratic-leaning area that sometimes tilts to Republicans and includes southern San Jose and sections of the prosperous, fast-growing Santa Clara and Santa Cruz Counties -- has become the test case for no other reason than that there is no other race.
When Mr. Mineta, a 21-year incumbent, unexpectedly announced that he was resigning to work for a military contractor, the seat looked like a sure bet for Mr. Campbell. He is a former two-term House member who gave up his seat in 1992 for an unsuccessful run in the primary for United States Senate. Mr. Campbell is still a familiar figure in this district, having been elected to the State Senate in 1993.
And Democratic leaders in the district were unable to persuade their first choice, Mayor Susan Hammer of San Jose, to make the race. They settled on Mr. Estruth, a former San Jose Councilman who tells of his ancestors who came to California "in a covered wagon in 1864."
He, like Mr. Campbell, describes himself as a fiscal conservative who is progressive on social issues. Unlike Mr. Campbell, who has a confident command of the issues, Mr. Estruth relies heavily on notes in campaign appearances. "I haven't run for office after office to bring myself up to speed on these issues," Mr. Estruth conceded in a debate on Tuesday night.
But with Mr. Gingrich as their target, Democrats have dispatched heavy hitters like Vice President Al Gore here to campaign, and have pumped money into the race -- all to the consternation of Mr. Campbell.
"I'm about the last Republican in California that would fit a right-wing label," Mr. Campbell, 43, said in an interview. "It's absurd. They chose the wrong target." Hopping off a stool at the close of one debate this week, he asserted, "I've got the right to be judged on my own merits."
Though he supports many of Mr. Gingrich's economic proposals, Mr. Campbell sounds closer to President Clinton -- or even to the left of him -- on most social issues: Mr. Campbell favors abortion rights and homosexual rights. He opposes school-sponsored prayer. He favors gun control and more money for the environment. He says he is the only California Republican to oppose the state's initiative to curtail services to immigrants.
"This guy is not Atilla the Hun," said Jay Marlin, Mr. Estruth's spokesman. "We'd rather run against a more conservative candidate. So if it's Jerry vs. Newt, we have a much greater chance of winning than if it's Jerry vs. Tom Campbell."
To that end, Mr. Estruth seizes on the fact that when Mr. Campbell as in the House, he backed Mr. Gingrich in his successful race for the No. 2 Republican post in 1989, which put him on the path to Speaker. And he asserts that Mr. Campbell voted with Mr. Gingrich 76 percent of the time in his second term in Congress.
Mr. Campbell insists that he would not be beholden to Mr. Gingrich, and that he would vote for "a more moderate" challenger to the Speaker if one ever took him on.
Charles F. Rund, a Republican pollster in San Francisco, said that while he expected the better-financed Mr. Campbell to prevail, Democrats could take heart because "Campbell should have won this thing in a slam dunk."
But Mr. Rund said he was concerned that making the race a national example would be damaging to both sides. "The political parties jumped into this race and they're not talking issues and they're not talking personalities," he said. "They're talking institution vs. institution. And the public is saying, 'Enough!' "
As gleeful as Democrats are that they are waging a vigorous race, Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, general chairman of the Democratic Party, cautions his colleagues not to rely too heavily on Mr. Gingrich.
"Using Newt as your lunch ticket for '96 would be a huge mistake," he said. "You've got to have more going for you than that. But what he's done is open up a door. For that, I owe him an eternal debt of gratitude."

HEADLINE: Growth Predictions Cut for Big Industrial Nations

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
These are nail-biting times for the Group of Seven major industrial powers as they watch their economies weaken under the double impact of faltering consumer confidence and self-imposed campaigns to curb their budget deficits.
When they last met in early October, Group of Seven finance ministers publicly congratulated themselves on the "improved outlook" for the world economy. 
 But even then, many private forecasters felt that outlook was starry-eyed. And since then, fresh evidence of weakness in the Group of Seven economies has led some economists to weigh in with even lower projections.
The latest to do so is Salomon Brothers, the New York investment bank, which yesterday issued the results of its annual year-end crystal gazing.
For the Group of Seven countries as a whole, Salomon foresees unchanged low growth at 2.2 percent this year and next with a slowdown in the United States and Europe offset by a speedup in Japan.
Over all, Salomon describes 1996 as a year of "moderate growth." But the chief economist, John Lipsky, cautions that "all the risks are on the downside."
The Japanese economy is forecast to grow by 2.1 percent next year thanks to the latest stimulus package and a weaker currency. The economy is expected to grow only a tenth of a percent this year.
Salomon sees growth slowing in the United States from 2.5 percent this year to 2.1 percent next year, a less pronounced fall than the International Monetary Fund predicted in October when it said growth would slow from 2.9 percent to 2 percent.
German growth is forecast to slip from 2.2 percent in 1995 to 2.1 percent next year although the I.M.F. had foreseen an acceleration to 2.9 percent from 2.6 percent. Similarly, Salomon thinks growth in Britain will decline to 2 percent from 2.6 percent instead of speeding up, as the I.M.F. predicted, to 2.9 percent from 2.7 percent.
France's growth rate is seen by Salomon as dropping to 2 percent from 2.7 percent, a steeper fall than the I.M.F.'s forecast of a decline to 2.7 percent from 2.9 percent. Italian growth is expected to decelerate to 2.6 percent from 3.2 percent, although the I.M.F. predicted a smaller fall, to 2.8 percent from 3 percent. And while Salomon says growth in Canada will pick up to 2.4 percent from 2.3 percent , the I.M.F. thought it would rise more steeply, to 2.7 percent from 2.2 percent.
This Group of Seven forecast assumes a steady easing in monetary policy on both sides of the Atlantic next year, with the Federal Reserve lowering its key short-term interest rate to 4.5 from 4.75 percent by mid-1996, while the Bundesbank lowers German rates.
Growth in the United States hit an annual rate of 4.1 percent in the third quarter. But subsequent developments have been mixed, including a drop of five-tenths of a percent in the index of leading economic indicators for October, which was reported yesterday.
This week, the investment firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which is owned by the Equitable Companies, predicted American growth would slow to a mere 1.3 percent next year and drop under 1 percent in the final quarter.
And problems in Europe, especially the current strikes in France and the possibility that the move toward a single currency by 1999 could falter, may hurt growth.
J. Paul Horne, Smith Barney's Paris-based economist, predicts that the current strikes and stoppages will produce a contraction of 1.3 percent in the French economy in the final quarter of this year.
In October, Germany's six leading economic institutes forecast a slowdown in German growth to 2 percent next year. And September industrial output was 2.9 percent below the level of a year earlier. British third-quarter growth was the slowest for two years.
This midyear slowdown throughout much of the industrial world partly reflects a buildup in unsold inventories reflecting over-ordering during last year's unexpectedly strong recovery. As inventories reach normal levels, merchants should start ordering again and activity will pick up.
But another factor is the generalized attack on budget deficits, with the United States committed to balancing the Federal budget in seven years, while European countries squeeze their deficits to meet criteria for monetary union.
As Mr. Lipsky says: "The good news takes time to work through. In the short run, deficit cutting depresses activity."

HEADLINE: Panel Urges Shift of Focus For School Science Courses

 BODY:
Rather than memorizing the nomenclature of plant families, the anatomy of a frog or the periodic table, long staples of school science courses, students should learn to investigate and question the workings of the natural world, a national panel of teachers and scientists recommends.
Their report, a set of guidelines known as the National Science Standards, is the latest in a series of recommendations for 11 disciplines, including history, mathematics and social studies. Most have been announced; two others, English and economics are still being written. 
 Scientists and educators have long believed that the schools have failed to teach adequately even the most basic scientific concepts and have not done enough to make science an appealing subject.
"We've managed to turn people off of science by making it some kind of rote learning exercise," said Bruce M. Alberts, chairman of the National Research Council, which coordinated the study, and president of its scientific arm, the National Academy of Sciences. "What we're talking about here would be a revolution in science education."
The guidelines, developed over the last three years teachers, scientists and school administrators, say that fourth-grade students should have a basic understanding of the properties of objects and materials, life cycles of organisms, objects in the sky and the use of science and technology in solving simple problems. By eighth grade, students should be able to model scientific inquiry and understand motions and forces, reproduction and heredity, the Earth's history and the history of science. By 12th grade, their understanding should include chemical reactions, natural resources and the nature of scientific knowledge.
Many of the same themes already appear in science curriculums being developed in about half the states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, with a greater focus on the bigger ideas of science: energy, evolution, stability, change and equilibrium.
"We were doing a darn good job of training highly skilled specialists," said Eugenie C. Scott, executive director of the National Center for Science Education in El Cerrito, Calif. "But there were quite a series of sieves we would put people through to get that highly trained elite. And in the process, we lost most of the American public."
While the dense, 250-page document, released yesterday, offers state and local educators more philosophy than prescription, it calls for specific changes like making science a "core" course that students would take every year, starting in kindergarten, and providing all teachers with science training.
While many science teachers said they welcomed the national standards, some were doubtful that states and local districts would have the resources to implement many of the recommendations. For instance, the standards call for extensive teacher training and "more space and time" for classroom exercises.
"It's not good enough to tell people you have to do this," said Carole Greene, who heads the biology department at the Bronx High School of Science in New York. "You have to give them tools. It's not necessarily even the materials because clever teachers know how to keep things cheap. But the labs are extremely crowded and when you've got 34 kids in a 40-minute class, not everyone is going to have the opportunity to investigate and inquire."

HEADLINE: Labor Chief Asks Business For a New 'Social Compact'

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new president, called yesterday for a new "social compact" between America's corporations and workers, saying he and the labor movement might forgo their rhetoric of confrontation if business adopted what he called a less greedy, more respectful attitude toward the people it employs.
In what was billed as a major speech, Mr. Sweeney told 400 New York business executives and civic leaders that companies were undermining the nation's prosperity by holding down wages and slashing their work forces at a time of record profits. 
 "I want to build bridges between labor and management, so that American business can be more successful and American workers can share in the gains," he said.
But while holding out an olive branch with one hand, Mr. Sweeney did a little table-pounding with the other, voicing the labor movement's frustration, even anger, with low wage increases.
"Our problem is stagnant wages -- America needs a raise," he said. "We are going to take the fight to greedy employers who have been picking our pocket."
Mr. Sweeney, speaking at the New York Hilton to the Association for a Better New York, a business-led civic group, said many American companies seemed to have dropped the practice of "raising the standards of living for working Americans, not just accumulating enormous wealth for a fortunate few."
Referring to a sit-in that low-paid janitors held on a bridge in Washington in September, he said workers were so frustrated about low wages that many felt like blocking bridges rather than building them.
Mr. Sweeney, who had been president of the Service Employees International Union, was elected president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in October, after spearheading a drive to replace the federation's longtime president, Lane Kirkland, whom dissidents accused of doing far too little to invigorate a languishing labor movement.
Mr. Sweeney's aides say that between now and the 1996 elections, he will focus his energies and speeches on attacking the growing wage gap between the rich and the rest of the country, and on pushing government, business and unions to do more to reduce that gap.
The federation's officials say Mr. Sweeney's strategy of focusing on the wage gap has several goals: to heighten pressure on companies to be more generous in wage settlements, to cause more Americans to warm up to the labor movement and to throw laissez-faire Republicans on the defensive. At the same time, these officials privately fault President Clinton, saying he has not done nearly enough to reduce wage inequities.
"Since 1979," Mr. Sweeney said in his speech, "all of the income growth in our country has gone to the top 40 percent of households, and nearly all of that went to the top 20 percent. Well, that isn't the way America built the world's largest middle class and the world's strongest economy."
Mr. Sweeney said raising wages had become the leading political and economic issue in the country, and he predicted that next year's elections would revolve around who could offer the best ideas for creating jobs and increasing incomes.
Playing on an unofficial motto of Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign, "It's the economy, stupid," Mr. Sweeney said, "Look for smart candidates and their campaigns to hang signs in their headquarters with this slogan: 'It's wages, stupid.' "
After citing a social compact articulated by President John F. Kennedy -- "A rising tide lifts all boats" -- Mr. Sweeney noted that when Chase Manhattan and Chemical Bank earlier this year announced a merger that would reduce their combined work force by 12,000, the price of their stock rose.
"Does a rising tide now sink most ships, except for the luxury yachts?" he said.
Mr. Sweeney said it was unfortunate that American business no longer followed Henry Ford's practice of paying his workers enough so that they could afford to buy the cars they built. He said car prices had risen 70 percent in the last decade, while family incomes had risen 40 percent.
"Labor's victories can be yours too," he told the business executives. "With decent paychecks, we can buy your products and services."

HEADLINE: Court Expands Its Monitoring Of the Trash-Hauling Industry

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
In the latest move to rid Long Island's garbage-hauling business of Mafia control, Federal prosecutors said yesterday that six companies with a "healthy share of the market" will come under Federal Court oversight, joining eight companies already under such supervision.
The prosecutors and a court-appointed monitor said the growing court supervision of the business on Long Island had resulted in increased competition among hauling companies in Nassau and Suffolk counties and sharp drops in the cost of commercial-trash collection. 
 In one case they cited, a Seaford diner is now paying one-third what it previously paid to have its garbage carted away. In other instances, they said, carting companies have offered prices that are half what the customer previously paid.
The addition of the six companies to the year-and-a-half-old monitoring program is the latest effort by the authorities to curb mob domination of the private garbage-hauling business in the New York region.
Last week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced plans to create a commission that would regulate and license carting companies in New York City and would have the authority to audit their records, set maximum fees and investigate and fingerprint their executives and employees. Last summer, a state grand jury brought racketeering and other charges against some of the largest garbage haulers in the city, accusing them of using violence to enforce a noncompetitive system.
In the city, private companies pick up garbage at commercial sites while the Department of Sanitation collects residential trash. On Long Island, private companies may pick up residential or commercial trash, depending on the municipality.
The Rand Corporation has estimated that the mob-enforced, competition-stifling system of allocating customers on Long Island, which the court monitoring is intended to curtail, caused businesses to pay 50 percent more for commercial collections, and residential customers 15 percent more, than they would under a competitive system.
The monitor for the Island, Michael G. Cherkasky, was appointed by Judge I. Leo Glasser of Federal District Court in Brooklyn as an outgrowth of a civil suit that Federal prosecutors brought against more than 40 companies hauling trash on Long Island. Litigation is pending to bring more than 25 additional companies under the monitoring.
Zachary W. Carter, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, identified the six companies added to the program as MCM Sanitation, Enviro Carting, Enviro Recycling, Golden Eagle Disposals, Vinnie Monte's Waste Systems and VAM Management.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Justifying Government rules and dumping the dumb ones.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
EASING Washington's regulatory burden is high on the agenda of the Republicans who control Congress. While big changes are not likely to occur until after the 1996 elections, once-settled issues ranging from the preservation of endangered species to tough inspection standards for cars are bound to receive a serious second look. And when they do, those who dare to complicate the debate with facts will have some sobering research by Robert Hahn to draw on.
In an analysis to be published next year by Oxford University Press, Mr. Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, looks closely at 92 health, safety and environmental rules issued by five Federal agencies since 1990. Only 17 of them, he finds, can be justified in the sense that the measurable benefits exceed the costs. 
 The catch, readily acknowledged by Mr. Hahn, a former official in the Bush Administration, is that it is easier to criticize the system than to fix it. Nobody has a sure-fire formula for sparing the cost-effective regulations while dumping the ones that in Mr. Hahn's words are "as dumb as stone." Nor, for that matter, is it clear that those in power really want to contain the excess: Congress has often been content to promise all things to all people, and leave it to the bureaucrats to sort out the mess.
Most Federal agencies are required to conduct "regulatory impact analyses" before issuing new rules. And while these analyses come in assorted shapes and flavors, virtually all provide enough information to compare estimated costs with benefits.
Mr. Hahn applied common methodology to the data behind five years' worth of rules from five agencies to assay their cost-efficiency. Some easily passed the test. For example, the Consumer Product Safety Commission's 1993 standard for child-resistant cigarette lighters is estimated to save lives for less than $1 million each.
But most were of dubious value. A 1990 standard set by the Environmental Protection Agency for handling benzene wastes will cost an estimated $299 million for each life saved. That is 60 times the $5 million a life that research suggests Americans are willing to pay for increased safety.
It is easy to nit-pick Mr. Hahn's conclusions: different assumptions would produce somewhat different results. And it is a bit gruesome to make the philosophical leap required to translate injury and death into finite dollar values. But there is no escaping the choice. And it is undeniable that by the Government's own numbers the cost of most new health and safety regulations far exceeds the benefits.
What's more, there is good reason to believe that Federal agencies generally inflate benefits and deflate costs. Government figures suggested that the clean air amendments of 1990 -- after taking both sides of the equation into account -- would provide a net benefit to society to the tune of $50 billion or so. But an independent assessment by Paul R. Portney, an economist at the non-partisan Resources for the Future in Washington, estimated that they would end up costing roughly $10 billion to $20 billion.
The Senate majority leader (and Presidential hopeful), Bob Dole, proposes to bring rationality to the process by requiring every major rule to pass a cost-benefit test. George Eads, an economist at Charles Rivers Associates who advised President Jimmy Carter on regulation, argues the agencies could often defeat the intent by fudging the numbers. But he says he suspects that the elaborate procedures specified in the Dole bill would "throw sand in the wheels," effectively blocking controversial new regulations for years.
This might be justified on purely pragmatic grounds. Better the train go nowhere than in the wrong direction. But it is an odd way to govern, only reinforcing the view that Washington can never do anything right.
That's why Mr. Hahn leans toward a simpler change in which agencies would be required to compare costs with benefits in systematic ways without making them binding on the rule makers. The idea is to spread the gospel of cost-benefit analysis by making the public aware that economic life inevitably consists of trade-offs. At very least, this would make it harder for Washington to take credit for making omelets without acknowledging the need to break a lot of expensive eggs.
Lawrence J. White, an economist at New York University's Stern School of Business, adds that people would be less hostile to the principle if benefits were cast in terms of "reduced risk of injury or death -- not whether little Sally Jones next door will live to attend her high school prom." Once life is personalized, even the prophets of Adam Smith have trouble deciding which ones are not worth saving.
Democracies are unlikely to come up with a one-size-fits-all formula for regulating spotted owls and tailpipe gases. Surely it would be a step in the right direction, though, to get the notion of economic limits on the table. The Government simply cannot do everything people might like to make life better for Americans -- and what it does do almost always has a cost.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Farewell, Red Ink

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
Paris is paralyzed by a strike of workers determined to keep the lavish benefits of France's anachronistic welfare state.
We cannot mock; Washington D.C. commuters were blocked on their way to work this week by "Sweeney's garbagemen," militant A.F.L.-C.I.O. unionists resisting overdue cuts of waste in waste management. 
 Will France stem the tide of red ink that has reached 5 percent of its domestic product? If the U.S. ran such a rate of deficit, we would be borrowing over a half-trillion dollars a year. That way lies national bankruptcy and political upheaval.
Though not in such dire straits as unemployment-ridden France, the U.S. has made the right decision about moving toward balance. We realize that the percentage of our budget paying interest on debt has doubled in the past generation, and -- if President Clinton's original budget went forward -- the interest slice would be on the primrose path to redoubling.
That would mean saddling everybody under 40 today with huge taxes and reduced services tomorrow to pay for our profligacy. Never in history have the young put up with such pocket-picking by the old.
With every year in deficit, future discretionary spending is snatched away. In France, students joining workers on the red-ink ramparts are throwing away their chances as grown-ups; and polls here show most young Americans, their heads in computers, also to be a little slow on the upload.
The under-40 set's inability to see and speak up for its self-interest (justifiable in tots but surprising in thirtysomethings) has given President Clinton license to engage in "Mediscare." This is his shamelessly demagogic campaign to frighten older Americans into thinking that deficit reduction might soon leave them destitute in the snow, and to bamboozle them with pie in the medical sky.
Yesterday came his promised veto of the Republican opening plan; today comes a Clinton counterproposal and negotiation begins. Here's what is likely to happen:
Clinton will continue his poll-directed lurch to the left for at least another month, professing to protect the old folks -- and the poor's Medicaid entitlement -- from those mean, seven-year budget-balancers.
Meanwhile, the Congressional Budget Office will rosify its projections to come nearer White House optimism. The gap between Clinton and the G.O.P. will be narrowed further by a rejiggering of the Consumer Price Index, which -- don't say this out loud -- in effect reduces the increase in Social Security benefits and also raises income taxes.
The "give" on both sides will be not so much on spending as on taxing. Republicans will come down from their $245 billion cut, and Clinton -- whose $100 billion straddle offends everybody -- will at first take refuge behind the conservative Democratic "Blue Dog Coalition," which will become a media favorite because it calls for no tax cut at all.
In the end, the tax package will probably be: a capital gains cut but not retroactive; a reduction in the G.O.P. child deduction; restoration of the earned income tax credit; plus a token Clintonesque education credit. Total tax reduction: about $170 billion, back-end-loaded, small enough to make the seven-year ball balance on the Presidential seal's nose in time for next month's State of the Union address.
A nagging thought intrudes: How close are any of these varied projections to reality? What if recession strikes or inflation re-ignites or the standard forecast is cockeyed? Aren't we haggling over figures that are imaginary, and subject to change by the economy or the next Congress?
Yes, but. The actual numbers mean little; the direction they represent means much. The Republican impetus toward balance is needed for continued prosperity. The grudging Democratic agreement to end deficit spending -- but to attain it by continuing high taxation rather than substantially reducing the spending growth rate -- clings to liberal philosophy, making compromise easier.
What should America learn from France's budget anguish? In Paris, the Bourse is shaky because the political will is uncertain. In the U.S., investors know that impending budget balance will lower interest rates, and confidence in that has boosted stocks and bonds. Listen to the markets.

HEADLINE: Casinos Are No Solution

BYLINE: By David R. Johnson; David R. Johnson is professor of urban history at the University of Texas in San Antonio.

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO

 BODY:
New York's mayors seem unable to resist casinos. In the 1860's, Fernando Wood consorted with John Morrissey, the city's premier gambler, at Morrissey's posh illegal gambling hall on West 24th Street. Jimmy Walker liked to conduct city business from the elegant Central Park Casino in the 1920's.
In the glory days of the early 20th century, "entrepreneurs" like Richard Canfield and Arnold Rothstein made the city a mecca for high rollers without worrying about whether gambling was a public good. Now, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is weighing whether gambling, in the form of a proposal for floating casinos that sail out of Staten Island to international waters, can be a civic virtue, the fertilizer for economic development. But if there are any lessons from the colorful characters of the past, it is to keep an eye on the bottom line. 
 The prospect of attracting gambling tourists and siphoning their dollars into the city's coffers while creating jobs by building an "entertainment village" on Staten Island has only a superficial attractiveness.
Casinos, whether afloat or on land, have usually generated local prosperity only when nothing else can. Las Vegas owes its spectacular success to the desperation of local businessmen seeking to stave off economic ruin for their isolated and unattractive city. When Atlantic City slid into a deep decline as a resort, gambling was brought in to rescue it. Biloxi, Miss., with its health-spa business long dead, has found temporary relief in riverboat casinos. A few Indian tribes, surviving on reservations that generated little income, have amassed riches beyond their wildest expectations.
But New York is neither a desolate desert outpost nor a dying city. It is difficult to know if gambling might benefit the city because there has been no systematic study of its effects on local economies. That has not stopped the gambling industry from peddling sugarplum visions. Politicians hungry to increase revenues without raising taxes make gullible audiences.
But not all forms of gambling are equally popular or profitable. State lotteries have made money. But, as last month's collapse of a plan to build a huge casino in New Orleans shows, there are limits to this part of the business, even in a city famous for its love of a good time.
At its heart, the floating-casino idea makes little economic sense. The city's lawyers, apparently wishing to avoid conflict with the state law against the possession of "gambling devices," seem to think the casinos would be legal so long as they did not have slots. But slot machines are the heart and soul of a profitable casino. The house's take on slots is enormous and helps compensate for the much narrower odds in poker and blackjack. Where will the big bucks come from -- a gaming tax?
The logistics also seem iffy. Tourists like easy access to entertainment. A ferry ride to Staten Island, the wait to lift anchor and the 45-minute sail into international waters probably would not deter a determined bettor, but the casual bettor -- the one who likes to pop into an Off-Track Betting parlor -- might find it a waste of time.
Mayor Fiorello La Guardia considered slot machines immoral and made a public display of destroying them. Mayor Giuliani has said he has no moral objection to gambling. That's his judgment. But economically, the plan for seagoing casinos seems neither a good business prospect nor a wise exercise in political leadership. Mayor Giuliani should emulate La Guardia and find more productive ways to invest in the city's future.

HEADLINE: Bilingual Education Should Be Goal for All

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Representative Peter T. King's Dec. 5 letter rests on a flawed premise. He implies that mastery of a second language is comparable to an unearned handout, to laziness and sloth. 
 To compare bilingual education to a (Republican) vision of welfare makes no sense.
I have worked as a writer-in-residence at a number of elementary schools in Houston. Students in bilingual classes have taught me a great deal of Spanish while I taught them creative writing.
They are industrious and eager to learn, in spite of the enormous distractions caused by frequently difficult home lives.
By the end of the year, under their teacher's instruction, their English has improved dramatically.
For bilingual education to work, of course, its teachers must be competent.
I am in residence at the Rice School-La Escuela Rise, a K-8 laboratory school created under the auspices of the Houston Independent School District and Rice University.
Part of its mission statement is that every student shall be bilingual, in both English and Spanish, because every student "deserves" mastery of two languages in a global economy.
As the students from many backgrounds in the school learn Spanish, while studying content areas in English, nobody worries that they will be victims of a "separate and unequal society."
I am also astonished at Representative King's naive idea that countries cannot function effectively with more than one official language.
Poor Switzerland! If only the Swiss would come to their senses and speak just English. Maybe their trains would run on time and maybe we could finally count on their banks.
 
AMY STORROW
Houston, Dec. 5, 1995

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Report by Fed Helps Derail Bond Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
A Federal Reserve report showing wage pressures helped derail a strong bond rally yesterday, erasing much of the day's price gains.
Earlier, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose as much as 11/32 , pushing the yield below the psychologically important level of 6 percent, to 5.97 percent. Prices and yields move in opposite directions. 
 But bond prices later retreated, settling up 5/32 , to 11121/32 to yield 6.03 percent, down from 6.04 percent on Tuesday.
The early buying was prompted by a Commerce Department report that showed the index of leading economic indicators had fallen by half a percentage point in October. The decline was sharper than economists had expected and was the seventh drop in the last nine months. The data heightened the market's anticipation of a cut in short-term interest rates by the Fed on Dec. 19, when its policy-making committee meets.
"While the accuracy of this index has been questionable at times," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, "its noticeable weaknesss of late should not be ignored, as it seems to be suggesting that the slowdown in economic growth currently taking place in the fourth quarter is likely to extend into 1996 as well."
As a result, Mr. Fine said that he expected the Fed would cut rates on Dec. 19, and that another rate cut was possible in early 1996.
"To a large extent, it is for precisely these reasons that the bond market has rallied."
The early buying was bolstered by coupon purchases by the Fed and rumors that large hedge funds were in the market to buy.
Even surprisingly strong numbers for construction spending in October failed to halt the market's momentum.
The rally lost steam, however, in the early afternoon after the Federal Reserve's report on regional business conditions, known as the beige book, showed tight labor markets and increasing wage pressures in a number of Fed districts.
The beige book, noted Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, is "a big-ticket item for Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan."
" If he needs a reason not to ease, you can be sure that one will get a mention or two during the Dec. 19 meeting," Mr. Burtnick said.
Trading in the March bond contract on the Chicago Board of Trade once again set a contract high, this one at 12112/32 , with a low price of 1203/32 . The contract closed near the lower end of the range.
"The day before yesterday people were saying the market looked tired," said Robin Mesch, chief fixed- income analyst at Thomson Research. "Yesterday they slammed on the brakes. "All this talk of where the top is going to be is the wrong orientation. Good resistance levels are going to have their day in court, but what should be monitored in an uptrend market is the support level, and those continue to hold firmly."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Rallies in U.S. Stocks and Bonds Help to Fuel Gains by the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday as Wall Street stocks and bonds pushed to fresh highs and the European currencies regained strength against the German mark.
 "The mark gave back a lot of ground against the lira, franc and yen," said Steven Jury, chief dealer at Union Bank of Switzerland. "The result was that the dollar was able to pop up." 
 Strikes and political turmoil rocked France, but French stocks jumped after the Government pledged to press ahead with austerity measures. The Government also indicated that no concessions would be offered to labor unions.
The French franc also rallied on rumors, which were later denied, that the French and German Governments planned to peg their currencies together at a summit meeting today.
The Italian lira gained on prospects that foreign investors, particularly in the United States and Japan, would take renewed interest in Italian debt because a budget amendment eliminated a 12.5 percent withholding tax on nonresidents.
In late New York trading, the dollar surged to 1.1435 marks, from 1.4338 marks on Tuesday, and to 101.37 Japanese yen, from 101.26 yen. The British pound slipped to $1.5425 from $1.5430.
The dollar was also supported by expectations that the German central bank, the Bundesbank, would lower German interest rates in coming months.
"The increasing sentiment for lower rates in Germany and the movement up in the lira is weighing on the mark, which is basically helping the dollar," Seth Cohen, director in foreign exchange sales at Merrill Lynch & Company, said.
Strong gains in American markets bolstered the dollar. The Dow Jones industrial average broke across 5,200-point level for the first time during the session and closed at 5,199.13, its 68th record high close this year. United States bonds also rallied before giving up much of their gains in the afternoon.
"You can't ignore the fact that the bonds have been able to rally in quite a spectacular fashion over the past few days," Mr. Jury of Union Bank said.
Currency traders also said the dollar recovered yesterday because the market failed to push it below key technical trading levels on Tuesday, opening the door to a test higher.
The dollar's strong showing was exacerbated by thin trading conditions nearing the end of the year.

HEADLINE: With Unions Adding Drama, the Season Is On at La Scala

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MILAN, Dec. 6

 BODY:
When La Scala, the grande dame of Italian opera houses, opens its season on Thursday with a gala performance of "The Magic Flute," the sigh of relief from both audience and cast will be almost as loud as the first notes of Mozart's overture.
Until a few days ago, there was a risk that La Scala's traditional St. Ambrose Day opening -- the crowning event of Italy's cultural calendar -- would fall victim to a strike, a tradition that in recent months has become part of the opera's repertory. 
 Union bluffs are as Italian as opera buffa, but twice this year, La Scala's various unions actually made good on threats to stop the show. In June, when the orchestra went on strike moments before a performance of "La Traviata," Riccardo Muti, the conductor at La Scala, went to the piano and in a grand geste worthy of Verdi provided the accompaniment himself.
In October, not even Mr. Muti could salvage six days of scheduled performances of "Lucia di Lammermoor," which were canceled because of the labor dispute. The dispute ended over the weekend with what both sides called a "hypothesis of an accord," which for the moment has put to rest a backlog of labor issues that have dogged La Scala since 1991, when its local union contracts expired.
But the problems witnessed at La Scala run deep and spread across the length of the Italian peninsula to the 11 other full-fledged opera houses that, together with Rome's Orchestra di Santa Cecilia, are subsidized by the Italian Government at an annual cost of around $281 million. While no one argues that the state should stop supporting opera, many now realize that its track record as manager has been dismal and believe that its role should be reduced.
Even Mr. Muti, who usually maintains a discreet distance from La Scala's tangled internal affairs, has few kind words to say about the way the Italian Government treats opera. At the announcement in August of La Scala's 1995-96 season, he admitted that he found working in Italy increasingly difficult.
"After 20 years abroad, when I decided to come back here I felt that it would be a gamble, difficult but do-able," he said. "But now I say that all of us involved with culture in Italy are in serious danger."
Frustrations about the mismanagement of opera in Italy have this year led to a new proposal, now included in the 1996 national budget, to "privatize" opera in effect through the creation of autonomous private foundations described here as "quasi-American." The idea is to encourage private donors to support opera by offering them healthy tax breaks on their contributions, and to allow the opera houses to run themselves as independent entities free of the constrictions of public-employee labor contracts.
"In Italy we must now make an attempt to rationalize the management of the opera houses, to keep the costs within limits, and at the same time try and involve the public to participate in the costs," said Prof. Mario D'Addio, an Under Secretary at the Ministry of Culture.
The budget amendment calls for a new law to be adopted by June that will lay out in greater detail how the new foundations will operate and what kind of tax breaks will be given to opera's private patrons.
La Scala is one of the few opera houses in Italy to have successfully experimented with private sponsorship. The Foundation for the Theater of La Scala, created in 1991, raised $1.625 million in private donations last year, amounting to about 2 percent of the opera's 1994 budget of $83 million. The foundation's president, Jean Rodocanachi, predicts that with significant tax reductions, that amount could grow to $16 million.
La Scala has traditionally enjoyed healthy box-office receipts, bolstered by its reputation for top-quality performances and productions that aim for painstaking excellence. For "The Magic Flute," for example, Mr. Muti had a glockenspiel specially made to Mozart's specifications. The theater's own workshops produce all the sets and costumes, down to the shoes, for the three or four new productions that La Scala usually puts on each year.
Even though La Scala receives first-class treatment by the Government (that is to say, a disprportionate share of state subsidies in recognition of its international reputation), it, too, has been forced to economize. Belt-tightening measures were brought home two years ago by a Government-ordered hiring freeze that has left 108 of La Scala's 812 employees working without a permanent contract. That was a major issue in the recent labor dispute. Currently, eight orchestra members are in so-called temporary positions, a situation that some say could lead top-notch musicians to refuse positions at La Scala for more secure jobs elsewhere.
But the Government's latest proposal, coming after several years of reduced subsidies, has raised fears among management and unions alike that officials are looking to private contributors as a way of shirking the Government's own commitment to opera.
"One of the unions' principal worries is that the state will stop funding us, but that is one of our worries as well," said Maria Di Freda, director of personnel at La Scala. "We agree to having other resources made available, but we don't want the state extracting itself from its role in years to come. Everything is up in the air and until we have certainty, the unions' preoccupation is justified."
A big frustration at La Scala and other opera houses in Italy derives from civil service laws that continue to treat musicians and stagehands on a par with postal workers. Some of these regulations benefit the unions; for instance, ballerinas at La Scala are kept on the payroll until the age of 46, long after the usual retirement age for ballerinas in other countries. But others, like a law forbidding musicians to hold part-time teaching jobs, are widely regarded as obstacles to sensible management.
There are also fears that when more stringent budget mechanisms come into place, artistic considerations -- some might say artistic license -- will be forced aside as managers take an increasingly cold look at the bottom line.
"Italian opera is famous for more than the music," said Sergio Leonardi, a union representative and set mover at La Scala. "Our sets are different from those of the rest of the world and that is why they cost more. Our style of work is old-fashioned, but this care naturally makes for higher quality. In the rest of the world, stages are increasingly electronic, but here everything is still made by hand."
The Italian Government, facing pressure at home and abroad to bring its overall budget deficit under control, is wary of tackling cultural shrines like La Scala. But Government critics, themselves opera lovers, argue that Italy's opera houses still have ways of cutting costs without sacrificing artistic excellence.
"The real problems are of management, of professional capability and personnel," said Professor D'Addio, who estimated that of the 6,000 people working in Italy's 12 opera houses and in the Santa Cecilia orchestra in Rome, probably only 4,000 were really necessary. "Opera is one of the great glories of Italy," he said, "and that is why these problems have not been addressed until now."

HEADLINE: Museums Share More Art to Save Money

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
Distinguished youngish medium-size museum in the hinterlands with lots of wall space and ambition to match seeks like-minded partner(s) for art-to-art sharing relationship. Photo a must. (Of the art.)
If it hasn't quite come to this in the once-starchy precincts of American museums, such appeals may not be all that farfetched, not when tough economic times in the arts are making for interesting new institutional bedfellows. With government contributions down and private and foundation giving stretched increasingly thin, museums around the country are seeking ways to cut costs and maximize resources. 
 Sharing art collections is one idea whose time seems to have come. Not just famous museums digging into their storage vaults to lend art to smaller institutions, often for a fee, but museums of like size lending to each other and collaborating on traveling shows by dividing the work and expenses. While lending art is nothing new, museum professionals say, the growing formalization of the process is.
There is, in fact, already a kind of "personals" column for museums looking for partners: the Collections Exchange Newsletter, published by the Samuel P. Harn Museum of Art at the University of Florida in Gainesville. The latest semiannual issue lists 110 exhibitions that can be borrowed free from 32 museums from Canada to Mexico.
"The smarter we get, the greater the likelihood that we'll live," said Ellen Harris, director of the Montclair Art Museum in Montclair, N.J., which has joined nine museums of similar size in the Northeast in a consortium to circulate exhibitions of American art from their collections.
The signs of such matchmaking are widespread.
In a major initiative in October, two leading charities, the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation and the Pew Charitable Trusts, announced the creation of the Museum Loan Network, to be administered by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. At least 100 museums have sought information on the program, which is to compile a vast database of artworks available for loans of several years to fill gaps in significant collections.
At the same time, five museums, in Pittsburgh, Minneapolis, St. Louis, Kansas City, Mo., and Toledo, Ohio, pooled works for their second joint show in five years, "One Thousand Years of American Art." It is wending its way to each museum.
The 10 members of the consortium assembled last January by the Montclair Art Museum do not combine their collections for shows but coordinate efforts to exhibit each other's shows. One recent show in Montclair, "Affinities and Influences: Native American Art and American Modernism," is booked next year at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, L.I., and the Currier Gallery of Art in Manchester, N.H.
Although the approaches vary, the motivation is often the same: a desperation to conserve money while cuts in government aid and slower growth in foundation giving are sending a chill through many arts organizations. In many cases the new fiscal realities are prompting museums to focus more on their own collections for special exhibitions.
According to the latest figures by the Foundation Center, a research organization, art and cultural groups captured a steady 13 to 15 percent of all foundation grant money over the last decade -- an estimated $1.36 billion in 1992, for example -- but the share given to museums has fallen sharply. The trend is also toward larger grants to fewer recipients.
Many of the survival strategies were discussed in New York City last month at a forum of museum directors sponsored by the American Federation of Arts, a museum service association founded in 1909 to funnel art to "the hinterlands."
One speaker, Saralyn Reece Hardy, director of the Salina Art Center in Salina, Kan., urged her fellow directors to view their museum walls as "permeable boundaries" allowing easy give and take -- and cost-sharing -- with the community. "Take a cue from the natural world," she said, urging museums to join forces with other community institutions. "Think of yourselves as part of the cultural ecology."
For example, she said, the art center is collaborating with the Land Institute, an environmental park, on a school study unit built around the ancient elements -- earth, air, fire and water -- to teach pupils about art and nature.
James Cuno, director of the Harvard University Art Museums, argued for a better division of labor among smaller museums. Be a university collection or a community art institute or a public exhibition space, he said, but don't try to be all three.
Collection-sharing came up repeatedly. Generally, experts say, only 5 percent of a museum's collection is on display at a time; the rest is locked away. If more of it could circulate, the sending museum could save storage space and perhaps earn loan fees, while the receiving institution could assemble exhibitions drawing many people at little cost.
At the Montclair museum, founded in 1914, for example, the vaults contain the vast bulk of the 11,000-piece collection, including paintings by John Singer Sargent, John Singleton Copley, George Inness, and Elaine de Kooning, and Native American dolls, beadwork and woven baskets, some no bigger than a pinhead.
Its consortium began modestly a year ago. "People glommed on to a show I was about to do," said Ms. Harris, the director, a former deputy director of the Museum of Modern Art. "Responses revealed far greater enthusiasm and more exhibition options than expected." The Montclair museum acts as a clearinghouse, and the members elected not to charge each other loan fees and to skip formal catalogues.
"It makes sense on many levels," Ms. Harris said. "I get my collection to a broader audience. I stand to get great works. Our name gets out and everybody wins." The other members are the Albany Institute of History and Art, the Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., the Munson-Williams-Proctor Institute Museum of Art in Utica, N.Y., the Neuberger Museum of Art at the State University College in Purchase, N.Y., the Hudson River Museum of Westchester in Yonkers, N.Y., the Museum of American Art of the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in Philadelphia, and the Williams College Museum of Art in Williamstown, Mass.
The pioneers of the consortium approach were mostly in the Midwest: the Toledo Museum of Art, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, the St. Louis Art Museum, the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City and the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh. They grouped in 1985 to plan a joint show on Impressionism. The exhibition, based on works contributed by all, circulated among the members in 1989 and 1990. No fees were charged and members shared the administrative, education and publicity duties.
"One of the basic realities of the art world is that big shows tend to be East Coast, West Coast, and if they make a stop in the Midwest, it tends to be in Chicago," said David Steadman, director of the Toledo Museum of Art. The consortium sought to buck that trend, he said, providing shows "of real solidity just from our own collections."
Increasingly, however, museums are also using their collections to raise money, charging for loans of art, said Serena Rattazzi, director of the American Federation of Arts. "The first time we heard this, we said, 'Oh my God, what are we coming to?' " she recalled. But now, she said, charging for the loan of even a single piece is commonplace and accepted.
With the growth of the sharing movement, a newsletter was all but inevitable. The Harn Museum in Gainesville began publishing a free one in April 1994. It listed 19 shows from 8 museums and was dedicated to "reducing the disparity of the haves and have-nots," said Budd Harris Bishop, the museum's director. A second issue came out that fall and two more this year. "It's grown by leaps and bounds," said Dixie Neilson, the editor.
The latest issue's 110 listings include the National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Monterrey, Mexico, and shows ranging from "Star-Struck: Images from Hollywood's Golden Age," an exhibition of vintage photographs from the Columbus Museum in Georgia, to "Recent Czech and Slovak Printmaking" from the Harn Museum.
Beyond one-stop shopping for art shows, Mr. Bishop said, the newsletter "eliminated the need for personal relationships" as a condition of museum loans. "What we are trying to do," he said, "is establish an open exchange."
The initiative of the Knight Foundation and Pew Trusts is yet something else. With a start-up grant of $770,000 for the first year, the charities are establishing a network to track artworks available for long-term loan, perhaps two years. The first 15 or 20 grants are to be awarded in February.
"If a borrower in, say Oklahoma, wants to borrow from the Met, they agree on the objects and the costs, and we pay for all that," said Lori Gross, the director of the loan network, who has held museum posts in Montreal and Madrid.
"We'll be creating a directory of available works, but borrowings are not limited to what's in the directory," she said. She said the sponsoring foundations were committed to the experiment for at least two years "and there's no reason to think they won't go beyond that."
If collaborations are the wave of the future, as Barbara Van Vleet, a spokesman for the Toledo Museum, said, they are hardly a panacea for a budget-troubled museum industry.
"It's just one show out of 15," said Ms. Harris of the Montclair museum, referring to the consortium's show on Native American Art. "It's not going to solve the problem."
