HEADLINE: James Reston, for Many Years a Nonpareil Among American Journalists, Dies at 86

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.; Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
James Reston, former columnist, Washington correspondent and executive editor of The New York Times, died on Wednesday night at his home here. He was 86.
The cause was cancer, said his son Thomas. 
 First as a reporter and then, beginning in 1953, as a columnist, Mr. Reston was perhaps the most influential journalist of his generation. In Washington, where he was based, and also in other capitals around the world, he had unrivaled access to the high and the mighty. Yet he retained a wry, self-deprecating personality, free of bombast, and always sought to reduce political complexity to plain language.
"What I try to do," he said, "is write a letter to a friend who doesn't have time to find out all the goofy things that go on in Washington."
Interested in China and the Soviet Union as well as the United States, a student of diplomacy as well as domestic politics, he won two Pulitzer Prizes and dozens of other awards.
Mr. Reston was forgiving of the frailties of soldiers, statesmen and party hacks -- too forgiving, some of his critics later said, because he was too close to them. But his stern moral standards, rooted in the Victorian values of his youth, never wavered. He remained an idealist in a world of cynics.
From his strong-minded mother he inherited a Presbyterian conscience and an abiding sense of duty and responsibility. Work hard, he was taught. Work for large goals that transcend self-interest.
A talent scout of prodigious capacity, Mr. Reston hired and trained many of The Times's best-known journalists, and served as mentor to many more. To each of them, he passed along a lifetime's lessons about craft and country.
Mr. Reston's 50-year association with The Times began when he joined its London bureau on Sept. 1, 1939, the day Hitler's armies marched into Poland, igniting World War II. It was a fitting day on which to start his career at the paper, much of which would be spent recording and reflecting upon the aftermath of that fateful day.
His nationally syndicated column appeared regularly until 1987, when he became senior columnist. He retired from The Times in 1989, without ceremony, on his 80th birthday.
In an interview marking the occasion, he said the two greatest political triumphs in his lifetime had been the common defense system developed by the West after World War II and the improvement in the lot of black people in America since 1960.
Mr. Reston, who was born in Scotland, described the men who met in Philadelphia in 1787 to draft the Constitution as the great heroes in his adopted country's history. The document that they produced, he said, made possible "the triumph of the moderates" over the next two centuries.
A moderate himself, hostile to both fascism and communism, he described journalism's role in their eclipse as "one of the great pleasures of my life."
Asked whom he had most admired, he cited Franklin D. Roosevelt as the finest President he had known and Dean Acheson, Secretary of State in the Truman Administration, as "the key man" who "came to the fork in the road" and concluded that containing the Soviet Union would require a new alliance.
But he chose Jean Monnet, the French visionary who conceived the European Community, as the greatest man he had ever known as well as the person who had most deeply influenced his own thinking. Monnet proved, Mr. Reston often said, that "if you don't demand credit for things, you can push them through."
 
First and Foremost, A Dogged Reporter
Mr. Reston thought of himself primarily as a reporter, and he often beat his competitors to be the first to write about major news events. His coverage of the Dumbarton Oaks Conference in Washington in 1944, which laid the groundwork for the United Nations, was one of the era's most important exclusives and won him his first Pulitzer, in 1945. Those articles disclosed the substance of secret documents that were then being circulated among delegations from the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and China on the structure of the proposed international organization.
Mr. Reston won his second Pulitzer in 1957 for distinguished reporting from Washington. The articles cited were written in June 1956 and analyzed the effects of President Dwight D. Eisenhower's illness on the functioning of the executive branch.
He was also responsible for The Times's publication in 1955 of the documents of the 1945 Yalta Conference. And in 1954 he disclosed that J. Robert Oppenheimer, who had directed the making of the first atomic bomb, had subsequently been denied access to secret documents by the Atomic Energy Commission because of suspicion that he was passing information to the Soviet Union, a charge of which Oppenheimer was later cleared.
One exclusive dispatch came by accident. In 1971, as one of the first American reporters allowed into China, Mr. Reston developed appendicitis. His report about his surgery and postoperative acupuncture treatment, filed from his bed in the Anti-Imperialist Hospital in the capital, ran on the front page under the headline "Now, About My Operation in Peking."
 
'My Own Opinions Aren't That Good'
From the 1950's on, Mr. Reston interviewed most of the world's leaders, often producing major news accounts that were scrutinized at the State Department for their every nuance. The interviews often bore the special Reston stamp: He sought to reveal not only the policies and the politics of the people he interviewed, but also their vision of life and their view of history.
Mr. Reston, who was called Scotty by virtually everyone who knew him, was 5 feet 8 inches tall and had a round and ruddy face, gray-green eyes, an ever-present pipe and an invariably pleasant manner. He was courteous not only to officials but also to the young people who worked for him.
"He believes in hard work, in thrift, honor your parents, woman's place is in the home, play by the rules and live clean," his colleague Russell Baker once said.
Mr. Reston was credited by competitors with having more high-level news sources in Washington than almost any other reporter, although some critics felt that he was too kind in print to some of them. The economist John Kenneth Galbraith, reviewing Mr. Reston's "The Artillery of the Press," a 1967 collection of his talks before the Council on Foreign Relations, suggested that Mr. Reston had learned to his disadvantage "to treat all people in the manner of a newspaperman who must one day go back and see them again."
But in a 1980 article in The New Republic, Mr. Reston was quoted as saying: "If you spend your life as a hatchet man -- and there's something to be said for that -- then eventually you find that everybody's out to lunch when you call. You're left with only your own opinion. I wouldn't like that because my own opinions aren't that good."
Writing his column three times a week, Mr. Reston was a procrastinator, often filing right on deadline. A two-finger typist, he regularly wore out typewriters because he banged so hard on the keys, and his desk was a litter of papers, many of which bore tiny black marks where a stream of smoldering matches had landed in the course of a never-ending pipe-lighting ritual.
His columns, laced with quotations from Walter Lippmann, H. G. Wells, Matthew Arnold and Churchill, were a combination of high moral tone, detailed reporting, allusions to sports, impish humor and evocative descriptions of seasonal changes along the Potomac. They seldom offered absolute judgments about people or events; he used the word "maybe" more than most pundits.
His first column, on Oct. 18, 1953, established the Reston style.
"This town is still full of echoes from the days of America's isolation," he wrote of Washington. "It has changed in policy and personnel, more than any other world capital in the last generation. No nation has taken on so much or moved so far in such a hurry. Yet the habits of the past, like the bent figures of homeless former senators, still haunt the capital."
 
Press and Politics: 'Like Cats and Dogs'
He often returned to certain themes, such as the role of the press. In his column of Oct. 30, 1968, when Spiro T. Agnew, soon to be elected Vice President, was denouncing news organizations, Mr. Reston wrote:
"The candidates and the press are fussing at each other again, and this is the way it should be. They have different jobs, and in many ways they are natural enemies, like cats and dogs. The first job of the candidate is to win, and he usually says what he thinks will help him win. The job of the reporter is to report what happens and decontaminate as much of the political poison as he can. The conflict is obvious."
In addition to his two Pulitzer Prizes, Mr. Reston was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1986 and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Four Freedoms Award in 1991. He received the Overseas Press Club award for interpretation of international news three times, the George Polk Memorial Award for national reporting and the French Legion of Honor, and was named Commander, Order of the British Empire. He also received 28 honorary degrees.
After retiring, he fulfilled a longtime promise to his wife, Sally, by writing his memoirs. Titled "Deadline," they were published by Random House in 1991.
Reviewing the book for The New York Times, Ronald Steel, author of "Walter Lippmann and the American Century," called Mr. Reston "the quintessential Washington insider."
"Officials used him to test out new ideas on the public or to drop leaks for which they did not want to be held accountable," Mr. Steel wrote. "Because of his high position at The Times and his personal integrity, he was trusted both by those who provided the news and by those who read it. "But what he did so well and so usefully for so long could not be done today. Journalism and the political world have changed too much."
Mr. Reston is survived by his wife; his sons, Richard F. Reston of Edgartown, Mass., James B. Reston Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., and Thomas B. Reston of Washington; his sister, Joanna Richey of Santa Cruz, Calif., and five grandchildren.
Funeral services will be held at 10 A.M. on Saturday at Saint Albans Church on the grounds of the Washington National Cathedral.
 
Born in Scotland To Years of Poverty
James Barrett Reston began life about as far from the Washington power center as one could get.
He was born in Clydebank, Scotland, on Nov. 3, 1909, the son of James, a machinist, and Johanna Irving Reston. The Restons migrated to the United States when he was an infant, but Mrs. Reston became ill, and the family returned to Scotland.
There followed years of harsh poverty, of life in a brick tenement where young James and his sister slept crosswise at the foot of their parents' bed. In 1920 the family returned to the United States and settled in Dayton, Ohio. His father worked for the Delco Remy Division of General Motors.
When his parents were naturalized, young James automatically became an American citizen. In 1932, he graduated from the University of Illinois with an undistinguished academic record. He had majored in journalism, skipping the course in governmental reporting but getting an A in sportswriting.
During his high school years he caddied at the Dayton Country Club golf course. His own game became so good that he twice won the Ohio state public links championship and at Illinois was captain of the Big Ten championship golf team in 1932. His father wanted him to become a golf pro. His mother wanted him to be a preacher, which, he was to say later, is really what he became.
In the winters during his school days, he hung around The Dayton Daily News. "When the phone rang, I'd pick it up and take down the scores," he later recalled. "And from that I just moved into newspapering. I never thought of anything else."
Another link to the world of newspapers was Gov. James M. Cox, the Ohio publisher and 1920 Democratic Presidential candidate, for whom young Reston had caddied. Mr. Cox gave him his first job after college on one of the Cox newspapers in Ohio, The Springfield Daily News, where he earned $10 a week as the sports editor.
Later he was hired as traveling secretary and publicity director for the Cincinnati Reds baseball team. In 1934 he moved to New York as a sportswriter for the Associated Press Feature Service.
The next year he married Sally Jane Fulton, a former college classmate who had been president of her sorority, an A student and a Phi Beta Kappa in her junior year. Named Sara but always called Sally, she was the daughter of a judge from Sycamore, Ill., a small town near Chicago.
Mr. Reston once told a University of Illinois graduating class, "I should say in passing that I myself married a recklessly beautiful girl whom I first saw on Wright Street wearing a scarlet coat."
"My gal Sal," as he called her in the dedication of "Sketches in the Sand," a collection of his columns published in 1967, became his closest confidante, frequent collaborator and steadiest supporter.
They had three sons, and Mr. Reston's own happy situation made him a champion of marriage. He was forever asking his young bachelor colleagues when they were going to wed.
In 1937 The Associated Press sent Mr. Reston to London on a rather loose dual assignment: in summer covering sports events, in winter the British Foreign Office.
In 1939 he joined The Times's London bureau, with a salary of $85 a week. He was so little known on the foreign desk in New York that his first byline in The Times had his name wrong -- John instead of James.
Then came the London blitz. The Times's office for much of the war was on the seventh floor of the Reuters Building on Fleet Street, which offered a view of the dome of St. Paul's Cathedral. He described this view of the battle in his first book, "Prelude to Victory."
"Before we got better sense, we used to put the lights off in the Times office every night and watch this effort," he wrote. "With uncanny regularity, the German bombers would come over just about 10 minutes after blackout and start dropping incendiary bombs all over this section. About an hour before we could see the flames, we would begin to hear the steady throb of scores of engines along the banks of the Thames; these were the pumps, driving the muddy water from the river up through miles of new hose. . . .
"A little later the sky would begin to change in color from midnight blue to a reddish glow, and soon the great dome of the cathedral would stand out in silhouette against the flames of perhaps a dozen raging fires. Night after night we watched this incredible scene, and morning after morning we marveled at the fact that the fires were somehow put out."
In December 1940 he was reassigned to Washington, and in 1942 published "Prelude to Victory," a call to action that was acclaimed here and abroad. Its theme was pure Reston: Unless Americans put aside personal aims and materialistic thinking and made sacrifices in a crusade for their country, the war would not be won.
In late 1942, Elmer Davis, head of the Office of War Information, obtained a leave of absence from The Times for Mr. Reston and sent him to London to set up the agency's effort there.
John G. Winant, the United States Ambassador to Britain, recommended him to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, then president and publisher of The Times, who was looking for an assistant. It was the beginning of Mr. Reston's close friendship with the Sulzberger family.
 
After the War Years, Washington for Good
Mr. Reston returned to Washington and was named national correspondent in 1945. He made his mark with his coverage of Dumbarton Oaks, which illustrated a Reston maxim: Seek out the disgruntled party. His theory was that people who were disenchanted were more likely to talk candidly.
In this case, it was the Chinese representatives to the conference who were disenchanted. In his memoirs, Mr. Reston told of having met Chen Yi, one of the Chinese delegates, before the war through Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, wife of The Times's publisher. At Mr. Reston's urging, Chen Yi slipped him the texts of the proposals.
Instead of writing one long article, Mr. Reston doled out the information, producing an exclusive a day. The Russians thought Washington had leaked the material; Washington suspected the British, and the F.B.I. started an investigation of Mr. Reston.
In 1948 Mr. Reston became diplomatic correspondent for The Times, and in 1953 he became Washington bureau chief, succeeding Arthur Krock. He continued as bureau chief until 1964, when he elected to step down to concentrate on his column.
In 1968 he was summoned to New York by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who had become publisher, to succeed Turner Catledge as executive editor, in charge of the entire news operation. The internal politics of the news department had received publicity after an unsuccessful effort by editors in New York to exert more control over the Washington bureau. Mr. Reston's mandate was to re-establish peace.
For 13 months he ran the news department while commuting to Washington a few times a week to write his column. It was an almost impossible job. In 1969, knowing that he had to choose between his column and the editor's post, he gladly chose the column.
Mr. Reston was eminently a Washington man. He loved and understood the capital. Moreover, he had helped shape the Washington bureau. These were his people, and many of them regarded him as a father figure. The New York office seemed to him a vast, impersonal beehive.
During these years the Restons lived in a pleasant red brick house on Woodley Road in leafy northwest Washington and spent weekends at their log cabin in Fiery Run, Va. Mr. Reston often used Fiery Run as the dateline on his Thoreau-like columns about the restorative life in the country.
In 1968 the Restons purchased The Vineyard Gazette, a 122-year-old weekly on Martha's Vineyard, Mass., where they vacationed in the summer. Their son Richard is now editor and publisher, and his wife, Mary Jo, is publisher and general manager.
 
Two Cuba Episodes And the Pentagon Papers
Mr. Reston played a part in the publication of the Pentagon Papers in 1971 and in two other major news events involving The Times in questions of national security. The others were the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961 and the Cuban missile crisis of 1962.
In the spring of 1961, The Times was preparing to publish an article by Tad Szulc reporting that 5,000 or 6,000 Cuban exiles who had been training in the United States and in Central America for nine months were about to launch an invasion of Cuba to overthrow the regime of Fidel Castro.
The article was planned for page 1 on April 7, under a four-column headline. But Orvil Dryfoos, then the publisher, was troubled by the security implications of the report. On April 6, he and Mr. Catledge, then managing editor, telephoned Mr. Reston, who advised them not to publish the article and cautioned against giving away the proposed timing of the landing as "imminent."
The article was published on April 7 under a one-column headline and with no mention of the invasion's date. The Bay of Pigs invasion took place 10 days later and ended in debacle. President John F. Kennedy, who took full responsibility, said that if The Times had published more about the operation, it might have saved the Administration from making such a colossal mistake.
"If I had it to do over, I would do exactly what we did at the time," Mr. Reston said later. "It is ridiculous to think that publishing the fact that the invasion was imminent would have avoided this disaster."
In 1962 Mr. Reston was apparently the only reporter who had found out that the Soviet Union, then under the leadership of Nikita S. Khrushchev, had secreted nuclear missiles in Cuba, only 90 miles from Florida. When Kennedy realized that Mr. Reston had the information, he telephoned him directly.
Four years later, Mr. Reston recounted the incident to Clifton Daniel, then managing editor of The Times.
"The President told me that he was going on television on Monday evening to report to the American people," Mr. Reston recalled. "He said that if we published the news about the missiles, Khrushchev could actually give him an ultimatum before he went on the air.
"I told the President I would report to my office in New York," Mr. Reston continued. "And if my advice was asked, I would recommend that we not publish. It was not my duty to decide."
Kennedy then called Mr. Dryfoos, the publisher, and asked him not to print Mr. Reston's article. Mr. Dryfoos left the matter up to Mr. Reston and his staff, and the article was withheld.
It was a different story, however, in 1971 when The Times obtained and published what became known as the Pentagon Papers, the Government's top-secret documents on the Vietnam War. Seeing this at once as "the story of the century," Mr. Reston was one of the editors who felt that the documents should be published because they were history and therefore no question of national security was involved.
One of Mr. Reston's contributions to journalism was the corps of young reporters he discovered and developed.
In 1961 he instituted a program of internships for young would-be reporters, modeled on the clerkships at the United States Supreme Court and suggested to him by the late Justice Felix Frankfurter. Each year he would recruit a new college graduate as his clerk and researcher. He paid a price for this program, as time and again the young clerks with lofty journalistic thoughts would mix up his airline reservations or keep the Secretary of State waiting because they had failed to cancel a scheduled appointment.
Linda Greenhouse, who went on to report on the Supreme Court for The Times, recalled that on her first day as a clerk, Mr. Reston asked her to get Ted Sorensen on the phone and suggested she try Paul Weiss in New York. After trying every Weiss-comma-Paul in the Manhattan phone book, she reported back to Mr. Reston.
"He didn't groan, tear his hair or -- more important, and the reason for my undying gratitude -- laugh at me," Ms. Greenhouse said. "He gently explained that Paul, Weiss was a New York law firm where Ted Sorensen was working, looked up the number and gave it to me."
It was perhaps this quality, this unfailing kindliness, that constituted his special attractiveness. It enabled him to view the faults and frailties of the world with compassion and to carry on in the belief that the best in mankind would eventually win out over the worst.
"Stick with the optimists, Niftie," he wrote in a column in February 1980, welcoming his new grandson, Devin Fitzgerald Reston, to the human race. "It's going to be tough enough even if they're right."

HEADLINE: Clinton Asks Crackdown On Tax Deals

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Challenging aggressive Wall Street deals that it contends have improperly stretched the tax law, the Clinton Administration proposed today to limit the deductibility of various innovative financial practices.
The limits would raise nearly $6.5 billion in the next seven years as part of a $28 billion list of initiatives included in President Clinton's budget plan that he sent to Congress today. They are intended to curb corporate subsidies and to close loopholes involving activities ranging from the issuance of 100-year bonds, to farming, to manufacturing pharmaceuticals in Puerto Rico. 
 While accounting for less than 25 percent of the total revenue at stake, much of the focus concerning the plan was on the securities industry and its role in the increasingly blurred distinction between debt and equity. Equity, or ownership interest, is often disguised as debt to generate tax deductions that issuers of debt can claim on interest they pay.
"These are abusive transactions designed to take advantage of uncertainty in the tax system," Cynthia G. Beerbower, Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Policy, said. "These are not normal things that companies do."
The proposal is likely to meet with stiff opposition in the Republican-controlled Congress, and Wall Street reacted angrily.
While some of the practices are arcane, most have become popular enough to no longer be considered unusual to Wall Street and have provided lucrative business for investment banks. On Monday, for example, Morgan Stanley & Company advertised four separate issues of 100-year debt, the latest in a string of supermaturity securities inspired largely by the drop in long-term interest rates.
The Treasury proposes to deny deductions for interest paid on debt of more than 40 years, arguing that since "few companies survive" for a century, the debt may never be paid, and the money raised is perhaps better regarded as nondeductible equity.
Another initiative would deny interest deductions to companies whose money-raising transactions are tailored so that the interest or principal is paid not in cash but in the stock of the company or a related party. By calling the instrument debt -- until it is paid off in stock -- the company can entitle itself to a tax deduction.
The Treasury proposed that most of the changes take effect today.
A. B. Krongard, chairman of the Securities Industry Association, a trade group, declared, "This gives the appearance of sort of being slapped onto the tax package to achieve gains in the same way that when you finish making a salad, you might say, 'What the heck,' and throw in a couple of pieces of grapefruit."
Walid A. Chammah, an architect of many 50- and 100-year bond deals for clients at Morgan Stanley, said the industry would work hard for reconsideration of the 40-year limit. He argued that the supermaturity securities should not be treated like equity because companies were obliged to make interest and principal payments regardless of business conditions, whereas dividends on stock could always be eliminated.
Other major losers would be Goldman, Sachs and Merrill Lynch. Goldman is the creator and biggest underwriter of monthly income preferred stock -- subordinated debt, either bonds or notes, that has been repackaged as preferred stock bearing a monthly or quarterly interest payment that is tax deductible for the issuer.
In seeking to curb these securitities, the Treasury complained that they were set up to be treated by companies as debt for tax purposes, while shown on the company balance sheet as equity.
Issuers of securities, the Clinton Administration argued, should not be able to obtain the best of both stocks and bonds.
Wall Street, however, noted very quickly that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin was formerly the co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs.
Another proposal attacks the practice of issuing securities labeled debt but with very low interest rates or other features that in effect force their conversion into stock. The Treasury seeks to defer the deduction until maturity or to eliminate it if the instrument is converted before then.
Following are other Administration proposals involving securities:
Companies that own less than 20 percent of another company's stock can now deduct 70 percent of the dividends they receive from that stake. The Administration proposes to cut that deduction to 50 percent, reducing the incentive for "tax arbitrage."
Companies making stock purchases with the intent of qualifying for a deduction on the dividends received from that stock would be compelled to honor the 46-day holding period "at a time proximate" to each dividend to insure that the company runs market risk on its holding, or else the company would fail to qualify for the deduction.
In corporate reorganizations, the Administration proposes several rules intended to prevent shareholders of target companies from deferring gains for tax purposes if they no longer maintain a continuing interest in the surviving company.
In contrast to these financial proposals, which Ms. Beerbower described as "brand new," various of the Administration's other revenue-raising proposals have been addressed repeatedly.
One of the more contentious, tax breaks for companies doing business in United States territories, would extend limitations enacted in 1993. The proposal of the Republicans on this issue is less severe.

HEADLINE: CLINTON OUTLINES ALTERNATE PLAN TO HALT DEFICIT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Hoping to get budget negotiations with Congress off the ground, President Clinton today offered a new plan that he said would balance the budget in seven years, but it was immediately assailed by Republican leaders.
Following a 90-minute negotiating session in the Capitol this afternoon, Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said of the President's new proposal: "We think it works. We think it's credible. We think it's defensible." 
 But Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, declared: "I am as disappointed as I can be. They do not in any way bridge the gap."
And his counterpart in the House, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, said that the Democrats were "not just a day and a dollar short -- they're 17 days late and $400 billion short."
It was impossible to tell how much of this reaction was political theater and how much was genuine disgust with the President's position. Whatever the case, the negotiators from both sides agreed to resume meeting on Friday.
Participants said today's session had few of the angry exchanges and sharp recriminations that had characterized previous negotiations.
"For the first time in five meetings," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, "we actually started turning pages and talking about policy. We weren't shouting at each other, and that hadn't happened before."
Today's proposal amounts to the third budget President Clinton has offered this year. It differs only on the margins from the one he put forth last June that was supposed to balance the budget in nine years.
The main change was the President's offer to make cuts averaging 5 percent in some domestic programs, which he did not specify. He said high-priority programs would not be trimmed.
One new proposal today, trivial in budget terms but important on Wall Street, would crack down on various aggressive or innovative financial practices that turn on stretching the tax law farther than the Administration believes is acceptable. [Article, page D1.]
What is important is that both sides now have their opening offers on the table. Neither offer -- today's proposal by the White House and the mammoth budget legislation approved by Congress last month and vetoed by the President on Wednesday -- will ever become law, but they mark the starting points for the negotiations.
Under the agreement that ended last month's partial shutdown of the Government, funds will run out again on Dec. 15 unless all the spending bills are approved or a new temporary extension of spending authority is adopted.
Mr. Clinton suggested today that Congress allow more breathing room by approving a temporary spending bill that would run through January. Mr. Kasich assessed the chances of Congress's accepting that as between "slim and none."
The biggest hurdle to be overcome is that the two sides are operating from different economic assumptions. The Administration's forecast, prepared by the Office of Management and Budget, is slightly more optimistic than the one Congress uses, which was done by the Congressional Budget Office.
But the slight differences mushroom when they are stretched to cover seven years. The result is that Congress, using its figures, had to find $812 billion in savings over seven years to have the budget in balance by 2002, while the Administration needed only $465 billion to make its figures balance.
The Congressional Budget Office plans to provide a recalculated forecast next week that is expected to narrow the difference somewhat, but the two sides will still be hundreds of billions of dollars apart.
Mr. Panetta suggested that these differences would become moot if the negotiators could agree to some kind of enforcement mechanism that would lock in a balanced budget whatever the state of the economy turned out to be. But though he repeated the term over and over, Mr. Panetta did not describe what such a mechanism might look like.
Still, the main obstacle in the way of compromise seems to be not so much the dollars as the principles. The Republicans are determined to shrink the size of the Federal Government and reduce its place in the lives of Americans, while the Democrats in most instances want to keep the Government's influence and control.
The new proposal does not fundamentally change the extent to which the President wants to preserve Federal assistance to poor people and the Republicans want to diminish it.
This basic dispute flared briefly in today's closed-door negotiations, participants said. White House officials insisted that Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor, must remain a Federal program that would serve everyone who met Federal eligibility requirements. Republicans said that was out of the question and demanded that the program be turned over to the states to administer as they want.
Mr. Clinton's new plan suggests spending about $140 billion less over the next seven years than did the plan he put forward in June.
About a quarter of that would come from adopting the Bureau of Labor Statistics' new method of calculating inflation. The new calculation would lead to smaller annual cost-of-living increases in Social Security and other benefit programs and to higher tax revenue.
Another sizable chunk would come from selling Government assets, including Governors Island in New York Harbor, and from a new auction of space on the broadcast spectrum.
But the biggest single share, $64 billion, would result from unspecified savings in domestic programs.
As described by Administration officials, spending on most Government programs would be cut by an average of 5 percent below current levels. The cuts would not affect benefits called entitlements, military programs or programs the Administration calls high-priority investments. The cuts in the other programs would amount to 20 percent after adjustments for inflation, the officials said.
The officials would not specify what they consider investments except to say that the term included education, job-training, technology and environment programs. Spending on these programs, the officials said, would not be cut and in some instances might be increased.
They suggested that the reductions would fall in areas like housing, energy and transportation.
This offering is quite similar to President George Bush's proposal several years ago for a "flexible freeze" on Government spending, an idea that Democrats ridiculed at the time for its lack of specificity.
The President made no changes in the proposals put forth in June for Medicare, Medicaid or tax reductions, and these remain the biggest points of departure between his budget and Congress's.
Congress found $270 billion in savings from Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, and $163 billion in Medicaid. The Administration countered with $124 billion from Medicare and $54 billion from Medicaid.
Congress would cut taxes by $245 billion; the Administration, by $98 billion. By the Administration's reckoning, 47 percent of the Republicans' tax cuts would be realized by taxpayers with incomes over $100,000, while that would be true of only 15 percent of Mr. Clinton's tax reductions.
In addition to the usual budget items, the Administration's proposal today included an increase of the minimum hourly wage to $5.15 from $4.25 and a line-item veto, which would allow the President to veto specific items in spending bills. These proposals were seen more as bargaining chips than as measures Congress was likely to accept.
While most of the attention was on the budget negotiations, Congress took further action on two spending bills. One would dismantle President Clinton's program to get more police officers on the street. The other would reduce funds for the Environmental Protection Agency. The President has vowed to veto both.
By essentially party-line votes, the Senate approved money for the Departments of State, Justice and Commerce, and the House approved a measure for the Departments of Veterans Affairs, Housing and Urban Development, and the Environmental Protection Agency.
An intriguing proposal by the President today would raise $15.3 billion over seven years by selling off rights to an invaluable parcel of the nation's airwaves now being used by television broadcasters.
The idea is certain to meet intense opposition from broadcasters, a politically powerful force, and it could indeed wreak havoc for television viewers about 10 years from now. For those reasons, its approval by Congress is extremely doubtful.
Under the Administration proposal, the Federal Communications Commission would force all broadcasters to speed up their transition to new digital transmission technology that would make it possible to transmit sharper pictures and multiple programs over a single channel.
Then, between the year 2000 and 2002, the agency would force broadcasters to give up their television channels and would auction off those licenses to the highest bidders.

HEADLINE: Christians Against Welfare Cuts Are Arrested in Capitol

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
In a barely noticed counterpoint to the budget battle, 55 evangelical Christian preachers and their followers were arrested today in the Capitol Rotunda as they sought to speak up for the poor and to confront lawmakers with biblical verses against retreating from society's duty to help the needy.
"Woe to the legislators of infamous laws," the demonstrators recited in unison. In paraphrase, the words of the prophet Isaiah boomed about the Capitol dome as the police moved in and the demonstrators lambasted Republicans and Democrats alike for variously demonizing and bureaucratizing the poor. "Woe to those who issue tyrannical decrees, who refuse justice to the unfortunate." 
 The demonstrators sought arrest under the Capitol ban on public demonstrations in order to dramatize the fact that while competing budget plans would drastically reshape and crimp the Government's welfare obligation, virtually no ideas had been sought from the impoverished communities where the Christian groups help the more-resilient poor run self-help programs.
"The poor don't have a voice here," said the Rev. Jim Wallis, editor of Sojourners magazine, stressing that the preachers' roots are in neighborhood evangelical and Pentecostal churches, not the Christian Coalition and other groups that regularly lobby lawmakers in the name of God and religion. "The poor don't have the clout. They don't have the special interest."
No lawmakers were at the scene to watch as the Capitol police obliged the demonstrators, gently handcuffing them as they knelt and sang hymns before statues of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
But a passing group of eighth-graders from St. Luke's Roman Catholic School in McLean, Va., was transfixed at the unexpected display of peaceful protest in the heart of Government. They broke into applause to hail the demonstrators as the latter were marched off as they sang, "Lead me, Oh Lord, to Thee."
"I think it's good, what they did," Eamon Eager, 14, told a St. Luke's classmate. "They got their point through."
The youngsters' social studies teacher, Mary Ellen Sawyer, found that the demonstrators offered a timely lesson.
"Personally, I'm proud of the fact that our Government takes care of the basic human needs of its people." Ms. Sawyer said, "and I'm ashamed to think that we would be withdrawing that support."
With both houses caught up in debating other issues, and Democratic and Republican budget negotiators elsewhere, the demonstrators barely made a ripple as they gathered by the East Capitol steps, near two other protests, one for AIDS research and the other for gun controls.
"Hope is slashed and dreams are burnt alive," the Rev. Graylan Scott Ellis-Hagler shouted, rallying the demonstrators up the Capitol steps.
"Say it, brother!" a preacher responded. "We are being pushed to economic non-existence by the debate going on in there."
The religious demonstrators, acting in an association known as Call to Renewal, urged legislators to visit church self-help programs across the country to get first-hand guidance about their determination to end welfare dependency. They criticized Democrats as overrelying on Government to be the welfare mechanism while being wary of church-state partnerships in charity. And they criticized the Republicans as making a wholesale retreat on welfare in the name of deficit reduction.
"To simply slash and burn and dismantle all systems and safety nets without anything in their place is immoral," Mr. Wallis said. "It's a sin, and we reject it."
The demonstrators, which complained that Congress turned too often to the religious right for political blessings, run a variety of local programs for the poor, including clinics, after-school care, job training, housing loans and construction agencies.
Mr. Wallis said that Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, met with the group's leaders last spring and expressed an interest in what they were doing, but that he then produced a budget plan that would gut programs like the earned income tax credit for the working poor.
So, resorting to demonstrating in behalf of the poor, they renounced what one speaker termed the pro-affluent "flat-earth fundamentalism" that often passed for Christian activism in the Capitol. They proposed instead a "partnership" social program for the poor and urged lawmakers to remember Jesus' words to the effect that what one had done to the lowliest person one had done to him as well.
"The only big housing program in the last 10 years has been mandatory sentencing," declared the Rev. Ellis-Hagler of Washington, underlining his complaint that Congress preferred to see a convict costing society $27,000 a year rather than to invest less money in him earlier in education and jobs.
The preachers complained that budget plans included provisions to help the rich with tax breaks while reducing benefits for the poor. The speakers repeatedly resorted to Scripture in shouts of advice.
To all those in power in Washington, they offered some divine anger by way of Isaiah: "What do you mean by crushing my people, by grinding the face of the poor?"

HEADLINE: Leader Calls Cutbacks Vital For French Role in Europe

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The French Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, made some remarkably candid comments on Tuesday about why the French Government is determined to endure the worst unrest in a decade -- fear that France will permanently cede economic leadership in Europe to Germany.
"Either we will play in the first division or we will continue to be weighted down by deficits, and we slip back to the second division," Mr. Juppe said in a speech to Parliament. "In short, we will have moved over to the path of decline, slowly but surely." 
 Though he did not name France's mighty neighbor on the other side of the Rhine, no one doubted the reference was primarily to Germany.
Long the country of low inflation, a stable currency and industrial strength, Germany has emerged as the dominant force in Europe economy and the leader in moving the Continent toward greater integration, free trade and a single currency in the 21st century.
But whether France will be part of that is still a big question.
France's budget deficits have ballooned in the 1990's. Its currency has fluctuated widely, repeatedly becoming the target of market speculators. French interest rates have been far above those in Germany, driving away corporate investment. And France has developed an economy so top-heavy with Government employees reaping generous benefits, that its private-sector has struggled unsuccessfully to create new jobs that would ease a stubborn 13 percent unemployment rate.
"The French Government has been seized by a sense of emergency, prompting it to push reforms at an unusually high pace and frequency," said Jean-Francois Mercier, a French economist for Salomon Brothers in London. "There are worries that if France is not ready to join Germany in a single currency in two years, it may never be ready."
And it grates on both French politicians and business leader that Germany has emerged so dominant. For years, France has lived in the shadow of German economic might. Its has had to devalue its currency several times against the German mark. It has yet to shake its reputation of a high- inflation country. And its industry has lagged that of Germany.
"The French-German relationship is skin deep, there is real animosity there," said one French economist who insisted on anonymity. "French businessmen often blame their problems on the Germans."
But if France can put its house in order, it stands to benefit considerably: lower interest rates, a more stable business environment and more of a say in European economic policy.
Mr. Juppe's path to new credibility and a voice for France in European economic affairs is a series of five reforms over the next two years that in their totality would raise taxes and slash Government spending by more than $55 billion.
In American terms, that is more ambitious than if President Clinton and Congress agreed to balance the United States budget over the next two years, instead of the seven years currently being debated.
By far the most onerous reform is the proposed overhaul of the French state health system, which runs an annual deficit of $12 billion and has accumulated debts of $50 billion. Mr. Juppe plans a series of new taxes and other measures to eliminate them.
These include imposing a 10 percent surtax on corporate profits and raising social security taxes to 2.9 percent of taxable income, from 2.4 percent currently. Last summer, Mr. Juppe increased France's value added tax to 20 percent from 18 percent.
"This has angered France's white-collar union leaders, because their principal power base is among workers in the health system and they see this as possibly eroding their power," said Paul Horne, chief international economist for Smith Barney Inc. in Paris.
Transport workers are upset because of cutbacks proposed for the nation's train system, which is running deficits of $2.4 billion a year and has an accumulated debt of more than $35 billion. Mr. Juppe has said that in return for the state assuming a large chunk of the debt, the rail system has to close 3,600 miles of uneconomic track and lay off workers.
A third plan that has disturbed civil servants is a plan to increase the retirement age to 65, from 60, and increase to 40 years from 37 years the time a worker has to contribute to the system in order to get the highest benefit.
Finally, Mr. Juppe has promised to get France's privatization plan back on track for France Telecom, the country's telephone system, and Air France, its national airline. But this is likely to mean a loss of jobs, which has union leaders steaming.
Though many have predicted the Government will backtrack, the markets seem to believe in the resolve of both Mr. Juppe and Jacques Chirac, the French President. After a swoon last week, the French stock market has rebounded this week, the franc has firmed, and the Bank of France today lowered a key interest rate.
Mr. Chirac today repeated his commitment to the reforms. After a meeting in Baden-Baden, Germany, with Chancellor Helmut Kohl, he told a news conference, "our budget constraints have been approved by Parliament; there is no question of putting them into question."
What is making the current reforms particularly difficult is that the deadline is fast approaching when European governments must decide which countries have shown the budget discipline to be part of the first group of nations that make up the new European currency.
That decision will be made in early 1998, based on economic performance in 1997. Under the Maastricht Treaty that established the push towards a single currency and a single European market, governments must have budget deficits of no more than 3 percent of gross domestic product, as well as fulfilling other criteria on inflation, total accumulated debt and interest rates.
Currently only Germany and Luxembourg meet all the tests. France's annual budget deficit is approaching 6 percent of G.D.P. this year, twice the Maastricht level.
While Mr. Chirac denied today that Maastricht was dictating the pace of his reforms, almost across Europe, governments are cutting their budget deficits in order to meet the treaty's standards.
France is also handicapped by a rapidly slowing economy and may entering the a recession.

HEADLINE: Feldman Vows to Renegotiate

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from last night's statement by Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, after the defeat of the proposed teachers' contract. 
 Understandably angered at their terrible conditions, the two-year wait for salary increases to kick in and the general lack of regard for education and educators in this city, teachers are sending us back to the bargaining table.
Although I believe it will be extremely tough to do any better in this economic climate, we will certainly do our damndest. Hopefully, the message teachers have sent to the Mayor will encourage more flexibility on the city's part.
Let me say that I fully understand the disappointment that New York City's teachers have shown with this contract proposal. While it did reach a top salary of $70,000, offer job security for what looks like a turbulent next three years and provide a wide range of professional improvements, teachers are most angry at having to wait two years for a salary increase. That anger was exacerbated by the Mayor announcing pay increases for himself and other political and management people just before the voting began.
It's bad enough that our teachers are forced to work under the most horrendous conditions in the state, with overcrowded and jam-packed classrooms, with school buildings that are literally falling apart and often without even the most basic supplies, such as paper, chalk, textbooks and science equipment. The Mayor's proposal for pay raises for politicians and managers, while asking teachers to wait two years, was just plain insulting.
We now face great uncertainty as we go back into bargaining. . . . But we will be going back to the table for teachers. We will do so with renewed determination and will fight hard again for an agreement that is acceptable to our 68,000 teachers -- who I firmly believe are the best in this nation.

HEADLINE: Budget-Busy Capital Now Fixes Gaze on Bull Market

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Politicians in Washington are always wary of the financial markets, an unpredictable force playing by shifting rules that few in this city pretend to understand. And the markets never quite know how to measure the odd political dynamics of budget battles.
Now, however, anxiety about a link in the fates of the budget talks and the nation's soaring stock and bond markets has begun to rise here among Democrats and Republicans alike. 
 Almost everyone says the sky-high markets are sky high in part because there is a worldwide assumption that a budget deal will be struck, the deficit will come down, and low interest rates will sink lower still. And in subtle and unsubtle ways, everyone from Speaker Newt Gingrich to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is beginning to question what will happen to the markets -- and who will bear the blame -- if the result of the negotiations is a prolonged struggle or a total breakdown. Hardly a day goes by in which someone does not jockey for position, ahead of the disaster they all say must be averted.
Mr. Gingrich is the most blatant in using the fear of a market sell-off as a weapon to win his way. Earlier this week he warned that "you will see interest rates skyrocket and the stock market crash" if Republicans fail to deliver on their promises. Naturally the Democrats were quick to call his comments irresponsible.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, who makes a science of cryptic pronouncements, has been far less apocalyptic than the Speaker but has said that if there is "a shattering of expectation," the market's reaction "could be quite negative." Mr. Greenspan defined that reaction for Congress recently as an increase in long-term interest rates that would push mortgage rates higher -- always a way to get a politician's attention as an election year approaches -- and that could send "interest-sensitive areas of the economy into trouble."
Then there is Mr. Rubin, perhaps the most circumspect of all, because his status as Washington's most prominent Wall Street veteran gives his opinions special weight. At a recent strategy session at the White House, he talked at some length about the quirky way in which markets can ignore bad news in good times and fixate relentlessly on the same news in bad or nervous times. He laid out a "probability curve" of what would happen if the budget talks failed, ranging from "a chance nothing will happen" to the markets, to "a chance of a mild reaction, and a chance of a very big one."
Mr. Rubin did not offer any odds on those alternatives, people who attended the meeting say, but called them "all realistic probabilities." The danger, he said, is that the markets could miss a political cue by focusing on budget negotiators' narrowing numerical differences, which might lead Wall Street to think a deal was imminent, instead of on ideology that divides the two parties.
On several occasions since arriving in Washington three years ago, Mr. Rubin has remarked that Wall Street executives little understand the politics of putting together a Federal budget -- a comment that only he could safely make, because he used to be one of those executives.
"The Delta shuttle only flies 250 miles, but this is a case where New York and Washington seem a thousand miles apart," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs & Company, who travels often between those two worlds. "The disconnect between the two cities may be wider than ever now."
Ordinarily, Wall Street is pretty good at discounting the daily detritus of Washington's machinations. On any given day, 10-day car sales or the index of leading indicators has a lot more to do with the movement of the markets than do predictions about what the Federal debt will look like in 2002.
But these are not ordinary times. The high level of the markets has made a lot of people nervous that the end of a remarkable run is approaching. And that nervousness in itself means that blips in the budget process that might be shrugged off when the markets are behaving more modestly can quickly become what one of Mr. Rubin's confidants calls "the brick that pushes over the whole load."
Budget and market optimists alike say this is an exaggerated concern. No matter how the negotiations turn out, they say, the long-term trend will be toward smaller deficits, and the markets will ignore the details.
In any case, the markets are betting for now that the budget talks are taking on a momentum of their own that will ultimately carry the negotiators toward a deal.
"Who would win if that doesn't happen?" Senator William V. Roth, the Delaware Republican who heads the Senate Finance Committee, asked today at a breakfast with several reporters. "No one knows. It is possible both sides could lose, and that could spur a third party" to enter the 1996 Presidential race.
What seems certain is that each side will be walking a thin line in coming weeks, trying to intimidate the other with forecasts of how the markets might react to failure while carefully trying to avoid anything that might bring on that reaction. Mr. Rubin has warned that America's standing abroad will suffer if the nation seems perpetually only one step ahead of default because of Congress's refusal to approve an increase in the Government's borrowing authority. That is another way of saying the United States could be left with paying slightly higher interest rates on its debt.
Mr. Gingrich, meanwhile, will continue to argue that Mr. Rubin is manipulating the markets. Recalling one instance in which Mr. Rubin warned of the possibility of default -- which the Secretary has avoided by using techniques that the Speaker has condemned -- he said Mr. Rubin "held his breath; his face turned red."
No one can remember that actually happening. But if the Administration cannot keep up its current balancing act -- high standing in the polls, high markets, some movement toward compromise -- it could start any day.

HEADLINE: In Package Deal, Greenspan May Stay On at Fed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Passing up a chance to reshape the Federal Reserve for fear of a political battle with Congress, the Clinton Administration is leaning toward reappointing the central bank's top two officers as a package deal.
Administration officials hope that Senate Republicans' fondness for the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, will persuade them to accept another term for the vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder. 
 The Administration is also planning to try to fill a third, already vacant seat on the board as part of the package of nominations, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
While no decision has been made on reappointing Mr. Greenspan, White House officials have operated for months on the assumption that President Clinton will name him to a rare third term. Such a move would reflect the White House's respect for his success in controlling inflation and an acknowledgment that any other choice might alarm the markets and run into opposition in Congress.
President Ronald Reagan appointed Mr. Greenspan, a prominent Republican economist, to his first term in 1987, and George Bush reappointed him early in 1992. But there are ample precedents for a President to reappoint a Federal Reserve chairman of the other party -- most recently in Mr. Reagan's first term, when he redesignated Paul A. Volcker, a Carter appointee.
Mr. Blinder, since being named vice chairman last year, has pushed his colleagues to allow slightly lower short-term interest rates in hopes that the economy can grow a little faster with little if any extra inflation. The Administration wants to keep him at the Federal Reserve, and hopes that packaging him with Mr. Greenspan will allow them to avoid their worst-case scenario: confirmation of Mr. Greenspan, while the nominations of Mr. Blinder and another Clinton appointee languish in the Senate or are rejected.
Even if the Administration proposes three nominations at the same time, the Senate is not obliged to consider them together. But Mr. Greenspan's influence and visibility might allow less strenuous opponents of inflation to win approval.
However, Mr. Blinder's willingness to remain in Washington is in some doubt. "I am genuinely undecided about whether to seek a second term, and because I don't know, nobody else can know," Mr. Blinder said in an interview this week. He had previously planned to return to Princeton University, where he is an economics professor.
Mr. Blinder had become disenchanted with the job last summer, prompting Administration officials to ask Richard Syron, head of the American Stock Exchange and a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, whether he would like to become vice chairman. But in recent discussions with Administration officials, Mr. Blinder has expressed more enthusiasm
"We'd much rather he stay on," said an Administration official who requested anonymity.
At least two people are under consideration for the other vacancy. They are Sheila L. Tschinkel, research director of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, and Eugene A. Ludwig, Comptroller of the Currency, the nation's top regulator of Federal-chartered banks.
Ms. Tschinkel declined comment today. Mr. Ludwig, responding to a brief message asking about his plans for any job changes, Mr. Ludwig left a message on Wednesday night saying that "I have no plans to leave my job as comptroller." Today, he declined through a spokeswoman to comment specifically on the Federal Reserve position.
Interest-rate policy at the Federal Reserve is made by a committee composed of the seven members of the Federal Reserve Board, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and four presidents of the 11 other Fed regional banks, who rotate on the committee.
One seat on the board has been vacant since the retirement last spring of John P. LaWare, a New England banker. Mr. LaWare strongly urged in his resignation letter that another banker be named to succeed him, in keeping with a tradition that one of the Federal Reserve Board governors always be a former banker because the Fed regulates bank holding companies and many large, state-chartered banks.
Ms. Tschinkel is a former vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank, where she managed the bank's portfolio of domestic and foreign securities. Mr. Ludwig is a former law partner at Covington & Burling in Washington, who represented many big banks. He attended Oxford University and law school at Yale University with President Clinton.
Several officials said it was unclear whether Mr. Ludwig would consider one of the seven seats on the Federal Reserve Board to be a promotion. He currently oversees an agency regulating 3,000 banks.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The U.N.'s Master Juggler;
An Accountant Copes With Deadbeats and Bad Debt

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 1

 BODY:
It sounds like a chief financial officer's nightmare: a multinational corporation with no cash reserves, with no authority to raise capital or write off bad debts and with its most influential customer a chronic deadbeat who cheerfully admits that the billion or more dollars he owes will not be in the mail soon.
Joseph E. Connor doesn't need to imagine such a nightmare. For the last year and a half, he has lived it as the United Nations Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, trying to impose financial sanity on an organization tottering on the brink of insolvency, thanks to the refusal of member countries -- most notably the United States -- to pay their dues. 
 Few financial managers as seasoned as Mr. Connor would risk their reputations trying to rescue an organization whose finances have the characteristics of a Ponzi scheme. "I've never seen anything so precariously balanced at this scale," he said in his office on the 27th floor of the Secretariat building overlooking midtown Manhattan. "There's no capital and no reserves."
What abounds are lots of headaches: dues paid late or not at all, forcing bookkeeping sleights of hand such as dipping into emergency peacekeeping funds to finance routine expenses; a staff that cannot be reduced, at least for now, because there is not enough money for buyouts; the inability to borrow money, even from the World Bank, and sinking esteem in the United States and elsewhere.
While most people assume the United Nations will somehow limp along, as it has done for the last half century, Mr. Connor is not convinced. As a certified public accountant, he bases his analysis on hard numbers, not politics. He speculates that 1996 could be a year of reckoning as peacekeeping missions are scaled back and member assessments drop, generating too little money to repay what was borrowed to finance the regular budget.
Member countries, he predicts, will provide only $500 million of the $1.2 billion in assessments due in February, barely enough to carry the organization through next spring. "The expedient financial improprieties that we progressively adopted suddenly come home to roost," he said.
The 64-year-old Mr. Connor's descent into the financial chaos of the United Nations follows an accounting career of proven probity. A graduate of the University of Pittsburgh, he earned a master's degree in business from Columbia University and worked for 37 years for Price Waterhouse, retiring as its chairman in 1993. He taught at the Georgetown University School of Business before Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali asked him to take his current job on May 1, 1994.
At Price Waterhouse, Mr. Connor handled the books for the Exxon Corporation and other blue-chip companies like Allied Signal Inc., Young & Rubicam Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company. The United Nations, by contrast, "is the type of company that we wouldn't have accepted as a client," he said with a smile.
The United States is by far the biggest delinquent, owing $1.23 billion of the organization's total arrears of $2.7 billion. It is perpetually nine months behind because in 1982 the Reagan Administration began delaying its payments from the February due date to the beginning of Washington's fiscal year the following October.
Few other counties meet the February deadline either, but now the Republican-controlled Congress has carried American backsliding a step further by slashing appropriations for both ordinary expenses and the cost of United Nations peacekeeping missions around the world.
Because of the unpredictable cash flow, Mr. Connor said, "We manage our finances imprudently because we have to." He called his job a juggling act, adding, "It really requires a lot of attention to keep the organization from foundering."
Performing some of his most inventive juggling, Mr. Connor has raided payments earmarked for peacekeeping to pay salaries and other routine bills. This has meant postponing reimbursements to the countries that send troops to the world's hot spots at $985 or more per soldier per month. By the end of the year, the United Nations expects to owe $1 billion to such contributors.
Mr. Connor has also used new peacekeeping payments to work off some of the United Nations' most pressing debts. And to find $20 million to finance the tribunal in The Hague that is investigating war crimes in Bosnia and Croatia, he dipped into the regular budget.
"In the textbooks it's called a Ponzi scheme: use current cash to pay past bills," said Mr. Connor, who did not hide his distaste. "We had to shout from the rooftops, 'This is what we were doing,' and no one said, 'Stop.' "
What is to be done to plug the deficit? Right now, Mr. Connor is pushing for much earlier payments for peacekeeping missions. He has also come up with a series of inventive money-raising ideas.
One is borrowed from the world of retailing, where overdue bills are a way of life. "Every day on Seventh Avenue, when a retailer can't collect, he factors them by selling them at a discount to intermediaries," Mr. Connor said. Similarly, he said, the United Nations could convert its mounting arrears into cash by selling overdue obligations at a discount.
Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs (International) and a former assistant secretary of state for economic affairs in the Reagan Administration, called the idea interesting but said it needed a lot of work. "I think Wall Street would probably be interested, but at a substantial discount," Mr. Hormats said in a telephone interview. He went on to wonder if a government would feel less obligated to pay if the debt was transferred into private hands.
Mr. Connor has floated some other imaginative proposals, to no avail. Earlier this fall, he suggested that the United Nations be allowed to borrow from the World Bank. The bank rejected this, however, because it is only allowed to lend to sovereign nations.
And at Mr. Connor's behest, Mr. Boutros-Ghali took a novel solution to the leaders of the wealthy industrialized nations at their meeting in Halifax, Nova Scotia, earlier this year. He proposed creating a kind of bond that would assign debts of member countries in arrears to other member countries that were owed money. The proposal met with silence. There is no provision in the United Nations Charter to raise money on the financial markets.
Mr. Connor also started to reduce the work force of 14,380 employees at the organization's New York headquarters. But his buyout plan was never carried out for lack of $10 million to compensate 165 employees who agreed to retire early.
He estimated that perhaps 15 percent of expenditures could be saved by eliminating overlap in the sprawling operations of the United Nations. But dispensing with duplication is difficult because the Secretary General lacks control over the numerous semiautonomous agencies, like Unesco and Unicef.
"The organization has the narrowest type of executive line of authority," Mr. Connor said. "By contrast, there's no question about who's in charge of I.B.M."
In another move inspired by Mr. Connor, Mr. Boutros-Ghali instituted a cash conservation program on Sept. 12. It included freezing the recruitment of new employees and curtailing staff overtime and travel. About $60 million was saved to meet the next payroll; Mr. Connor describes it as only a Band-Aid.
Mr. Connor has trimmed operating costs to produce a biennial budget for 1996-97 that he says will be 4.2 percent less in real dollars than the present one. But anticipated savings may be mostly offset by the weakness of the dollar, the official denomination of the United Nations, against the Swiss franc, which is the working currency for the group's operation in Geneva.
Even the cost-cutting that Mr. Connor has brought to the United Nations has real limits. Many expenses are mandated by the Security Council or General Assembly, whose members show little interest in folding up projects that outlive their usefulness. And executives at the United Nations lack the sort of management skills taken for granted in private business.
"In my first year at Price Waterhouse, I was reviewed five times," Mr. Connor said. "Here that doesn't happen." The United Nations gets around to its evaluations every three years, which Mr. Connor described as "ridiculous."
He is not the first high-powered American to despair over the sad state of the United Nations' books. Dick Thornburgh, a former United States Attorney General who held Mr. Connor's post in 1992 and 1993, remarked in a report at the end of his tenure that "the term 'financial crisis' has become so overworked as to be a permanent description of the organization's financial status."
Today, Mr. Thornburgh remains pessimistic. "It's an impossible job if the leadership of the organization is not committed to reform," he said in an interview. "I think there is an obvious devotion to the status quo at the upper levels of the U.N."
For all his frustration, Mr. Connor says he has no regrets about taking his job. He said he felt he could not refuse the Clinton Administration's request, but added that he jumped at the challenge, in part because of a life-long interest in politics. "Frankly, I like what I'm doing," he said.
To bail the United Nations out of virtual bankruptcy, he said, the countries that owe money must commit themselves to a payments timetable, as Russia recently did; systems must be created for writing off bad debts and for turning commitments into cash quickly, and the scale used to assess members must be reviewed to make countries more willing to pay.
Otherwise, Mr. Connor said, "when we run out of regular budget cash, we'll close the door, because there's nothing else we can do."
"It's an easy management decision," he added wryly.

Chart: "Midlife Crisis"
 As the U.N. turns 50, these are its most pressing financial problems:
 
1. NO LIQUIDITY -- The organization suffers from a chronic shortage of cash. A $250 million reserve fund was cleaned out long ago.
 
2. INABILITY TO RAISE CAPITAL -- The U.N. lacks standing in the financial market; the World Bank says it cannot lend to the U.N.
 
3. UNPREDICTABLE CASH FLOW -- A majority of the 185 member states have stopped paying their dues on time.
 
4. NO WRITE-OFF BAD DEBT -- The biggest member, the United States, owes more than $1 billion and will not pay.
 
5. DECLINING REVENUE -- Smaller peacekeeping assessments cannot cover unpaid expenses or reimbursements to countries that contribute troops.
 
6. LACK OF FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT EXPERTISE -- The U.N. does not have an executive training program. Hiring and promotions are sometimes guided by politics instead of management skills. (pg. D1)

HEADLINE: In Primary Season, Big Question Is, Who's On First?

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
It is not as threatening as plummeting hog prices or widespread corn blight. But a move in Louisiana to hold Presidential caucuses ahead of those in Iowa has infuriated top Republican officials in Iowa who feel proprietary about their first-in-the-nation standing.
This week, Iowa's Governor and House Speaker held news conferences to denounce the idea, which has been proposed by Louisiana Republicans. One of Iowa's United States Senators has asked the Justice Department to investigate whether Louisiana's plan violates Federal civil rights laws. And the state's Republican Party has asked all Presidential contenders not to campaign in Louisiana. 
 "Iowans feel very passionate about their first-in-the-nation status," said Brian Kennedy, chairman of the Iowa Republican Party. "It's something we take very seriously. I think people in other states have a hard time appreciating this."
Among those that do not seem to get it is the Louisiana Republican State Central Committee, which earlier this year switched from a Presidential primary in March to caucuses now scheduled for Feb. 6, one week before the Iowa caucuses.
Louisiana Republican officials say the change was made to give a state in the South -- an area of growing Republican strength -- a voice in the early primaries. And they hope that Louisiana's culinary and climatic inducements will lure candidates and journalists to their state.
"We offer gumbo instead of Iowa snow," said Rhett Davis, a consultant for the Louisiana Republican Party.
The dispute between Iowa and Louisiana is not the only example of electoral rivalries among states. Having fended off efforts by Arizona to hold the country's first primary, New Hampshire officials are now upset by Delaware's plan to conduct a Presidential primary four days after the one in their state. Such an occurrence would violate a New Hampshire law requiring that its primary be seven days before a "similar contest" in any other state.
Officials in Iowa and New Hampshire say that if Louisiana and Delaware do not alter their plans, they will move up the dates of their contests to make sure they remain first by a sufficiently wide margin.
State officials in Iowa and New Hampshire evoke tradition to defend the status quo, even though the predictive value of some of these early Presidential contest has been dubious at best. Since 1976, no winner of a hotly contested Iowa caucus has gone on to win the Presidency.
Nevertheless, Iowa and New Hampshire officials, fearful that too many states may be tempted move the primary and caucus dates close to or ahead of theirs, continue to spurn efforts to share the limelight.
"If other states like Louisiana look to move ahead of Iowa, and others look to move ahead of Louisiana, it will have a snowball effect," said Ron Corbett, Speaker of the Iowa House of Representatives. "We're concerned that if other states move ahead of us, our role in winnowing the field will be diminished."
But to party officials in other states, the arguments put forward by Iowa or New Hampshire seem silly.
"Gosh, we're not challenging them to be first; we're coming after," Basil R. Battaglia, chairman of the Delaware Republican Party, said of New Hampshire's protestations over his state's plan to hold its primary on the Saturday after New Hampshire's. "I don't know what's so magical about seven days."
The fight is about economics as well as magic. Campaigns produce large infusions of cash for the economies of small states every four years as the candidates' entourages and the army of reporters and photographers that follow spend freely on everything from rental cars to hotel rooms to meals and telephone service.
"When these things become popular, some other states are saying, Hey, they're making money up there; we ought to have it, too," said Bill Gardner, New Hampshire's Secretary of State.
Top state officials in Iowa and New Hampshire say they suspect that the hand of Senator Phil Gramm of Texas is behind these efforts to challenge the primacy of their contests. These officials, who tend to be supporters of Senator Bob Dole, the Republican front-runner, say Mr. Gramm -- who sees his support eroding in New Hampshire and Iowa -- has pushed plans for contests in other states where he might have a better shot at winning.
But the Gramm campaign and party officials in Louisiana and Delaware deny the accusation, noting that the agitation to change the dates of their states' caucuses and primaries began years earlier.
Nevertheless, Iowa and New Hampshire are fighting back. Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican, has asked the Justice Department to investigate whether Louisiana's change in its election law violates the Federal Voting Rights Act. The act, intended to protect black voters, requires that Louisiana get approval by the Justice Department for any changes in its election procedures that might dilute minority voting strength.
"The Justice Department needs to take legal action to prevent them from doing this," said Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, also a Republican.
Justice Department officials say it might be necessary for Louisiana to get approval for the changes in its election law regarding the switch to caucuses. But officials declined to say how soon they would make that decision.
In the meantime, Iowa Republican officials have demanded that all Presidential candidates sign a pledge not to participate in Louisiana's caucuses. So far, nearly all have, except for Mr. Gramm, Patrick J. Buchanan and Alan Keyes. "We haven't heard from Alan Keyes and we can't find him," Mr. Kennedy said of the former State Department official.
The refusal by the three to shun the Louisiana caucuses has become a campaign issue in Iowa. Mr. Dole's campaign has been faxing a blizzard of statements to the press deriding Mr. Gramm's "insult" to Iowa voters. And former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, who is battling Mr. Gramm and Mr. Buchanan for second place behind Mr. Dole in Iowa, hastily replaced radio commercials proclaiming the candidate's support for term limits with advertisements proclaiming that he was the first to sign the pledge.
