HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Remarks by German Bank Chief Are a Boon to the Dollar's Value

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday after the president of the Bundesbank said that a weak mark and a strong dollar would be good for his country's economy.
The official, Hans Tietmeyer, made his remarks as new economic figures showed a further slowdown in Germany. His comments, combined with the economic data, further convinced analysts that lower German interest rates were imminent. 
 The improvement by the dollar against the mark helped pull it up against other leading currencies, as well. The dollar ended higher against the Japanese yen, drawing support from news of a lower Japanese trade surplus.
The dollar was also helped by American traders' squaring their positions ahead of today's report on November employment. Currency movements were exaggerated yesterday by thin trading, with dealers trying to hold on to the year's gains.
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 101.47 Japanese yen, up from 101.37 late Wednesday. It sold at 1.4467 German marks, up from 1.4435. The British pound slipped to $1.5325 from $1.5425.
Earlier, in Asian and European trading, the dollar had been weaker.
"The dollar had declined against the mark in overseas trading on a weakening U.S. economy and a widespread belief that the U.S. Federal Reserve is going to lower interest rates" at its Dec. 19 meeting, said Dan Ascani, editor and publisher of Global Market Strategist, an advisory firm in Gainesville, Ga. Lower interest rates typically make investments denominated in a country's currency less attractive.
But the dollar strengthened on continued speculation about a German rate cut. Such speculation was heightened when the German Government released data showing no growth in the third quarter and the unemployment rate rising slightly, to 9.3 percent.
Later in the day, Mr. Tietmeyer said he hoped that the weakening of the German currency, "especially versus the dollar, will go further soon," and that the "excessive appreciation" of the mark against currencies of Germany's trading partners had weighed on the economy.
The dollar got some support after Japan reported that its trade surplus umbled 51.8 percent in October, compared with October 1994, the biggest such slide in nearly five years.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Wheat Soars to 15-Year High As Europe Puts Tax on Exports

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Wheat prices jumped to a 15-year high on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after the European Union adopted a tax aimed at restricting wheat exports, forcing importing nations to pay higher prices or look elsewhere.
On other commodity markets, copper and heating oil prices rose. The reformulated Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities gained 0.61 point, to 244.2. 
 The European Union, collectively the world's largest wheat exporter, set a tax of 25 European Currency Units a ton, or about $32, on wheat exports. A partial reduction in the tax, which is the first in 20 years, may be available to exporters through direct application to the European Commission, the union's executive agency. The agency could allow sales based on internal European wheat prices.
The tax "should funnel a lot of business to the U.S.," said Joel Karlin, vice president of Everen Securities Inc. in Chicago. "That really gave the market a boost."
Wheat for March delivery rose 5 cents, to $5.06 a bushel. December wheat gained 8.25 cents, to $5.16 a bushel, the highest for a contract closest to delivery in 15 years.
The tax comes amid soaring demand from importing nations and a smaller American harvest. Exports of wheat from the United States, normally the world's second-largest exporter, are running 15 percent above last year. Europe's action is intended to stop an exodus of wheat to the world market and head off food inflation in Europe by insuring adequate supplies.
Copper prices rose for the first time in eight days amid signs of stronger demand.
Copper stockpiles held in warehouses of the Commodity Exchange of New York resumed their decline after a brief increase during November, falling 748 short tons, to 3,262 tons, a report showed Wednesday.
Traders said demand from manufacturers was still strong as spending on construction rose 2.7 percent in October, the Commerce Department reported on Wednesday. Construction is the single largest source of demand for copper.
March copper rose as much as 2.6 cents, to $1.2165 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fear the Fed Won't Cut Hurts Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of bonds dropped yesterday as nervous investors sold amid concern that the economy might not be slowing fast enough to warrant an interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve.
The 30-year bond fell by 25/32, to a price of 110 28/32 to yield 6.08 percent, up from 6.03 percent on Wednesday. The yield of a bond moves in the opposite direction of its price. 
 Traders and investors, who have been pricing in expectation of a rate cut with each weak economic report, were unnerved by comments made by Susan M. Phillips, a Fed board governor, in an interview yesterday with the Dow Jones wire service. Ms. Phillips said she was "reasonably optimistic" that the economy would stay on a moderate growth track well into 1996, and that was not what the market wanted to hear.
Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco, noted that Ms. Phillips had cited a tight labor market putting pressure on wages and suggested that the housing sector remained in good shape.
"These statements suggest she may not argue strongly for a rate cut at the upcoming meeting," Ms. Rupert said.
Selling was also attributed to some investors who were holding more long-maturity securities than they wanted to ahead of today's employment report.
Another negative for the market was a mediocre one-year bill auction yesterday, at which the average rate declined to 5.06 percent, the lowest since June 1994. Despite this, the auction saw a lessening of interest by small investors, suggesting that large institutional investors dominated buying at this auction.
Traders and investors are waiting to see if today's employment report will offer convincing evidence that economic growth is slow enough to keep inflation from accelerating, thus allowing the Fed an opportunity to ease. The data are seen as perhaps crucial to the Dec. 19 meeting by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making arm.
It was obvious that the market was a little disappointed in some of the data released yesterday, including the Commerce Department's factory orders report for October, which fell by three-tenths of 1 percent. Forecasts had put the drop at four-tenths of 1 percent. The previous month's data were revised to show a gain of 1.4 percent.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said that including yesterday's orders report, "the trend continues to fit with a manufacturing sector that is continuing to expand, albeit at a very slow pace."
But the market quickly recovered on a higher-than-expected jobless claims report for the week ended Dec. 2, which showed a gain of 14,000 in those filing for unemployment insurance for the first time, to 377,000. Many economists had expected a gain of 7,000.
Ms. Schaja said that despite the bounce in the weekly data, the four-week moving average remained around 370,000 for the last several weeks, "indicating a moderate deterioration in the labor market relative to last year."
Traders noted some institutional buying ahead of the data, and local short-covering, lending some strength to the market, but most players were on the sidelines as the latest data failed to cause any real buying.
Looking to today's data, Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said: "the payroll numbers could certainly modify market expectations, but these November statistics are subject to a statistical quirk that is very likely to bias the overall payroll number upward, all other things being equal."
He said this year there was a five-week interval between sampling periods, while in the recent past there were only four-week intervals in this time period.
"The seasonal factor doesn't know about the extra week, and will therefore 'underadjust,' " Mr. Fine said. "On the other hand, employment growth this year is slower than last year, which will likely act as a partial offset to the seasonal adjustment problem."

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton's Budget

 BODY:
President Clinton, as the price he paid to open shuttered Government offices, promised the Republicans that he would agree to their demand to balance the budget in seven years in accordance with estimates by the Congressional Budget Office. The plan that Mr. Clinton released yesterday to balance the budget does not really meet that goal, since he used his own budget office's figures. By Congressional Budget Office standards he is still perhaps $300 billion short of the mark. Even so, the new Clinton budget is becoming perilously like the G.O.P. version. What the revised budget plan shouts out is that seven years of budget-cutting will be a very ugly process.
For example, the previous Clinton budget would cut welfare programs -- food stamps, cash assistance for the disabled and aid to legal immigrants -- by $38 billion. His revised budget would subtract an extra $8 billion. The previous White House plan would have taken $186 billion out of discretionary programs -- reducing these, as a percentage of total economic activity, to their lowest level since the early 1960's. Now Mr. Clinton could cut an additional $64 billion. His plan includes steep reductions in Medicare payments to hospitals that treat the poor and train medical students. If he closes the $300 billion shortfall, then he will be forced to make mammoth additional cuts in these and all other programs. 
 To his credit, Mr. Clinton tried hard to protect the needy and the public investments that lie at the core of his economic agenda. For example, unlike the Republicans, he would preserve federally guaranteed health insurance for the poor under Medicaid and reduce poverty programs much less than the G.O.P. Yet his best was not good enough, and there are ways for him to improve his plan.
He proposes to cut wasteful farm subsidies by only $5 billion, instead of the $12 billion that the Republicans propose. He plans to nick corporate giveaways by only about $25 billion, the same as the G.O.P. Some estimates put needless subsidies to corporations at $75 billion or more a year. The White House says its plan would insulate education, training and research initiatives. But the claim does not amount to much because it is the Republican-controlled Congress that decides how money for discretionary programs is spent.
So if Mr. Clinton is to take a real shot at proposing a gentler plan, he needs to make two major changes, both politically hazardous. First, he would need to discard his ill-conceived $100 billion plan to cut taxes on non-needy families. The danger is that the Republicans would continue to wave their $245 billion tax cut before voters. Second, he proposes raising Medicare premiums for the non-poor elderly. Here the Republicans have provided some political cover for the President because their budget already correctly proposes such increases.
The Administration knew it would come under heavy criticism for substituting its budget projections for those of the Congressional Budget Office. Leon Panetta, the White House chief of staff, says the issue is moot because the White House will propose a procedure by which spending would be automatically cut if its budget estimates proved optimistic. But the purpose of proposing alternative budgets is candor. Voters deserve a side-by-side comparison of Republican and Administration budgets to see which they like better. By stopping the budget-cutting hundreds of billions short of the mark, the Administration has short-circuited this vital comparison process.
The moment Mr. Clinton agreed to a seven-year bloodletting based on Congressional Budget Office numbers, he guaranteed that any budget he signed would look almost as unforgiving as the one the Republicans have passed. He can fight hard to make it gentler at the margins. But yesterday's plan shows how much the G.O.P. has already won.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Fall as Consumer Debt Surges

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Factory orders declined in October, but consumer debt surged, according to Government reports issued today.
While the consumer spending gives the economy a temporary shot in the arm, economists fear that consumers will soon pull back under the weight of their heavy debts. Thus the economists interpreted both reports as evidence that the economy was likely to start the new year on a sour note. 
 "I don't think a recession is in the cards," Jill Thompson, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass., said of the drop in factory orders. "But I'm a little worried about the first quarter."
Weaker demand for aircraft and autos, as well as industrial and capital goods, accounted for much of October's three-tenths of 1 percent decrease in factory orders, the Commerce Department said. That followed a 1.4 percent gain in September, revised from an earlier estimate of a 1.5 percent advance.
Another part of the Commerce Department report showing that factory inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October suggests manufacturers may have overestimated demand. It implies "slow growth ahead until surplus stocks are sold off," said Gordon Richards, an economist at the National Association of Manufacturers.
The Federal Reserve said consumer borrowing rose sharply in October. That indicates there is a growing bubble of household debt that may inhibit spending and domestic economic growth next year.
Consumer installment credit rose $10.6 billion for the month, to $1.004 trillion, the Federal Reserve said. That is more than twice September's increase and well above the rise of about $6 billion that economists had expected.
Credit card use alone rose $5.1 billion in October, and auto-related borrowing also increased.
So far in 1995, credit card balances have risen by 14 percent, while incomes are rising only at about 3 percent annually, according to Ruth Susswein, executive director of the Bankcard Holders of America. That gap suggests a growing mountain of debt, and may spell trouble for economic growth in 1996. Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of United States economic activity, is not likely to surge if Americans are stuck with large outstanding debts.
Moreover, analysts said that dismissals associated with corporate restructurings would continue, putting personal incomes at risk.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Factory Orders" tracks manufacturers' total new orders, seasonally adjusted, from May 1994 through October 1995. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: U.S. Cutbacks Paralyzing Mobile's Transit System

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 5

 BODY:
When Congress cut aid to transit systems by $310 million, the Mobile Transit Authority cut 22 percent of its bus service. And that is how Kenny Williams ended up waiting an hour and 45 minutes today for a bus to take him to a doctor's appointment.
The round trip is about six miles, but to make the journey, Mr. Williams said, "you make a day of it, basically." 
 Nearly every transit system in the country is pulling in its belt these days to absorb a Federal cut. This year aid to transit operating budgets will be $400 million, down from $710 million in the year that ended Sept. 30. And it will probably drop substantially again next year if Congress continues with its plan to gradually eliminate operating assistance over the next few years.
But Mobile, which was in trouble before the Federal cuts, has had to go further than most in trimming its service. The manager brought in three months ago to get the system on its feet, David Warren, said with a touch of bitterness that Mobile "is on the cutting edge in transit."
For the riders, who are mostly too young, too poor, too sick or too old to drive, the decline in service is making it harder to get where they need to go, including to work. And local leaders say that because the riders are mostly black, the cuts raise broad issues of social justice.
"Now," said the Rev. Clinton Johnson, the City Council president, "the question is not, can you ride in the front of the bus. The question is whether you can have a bus to ride on."
Mobile is, in fact, testing just how small a bus system can get and still be a system. Alabama does not offer any support for public transit, and no taxes specifically pay for the Mobile system, which gets only what the city and the Federal Government give it.
As a result, Mobile Transit has been in a spiral of service cuts for years and has lost half its riders since 1986, down to about 4,500 a day now. Fares went to $1 this year and will be $1.25 next year. Beginning in July, the system shut down for six weeks because expenses were running about $4.2 million and revenues were only $3.7 million.
But what was merely a half-million dollar gap turned into a $900,000 gap on Oct. 1, when the Federal fiscal year began, and Washington cut the subsidy to $400,000, from $800,000. So this fall frequency on some routes was cut, while other routes were rearranged. Mr. Warren had planned to cut Saturday service by 50 percent but settled for 25 percent.
During the shutdown this summer, several black churches in town offered their own vans to transport the stranded around Mobile, just as 30 years ago black churches in Montgomery helped transport people boycotting the segregated bus system. But this being the 1990's, fears of liability suits got in the way, and the churches stopped running the vans. Eventually, the school board volunteered its buses for four weeks, with the city government paying the drivers.
Over the years the bus system here has tried to raise revenue by selling advertising space on the sides of the buses to companies like Roto-Rooters and Wendy's. But most businesses are no longer willing to pay the $400 a month, Mr. Warren said.
"Why would you pay?" he asked, explaining, "They know we can't afford to repaint them" to remove the advertisements. Recently, the system did scrape together enough money to paint the buses white, with a restrained stripe and logo.
For some, the Federal cuts raise questions about how government will provide for poorer people who depend on public transportation. Chip Bishop, a spokesman for the American Public Transit Association in Washington, said in an interview that public transit systems were "part of a balanced national transportation policy."
He added: "Washington spends $20 billion a year building roads; it spends billions a year underwriting the cost of airports for air travel. It is not unreasonable in a pluralistic society like ours that we also have support for public transportation."
But the problem in Mobile, as Mr. Warren sees it, is that the bus system is used mainly by people who have little influence -- service employees, like fast-food restaurant workers and maids. These workers earn little and cannot afford cars, which in Alabama is poor indeed, because the state has no insurance or inspection requirements.
The people who work for Mobile's big employers -- paper mills, chemical plants and a shipyard -- generally drive to work, he said, and those large employers do not press for public transportation.
At the Mobile Area Chamber of Commerce, James M. Apple, the vice president for economic development, said that in luring new companies, he used to say he could get the bus system to add a route to their front door. He no longer bothers to mention this, he said, because the companies are not interested.
If the buses disappeared tomorrow, Mr. Apple said, "99.5 percent of the work force of the Mobile area could still get to work."
Mr. Warren said he suspected that many bus riders were near the edge economically, so much so that by the end of each month they could not afford bus fare. He said farebox revenues were $2,700 on Nov. 30 but jumped to $3,500 on Dec. 1, after many people received monthly checks.
To the people who rely on buses, the cuts have nothing to do with transportation policy or the economics of business development. They simply make it tough for people to get where they need to go.
The other day, Mr. Williams, who is 24 and works at a fast-food restaurant, sat in a little smoked-glass shelter from 8:50 A.M., when one bus dropped him off after a five-minute ride, until 10:35, when another picked him up.
When Mr. Williams first started riding the buses here four years ago, he said, he could make the trip without changing buses.
Michael A. Williams says the buses are all right when they run. But Mobile Transit ran out of money in mid-July and shut down entirely for six weeks, cutting him off from his job tending bar and setting up for events at the Convention Center here. He walked a few times, and when he had the money he took a taxi, paying $8 each way. He said he missed work entirely on a few days.
Andrea Moore, 16, a high school senior who works after school and on Saturdays at an A & W Root Beer restaurant miles from her home, does not wait nearly so long for a transfer. But she usually cannot work evening hours, because her bus does not run after about 6:30 P.M. On Sundays, it does not run at all.
Ms. Moore, who earns $4.25 an hour, says she spends more than an hour traveling to work on the two buses she must take. And to get to her job on time, she sometimes has to arrive an hour or even two early, she said.
Of course, she is not always early. "Sometimes I'm late, and that cuts into my pay," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Waiting an hour and 45 minutes for a bus is hardly unusual in Mobile, Ala., where Federal budget cuts have led the city to severely curtail transit service. The cuts have mostly affected those who are too young, too poor, too sick or too old to drive. Many have had difficulty getting to work. (G. M. Andrews for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Uneasy Rests the Village That Wears the Crown

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: ESSEX, Conn.

 BODY:
THE last bad news in town was pretty much of a shock: some of the oldest, most treasured buildings on the oldest, most treasured streets were lying about their age!
Residents said it just couldn't be that so many houses were younger than everyone had thought. Not here, where the first warship in the Continental Navy was built in 1775. But research proved it. A Federal-style house on Middlesex Turnpike was built not in 1764, but 1801. The Henry Champlin House on Champlin Square, one of the most admired homes in the community, was built not in 1765, but 1818. And so on. 
 Thank goodness the scandal the local historian uncovered last summer blew over. People in this Connecticut River seaport don't take to too much change, too fast. This is why it took two referendums to get a new firehouse approved, why Groundhog Day is a major occasion, and why Main Street looks as though the elevator was never invented.
It also helps explain why the latest big news, which seems very good, is making residents rather nervous. After all, until last week, Essex (pop. 5,790) was minding its pretty business, content to be 35 miles from a major population center (New Haven) and a good 5 miles from the nearest mall. Then, boom. There it was, on the cover of "USA Weekend," No. 1 in a book on the "100 Best Small Towns in America."
As soon as the news was out, Town Hall began fielding calls. From Iowa. From California. From reporters.
State officials started talking about garnering major national publicity. Residents started worrying about how their small town might change.
"People are proud, but there's a lot of concern," said Doug Paul, 41, a lifelong resident. "People are concerned about preserving the town's character."
THE cautionary tale that has begun spreading is of Elko, Nev., which was small town No. 1 when the first edition of "The 100 Best Small towns" was published (by Macmillan USA) two years ago. After the book came out, Elko's population, which was 14,800 in the 1990 census, grew to 18,000. This makes it too big to fit the definition of a small town (from 5,000 to 15,000 residents), according to the book's author, Norman Crampton.
Mr. Crampton, who gave Essex the No. 2 spot in his book's first edition, said people here were worried about publicity even then.
"They were typical of people in the small towns I visited," he said. "Pretty much the reaction was this is a hidden gem." Some townsfolk, like the retired Essex postmaster, Charles Doane, said Essex was already getting spoiled. "Any time after lunch until midnight," Mr. Doane said, "cars are bumper to bumper on both sides of Main Street, and not 1 in 20 you recognize."
Mr. Crampton's reasons for giving Essex top honors are predictable: low crime and unemployment, a healthy percentage of residents (28.2) with bachelor's degrees or higher, steady growth rate (1 percent), good schools and healthy per capita income ($26,590).
He also included bank deposits per capita ($23,860) and factored in intangibles. "Essex has a large reservoir of local residents who are willing to volunteer their time and their talent for the good of their community," he said. (The Fire Department is all volunteer. The town's gazillion annual parades are organized largely by volunteers, and with a police force of one, citizens pretty much police themselves.)
OF course, one man's best small town to live in is another person's nice place to visit. Essex, like most of the towns in the Top 100, is not exactly ethnically diverse. It is largely white, and despite its well-publicized soup kitchens, largely well-to-do. It is beautiful, with its marinas and boat clubs and old houses on winding roads and hills. But for someone who thrives on the action of city life, Essex may be a little too picture-perfect.
Busloads of tourists already come to town -- its steam-powered railroad is one of the state's major attractions, and the Groundhog Day parade on Main Street is a regional event -- but Essex is probably in little danger of getting overrun by new residents. The town is two hours from New York City and two hours from Boston, which is too far for it to worry about becoming a major commuterville.
Mr. Paul, for one, is not worried about the town's losing its identity. "People are very sensitive to keeping things the way they are," he said. As a co-owner of the Griswold Inn, the first three-story building in Connecticut and the town's centerpiece, he counts himself among them. (The Inn's sign says it opened for business in 1776, but the historical society has some doubts.) The Griswold, with 27 rooms, is usually booked on weekends. Mr. Paul doesn't expect much to change now.
"In 40 years, I could say I've noticed some changes here," Mr. Paul, 41, said. Some houses on Main Street, for instance, have become businesses, he said. What else? "Well, the number of kids is now about the same when I was growing up," he said. "When I think about it, a lot hasn't changed at all."

HEADLINE: Richard Haydock, 82, Legal Service Chief

 BODY:
Richard Haydock, who organized the legal referral service of the New York City bar association in 1947 and headed it until his retirement in 1984, died on Nov. 23 at Tally-Ho Manor in Boonton Township, N.J. A 43-year resident of Mountain Lakes, N.J., he was 82.
Mr. Haydock, a native of New York City, was an economics graduate of Harvard University and received his law degree from Columbia University Law School in 1937. He worked for the Legal Aid Society before forming the Legal Referral Service of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, taking the position of executive director. It was one of the first such services in the country for people unacquainted with the law or with lawyers, and provided legal help for a modest fee. 
 What started as a one-man operation taking just four calls in July 1947 has since grown to an organization that handles more than 100,000 calls a year. Its clients range from prison inmates to big corporations, although most calls come from middle-income people with ordinary legal problems.
Mr. Haydock is survived by two sons, Roger, of Eugene, Ore., and William H., of Mountain Lakes, and three grandchildren. His wife, Katherine Snyder Haydock, died two years ago.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Peter Marks 

 BODY:

Director Dismissed
Peter Masterson was at a loss over his dismissal. "I don't understand it," he said over the phone from Plano, Tex. "You do a play and it wins a Pulitzer Prize. The production is always praised. I am totally surprised." 
 Mr. Masterson was let go this week as director of "The Young Man From Atlanta," by Horton Foote, which won the Pulitzer for drama this year after it ran Off Broadway under Mr. Masterson's direction. His dismissal was the latest upheaval for the play, clouding its prospects for Broadway in the spring. A couple of weeks ago a producer, Anne Strickland Squadron, resigned.
David Richenthal, the lead producer, would not say why he jettisoned Mr. Masterson, whose wife, Carlin Glynn, was one of the play's stars; she will leave the project as well. "We're going to have another director direct the production for New York," Mr. Richenthal said, adding that the play's future was unclear.
Putting a serious play on Broadway is a tricky business these days, and riskier still when it is not a star vehicle. A recent Boston tryout of the Masterson production made everyone nervous after it received a tepid response from audiences. And while some in the theater world say the play really belongs where it began, Off Broadway, Mr. Richenthal and Mr. Foote have their hearts set on a big Broadway house.
Oddly, Mr. Masterson's show will go on. The play is scheduled for the Alley Theater in Houston in February, with Mr. Masterson as director.
 
 
 
Looking to Spring
 The troubles for "Young Man" are further proof that short of a California quake, nothing is shakier than planning a Broadway season. Spring held the promise of a bumper crop of new (well, newish) straight plays on Broadway, but the usual assortment of setbacks and changes of heart is shifting the theatrical landscape daily.
Here's where other pending productions that could compete for the Best Play Tony now stand:
*Steppenwolf's production of "Buried Child," by Sam Shepard, which won a Pulitzer in 1979, has been talked about for Broadway in the spring but now looks iffy at best. Frederick Zollo, the producer, says that Ethan Hawke, who was in the Chicago production, would not come with the play to New York. Though his part was not one of the biggest, he was the "name."
*"Getting Away With Murder" (formerly "The Doctor Is Out") is in. The comedy thriller by Stephen Sondheim and George Furth is to begin performances in February at the Broadhurst.
*August Wilson's "Seven Guitars" opens in March at the Walter Kerr, but it, too, has seen turmoil in recent weeks. Zakes Mokae, the South African actor ("The Blood Knot"), was let go in San Francisco, where it is playing. Benjamin Mordecai, the producer, said that Mr. Mokae was "having difficulty" adapting to Mr. Wilson's language. "One of those situations emerged where what Zakes as an artist brought to the role was not working," he said. Mr. Mokae's agent in Los Angeles did not return calls.
 
 
 
An Oldie Is Dropped
 The lineup of old plays is changing, too. Officials at the cash-strapped Circle in the Square have dropped plans for "The Petrified Forest" after "Holiday," which has been extended to Jan. 7. In its place: a revival of "Bus Stop." ("Petrified" has 22 roles, "Bus Stop" 8.)
 
 
 
Cat and a Therapist
 Carol Burnett is living the high life of a New York actress. She has found a posh hotel, a good physical therapist and a cat. The cat, named "Roxie," came from a shelter. The therapist came from her friend Julie Andrews. The kitty is company. The therapist is survival.
It's the nightly workout on an inclined stage -- in heels yet -- that has Ms. Burnett running for a hot tub filled with Epsom salts. "They said to me, 'These raked stages were traditions for hundreds of years,' " the actress said, sipping chardonnay in her hotel. "I said, 'Well, so were sweatshops!' "
Nevertheless, Ms. Burnett has re-upped with "Moon Over Buffalo," agreeing to stay until March. One change: Tuesdays off. She'll do seven performances instead of the usual eight.
"I don't like long commitments," she said. Still, she has done many New Yorky things, like attending workshop productions and spending time with Ms. Andrews, who invited her for Thanksgiving.
"When Julie and I first started, we talked about men," she said. "Later on we talked about children. Then it was, how do we keep in good shape? Now we talk Metamucil."
 
 
 
Foreign Intrigue
 For Brian Friel, the Irish playwright, who is in New York to direct his play "Molly Sweeney" at the Roundabout's second stage, getting here was more than half the battle.
Emanuel Azenberg, a co-producer, says the directors' union, the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, threatened to block the playwright's visa. They demanded that Mr. Azenberg make an up-front payment to Mr. Friel of $13,000 -- $5,000 more than the normal director's minimum advance for an Off Broadway production -- before sanctioning Mr. Friel's work.
"It was an outrage," Mr. Azenberg said. "They are supposed to judge him on artistic merit. This was done because of arbitrary economics."
Barbara B. Hauptman, the union's new executive director, said the demand was made after the union learned Mr. Azenberg and the Roundabout were paying the two foreign actors in the play, Catherine Byrne and Alfred Molina, on the higher pay scale of a Broadway production contract. "To me, this was all about a principle," she said.
Mr. Azenberg, who eventually agreed to pay the money, said that while Actors' Equity had negotiated the issue of pay for foreigners working here, the directors' union never had.
 
 
 
Bridey the 'Brit'
 Simon Jones has been a New Yorker for over a decade, but onstage he's never taken for one.
"I'm still usually the Brit," Mr. Jones said in his perfect English accent. He is one of those English expatriate actors -- he is married to an American -- who seem effortlessly sophisticated on the New York stage. This time, he's more devious than debonair, as the hypocritical Sir Joseph Surface in the Broadway production of "The School for Scandal," which closes this month.
Although he has worked steadily in New York, he is still best known as Bridey, the pompous scion of "Brideshead Revisited." In fact, he remains so well-known for the television series that when he is invited to do so, he does a behind-the-scenes slide show on making "Brideshead."

HEADLINE: U.S. Tests Border Plan In Event of Mexico Crisis

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: NOGALES, Ariz., Dec. 7

 BODY:
Sudden ly, a vast flood of illegal immigrants Mexicans driven to desperation by some unspeakable and unspecified social catastrophe -- surges across the Southwest border, inundating entire communities as it washes north into the American heartland.
That was the scenario driving three days of field exercises here this week, in which the Clinton Administration's top immigration policy-makers tested new plans to control the border in case Mexico's financial and political problems worsen dramatically. Their field radios crackling through a border canyon here, scores of Border Control agents practiced erecting cyclone-fence corrals, herding immigrants through them for emergency processing, and loading them onto bus convoys for travel to mass detention centers. 
 The Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Doris Meissner, who is here overseeing the exercises, said that although last year's mass migrations of Cubans and Haitians demonstrated anew how foreign events can trigger sudden immigration emergencies, the chances that a breakdown in Mexico's social order could unleash an immigrant stampede remained distant.
"I think its remote," she said in an interview. "But this is part of our world. We must be certain we can handle emergencies if they arrive."
Just as schoolhouse nuclear drills projected, and at times aggravated American terrors during the cold war, the "enhanced border control plan" practiced here this week underlined the fears currently associated with uncontrolled immigration in the American imagination.
Ms. Meissner said the exercise was not intended to send threatening messages to Mexico City. And a Mexican official who asked not to be identified characterized relations between the Clinton Administration and the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo as cordial. But the official said of the exercise, "We don't see this as appropriate or prudent."
For his part, Juan Rebolledo, Mexico's under-secretary of foreign affairs, speaking in a telephone interview from Mexico City, said that the cyclical flow of migrants into the United States in search of work has become a permanent condition of the North American labor market.
"Conditions in Mexico, with all its problems, are stable," he said. "So I view an invasion of thousands of Mexicans across the border to be, as you Americans say, far-fetched."
Several Border Patrol agents participating here said that they could not remember their agency carrying out any similar exercises for at least two decades, perhaps ever. But the Arizona exercise was the third this year; the Immigration and Naturalization Service walked through similar practice emergencies in June in Orlando and last month in McAllen, Tex.
Dutch Steenbakker, an assistant chief Border Patrol agent, said there were no specific scenarios for Mexican catastrophe written into the exercise.
"We decided it would be a mistake to start tailoring it around a particular situation," Mr. Steenbakker said in a briefing for reporters at a barbed-wire corral erected in a scrub oak campground in the Coronado National Forest six miles from Nogales on Arizona's southern border. "It could be a natural disaster, or the economy collapses, or the military attacks the Government, or any number of other situations."
Mr. Steenbakker called the corral, bathed in floodlights and equipped with five olive-drab army campaign tents, water tanks, and portable toilets, a "temporary collection point." During a border emergency, agents would ferry in migrants, read them their rights, which include seeing a lawyer and appearing before an immigration judge, and separate them according to their next destination: immediate voluntary deportation back at the border, or an emergency detention center set up about 60 miles north in Tucson.
There, immigrants might be held for 30 days or more, transferred to prisons, county jails or military bases and if all of those facilities were overwhelmed, held semi-permanently in "soft-cover detention" -- tent villages like those established last year in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
Intelligence agents would participate in the interviewing of immigrants during an emergency in an effort to establish the cause of the immigrant invasion, Mr. Steenbakker said.
"If its all of a sudden we're getting inundated, we want to find out what's causing it and maybe the U.S. Government can help solve it," he said.
In one of the tents, Kevin W. Oaks. a Border Patrol supervisor, gestured toward a bank of telephones, fax machines, computers and two-way radios. "This is the command and transportation center," Mr. Oaks said. "We'd be shifting around a lot of vehicle assets, maybe we'd have 15 vans moving masses of people out to the detention centers."
If so many immigrants crossed the border that the Nogales border station ran out of busses, more could be brought down from Tucson or Phoenix or even from neighboring states, he said.
"Say we're tapped out of people," Mr. Steenbakker said. "We could call in other resources, the sheriff's department or the national guard."
If these exercises had a certain military air to them, it was because the Immigration and Naturalization Service requested military help in its preparation, Ms. Meissner said. "They're very good at formal contingency planning and we wanted to tap some expertise," she said. The help came, she said, in the form of Army Col. Richard Coffin, whom the Pentagon had lent to immigration office.
Part of the exercise involved role-playing, in which Washington-based officials pretended to be law-enforcement officers recruited from afar to serve during the hypothetical emergency. Ms. Meissner, who during the exercise acted the role of an out-of-state F.B.I. agent detailed to coordinate transportation, said she had learned during a string of immigration emergencies since the 1980 Mariel exodus from Cuba that careful planning was essential.
"Planning makes the difference between an effective response and just dissembling," Ms. Meissner said.

The exercises included setting up a camp with Army tents, water tanks and portable toilets as a "temporary collection point." (Jeff Tipping for The New York Times) (pg. B16)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Sony of America to Widen Its Executive Committee
The Sony Corporation of America, reorganizing itself after the departure of its chief executive, Michael Schulhof, said it would broaden its executive committee, adding the heads of its main operating divisions.
Nobuyuki Idei, president and chief financial officer of Sony, the Japanese parent, said he would oversee the committee, which will include the heads of the electronics, films and record businesses. [Page 39.]
 
Specifications Set for Videodisk
Nine companies working on a new type of digital videodisk announced specifications for the medium, which would resemble today's compact disk or CD-ROM, but would be able to store far more music, video or data in a common format. The companies agreed in September to work together after a heated standards battle between companies led by Sony and Philips Electronics on one side and Toshiba on the other. They hope to avoid a repetition of the videocassette format wars of the 1970's. [39.]
 
A Surprise Resignation at Citicorp
The outsider hired by Citicorp two and a half years ago to help the bank, the nation's largest, become more efficient and productive, resigned unexpectedly. The role of Christopher J. Steffen will be assumed by a 23-year veteran of the bank, Victor J. Menezes. [39.]
 
Dow Falls, but Nasdaq Rises
Stock prices were mixed as a rise in the jobless rate to 5.6 percent showed a slowing economy. The blue-chip Dow industrials eased 2.53 points, to 5,156.86, but technology issues led the broader market higher. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 1.31 points, to 617.48, and the Nasdaq composite index increased 9.24 points, to 1,064.41. [41.]
 
Employment in New York dipped by 35,000 last month, but unemployment fell to 6 percent, from 6.3 percent in October. In New Jersey there were 36,000 fewer jobs but the jobless rate rose to 6.1 percent, from 5.8 percent in October. [38.]
 
Treasury Bond Prices Rally
Prices of Treasury bonds rose in a rally induced by a weaker-than-expected employment report, but closed off their peaks, after the Fed's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, said that traders were overly optimistic about an easing of interest rates this month. The long bond's yield slipped to 6.05 percent. [40.]
 
Westinghouse Plans to Repay Debt
Westinghouse said that it planned to sell its arms business and a smaller unit, said to be the Knoll Group, which makes office furniture. With the proceeds, it expects to repay $3.2 billion to $3.5 billion of the $5.4 billion in debt that it incurred in buying CBS Inc. by the end of the second quarter of 1996. [41.]
 
Diamond Agrees to Buy Arethusa
Diamond Offshore Drilling said it planned to take over Arethusa Ltd., a smaller but fast-growing competitor, as an operator of deep-water oil drilling rigs, for $516 million in stock. Combined, the two companies would have 30 semi-submersible rigs, far more than any competitor. Deep-water drilling has become of prime interest among major oil companies. [40.]
 
Belli Firm in Bankruptcy Filing
The law firm of Melvin Belli filed for bankruptcy protection, attributing its problems to Dow Corning's bankruptcy filing. The firm represents 800 women who received silicone breast implants made by Dow, and Mr. Belli said he had spent $5 million on their care but could now recover nothing. [6.]
 
California Overhauls Insurance
California moved to overhaul its homeowners' earthquake insurance market, replacing insurance companies. Morgan Stanley was chosen to lead securities firms in an innovative $1.5 billion bond sale that would be part of a $10.5 billion package to pay claims. [40.]
 
Sparring Resumes in Budget Battle
President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders reverted to casting aspersions and drawing lines in the sand only a day after the President submitted revisions to his budget, and a slight thaw appeared. [10.]

HEADLINE: Treasury Bonds Rally on Weak Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds moved higher yesterday in a rally induced by a weaker-than-expected employment report, but closed off their peaks.
The soft jobs numbers lifted investor hopes for a cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, bringing in buyers and reversing the effects of Thursday's selloff. Then, news services reported that the Fed's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, had said that the markets were overly optimistic about an easing in December, and trading chilled. 
 The 30-year benchmark bond rose 15/32 , to a price of 111 11/32 to yield 6.05 percent, down from 6.08 percent on Thursday.
The Labor Department reported that 166,000 nonfarm jobs were added to the economy in November, after a revised increase of 66,000 in October. The department also reported that the unemployment rate for November rose to 5.6 percent from 5.5 percent.
Another Government report yesterday showed that home sales were weak in October, but Treasury securities made no further gains and that troubled some investors, inducing some profit taking. Traders said it appeared that 6 percent was a difficult barrier for the long-bond yield to fall below.
P. Christopher Leary, senior vice president and portfolio manager at SunAmerica Asset Management, said the economic numbers confirmed "the market's perception of further weakness in the economy, which will further support a Fed easing in December and begin to raise questions about growth in early 1996."
Mr. Leary said the trailing three-month average of nonfarm payroll numbers was half that of early 1995, suggesting a weakening labor market. He said it indicated that there was no increase in wage pressures.
"We also saw today a continuing decline in the Columbia Leading Inflation Index to 103.3 versus a revised 104.4," Mr. Leary said. "The economic data support the continuation of a soft landing, and that should be good to the market." He also expressed optimism that Congress and the Administration would resolve their differences and balance the budget.
Michael Krauss, chief technical strategist at Chemical Securities Inc., described the session as choppy. "The bottom line is that technicals have been friendly since August, but early this week we reached a risk level," he said.

HEADLINE: First Lady Officially Sets Off Clinton Race

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 8

 BODY:
Stepping back onto the campaign trail and abandoning her self-imposed lower profile, Hillary Rodham Clinton officially registered her husband as a candidate in the nation's first primary state today. She lost no time in accusing Republicans of making budget proposals that would "knock down the ladder of opportunity after they themselves have reached the top."
With scores of reporters and camera people shoving each other to catch a glimpse of her, Mrs. Clinton stood at an antique desk in the office of the New Hampshire Secretary of State to submit the papers that officially begin President Clinton's re-election campaign. 
 "There weren't very many other people here when I was here before," she said, remembering what little notice she had received when she submitted the same forms in 1991.
Mrs. Clinton quickly put to rest any idea that her departure from the spotlight after the Republican sweep of Congress in 1994 and her focus on more traditional activities for a First Lady, like receiving the White House Christmas tree, meant that she would not be a force on the campaign trail in 1996.
"I'm going to continue to do what I've done for more than 20 years of marriage, which is support my husband," she said, when asked what her role would be in 1996. "I believe very strongly in what he's doing."
Mrs. Clinton crisscrossed the state in her first full campaign day, speaking at a Portsmouth apartment complex for the elderly, the University of New Hampshire in Durham and at a fund-raising reception for the State Democratic Party in Manchester.
Shortly after Mrs. Clinton left the Secretary of State's office, Senator Bob Dole, the Republican front-runner, showed up there to enter his party's primary.
"It is a race between Bill Clinton and Bob Dole," said Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader, acting as if he had already the nomination.
Mr. Dole, who chugged into town on a train called The Balanced Budget Express, was greeted at the station, in subzero temperatures, by a small group of supporters headed by Gov. Stephen Merrill
The Dole and Clinton camps coordinated their schedules to avoid a direct meeting between the two. As he signed up for the primary, Mr. Dole was asked about Mrs. Clinton's criticism of Republican plans for Medicare and education, and took the opportunity to suggest that the President was not serious about balancing the budget.
"The President has done nothing but play politics" trying to frighten people, Mr. Dole said. He called Mrs. Clinton's remarks "more politics as usual."
The President is using education and Medicare to define the difference between himself and the Republican-controlled Congress, and Mrs. Clinton stumped hard today against Republican budget proposals for savings in both.
Distancing herself from partisan battles of Washington, Mrs. Clinton never mentioned Republicans directly, simply referring instead to "some people" and "the other side."
Still, her message was unmistakable. Discussing Medicare with a selected group of the elderly people arranged around her before an audience at the Margeson Apartments, she mused about "the idea some people have that we don't really need a system like Medicare for everybody."
This she called, "really, a kind of survival of the fittest mentality -- if you are healthy and you can take care of yourself and you've had enough during your lifetime, then good for you, and if you're not, then you should have done something different along life's way."
At the University of New Hampshire, she criticized Republicans for proposals to make savings in student loan and education programs. "Today there are some among us who are willing to knock down the ladder of opportunity after they themselves have reached the top," she said. "That is not the American way."
As the next Presidential election approached, Mrs. Clinton said, the nation has to decide how it will provide its citizens with the skills to earn a living, "no matter where they're born, no matter to whom they're born, no matter what their income." She added, "I believe we do not answer that question just by talking about family values. We do it by valuing families."
In 1992, Mr. Clinton's Presidential dreams almost foundered in New Hampshire because of questions about his purported marital infidelity and his draft status during the Vietnam War. He fought his way back to a second-place finish in the Democratic primary, calling himself the Comeback Kid.
This time aides say that New Hampshire is already Mr. Clinton's first victory. He is the first Democratic President since Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964 not to face a primary challenge here. Still, the Clinton campaign opened an office here this week and wants to maintain a presence in the state to counter the expected deluge of attacks on the President as Republicans vie with each other to win their party's nomination.
Mrs. Clinton, who sought to expand the role of the First Lady, has become a lightning rod for conservatives and a target for the Congressional committee investigating the Whitewater real estate deal. Nonetheless, Democratic strategists call her one of the President's best campaign assets, a sure draw for the liberals, women and minorities whose votes Mr. Clinton needs.
Tonight, as Democrats brandished the season's first "Clinton-Gore 96" banners, Mrs. Clinton reminded them of the recession that haunted the state the year Mr. Clinton defeated President George Bush.
"America and New Hampshire are in better shape than when my husband came here seeking the nomination," she said.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Issues Off a Bit, But Technology Stocks Rise

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday in lackluster trading, amid indications that the economy was continuing to lose momentum. Blue chips fell, while computing issues led the broader market higher.
"There has been a definite shift in the mood of the equity market," said E. Wayne Nordberg, equity partner of Lord Abbett & Company. "You've got a lot of nervous holders out there looking for the slightest hole in the dike to run for cover." 
 The market tone was set by the Labor Department's report early in the morning that the United States unemployment rate in November rose to 5.6 percent -- its first increase in four months. Later the Commerce Department reported that sales of new homes dropped 2.7 percent in October, the third consecutive monthly decline.
The Dow Jones industrial average eased 2.53 points, to 5,156.86, for its second consecutive decline. But the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 1.31 points, to 617.48, and the Nasdaq composite index increased 9.24 points, to 1,062.41.
Advancing and declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange were almost even, with declines totaling 1,152 and advances equaling 1,132. Big Board volume slipped to 327.9 million shares, from 381.5 million shares on Thursday.
Many technology stocks turned higher as analysts pointed to their strong fundamentals. Microsoft gained 4, to 94 1/2; it was upgraded by a handful of brokerage houses yesterday after William H. Gates, the chairman, discussed the company's strategy on Thursday. Sun Microsystems increased 6 5/8, to 99 3/4; Hewlett-Packard advanced 4 5/8, to 86 7/8; Oracle Systems rose 2 3/8, to 46 5/8, and Intel was up 1 3/4, to 63 1/4.
Oil issues, which have predictable earnings growth, again rallied. Exxon rose 7/8, to a new high of 81 3/4, and Mobil increased 2, to 110 1/2.
Shares of companies involved in consumer nondurables were in demand because traders consider them to have less exposure to economic uncertainty. For example, Gillette closed at 53 1/4, up 1 1/8, and Warner-Lambert closed at 94 1/4, up 1 1/2.
However, with a slackening in demand for certain types of economically sensitive paper products, a number of companies in this field moved lower. International Paper fell 1/2, to 37; Westvaco dropped 5/8, to 26 1/2, and Willamette Industries declined 3/8, to 58 3/4.
Chemical stocks also were down. Dow Chemical closed at 71 1/8, off 3/4, and Union Carbide closed at 39 5/8, off 1/4.
Some heavy-industry issues declined, apparently because of prospects that corporations might be spending less on expansion in 1996. Alcoa fell 7/8, to 56, and Ingersoll-Rand dropped 1/2, to 36 1/2.
Among the special situations, Neuromedical Systems jumped 5 1/8, to 20 1/8, on its first day of public trading. Mobile Telecommunication Technologies surged 2 1/4, to 22 3/8, after one of its units announced that it would sell pagers in retail stores. Incomnet increased 7/8, to 7 3/8, after the Nasdaq small-capitalization market decided that the company would be allowed to keep its listing on the market.
Earlier yesterday, Japanese stocks ended weaker. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 125.35 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 19,286.97, after adding 532.79 points in the last two days.

HEADLINE: Report Shows Little Job Growth, Improving Odds for Rate Cut

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Job growth was modest in November and the unemployment rate edged up to 5.6 percent, the Labor Department reported today, raising the likelihood that the weak economy would cause the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates this month.
"All the way through it was a very soft report," said Donald E. Maude, an analyst in New York for Scotia McLeod, an investment firm. He raised his estimate of the odds of a rate cut this month to 50-50 instead of 70-30 against a cut previously. The markets have already moved in anticipation of a reduction. 
 Factories shed 32,000 more jobs in November, bringing the total lost since the most recent peak in factory employment, in March, to 220,000.
A second Government report today showed that sales of new single-family homes fell 2.7 percent in October, a third straight decline in a period when mortgage rates have fallen sharply, and one more report in a long string showing the economy had slowed markedly since a brisk summer. "Housing activity has probably peaked," Edward E. Yardeni of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell/C. J. Lawrence told clients.
The Clinton Administration, which admits to no fear that the recent sluggishness could deteriorate into an election-year recession, nevertheless fretted today about some aspects of the economy.
"Manufacturing continues to be troubling," said Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, referring to the loss of factory jobs last month. "It's directly related to a large pileup of unsold goods."
Mr. Reich also said he was "concerned" by a slight decline in hourly earnings last month. The decline left the 12-month increase at 3 percent, barely above the latest 12-month inflation rate. This, he suggested, implies that workers -- many of them heavily indebted -- are unlikely to do enough shopping to lighten overstocked shelves.
Others, however, took solace in the low inflation and in the improved prospects that the Fed will lower interest rates when it holds a policy meeting on Dec. 19.
Among 11 large industrial states, California saw its jobless rate jump a full point, to 8.8 percent, despite a smaller work force. The rate was 7.2 percent in September.
In New York, the rate improved to 6 percent from 6.3, but in New Jersey it increased to 6.1 percent from 5.8 in October.
Although the national payrolls expanded over all by a moderate 166,000, about what analysts expected, the gain was significantly exaggerated by special factors. One was that the department's survey period lasted five weeks, rather than the usual four, because of a quirk of the calendar. The survey thus picked up 25,000 more retailing and other seasonal jobs than the adjustment process allows for.
And 44,000 jobs resulted from the introduction of updated seasonal factors that will be applied from November through April.
Today's figures were unaffected by the midmonth furlough of "nonessential" Federal workers during the budget impasse, because they remained on payrolls. Nor did the furlough make the data significantly less accurate, since surveyors and processors were able to catch up with their work on overtime once they returned, Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said.
Strength in the payroll survey was confined largely to health services, which added 37,000 jobs; to transportation, and to a finance industry that posted its biggest job gain -- 14,000 -- in two years.
The loss in factory jobs was evenly divided between the durable and nondurable goods industries, with nearly half of the decline reflecting automotive layoffs. A number of auto plants have been shut down because of excessive inventories of vehicles.
The department's survey of about 56,000 households, which is more erratic than the payroll survey of 390,000 employers, showed a hefty 389,000 drop in employment. But this was accompanied by a 206,000 decline in the labor force, which has grown exceptionally slowly this year.
As a result, the unemployment rate moved up just a tenth of a point in November, a change deemed statistically insignificant.
Among demographic groups, joblessness among adult men jumped four-tenths of a point, to 4.9 percent, but this caused no alarm because it followed a drop by that amount in October.
In addition to California, other industrial states that had big increases in unemployment were Pennsylvania, up 1.2 points, to 6.3 percent, and Ohio, up 1.1 points, to 5.8 percent.
For lack of money to conduct sufficient sampling, the Government will discontinue publishing these figures for the 11 states, beginning with the Feb. 2 release covering January. Officials said they were considering the substitution of a list of four states -- New York, California, Texas and Florida -- whose samples will remain adequate. But Commissioner Abraham said that all four would need to agree to participate and that this was not assured.
Today's report also showed that the index of aggregate weekly hours, derived from the number of people at work and the hours they spent on the job, slumped to 133.3 in November from 133.8. That implies that industrial production fell for a second straight month. And only 43.2 percent of manufacturing industries added workers last month, down from 49.6 percent in October, the report found.

HEADLINE: Thaw in Budget Talks Freezes Over a Bit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
A day after President Clinton submitted revisions to his budget and a slight thaw seemed to have developed in the budget negotiations, the President and Republican leaders in Congress reverted today to casting aspersions and drawing lines in the sand.
With further formal negotiations put off until next week, Mr. Clinton called reporters to the Cabinet Room at the White House before a meeting with Democratic governors to say he would stand firm against the Federal Government's relinquishing control of Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor. 
 Republicans want to end the 30-year-old Medicaid system under which everyone who meets Federal eligibility standards is entitled to whatever medical treatment or nursing home care they need. The budget legislation approved by Congress last month and vetoed by the President this week would cut deeply into projected spending for the program, give what Federal money was left to the states in the form of block grants with few strings attached and allow the states to set eligibility.
The White House has clearly decided that this is an issue on which to take the firmest possible stand.
"The Republican budget," the President declared, "would be a disaster for the states and for the people who depend on Medicaid."
"So I just want to be clear about this," he said. "I very much want to work with the Republican Congress to get a balanced budget, but I will not -- I will not -- permit the repeal of guaranteed medical coverage for senior citizens or disabled people, for poor children and pregnant women. That would violate our values."
Later, the White House publicity machine was switched on, and assistants spread word of how serious the Medicaid issue was to the President.
But Republicans said they too intended to insist on their Medicaid position.
"This isn't about values, and it isn't about money," said Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia, chairman of the House Commerce Committee, which has jurisdiction over Medicaid. "No, this is about power," Mr. Bliley added, speaking in the Capitol at a news conference he had called to respond to the President. "This is about whether the states will be given the flexibility they need to meet the needs of their own citizens or whether they'll continue to have their hands tied by a huge, distant, inflexible Federal bureaucracy."
The revised budget Mr. Clinton submitted on Thursday would save $54 billion in the Medicaid program over the next seven years, only a third as much as the Republican plan would save.
The Republican legislation would set rigid ceilings on the Federal money that the program would make available to the states each year. Mr. Clinton, in contrast, would impose a limit only on the average amount that would be spent each year for each beneficiary. That approach would allow increases in total spending as Medicaid enrollment grew, a particular likelihood in times of recession.
The President's demand that Medicaid remain an entitlement is in contrast with his position on welfare. There, he has accepted the Republican argument that the main Federal welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, should be turned over to the states and that poor families with children should no longer be guaranteed Federal assistance.
On Tuesday, the Congressional Budget Office is scheduled to issue its latest economic projections and spending forecasts. But it is unclear whether that will be the moment for serious negotiations on the budget to begin or whether the two sides will continue, as they have for the last two weeks, merely to jockey for political position.
The agreement between the President and Congress that ended the partial shutdown of the Government last month expires next Friday. With no progress made in the negotiations this week, there seems little chance of a budget agreement before the deadline.
Mr. Clinton asked Congress on Thursday to approve another temporary measure that would extend the Government's spending authority through much of January, but Republicans in the House of Representatives have been resistant.
This afternoon the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, and Speaker Newt Gingrich sent a letter to the White House asking the President to submit a new budget next week with $400 billion in lower spending, the amount needed to match the Republican savings.
In a letter of response, Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, did not directly address the request but urged the Congressional leaders to agree to temporary legislation that would prevent another partial Government shutdown.

HEADLINE: Melvin Kranzberg, 78, Historian of Technology

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Melvin Kranzberg, a scholar who helped establish the study of the history of technology and explained its impact on society, died on Wednesday at his home in Atlanta. Dr. Kranzberg, a professor at the Georgia Institute of Technology, was 78.
The cause was cancer, said August Giebelhaus, a professor of history at Georgia Tech and a longtime colleague. 
 Dr. Kranzberg co-founded the Society for the History of Technology in 1958. From then until 1984, he was the editor of its quarterly journal, Technology and Culture.
"His life's work was to assert the autonomy of this discipline," Professor Giebelhaus said. "It was not just applied science, and it was not just a minor part of economic history, but it was a discipline in itself.
Dr. Kranzberg argued that technological development could not be understood without seeing how it was linked to society.
He wrote or edited 11 books and wrote more than 150 scholarly articles; he also popularized his field in newspaper articles.
In a 1968 article, he wrote: "Engineers, in general, live in the suburbs, vote Republican and mouth the cliches of conservatism. Actually, if unwittingly, they are greater social revolutionaries than many wild-eyed political radicals.
"Without necessarily meaning to, they invent new products, processes, systems and devices that produce profound socio-cultural transformations."
The automobile self-starter, he wrote, freed women and children to see the world and electric washers, driers, vacuum cleaners, supermarkets and telephones freed women for "drinking, loafing, heavy thinking about issues like Vietnam and even jobs, the same as men."
"Radicals" like the inventors Watt, Fulton, McCormick, Edison and Marconi, he said, changed the face of the world.
Early in the computer era, he foresaw immense social upheaval, but he remained optimistic, as he generally was about technological change.
Writing more than 25 years ago, he said, "There is no doubt that many individuals will be thrown out of their jobs by automation, and the process will accelerate with every passing year. At the same time computers are speeding and extending the advance of science and technology at a pace never before witnessed in history. This, we know, will create new lines of productivity, new and better jobs, new professions and untold wealth."
Dr. Kranzberg was born on Nov. 22, 1917, in St Louis. He studied history and economics at Amherst College in Massachusetts, where he earned a bachelor's degree in 1938. At Harvard University he earned a master's degree in 1938 and a doctorate in 1942.
During World War II, he served in the Army in Europe as a sergeant in military intelligence, fought in the Battle of the Bulge and interrogated German prisoners on the front lines. He won the Bronze Star for finding crucial enemy gun emplacements.
Originally a specialist in modern French history, Dr. Kranzberg taught at Harvard, the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., and Amherst. In 1952 he joined the faculty of at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland. There, while developing a history course for engineering students, he shifted to the history of technology.
He was appointed a professor at Case in 1959, and left in 1972 to become the Callaway Professor of the History of Technology at Georgia Tech. When he retired in 1988, he became a professor emeritus, and the institute named a professorship in the history of technology in his honor.
His awards included the NASA Apollo Achievement Award, the Roe Medal of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, the State of Israel's Jabotinsky Centennial Medal for eminence in science and letters, the Olmstead Award of the American Society for Engineering Education and the Bernal Award of the Society for Social Studies of Science.
Dr. Kranzberg is survived by his wife, the former Louise Lester of Atlanta; two sons by a previous marriage, John and Steven, both of St. Louis; a brother, Maurice, also of St. Louis, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A New Safety Net Is Created For Homeowners in Quakes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
California took a big step yesterday toward overhauling its homeowners' earthquake insurance market to create a new financial safety net for homeowners, replacing insurance companies.
After a heated competition among 40 securities firms, the state said firms led byMorgan Stanley & Company would handle an innovative $1.5 billion bond sale that would be part of a $10.5 billion package to pay homeowners' claims. 
 The plan also calls for homeowners to absorb much more of the risk from earthquakes because new policies will provide less coverage than existing policies.
After the Northridge earthquake in January 1994, which resulted in $12.5 billion of insurance losses -- $8.2 billion from homeowners, most insurance companies stopped accepting new customers, putting California officials under pressure to change the market.
"This plan makes insurance more widely available," said Chuck Quackenbush, California's Insurance Commissioner, adding that it also answered concerns about the solvency of many companies after a big quake.
Under the new mini-policies that will go on sale Jan. 1, homeowner premiums will be about the same as those for existing earthquake policies, but the new policies will provide less coverage. The two largest cutbacks are a $5,000 limit on coverage for a home's contents and a $1,500 limit on living expenses paid if a home is uninhabitable.
If the new mini-policies had been in place for the earthquake at Northridge, near Los Angeles, claims on homeowner policies would have been cut in half, insurers say. California Insurance Department officials expect the mini-policies to cost about the same as old policies, where premiums currently range from about $1.50 per $1,000 of coverage in a low-risk areas, to $4 per $1,000 in high- risk areas.
Although insurance companies will sell the new mini-policies and handle their claims, the $1.1 billion in annual premiums will go to the California Earthquake Authority, not the companies. The authority will use the premiums to pay for its expenses and for the $10.5 billion insurance plan.
The $10.5 billion plan taps many sources to pay homeowner claims, starting with $1 billion in cash contributed by insurance companies. The next $3 billion in claims would be covered by funds that insurance companies promise to provide if needed. The next $2 billion of coverage comes from reinsurers, followed by $1 billion from tax-exempt bonds that would be sold after an earthquake. The next $1.5 billion of claims would be covered by investors in the Morgan Stanley bond issue to be sold early next year, with another $2 billion available from an assessment on insurance companies.
Insurers and securities dealers close to the financing are optimistic that reinsurance can be bought for not much more than $300 million a year, or more than 15 percent of the coverage offered. Interest rates on the bonds would average slightly less than the reinsurance cost, but would vary widely depending on how much risk investors took.
Some investors, who agree that they would lose only part of their interest after an earthquake, might earn interest rates comparable with those of medium-quality corporate bonds, while others who could lose all of their interest or principal could earn rates more than 10 percentage points higher than Treasury notes.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Leaps in Early Trading But Falls Back on Profit Taking

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar soared in early trading yesterday to an 11-week high against the German mark, but then European traders took their profits and the currency ended little changed.
Currency traders said the dollar's ascent was set off by a rally in United States Treasury bond prices, which caused traders to push the currency through important technical levels. 
 Treasury bonds jumped after the release of a weaker-than-expected employment report for November improved the odds of lower interest rates ahead.
"The market bought the dollar because the bonds were rallying," said Joe Viola, a manager at Credit Suisse. "But after that there was no follow-through and the market sold it back down."
The dollar hit a high of 1.4550 marks, and soared to a 17-month high of $1.5205 to a British pound.
But once the bond rally stalled, European corporate traders, particularly from Germany, cashed in their dollar holdings.
"The dollar made some nice new ground on the top side, and we had some Friday afternoon profit taking," said Richard Vullo, dealer at Bayerische Hypobank. "That brought us down off the highs, but I don't think it changes the overall bullish tone."
The dollar continued to be supported by comments on Thursday by the president of the German central bank, Hans Tietmeyer, who said he hoped for a stronger dollar against the mark. Traders said the comments suggested that the central bank, the Bundesbank, could soon lower interest rates.
And the dollar was helped as French markets continued to perform strongly in the face of a crippling national strike by public-sector workers, but some economists said investors might be too optimistic. The French franc's resilience against the mark makes the dollar more attactive relative to the mark.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.4475 German marks, up from 1.4467 marks on Thursday. The British pound ended unchanged at $1.5325. The dollar slipped to 101.30 Japanese yen from 101.47 yen.
"It was really just magnified by thin conditions," said David Solin, partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics. "There has really been no net change on the day."

HEADLINE: Data Show Fewer Jobs in New York Region

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Employment in the New York City metropolitan region dipped in November as a national slowdown continued to spill over into sluggish hiring across New York City, New York State and New Jersey.
According to the Federal Government's monthly employment report, there were 35,000 fewer jobs in New York State in November than in October, a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent. The loss was concentrated in New York City, where there were 46,000 fewer jobs in November than in the previous month, a 2 percent decline. 
 In New Jersey, the report said, 36,000 fewer people were employed in November than in October, a decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent.
The unemployment rate, a measure of the number of people who are actively seeking jobs but unable to find them, improved slightly in New York State, to 6 percent, from 6.3 percent in October, and in New York City, to 7.8 percent, from 8 percent in October. But the rate rose in New Jersey, to 6.1 percent, from 5.8 percent in October.
John L. Wieting, the New York regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which issued the report, said the slowdown reflected a decline in hiring across the nation. The report covered employment in the 11 largest industrial states; Connecticut is not among the 11 surveyed.
"The forces of the national slowdown filtered into the region in November," he said. Among those forces, he said, was a downturn in manufacturing that was particularly sharp in the Middle West, but also undermined employment in the region, particularly in New Jersey.
The dip in November came after a slight improvement in October, when both New York and New Jersey had employment gains, and reflected a series of small monthly gains and losses that have left the regional economy sluggish, but on a largely even economic keel, since the beginning of the year.
Among the strongest sectors of the regional economy in recent months have been tourism, restaurant sales and the entertainment industries.
"The numbers are still somewhat encouraging," Mr. Wieting said. Although the New York region lagged behind most of the nation in the economic recovery of 1993-94, he said, it did not experience the downturn suffered by other regions in the last 11 months.
"We are holding our own," he said.
